Advertisement, vol.1						Historic explanation on how Jules Goury and Owen Jones began to gather the information for the volumes in the summer of 1834; the unexpected death of cholera in Granada of Jules Goury; the return of Owen Jones to England in 1835 and the subsequent publication of the original drawings; and the visit of Owen Jones in 1837 to Granada to obtain copies of the uncollected ornaments throughout the fortress. The text is written in English and French		Goury, Jules, 1803-1834; Jones, Owen, 1809-1874									NA387.G64 1842		1 p. ; 69 cm.	eng, fre	jmap														asc99990000570008001		Goury, Jules and Owen Jones. Historical notice, vol. 1 [p. 1]						The historical notice is compiled in twenty pages, of which pages 16, 17 and 18 have engravings. The notice is a brief history of the city of Granada dating back to the city foundation over a thousand years ago by King Espero, who named the city Illiberia after his wife. After the Arabs invaded the Iberian Peninsula in 711, the fortress of Granada evolved upon the expulsion of the Moors in 1492. First, the fortress of Granada was given to the Jews and called Karnáttah-Al-Yahoud (Granada of the Jews). In 767, Adir-R-Rahmán Ash-Sheybaní built a castle referred to as kal'At Al-hamrá (the red castle). After multiple civil wars among the Moors, the progressive Reconquista by the kings of Castile & Aragon ended with the siege of Granada in April 1491. In the morning of January 2, 1492, the Moorish king Abu 'Adillah, Boabdil, surrendered to Ferdinand and Isabella. Several insurrections followed until 1570 when Don John of Austria announced a compulsory baptism. During his reign Phillip III expelled the rest of the Moors from the peninsula		Ferdinand V, King of Spain, 1452-1516; Isabella I, Queen of Spain, 1451-1504; Philip III, King of Spain, 1578-1621; Boabdil, king of Granada, d. 1527?; Granada (Kingdom) -- History; Granada (Spain) -- Genealogy; Islamic Empire -- History; Islamic Empire -- Kings and rulers; Arabs -- Spain -- History; Jews -- Spain -- History									NA387.G64 1842		1 p. ; 69 cm	eng, fre	jmap														asc99990000570009001		Goury, Jules and Owen Jones. Plans, elevations, sections, and details of the Alhambra, from drawings taken on the spot in 1834 by Jules Goury, and in 1834 and 1837 by Owen Jones : with a complete translation of the Arabic inscriptions, and an historical notice of the kings of Granada from the conquest of that city by the Arabs to the expulsion of the Moors, by Pasqual de Gayangos. London: O. Jones, 1842-1845. Volume I. Plate I [p. 1], Plano general de la fortaleza de la Alhambra, vol. 1	General plan of the fortress of the Alhambra ;  Plan general de la forteresse de l'Alhambra					Text and illustrations of Plate I. Here is given the location of the Alhambra in Granada and all the streets and buildings from its entrance from the Calle de Gomelos to the public gardens and Gate of Justice, Puerta del Vino, Plaza de los Algibes, also known as Place of the Cisterns. Also, the Palace of Charles V and the Casa Real, which is the remains of the ancient palace of the Moorish kings and the Alcazaba or citadel, which is located on the left of the Place of the Cisterns; Three engravings in [p. 1] offer: a distant view of the Alhambra from the neighborhood of the Albayzin; the front façade of the Palace of Charles V; and a distant view of the Alcazaba, which was used as a prison at the time.  The Alhambra Alta, which has houses, gardens and the parish church, was formerly the location of the great mosque and where the house of the Cadi stood. The walls and towers are also mentioned, including the Tower of Comares, which contains the Hall of the Ambassadors. Finally, the authors mention that the architecture of the Arabs is essentially religious and does not represent animal life, which results in decorations of geometrical ornaments, flowers and inscriptions from the Koran.  Two engravings in [p. 2] offer a distant view of the Tower of Comares and an unidentified location within the Alhambra		Charles V, Holy Roman Emperor, 1500-1558; Alhambra (Granada, Spain) -- Alcazaba; Arabs -- Spain -- History; Decorations; Palaces -- Spain -- Granada; Palacio de Carlos V (Granada, Spain); Architecture, Islamic -- Spain -- Granada; Andalusia (Spain)	Drawings								NA387.G64 1842		1 p. : ill. ; 69 cm	eng, fre, spa	jmap														asc99990000570030001		Goury, Jules and Owen Jones. London: O. Jones, 1842-1845. Volume I. Plate II [ p. 2], Puerta principal o de Justicia, [p.2], vol.1	Gate of Justice ;  Porte de Justice					Text of Plate II. It gives information of one the four entrances the Alhambra originally had: Torre de las Armas (Tower of Arms);  Torre de los Reyes Católicos (Tower of the Catholic Kings); Torre de los Siete Suelos (Tower of Seven Stories); Puerta de la Justicia (Gate of Justice). The last gate was originally called the Gate of Law (Babu-Sh-Shari'ah) and was built in 749 by Sultan Abu-L-Hajaj Yusuf. The door contains inscriptions carved in Arabic in the capitals placed in the interior of the horseshoe arch and also on top of the corona. A foot note explains the practice in the East of sitting under the gate of justice to administer justice to public matters. [p. 1] offers 3 architectural drawings -a section, plan elevation, and front facade- and [p. 2] the text and a distant view of the Gate of Justice		Alhambra (Granada, Spain) -- Gate of Justice; Architecture -- Spain -- Islamic influences; Palaces -- Spain -- Granada	Drawings								NA387.G64 1842		1 p. : ill. ; 69 cm	eng, fre, spa, ara	jmap														asc99990000570033001		Goury, Jules and Owen Jones. Plans, elevations, sections, and details of the Alhambra, from drawings taken on the spot in 1834 by Jules Goury, and in 1834 and 1837 by Owen Jones : with a complete translation of the Arabic inscriptions, and an historical notice of the kings of Granada from the conquest of that city by the Arabs to the expulsion of the Moors, by Pasqual de Gayangos. London: O. Jones, 1842-1845. Volume I. There are several cuffic writings dedicated to the grace and blessings of God appear around the small niches in the jambs of the doorway that are transcribed and translated. The private Mosque was converted into a chapel by Charles the Fifth. The niche located near the entrance of the chapel was probably the Mihrab or sanctuary of the mosque. Plans, elevations, sections, and details of the Alhambra, vol. 1		La Alhambra Palais; The Alhambra Palace		Goury, Jules, 1803-1834; Jones, Owen, 1809-1874	Gayangos, Pascual de, 1809-1897 (translator)	Volume one of a two volume set in which the authors give historical and pictorial information on the Alhambra Palace. The name in Arabic means "red fortress" and it is an exquisite example of Moorish architecture built by the Moorish rulers of Granada in southern Spain in the area known as Andalusia. After the expulsion of the Arabs from the Iberic Peninsula by the Catholic rulers, Fedinand and Isabella, the Christians occupied the palace and several modifications were made to the building and the gardens	Two images are not available in this volume: illustration of plate VII and the text of plate XLIV	Alhambra (Granada, Spain) -- History; Alhambra (Granada, Spain); Architecture -- Spain -- Islamic influences; Andalusia (Spain); Umayyad dynasty; Architecture -- Spain -- Granada; Art, Islamic -- Spain -- Granada; Architecture, Islamic -- Spain -- Granada; Caliphate; Caliphs; Decorations; Inscriptions, Arabic; Palaces -- Spain -- Granada; Paleography, Arabic (Cufic); Granada (Spain) -- Buildings, structures, etc.; Islamic Empire -- History; Islamic Empire -- Kings and rulers; Spain -- History	Architectural drawings; Elevations; Inscriptions; Plans;	London : O. Jones	1842	1840-1850	Spain				NA387.G64 1842		1 vol. : ill. Page 1																																asc9999001012		Is  NEGRO   EMANCIPATION  NO  PHILANTHROPY:  A LETTER  THE   DUKE   OF   WELLINGTON.  BY  A JAMAICA PROPRIETOR.  6 It would certainly never be argued in that House, that the West  India Islands were not an important part of the British empire, and that their interests did not deserve thue most serious  consideration."—LORD HOWICK, Feb. 10, 1807, Pari. Deb.  &lt; To emancipate the Negroes would not be to add to their happiness  even if the Legislature had a right to interfere with the  property of the Colonies."—LD. H. PETTY, March 17, 1807  Pari. Page 2																																asc9999001012		I     B     R     A     R  =yi  CHARLES WOOD AND SON, PRINTERS,  Poppin's Court, Fleet Street. 	asc99990010120002001									8	600	51471768 Bytes	3395	5052	636202099	RGB	asc99990010120002001.tif		2013-07-24	2013-07-24	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/4769	4769	4770.jp2	/scbooks/image/4770.jp2
Page 3																																asc9999001012		A  LETTER,  The magnitude of the interests, my Lord Duke,  which are involved in the question, must be my  excuse for presuming to address your Grace on  the almost exhausted subject of Negro Emancipation. Among the many political topics which are  periodically placed before the public, that on  which the fate of millions of private property may  depend, and, which is perhaps of not less importance, that on whioh no inconsiderable portion  of public revenue may depend, and on which,  till within the last few years of illumination, our  maritime greatness was considered mainly, if not  entirely, to depend, is surely not one which is to  be ranked among the minor subjects for parliamentary investigation. Nor indeed is it. It is  not however on the ground of individual ruin, nor  national loss, that this question is annually agitated.     Philanthropy  is  the ruling  principle  of 	asc99990010120003001									8	600	51599460 Bytes	3384	5081	596853978	RGB	asc99990010120003001.tif		2013-07-24	2013-07-24	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/4770	4770	4771.jp2	/scbooks/image/4771.jp2
Page 4																																asc9999001012		action; a philanthropy enlarged, expansive, but  by no means uniform; a philanthropy unconfined  by the limits of European policy, and which, disdaining the confines of one quarter of the globe^  encourages its votaries to navigate the Atlantic  in quest of objects on which they may alleviate  the ravening of their insatiable benevolence. The  British House of Commons is the arena on which  every little act of oppression, from the borders of  the Burmese empire to the confines of Canada, is  eloquently combated, the bar before which the  corporeal injuries of our species, and indeed of  every other species, are pathetically dilated upon.  But whatever compassionate tenderness we may  feel, or pretend to feel, for the poor, and the  houseless, and the destitute in our own country,  is of small moment, when compared with those  higher duties, whereby British subjects, acting  under British laws, are especially singled out as  the victims of British persecution. Consistency  seems immaterial; we go on in an amicable intercourse with our ancient and slave-driving ally  at Constantinople, we keep on the best possible  terms with our friends at Algiers, at Tunis, and  at Tripoli, and fix our philanthropic fangs in the  unhappy victims of our own name and kindred.  It matters not to us whether the Turk who sells  us   our   carpets   has   bastinadoed  his  slave   or 	asc99990010120004001									8	600	51594256 Bytes	3391	5070	440695528	RGB	asc99990010120004001.tif		2013-07-24	2013-07-24	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/4771	4771	4772.jp2	/scbooks/image/4772.jp2
Page 5																																asc9999001012		3  drowned his mistress, whether the Chinese who  furnishes us with tea has cut the throats of his  children, or merely buried them alive, whether  the Fezzan has starved his Negroes in the desert,  or stillettoed them in his own house. All goes  smoothly, so long as we can carry on our commercial interchange of toys and cutlery for ostrich feathers and gum arabic ; and every effort to  ameliorate the condition of our own countrymen,  is as dust when compared with the holier office of  liberating the African of the Antilles from the  chance of his thirty-nine lashes. People are  very ready to be charitable at the expense of  others. If the Abolitionists are honestly sincere,  let their philanthropy be general and not partial :  if they are really anxious to extinguish slavery  at all hazard in our colonies, with " a true attention to the interests of ail parties,'' as the reso-  lut'ons of the House of Commons have declared,  nothing is more easy than to enter into a subscription and establish a company for the purpose of purchasing the Negroes, and removing  them to some distant settlement; for President  Boyer, as is well known, will have nothing to say  to them, having quite enough of the unadulterated  African blood in his own dominions. But no,  my Lord, they will do no such thing; their manifest object is to consult the supposed  interests  b 2 	asc99990010120005001									8	600	51101364 Bytes	3331	5112	3859996979	RGB	asc99990010120005001.tif		2013-07-24	2013-07-24	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/4772	4772	4773.jp2	/scbooks/image/4773.jp2
Page 6																																asc9999001012		of the one party, without any consideration for  those of the other. " Men," said Mr. Burke in  speaking on the Slave question, " are always  ready to obey their sympathies when it costs  them nothing. Are they prepared to pay the  price for their virtue?" Not a sixpence. The  simple mention of a tax for such a purpose  would produce a panic from Cornwall to Caithness ; and the announcement of a public subscription would reduce the first subsequent meeting  at the Freemasons' Tavern to a respectable matronly assemblage, collected, most conscientiously  no doubt, for the purpose of rendering the Negro  of the West Indies by so much the more inde- jfa  pendent of work than the English labourer, as  he is now the more independent of starvation.  No one can have the effrontery to advocate slavery per se ; but we, in our capacity of West India  Proprietors, did not originate it. We found it, we  continued it; and as for the trade in slaves, we  were not only encouraged in it, we were absolutely  at one time prevented by the fiscal rapacity of  the mother country from restricting it. It was in  an evil hour that both that and the sugar cane  were introduced. Instead of becoming, as we  might have become, a colony of English, increasing in population, with smaller gains but greater  stability, with more of an agricultural and less  r 	asc99990010120006001									8	600	52310152 Bytes	3451	5051	4292478731	RGB	asc99990010120006001.tif		2013-07-24	2013-07-24	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/4773	4773	4774.jp2	/scbooks/image/4774.jp2
Page 7																																asc9999001012		1  4,  of a commercial character; we have concentrated  a dense population on one spot, and the rest of  our estates is waste. The labour of 300 Negroes  is brought to bear on a portion of land, which in  the ordinary cultivation of the richest European  soils would require but ten or twelve efficient  labourers. The prospect of high gains from sugar  has checked the cultivation of minor products.  The country urged us on, and the consequence has  been, that the colony has been rendered more  like an assemblage of coal-miners, than a body  of active agricultural residents. u Let us find  employment for whites," said the historian of  Jamaica, " and white families will with ease be  procured for these employments; in fact, we are  ceasing to be a colony and becoming a factory,  without sufficient production to ensure this station." Having got into this position, or rather being forced into this position, with a machinery for  cultivating our properties very far from being our  own sole creation, we are vilified and abused, because, in the course of nature, we have succeeded  to the ownership of slaves. But lamentation is  superfluous. The evil exists, and there is no  honest help for it, but to buy our Negroes and  bear with it.  My Lord, it is my intention to examine this  question principally on six grounds : —First, as a  - 	asc99990010120007001									8	600	53851516 Bytes	3545	5062	1914054290	RGB	asc99990010120007001.tif		2013-07-24	2013-07-24	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/4774	4774	4775.jp2	/scbooks/image/4775.jp2
Page 8																																asc9999001012		6  question of humanity to the Negro; Secondly,  as one of profit to the country; Thirdly, as one  of prudence towards the white inhabitants;  Fourthly, as one of justice towards the Negro;  Fifthly, as one of justice towards the proprietor ;  and, Lastly, as one of policy with respect to  other powers.  First then, my Lord, as a question of humanity to the Negro. There is no occasion  here to embark in any discussion on abstract  principles of liberty, because they have no immediate reference to this particular position. We  are to look at the case as it stands, and see whether the emancipation of the Negro would conduce more to his happiness, would promote the  enjoyment of life and the expansion of intellect  more than the state he is in at present. In the  first place, the emancipated Negro, having no  shadow of right to an acre of any of the soil,  can have no claims upon the white proprietor,  excepting on account of his labour. Experience  has fully shown, that industry and emancipation  are, as yet, utterly incompatible; and although  the onus probandi, the duty of showing that free  labour is available, rests with the emancipationist  and not with the proprietor, we may securely  maintain the negative, and challenge contradiction  on  the   facts  within our  reach; and  when   we  *&4  V 	asc99990010120008001									8	600	53074276 Bytes	3461	5110	385892411	RGB	asc99990010120008001.tif		2013-07-24	2013-07-24	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/4775	4775	4776.jp2	/scbooks/image/4776.jp2
Page 9																																asc9999001012		w~  assert, that the labour of the emancipated Negro  would be just enough to place him beyond the  limits of starvation, and that the labour required  for that object in a tropical climate is such as  would produce no adequate return to the proprietor, we assert that which is fact We have  the plainest practical experience of the effects of  emancipation. In the 27th year of Haytian  Independence, Mr, Consul General M'Kenzie,  the accredited agent of the British Government,  r writes to Mr. Canning, that there is a " deplora  ble absence of religious instruction;" that " morality is at its lowest ebb; " that " marriage is  scarcely thought of;" and that "the few young  females that live on a plantation, live in a constant state of idleness and debauchery." This  x is what Mr. M'Kenzie states so late as 1826;  and after this explicit declaration are we to be  told, that emancipation wquld add to the state of  happiness, and be unattended in Jamaica with  those effects which seven-and-twenty years of  liberty have not sufficed to remove in a neighbouring island ? and more especially are we to be  told so by those who affirm, as Mr. Wilberforce does,  that the essence of human happiness consists in  " the native feelings " and " moral dignity of man?"  Idleness is the essential characteristic of the  » Negro race.    If the labour of a few days will  suffice  to  supply  every  want)    how   could   we 	asc99990010120009001									8	600	53327244 Bytes	3468	5124	1713097048	RGB	asc99990010120009001.tif		2013-07-24	2013-07-24	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/4776	4776	4777.jp2	/scbooks/image/4777.jp2
Page 10																																asc9999001012		8  oblige them to carry their industry beyond? We  could not force them to be religious ; we could  not prevent them from being profligate; and I  question whether there is one West India resident,  who would not rather see the black population  embarked for the coast of Guinea, than retain it  in the hope of its available industry, and at the  risk of its insubordination. Every day would be  marked by agricultural ruin, and unbridled licentiousness. Mr. Canning, in making choice  between perpetual slavery and immediate emancipation, " had no hesitation in preferring the  former;" and Lord Lansdown, though at an  earlier period, maintained that " the emancipation of the Negroes would not be to add to their  happiness." If unrestrained idleness and unbounded debauchery constitute happiness, then  is the Negro not so happy as he would be; but it  may be, that he is now unhappy by reason of ill  treatment. My Lord, with respect to the present  treatment of the slave population, the best proofs,  it will be admitted, are to be collected from the  official statements of the slave protectors, or of  the governors. Mr. Young, the protector at De-  merara, says that he " cannot refrain from remarking on the contented appearance of the Negroes,  and, from opportunities of judging, thinks that  they generally have every reason to be so." It  may be that there are cases of active individual 	asc99990010120010001									8	600	54469848 Bytes	3559	5100	2270055743	RGB	asc99990010120010001.tif		2013-07-24	2013-07-24	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/4777	4777	4778.jp2	/scbooks/image/4778.jp2
Page 11																																asc9999001012		9  oppression. In his letter to the Lieutenant  Governor, Mr. Young says, that there have been  only two cases of prosecution under the ordinance ; one, " a child punished to an improper  excess," not by an European Hibner, "but by  a free black tradesman." The other, a female  struck in the field by the driver, in a moment of  anger. I question whether the annals of apprenticeships in this country are so barren of philanthropic food #. It may be that they suffer from  over-work; and most assuredly the way to promote this object, is to give the proprietor reason  to believe that he had best " make hay while the  I y sun shines," for that his slaves will be shortly out  of his power. Mr. Bennett, the fiscal of Berbice,  says, that " when slaves are occasionally employed  in boiling sugar at late hours of the night, it  proceeds generally more from casual circumstances, than from an intention or inclination of  the planter to work slaves at night." And what,  let me ask, are the annual exertions of the labourer  in harvest time in this country, but the result of  "casual circumstances?" My Lord, in the last  returns relating to the amelioration of the slave  population, it will be seen, that in all cases where  the governors of any of the islands have made  remarks on the treatment of the Negro population,  * The recent Oldham inquiry, for example. 	asc99990010120011001									8	600	53065216 Bytes	3455	5118	3614254853	RGB	asc99990010120011001.tif		2013-07-24	2013-07-24	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/4778	4778	4779.jp2	/scbooks/image/4779.jp2

For instance : Sir Charles Brisbane, the Governor of  St. Vincent, in writing to Sir George Murray,  Nov. 26, 1828, says, " In my long residence here  I have never known or heard of any instance in  which the proprietor had attempted to compel his  slaves to work on Sunday." " As regards religious instruction, I am sure there are no impediments thrown in the way of it by any, and many  are zealous in promoting it;" and he adds, " I  believe few labouring classes in any part of the  world enjoy a larger share of the real comforts of  life than falls to the lot of the industrious and  well-disposed slaves of St. Vincent." Sir Lowry  Cole, the Governor of the Mauritius, Dec. 24,  1826, says, " I am gratified in being able to  state, that both from the information I have received, and from my own observation, the treatment of the slave population has materially improved in this colony." Sir James Campbell, the  Governor of Grenada, Dec. 1, 1828, says, " I  am happy at the same time to say, that every  exertion is making by the inhabitants of the colony generally for the adoption of every possible  measure for the instruction of the slave population." Page 13																																asc9999001012		11  that its existing code of laws is considered to  contain a greater number of enactments in favour  of the slave population, than that of any other  legislative colony, with the exception of St. Christopher's."  My Lord, it is really wearying to wade through  the mass of documentary evidence, which the  importunities of the Emancipationists and the  compliances of the Government have forced upon  us. Such, however, are the accounts of Slavery  as it is. With respect to Slavery as it was, we  have indeed some evidence : we have the authority of a member of the legislature in 1806. He  stated, that he " had been in the West Indies  some years ago, and had been at all the great  plantations in Jamaica; and he declared the condition of the slaves was almost uniformly ameliorated, and they were generally treated with great  kindness, such as he had known a great family in  this country use to their ancient domestics."  Your Grace will very naturally conclude that  this was simply the bare assertion of a slave proprietor, of one blinded by interest and familiarized  with cruelty. My Lord, the speech in question  is that of one of the greatest advocates of civil  and religious liberty : it is that of an individual  who is identified with every thing that bears the  semblance of   eloquence  and  liberality,   in  the 	asc99990010120013001									8	600	52855288 Bytes	3442	5117	1020911594	RGB	asc99990010120013001.tif		2013-07-24	2013-07-24	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/4780	4780	4781.jp2	/scbooks/image/4781.jp2
Page 14																																asc9999001012		12  senate or at the bar, and whose name will be ever  handed down to the latest posterity, with the glorious adjunct of " Trial by Jury:" it is the speech  of Lord Chancellor Erskine ! Is it, my Lord,  against authorities, past and present, such as these,  (one given more than twenty years ago, when,  from the importation of fresh Negroes there might  have been some reason for presuming a prodigality  of cruelty, in the conviction that more might be  gained by forced labour than lost by fresh purchases), is it against authorities such as these  that we are now to array the evidence of disgraced  attorneys and discarded book-keepers ?  We are told, however, that if they are happy,  it is the happiness of the brute — the enjoyment  of eating, drinking, sleeping, and dancing, and  unaccompanied by those high and lofty intellectual endowments which elevate the mind within  the atmosphere of liberal institutions. Again,  my Lord, I say, let us look at Hayti, the glorious  issue of seven-and-twenty years of freedom, the  beau idSal of Black dominion. Let us be told  that slavery is an evil, but let us not be told that  the slave is unhappy, inasmuch as it is an assertion completely at variance with all the respectable evidence that can be collected. We admit  partial cases of cruelty: we admit that a Negro  has been flogged with a cart whip: we know that 	asc99990010120014001									8	600	54286248 Bytes	3547	5100	1476709774	RGB	asc99990010120014001.tif		2013-07-24	2013-07-24	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/4781	4781	4782.jp2	/scbooks/image/4782.jp2

It is surely not from any one connected with  the East Indies that we have a right to expect  either the charge of cruelty to our slaves, or a  flaming panegyric on free labour sugar. The  fraudulent grocer may be permitted to impose  upon the credulity of all the old women in a  parish, by labelling his loaves with that title ; but  it is not from any one of those who have furnished  a report of 937 pages on East India Slavery, that  we should expect such an* attack. If the Orientalist is not possessed of the fee simple of a fellow-creature, he is at best but a dealer with those  who are. Sir John Malcolm has harnessed us as  yoke-fellows. He tells us, that the " price of females in Malabar varies from 40 to 150 rupees;"  that they " are sold to prostitution ;" that " it is  not the habit of the native governments to take  cognizance of the punishments which masters inflict upon slaves, except such as extend to life."  Merciful provision! This is Sir John Malcolm's account.  The Asiatic Journal of February last, contains  the following statement respecting Prince of  Wales's Island. " Plans for the abolition of  slavery were proposed in 1805, 7, and 8; but  upon full investigation it was found that the  absolute emancipation of the slaves was inconsistent with the habits of the native settlers, and  in short impracticable;" and the whole affair evaporated in a mere establishment of regulations to  prevent the slave trade.  My Lord, I will dispute no further the claim  which the East Indian advances to the merits of a  mitigated vassalage rather than a direct slavery;  nevertheless, while we expose the deformities of  our enemy, we need not shrink from a disclosure  of our own. We do not pretend to free labour,  but we disclaim cruelty and demand indemnity,  as the words of an unquestionable authority will  show. He says, " the individuals," meaning the  slaves " are born in it," meaning slavery, " and it  is a second nature to them;" that " though it may  be allowed that slavery in the West Indies is not  intolerable,   and not  exercised  to  an  excessive 	asc99990010120016001									8	600	56689428 Bytes	3661	5160	1088907678	RGB	asc99990010120016001.tif		2013-07-24	2013-07-24	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/4783	4783	4784.jp2	/scbooks/image/4784.jp2

" The  most  serious  objection I have  heard against any active measures in favour of the  slaves, is  the violation of the rights of private  property which it would involve."    " A prospect  should be opened of eventual but gradual emancipation,  and proprietors should be indemnified  by the payment of the maximum of price."  These,  my Lord, are the observations of a well-informed  writer, as I am taught to believe.    It is perhaps  going a little too far, to say, that slavery is  "a  sort of second nature" to the slave; but that there  are not many cases of "active cruelty" I confidently credit; and the remarks on  the right to  indemnity would seem unquestionable.    But, my  Lord, will this satisfy the framers of parish petitions and the eaters of East India sugar?    Indeed, my Lord, it ought; for the passages I have  quoted relate not to the West Indies,  but to the  East Indies, not to Jamaica, but to Malabar; and  they are to be found in a report furnished by  Mr. Graeme,  dated  1822, and published in the 	asc99990010120017001									8	600	50194192 Bytes	3297	5073	1088228333	RGB	asc99990010120017001.tif		2013-07-24	2013-07-24	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/4784	4784	4785.jp2	/scbooks/image/4785.jp2
Page 18																																asc9999001012		16  Asiatic Journal, which journal is the mouth-piece  of the Court of Directors !  My Lord, we are next to consider this question  with reference to the profit to be derived by this  country. The importation to this country in the  year 1828 of sugar (for I take that alone as being  the staple commodity) from our West India possessions, was upwards of four million cwt. on  which the amount of duty levied was upwards of  five millions sterling. If that is a sum to be sacrificed to the philanthropy of the few by the liberality of the many, well and good. We are told,  that the expense of maintaining the colonies more  than counterbalances the benefit that accrues.  But Jamaica is not in this situation, she pays her  own garrison troops. The quantity of sugar imported in the last year from that island was upwards of one million cwt. and the duty paid  considerably above a million sterling. If this is  a sum to be sacrificed, well and good. I say  sacrificed, for I apprehend that no one will have  the hardihood to deny the termination of the cultivation of sugar in the event of emancipation. It  is no theoretical case that admits of vague surmises, but a plain fact, in which cause and effect  are but too evidently obvious. Page 19																																asc9999001012		17  overpowering, I will not call it satisfactory, evidence on this point, as on many others. In his  letter to Mr. Planta, dated December 1826, he  answers the following queries thus : — " Have the  sugar plantations diminished ?" " Almost entirely  annihilated." " Is the labour on those still existing voluntary or compulsory?" " Most distinctly  compulsory." " Is the whip used ?" " Abolished  by law, but military men have the privilege of  using a thick stick." So much for the effects of  free labour at Hayti, in the twenty-seventh year  of liberty. In his letter to Mr. Canning he says,  " By the law passed, all cultivators were attached  to the plantations to which they might first engage themselves, without the power of subsequently quitting them," adscripti glebce ; in short,  slaves in every sense of the word, with the solitary advantage of being regarded as fixtures. Of  the code rural, Mr. IV^'Kenzie observes, that  its " provisions are as despotic as those of any  slave system that can be conceived;" that " cultivation would not go beyond that which daily  necessities require ;" that " trained as every man  has been to the idleness of a Haytian military  life, it will be difficult to induce them by gentle  means to labour;" and that " every branch of cultivation requiring systematic labour has fallen into  decay." Such  is this " colonie essentiellement agricole" this " asile  tranquille d'une active et const ante famille" and  such was the mellifluous annunciation that ushered  in the nativity of this unparalleled republic. The  state of the country will be better shown by the  same writer s description of an estate called Plantation Laborde, which in 1789 had 1,400 slaves,  and produced 1,200,000 lbs. of clayed sugar. All,  as Mr. M'Kenzie says, now ruined, and sixteen  labourers were wandering about, cultivating provisions for their own use. Such, my Lord, is  Haytian prosperity, and such the glorious prospect, which is held out to us in exchange for  the solid wealth and commerce that now exist.  But to come more closely to Haytian habits:  Mr. M'Kenzie informs us, that " the soldiers use  the coco macac (a species of heavy jointed cane)  in a most arbitrary and sometimes cruel manner;"  and that he was " told by a respectable proprietor, that in the time of Dessalines, he," the proprietor, " had witnessed the flogging of a pregnant female, which produced abortion." Page 21																																asc9999001012		19  Negro and the delusion of Haytian independence,  and the people themselves, those in power at least,  the Mulattoes, being unanimous in the adoption of  compulsive remedies, does it require further evidence to show, that, for years to come, free labour  is a fond delusion, a consummation devoutly to be  wished, but hardly to be realized ? And yet there  are some conscientious sceptics, some persons sufficiently infatuated to regard this island as having  become, what the prophetic views of its admirers  declared, the centre of Caribbean civilization and  the source of African regeneration. We have  been told to mark its rising prosperity, and beware of its fate.  " The flattering index of a direful page.*'  " No kind of traffic,  No occupation, all men idle, all,  And women too, but innocent and pure."  Such is to be the euthanasia of our colonial  empire, and for such an empirical nostrum are  we to barter our present well-being. African indolence is by no means confined to the Transatlantic Negro. In his own country he exhibits  that character. In Congo we are told, that " the  general indolence of the inhabitants prevents their  deriving any substantial benefit from the fertility  of the soil;" that " the Negroes are averse to labour, and spend their time in dancing," &e.    The  c 2  i 	asc99990010120021001									8	600	52275108 Bytes	3429	5080	2950010505	RGB	asc99990010120021001.tif		2013-07-24	2013-07-24	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/4788	4788	4789.jp2	/scbooks/image/4789.jp2
Page 22																																asc9999001012		20  article Africa, in the supplement to the Encyclopaedia, ends with an avowal that some species of  "compulsion" is necessary in order to civilize  barbarians ; and it is " only in this way that the  inveterate habits of sloth and indolence can be  overcome." The plainest course, if the example  of Hayti is not thought satisfactory, is for the  Government to try the system in one of its own  colonies; and if, after a fair trial of a long series  of years, free labour is found available, it may then  be attempted with safety by the rest; but until  this fact has been proved, we may be pardoned  for being a little sceptical on the subject.  There are many persons who deem the possession of colonies unprofitable to the mother  country. This may be the case in some instances, as for example at Sierra Leone, where  the sacrifice far outweighs the advantages. If it  is so, we may abandon them ; but we surely have  no right to assail the proprietors of the soil on  their mode of cultivation; to abuse them for the  fortunes that they may have acquired, and in the  same breath to proclaim the inutility of the colony. The colony is either a source of commercial advantage to the mother country, or not; if it  is, we ought rather to strive to increase than to  diminish its productiveness. It is either a source  of political importance,  or not; if it is, we have 	asc99990010120022001									8	600	53994360 Bytes	3546	5074	3925174648	RGB	asc99990010120022001.tif		2013-07-24	2013-07-24	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/4789	4789	4790.jp2	/scbooks/image/4790.jp2
Page 23																																asc9999001012		21  no right to complain of the expense of maintaining a force to protect it. But, my Lord, this  is not a case in which a colony is to become more  productive by escaping from the thraldom of monopoly : it is not a question in which we are  called upon to abandon it to its own resources of  free trade and independent government. We  are actually urged to destroy, in the first instance,  the creative powers of that colony. Produce is  wealth, and we purpose to diminish to a vast extent the productions of that colony. We are in  short called on to ruin the resident and proprietor in England, not to mention the exporting  manufacturer, in order to rid ourselves, as a nation,  of a presumed reason for moral reproach. The  effect would be much the same as if Yorkshire was  to be rendered waste; not only would the resident  and non-resident proprietors be ruined, but the  marketable productions*of the whole country, of  which Yorkshire is a part, would be diminished,  and consequently its power would be diminished  in proportion to the value of the productions of  Yorkshire.  Whatever may be the doctrines of the day as  to the value and importance of the West India  colonies, I cannot think our estimate is overcharged, when we are enabled to record the opinions of two  such distinguished  individuals  as 	asc99990010120023001									8	600	52498796 Bytes	3443	5081	1691699374	RGB	asc99990010120023001.tif		2013-07-24	2013-07-24	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/4790	4790	4791.jp2	/scbooks/image/4791.jp2
Page 24																																asc9999001012		22  Mr. Fox and Lord Grey, The former, in proposing the vote of thanks to Lord Rodney in  1782, said, "it would be needless for him to expatiate upon the greatness of the victory ; no one  could be a stranger to it: all that we held dear in  the West Indies, all that we held dear in America,  depended upon it, and all was saved." And in  1807, Lord Grey, as we have seen, declared, but  perhaps not in the truest spirit of prophecy, that  it " never would be argued in that house, that  the West India Islands were not an important  part of the British Empire, and that their interests did not deserve the most serious consideration." My Lord, I not only think that they deserve, but I hope, indeed I feel confident that they  will meet with the " most serious consideration."  My Lord, we have seen that it is by no means  probable that Emancipation would be attended  by any thing like a system of free labour; and  that consequently, cultivation beyond the mere  quantity of produce required for home consumption would be entirely abandoned, and that therefore the wealth of the West India Islands, and by  necessary consequence the wealth of the mother  country, would be sensibly diminished. We have  now to consider whether emancipation is justifiable as a question of prudence towards the white  inhabitants. 	asc99990010120024001									8	600	54068824 Bytes	3546	5081	1890836153	RGB	asc99990010120024001.tif		2013-07-24	2013-07-24	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/4791	4791	4792.jp2	/scbooks/image/4792.jp2
Page 25																																asc9999001012		I  23  If an almost total stagnation of industry and a  relaxation from manual labour are calculated to  promote security, then would the whites be singularly at their ease. But their presence on the different sugar estates would be unnecessary in the profitless state of such property. They must emigrate  to the towns, and leave the inland parts to the enjoyment of the black population. The sense of  subjection on the one hand, and the practice of  kindness on the other, are the surest methods for  promoting peace and order. Discipline with the  white, and slavery with the black, are nearly synonymous ; and in the army the former enforces  obedience, and, tempered with kindness, prevents  discontent. We might as soon expect to see  order and regularity in a regiment where each  man was to act at his option and convenience, as  industry and subordination in a tropical colony  where a Negro population was to consult its own  pleasures alone in ajl cases of manual labour.  The plain state of the case is this: shall we in  order to support an abstract principle of right,  viz. that no man ought to be required to work  more than he is obliged in order to satisfy his  own immediate wants, ruin our colonies, and produce, as Lord Liverpool most justly observed,  when speaking on the Slave Question, " a greater  evil by our sudden change  than previously ex- 	asc99990010120025001									8	600	52934448 Bytes	3475	5076	3918477570	RGB	asc99990010120025001.tif		2013-07-24	2013-07-24	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/4792	4792	4793.jp2	/scbooks/image/4793.jp2
Page 26																																asc9999001012		24  isted ?" Do the Emancipationists suppose that  the Negroes now held in slavery are of a nature  different from that of their Haytian neighbours ?  Do they suppose that indolence would not be the  first fruit of their labours, and insurrection the second? Is a laxity of discipline in a fleet less  likely to produce disorder, than a firm enforcement of orders ? The East Indian tells us, and  perhaps very truly, that the East Indian empire  must be governed by absolute authority. In like  manner we say, that the West Indian archipelago must be governed by absolute authority.  We are told, or rather the West Indian resident  is told, that the knife is at his throat; and those  who hold out the threat, have the inimitable effrontery to propose the best possible means for  confirming their assertion. All this would be  but idle and harmless gasconade, if it were not  accompanied by every attempt short of positive  proclamation to the Negroes to revolt. With  liberty or rather licentiousness for the end, and  massacre for the means, the Negro is taught to  consider himself as a soldier in the most sacred  of causes, in the " advanced guard of freedom :"  how inconceivably ludicrous ! the forlorn hope of  folly ! and an inflammatory effusion, which found  a ready entrance to the pages of a Review, has  assumed the shape of a pamphlet under the aus- 	asc99990010120026001									8	600	53890548 Bytes	3535	5080	3571260810	RGB	asc99990010120026001.tif		2013-07-24	2013-07-24	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/4793	4793	4794.jp2	/scbooks/image/4794.jp2
Page 27																																asc9999001012		*  25  pices of the Anti-slavery society, as if for the more  easy circulation of its insurrectionary stimulants.  Is this tending to excite rebellion or not? Are we  to be charged with unseemly violence, because we  repel the libeller who assails us ? Whatever base  malignity can insinuate, whatever undisguised effrontery can advance, whatever frantic folly can  suggest, is concentrated in array against the West  India proprietors, as if they were the sole slave  masters in the universe, and we are told to put  on the armour of patience,  M Till motives that might warm an ague's frost,"  may draw forth a tardy denial of such calumnies. Here we are too far removed from the  scene, where the phrenetic vagaries of such a  party are destined by their authors to promote  their end, to be sensibly alive to danger, and indignation may subside into indifference. But the  case is otherwise in Jamaica, and the preparers  of the poison are aware of it.  Under such circumstances, with a press prolific  in every thing that can insult, degrade, and alarm  them, is it to be wondered at that there seems a  slowness and timidity (a perverseness or obstinacy if it pleases so to call it) in adopting those  plans of amelioration which emanate in the first 	asc99990010120027001									8	600	53482656 Bytes	3511	5076	1698003041	RGB	asc99990010120027001.tif		2013-07-24	2013-07-24	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/4794	4794	4795.jp2	/scbooks/image/4795.jp2
Page 28																																asc9999001012		I  26  instance from the enemy's camp ? Moreover, are  not the residents in the West Indies fully borne  out by facts in their belief, that emancipation  would bring with it that train of disastrous consequences, which the parliamentary documents  in your Grace's possession show to have been the  result of Haytian independence? A fair case of  free labour, industry and subordination must be  made out before the property and life of the residents can in justice be endangered ; and as yet,  my Lord, no such case has been made out, and  consequently it is not prudent to expose the  white inhabitants to the risk of the insubordination necessarily concomitant with an idle and  dissolute black population of overpowering numerical force, any more than it would be to move  an army or manage a fleet by any other agency  than a purely despotic power, or to rule India  through the medium of a representative government.  My Lord, we are now to consider the question  as one of justice to the Negro. This is of a  more abstract nature, but here again I may be  at issue with the philanthropy and philosophy of  the day. My Lord, I know of no abstract;  hereditary, natural, or original right, that any one  has to any thing, not even to free agency. All  our pretensions to liberty are founded upon legal 	asc99990010120028001									8	600	54172704 Bytes	3523	5124	2122559435	RGB	asc99990010120028001.tif		2013-07-24	2013-07-24	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/4795	4795	4796.jp2	/scbooks/image/4796.jp2
Page 29																																asc9999001012		1  27  provisions and enactments; but for these the  weak would, time out of mind, have been the prey  of the strong; and the law of nature is little else  than the droit du plus fort. Personal liberty, even  in the most civilized states, is violated continually,  from the captain of the press-gang to the overseer of the parish. It may be said, that it is an  undeniable axiom that the Creator desires the  happiness of his creatures, and that slavery does  not conduce to that happiness. With respect to  a trade in slaves this is unquestionably true, but  as far as regards the present progress of the slave  towards civilization, I confess myself one of those  who think that any thing approaching to immediate emancipation would have quite a contrary  effect. That his animal wants and lusts might be  more amply gratified, I admit; but that he would  be one step nearer civilization, I deny. The little  knowledge that he Jias of religion is derived from  his condition and dated from his captivity. In Africa  where he was born, and in Hayti where he is free,  he is still stated to be " without religion." As to the  declamation about the "native feelings and moral  dignity of man," it is really time to abandon such  notions. The soldier barters his " native feelings" for clothes and rations to the recruiting  serjeant. The sailor surrenders his " moral dignity" without a  veto  to  the  lieutenant  of the 	asc99990010120029001									8	600	53299920 Bytes	3499	5076	3660549898	RGB	asc99990010120029001.tif		2013-07-24	2013-07-24	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/4796	4796	4797.jp2	/scbooks/image/4797.jp2
Page 30																																asc9999001012		28  press-gang. To the Russian serf slavery is a  " second nature," and the knout is in the ratio of  punishment to the cat-o'-nine-tails, what the cat-  o'-nine-tails is to the Negro whip. There can be  no question but that the carrying into slavery by  impressment in a civilized country is worse than  the continuing of slavery in the West Indies.  Necessity is the plea. There can be no question  but that military flogging is infinitely worse, both  as to violence and duration, than West India flog-  ing. Necessity is the plea. There can be no question but that the captain of a ship exercises as  arbitrary a rule as the owner of a sugar estate.  Necessity is the plea. In the same way, my Lord,  necessity is the plea for the continuance of slavery in the West Indies. Their very bondage  has raised them in the scale of creation: the  giving them emancipation would at once restore  them to their African habits. But if the time arrives when it can be done, with the certainty,  not the mere chance and hope, that it will be beneficial to them, without endangering the lives  and properties of the whites, let it be conferred,  as a blessing which may be in vain expected for  the rest of their brethren in Africa. Until that  time arrives, we must be contented to hold on  our course, maintaining with Lord Liverpool, that  ** it does  not  follow  that  every  evil  is  to be 	asc99990010120030001									8	600	56017344 Bytes	3643	5124	846133137	RGB	asc99990010120030001.tif		2013-07-24	2013-07-24	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/4797	4797	4798.jp2	/scbooks/image/4798.jp2
Page 31																																asc9999001012		1  29  abolished, without reference to the practical effect  of such abolition." When the practical effect  can be shown to be good, then let the evil be  abolished, and not till then.  We are now, my Lord, to consider this question of emancipation as one of justice to the  proprietors. That such an outrageous violation of  private property, that such an unwarrantable departure from parliamentary pledges, that such a  direct spoliation should find advocates, and that  those advocates should "profess and call themselves Christians," and hardly hold us to be so, is  indeed wonderful. I have no hesitation in saying  moreover, that any attempt to prod uce emancipation,  except by the concurrence of the colonial legislatures, and coupled with indemnity, is illegal, fraudulent, and arbitrary, and not one iota less iniquitous  than it would be to annihilate the national debt by  refusing to pay the interest; indeed more so, inasmuch as we might in the one case be reduced to  insolvency, whereas in the other we cannot be  driven into philanthropy; and the debtor in distress  is less criminal than the swindler in affluence.  But even in a case of national insolvency, we  should have no right to mulct one party to the  prejudice of the other ; all must share the burthen  alike. Property exists only by law; and the law  which protects the landholder and the fundholder. 	asc99990010120031001									8	600	51868848 Bytes	3389	5100	3910331713	RGB	asc99990010120031001.tif		2013-07-24	2013-07-24	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/4798	4798	4799.jp2	/scbooks/image/4799.jp2
Page 32																																asc9999001012		r  30  equally protects, or ought to protect, the West  India proprietor. We have no right to single  out one party for pillage and confiscation, and  fasten upon one species of property merely  because its nature does not happen to suit our  refined theories of right and wrong.  The fact of slavery being in itself a wrong,  does not affect the proprietor of a sugar estate  more than the purchaser of the sugar. We have  no right for the sake of general justice to inflict  partial evil, in order to cure an evil caused and  continued by common consent. Tithes are considered to be an evil. The right of abolishing  them quoad the church is defensible, and for this  reason, that the church is not an individual, and  cannot claim them in its corporate capacity ; but  we have no right to exonerate the lands of one  man from a burthen which he contracted and  expected to pay, in order to benefit another. The  imperium in imperio of a subject's sovereignty in  the Isle of Man was found to be injurious: we  purchased it: we never thought of forcing the  Duke of Athol to surrender without an equivalent, if we had it would have been robbery.  The cutting a canal, the widening a street, the  turning a road, is bad for the few, but good for the  many; yet we never commit such injuries without giving compensation;   and moreover we do 	asc99990010120032001									8	600	54188076 Bytes	3524	5124	1257469400	RGB	asc99990010120032001.tif		2013-07-24	2013-07-24	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/4799	4799	4800.jp2	/scbooks/image/4800.jp2
Page 33																																asc9999001012		31  not harass the  inhabitants till their property has  become precarious,   in order to  obtain a lower  estimate of its value.    All monopolies are injurious ;  but if the nation  has granted  a right to  an  individual, it  has  no  right  to   destroy that  monopoly,   even   though   the   grievance  should  increase tenfold annually.    Quit rents,   arbitrary  fines, heriots, all copyholds, are abominations, and  actually  injure the  country   by preventing  improvement :    yet  that  parliament   would   be   a  pattern  of perfidy that should  decree their unqualified abolition.   They must be purchased, not  according to that depression in price which the constant agitation of the question would have caused,  but according to the antecedent annual value to  the possessor.   And yet, my Lord, in the face of  such facts, we are urged by these equitable adjusters to annihilate rights which have received  the sanction of Parliament for nearly  two centuries.    We are called upon to do a double act  of perfidy,  to attack the rights of the proprietors  which we guaranteed, and annul the rights of the  colonial legislatures which we conferred.   In short,  public faith is to become the veriest mockery that  ever deluded a simple people.    Mr. Fox, even in  the most violent paroxysms of his philanthropy,  and in the most inflammatory stages of his ardour  for civil  and religious liberty, denied,  distinctly  I 	asc99990010120033001									8	600	51941604 Bytes	3426	5052	1757851738	RGB	asc99990010120033001.tif		2013-07-24	2013-07-24	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/4800	4800	4801.jp2	/scbooks/image/4801.jp2
Page 34																																asc9999001012		32  denied (and so did even a greater than he, Lord  Chatham) the right of interference with the colonial legislatures, My Lord, I must beg your  Grace's attention to some passages in a speech of  Mr. Fox, because they show, first, what his sentiments were with regard to the question of property;  and secondly, what they were with regard to the  question of interference.  In 1792, in the debate on the Slave Trade, in  answer to Mr. Dundas, who wished to begin by  emancipation, Mr. Fox said, " the Honourable  Gentleman called a mere regulation of trade an  invasion of property; but himself proposed the  very extinction of that property in the first instance." "With respect to the infringement of  private property, they surely might prohibit the  commission of crimes, without thereby being-  chargeable with taking away the property of the  West Indians, which certainly it was not their  intention to do." In 1796, on the same subject,  he said, "the question is not one which interferes  with the local jurisdiction of the colony. The  confusion in this instance has arisen from the  idea, that if the abolition takes place, it must necessarily be followed by emancipation. I hope  and trust it will, but this point I leave for the decision of the proper legislature, with whose provisions I  have no wish to interfere"    "We do 	asc99990010120034001									8	600	55266468 Bytes	3604	5110	1066381640	RGB	asc99990010120034001.tif		2013-07-24	2013-07-24	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/4801	4801	4802.jp2	/scbooks/image/4802.jp2
Page 35																																asc9999001012		I  33  not pretend to legislate for them on the point of  emancipation"     Such,   my Lord Duke,   are  the  recorded opinions of Mr. Fox; opinions ratified  by Lord Lansdown in 1807, when he  said  that  Parliament had no " right to interfere with the  property of the Colonies."    It is in the face of  this long recognized right that we were told by  Mr. Canning, that "the British House of Commons must do the part itself."    By Mr. Wilber-  force, that " few if any are bold enough to claim  for   the assemblies an exclusive jurisdiction  on  these  subjects   as  their  right."     And   lastly,   I  regret to add, by the present Secretary for the Colonies, who intimates, in his circular letter of September 15, 1828, that " the neglect of the colonists  to exercise their right of legislating for the slave  population," may " at length induce the necessity  of a legislative interposition from home."    Why,  my Lord, with all due submission, one portion of  this sentence explicitly contradicts the other.    If  the colonists have a right to legislate, they have  a right to legislate as it seems best to them ; and  if the Parliament of Great Britain has a paramount right to interpose, because the colonists  have exercised their rights, it is sufficiently evident that the colonists have a right, and yet have  no right, which  is impossible;   and " the prerogative with  which  the mother  country has  in- 	asc99990010120035001									8	600	52991652 Bytes	3487	5064	54552178	RGB	asc99990010120035001.tif		2013-07-24	2013-07-24	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/4802	4802	4803.jp2	/scbooks/image/4803.jp2

" No sovereignty, and yet he would be king on't."  There are some, my Lord, who style our property in the West Indies a speculation, a mere  mercantile adventure, for which no indemnity can  be claimed, any more than for an occasional failure  in trade, for losses by Poyais loans, Philhellenic  bonds, or Peruvian mining shares. In the selection of a comparison for this "speculation," a  speculation by the way which shows some stamina, having nearly attained the venerable age of  two centuries, we have been told to take the case of  an investment of land regained from the sea, and  that therefore if the sea should happen to break  in, the nation cannot be bound to compensate for  such a casualty. My Lord, there is another class of abolitionists,  who resist indemnity on the ground of the moral  illegality of the first acquirement. But will this  argument hold for an instant ? They give me  land and labourers to hold in perpetuity; they  plunder me, in my capacities of planter and consumer, of considerable sums in the shape of duties  for a series of years; and they then tell me my  hour is come, and that I must be robbed because  my tenure, which they guaranteed, was ab initio  void, and my profits, in which they shared largely,  were the product of inhumanity.  My Lord, there is yet another class of persons,  who say that we are engaged in a losing trade,  and that capital should be turned into a different  channel: and this operation of diverting capital  is talked of with as much complacency as the  turning of a road or of a te-to-tum*. Page 38																																asc9999001012		36  eipation of the Negro is far from being a mere  diversion of capital, it is nothing more nor less  than the destruction of that capital; it is not the  turning of our resources into another and a better  channel, it is the cutting off our resources ; it is  not the mere fracture of the machinery, it is the  deliberate destruction of the hands that work it.  No one would say, that if the labourers of Yorkshire were to have their arms amputated, and that  no extraneous persons should be employed, that  capital had been simply diverted into another  channel. The plain fact would be, that the Yorkshire landholders must be ruined, and the capital,  that is the land, would be about as useless as a  right of shooting would be, if we had no possibility of procuring powder and shot.  My Lord, with respect to the policy of the  measure, as it refers to other powers. Whether  colonies are an advantage to the mother country,  as a vent for her manufactures and a nursery for  her seamen, or not, is a question of some importance. There were days, when the wisest  held the affirmative; and if the proof of the  pudding is in the eating, we may suspect that the  doctrine is not altogether so erroneous as later  affecting its value, and by which its capital may be transferred  to new channels, must always be productive of hazardous,  speculation and loss."—Message of President Jackson. 	asc99990010120038001									8	600	55224216 Bytes	3668	5017	1366398480	RGB	asc99990010120038001.tif		2013-07-24	2013-07-24	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/4805	4805	4806.jp2	/scbooks/image/4806.jp2

Independent governments, that would give us the commercial advantages we now enjoy, would unquestionably be more for our benefit, while an abdication in favour of France, or Russia, or America,  might by accident bring another broomstick at the  mast-head to the Nore. The question is, whether,  having already assisted in a very marvellous  manner the cultivation of foreign sugar, we shall  assist it still further by cutting off our contribution  to the supply altogether ? Shall we proceed to  ruin our own fellow-subjects for the sake of benefiting, not simply the Black population in our  islands, which it is conceived that it would not  do, but in order to benefit the American, the  French, and the East Indian slave owners, and  the Spanish and Brazilian slave traders. My  Lord, with respect tor the trade in slaves still  carried on by the latter, the English consul writes  in 1826: " On the score of humanity, whatever  may be said by this Government, I look for very  little being done;" and Mr. Gordon, the minister,  in the same year speaks of the " repeated infraction of the slave trade treaties at Maranham." Page 40																																asc9999001012		38  coming with slaves into that port), " however  flagrant, or with whatever circumstances accompanied, would be an object of prosecution under  the colonial laws of Spain."  Is it, then, that we are to embark in the speculation of emancipation with a view to increase  our returns ? The idea is preposterous. Is it  that we may enable the black population to obtain  a quiet possession of the islands, and form a  Caribbean republic, in order that we may watch  the progress of African regeneration, and purchase slave-grown sugar from foreigners? Or is  it that the islands with their appurtenances may be  handed over to some more hungry power, leaving  us freed from the odium of being slave-owners, but  condemned to buy the sugar which we once sold,  extract it from beet root, or go without ? It is  possible that the colonies may not be a hold of political power : it is possible that they may not be  a source of commercial advantage : we may have  multiplied our means and strengthened our sinews  in spite of them: they may have been a millstone  about our necks, a fetter to the freedom of trade,  and a clog on the chariot wheels of victory.  These may, in our more enlightened days, be  reasons for abandoning them; but it is confessedly  no reason for emasculating them by emancipation,  ,in order to retain them and render them more pro- 	asc99990010120040001									8	600	54293688 Bytes	3572	5065	4092445695	RGB	asc99990010120040001.tif		2013-07-24	2013-07-24	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/4807	4807	4808.jp2	/scbooks/image/4808.jp2
Page 41																																asc9999001012		39  fitable;   still   less  for  subjecting  them  to  such  treatment if we mean to abandon them as useless.  Ju At all events, those who are adverse to the reten  tion of our colonies, on the ground of inutility,  have clearly no right to advocate emancipation  on the ground of philanthropy. If it is held that  the colonies are unfruitful now, it is worse than  folly to urge a measure which will obviously reduce their present unfruitfulness to absolute sterility ; and moreover to execute an arbitrary and  illegal act of sovereignty, when we say that we  wish to retain no sovereignty at all, is little less  than the mere wantonness of power.  My Lord, the subject of West India Slavery  has been the annual theme of provincial eloquence  and parochial petitioning, and is likely to conti-  ) nue to be so.    The Society of Friends is, I be  lieve, the only petitioning body that has paid us  the compliment of proposing to take our rights by  purchase instead of by robbery. We are emphatically styled the " Hibners" of the New World:  we are told that we are kept in existence by a  bounty, and that the people of this country are  plundered, in order to uphold a system of slavery  and support a West Indian monopoly; in other  words we are informed, that if the duties were  equalized slavery must perish of itself, because  the cultivation of sugar in the West Indies would 	asc99990010120041001									8	600	51814848 Bytes	3436	5025	3106061176	RGB	asc99990010120041001.tif		2013-07-24	2013-07-24	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/4808	4808	4809.jp2	/scbooks/image/4809.jp2
Page 42																																asc9999001012		40  be terminated as unprofitable. And what is the  purport of all this, but to throw the cultivation of  sugar into the hands of the French, the Ameri-  cans^ and the Brazilians, and to enable the English philanthropists to enjoy the gratification of  eating the free labour sugar of Malabar, where  the cultivators being " born in slavery," find it  only " a second nature to them." That any one  of those whose empire was founded in aggression  should dispute our title — that the guardians of  captive rajahs should charge us with oppression—  that the entire monopolists of the tea trade should  accuse us of being the partial monopolists of the  sugar trade — that any of those whose rule has  been a graduated system of encroachment, from  the times of Suraja Dowla to the days of the  Peshwa of Poonah, should put on such hostility  towards us,— is indeed marvellous. The joint  cases may be bad in a moral point of view; but  ours is at least defensible in law, if not in  equity.  Our claim for protection against the introduction of East India sugar on a par with that from  our own colonies is this :—putting aside the long  entertained opinion of our importance to the  empire; putting aside the revenue that is derived  from our duties, and the advantages obtained by  the monopoly of our supplies; putting aside also  ^ 	asc99990010120042001									8	600	53725452 Bytes	3536	5063	2322477702	RGB	asc99990010120042001.tif		2013-07-24	2013-07-24	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/4809	4809	4810.jp2	/scbooks/image/4810.jp2
Page 43																																asc9999001012		I.  r  41  the fact, that our cultivation was checked by the  abolition of the slave trade, while it has been in-  ^ creased in regard to foreign powers by its con  tinuance ; and lastly, putting aside the fact, that  the ceded foreign colonies have been admitted to a  free competition with our own; — I contend that  the East India trader (for he is no better) has not  only no right to expect an equalization on the  ground of free labour, but that even if the labour  was free, the sugar is grown on lands which  are not the property of Englishmen, and by the  laws of the East India Company never can be.  My Lord, even if the land in the East Indies was  the property of Englishmen, as the land in the  West Indies is, it would then be a question for  political discussion, whether it would be desirable  to assist the cultivation of sugar in the former to  the extinction of it in the latter; but as such is  not the case, there is no further occasion to  notice it.  Why, my Lord, are we to accuse the colonial  legislatures of perverseness and contumacy in not  immediately acceding to the wishes of the mother  country? "What are we to expect," says Sir  Charles Brisbane, " from men who apprehend  that they are walking on a precipice, with every  thing that they possess in this world on their  back ?    Can we wonder that under such circum- 	asc99990010120043001									8	600	51906108 Bytes	3440	5028	3235072782	RGB	asc99990010120043001.tif		2013-07-24	2013-07-24	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/4810	4810	4811.jp2	/scbooks/image/4811.jp2
Page 44																																asc9999001012		42  I  stances,   their  steps  should   be   hesitating  and  slow?   Any attempt to hasten their movements by  force, will at once render them immovable." And ~i  what if they are  immoveable ?   We may crush,  in the plenitude of our power, the victims that  we have been fostering and fattening upon for a  century ;  we may annihilate the laws which we  have sworn to keep inviolate, and bind the arm  that we have entrusted with the administration of  them.    But even this, to the pious proclaimer of  the " Truce of God," of that truce which it  is  prayed, with a mockery that would be laughable  if   it  was  not  blasphemous,    may   precede  the  righteous imitation of the matins of Paris and the  vespers of Sicily, would seem but tardy justice.  My Lord, it is really inconceivable how every  trumpery disturbance becomes the basis on which  a Babel of evidence is to be constructed, and the  solemn parade with which it is made the thesis  for an oratorical display. The attack on Mr. Rad-  cliffe's house, and the sermon of Mr. Brydges,  were magnified into a degree of importance,  such as rarely falls to the lot of much mightier  events; and occupied a greater share of the  public attention than if half the Chinese empire  had been put to the sword ; and we remained,  not indeed in a state of suspended indignation,  but pouring out the vials of our wrath at starting,  '4L 	asc99990010120044001									8	600	52745244 Bytes	3488	5039	1413489323	RGB	asc99990010120044001.tif		2013-07-24	2013-07-24	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/4811	4811	4812.jp2	/scbooks/image/4812.jp2
Page 45																																asc9999001012		I  43  as if it was to get the whip hand of evidence and  steal a march upon contradiction ; until the Duke  of Manchester was kind enough to inform us  with respect to the first outrage, that " as far as "  he could " learn it was a drunken frolic amongst  some of the privates on guard ;" and in respect of  the latter, that " the sermon was not written by  Mr. Brydges but by the archdeacon of Colchester, and had been often preached before."  My Lord, the age is not only prolific in philanthropy but precocious in intellect; not content  with the seven-leagued strides of the schoolmaster in this country, we are for shipping him  across the Atlantic before his scholars at home are  well out of their accidence : not content with the  religious instructions of the regular clergy, we  must have men who can conduct their hearers  through the mysteries of religion to the realities  of revolt, and surreptitiously substitute a more  approved mixture of three parts of sedition to  two of Christianity : not content with the really  religious labours of many of the Wesleyan Missionaries in the West Indies, we must correct the  insipidity of their doctrines by a stronger compound, furnished by their brethren from this hemisphere. All manner of politicians (I will not  adopt the purer phraseology of the reviewers and  say " all odious and foul birds,") are engaged in this  petitioning traffic, from the peripatetic who rants 	asc99990010120045001									8	600	51111228 Bytes	3390	5024	3395376847	RGB	asc99990010120045001.tif		2013-07-24	2013-07-24	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/4812	4812	4813.jp2	/scbooks/image/4813.jp2
