The violence of our enemies may  be received as a boon. It carries with it, we  trust, its own correction. Their ranks must  materially diminish, when the prudent and the  pious are called upon to unite with the unblushing instigators of massacre, the accessories in  murder before the fact. Hear it, ye just abolitionists, and consort not with those who can  rejoice in the spectacle  of  the Negro reeking  ^v 	asc99990010120046001									8	600	53573300 Bytes	3547	5033	113446767	RGB	asc99990010120046001.tif		2013-07-24	2013-07-24	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/4813	4813	4814.jp2	/scbooks/image/4814.jp2
Page 47																																asc9999001012		45  from his triumphant butchery, his Christian carnage ! cheered though he may be in the onset, by  the hosannas of one party, and the paeans of  another. My Lord, there are some who revile  us, that we cling to a sinking cause. If that  be a reproach, if resting on our own rights  and on our country's faith is a reproach, I  pray that we may continue to enjoy it. I  will not yet believe in the feebleness of our  cause, nor in the faithlessness of our friends; and  I am unwilling to believe that the country will  act like the bully, who has encouraged his younger  schoolfellow to rob an orchard, and then, not  content with engrossing the greater share of the  plunder, basely betrays his weaker companion  when the theft is discovered, and thrashes him  for the way by which he acquired the apples of  which he himself has partaken. My Lord, there  are others who tell us that we must look the thing  in the face, that emancipation must come, that the  impatience (the u ignorant impatience" perhaps) of  the people for it is too ardent, too irrestrainable,  that there is an ungovernable appetite for emancipation. That it will come some time or other I  hope and believe ; but the when is the difficulty.  It is hard that we should be hurried into the destruction of our property by the " ignorant impatience" of those who have no such property at  stake, and   that we alone   should  be made  the 	asc99990010120047001									8	600	50782864 Bytes	3381	5005	2684432796	RGB	asc99990010120047001.tif		2013-07-24	2013-07-24	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/4814	4814	4815.jp2	/scbooks/image/4815.jp2
Page 48																																asc9999001012		I  46  scape-goats   of   national   iniquity.     My   Lord,  I have no   hesitation   in saying, that the temporizing policy  of the times has rendered our  property   absolutely   unmarketable.     We   have  legislative   rights,   which   at   one   moment  are  acknowledged,   at  another   denied.     We   have  property, the tenure of which is at one moment  sacred,   at  another questionable.    Indemnity is  undisputed now, spoliation proclaimed hereafter.  My Lord, as far as security and saleability go, we  might nearly as well hold under the Grand Turk  in capite, or under  the Court of Chancery  in  equity.    We have been patient under abuse,  till  patience has degenerated into pusillanimity. If the  country is not prepared to proclaim aloud its perfidy  by   unqualified   emancipation,   but  is   still  anxious for the attainment of the object by legitimate means, let it be taxed to the amount of a  fair   valuation.    If a  party  alone   is   inflamed  with this furor philcethiopicus, let them prove the  honesty of their intentions by their alacrity in a  public subscription.    If neither the one nor the  other, let not our property be daily depreciated,  and our rights dribbled away by vacillating and  undecided   legislation,   a  legislation  which   has  hitherto shown but a partial desire to protect our  property, with a positive determination to deprive  us of our privileges.  MyLord Duke, I appeal to your Grace in the  .  '&gt;.. 	asc99990010120048001									8	600	54060732 Bytes	3563	5056	1474319801	RGB	asc99990010120048001.tif		2013-07-24	2013-07-24	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/4815	4815	4816.jp2	/scbooks/image/4816.jp2
Page 49																																asc9999001012		,  47  most perfect confidence, as to one who is prepared to render justice to all parties; who will  neither be blinded into a belief that no Negro is  oppressed, any more than that every overseer is a  ruffian and every judge a rogue; who will not  debase the proprietor with indigence in order to  elevate the slave into licentiousness; who will  neither presume that every slave owner is inherently a savage, nor every abolitionist essentially  a sage; and who will not violate the faith of the  country by ministering to the holy cheatery that  hourly encroaches upon our too credulous ears,  and cants "thus vilely."  My Lord, in common with others I have a deep  interest at stake. If the acts on which our  claims are founded were the mere ebullition of a  revolutionary assembly, our position might be  different; but when they exist by the consecutive  guarantee of nearly two centuries of Parliaments,  something like property must be presumed to  have been created, and to say the least, something like a general onus of criminality must be  allowed to have been produced. In the first case  the right should be respected, in the latter the  odium should be shared. If I partake not in the  powers and in the knowledge of earlier labourers  in the cause, I share equally in the obloquy that  is heaped upon us. If the want of local knowledge 	asc99990010120049001									8	600	51403932 Bytes	3404	5032	1667833950	RGB	asc99990010120049001.tif		2013-07-24	2013-07-24	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/4816	4816	4817.jp2	/scbooks/image/4817.jp2
Page 50																																asc9999001012		48  is against me, the same is the case with the great  mass of our antagonists. The lawyer speaks  from his brief, and the abolitionist from his Reporter. I rest my cause on Parliamentary pledges  and official papers. If I plead it with truth, though  I plead it not with eloquence, I feel that I shall  not have pleaded it in vain.  I remain, with the highest respect,  A JAMAICA PROPRIETOR. 	asc99990010120050001									8	600	55693060 Bytes	3683	5039	3171836038	RGB	asc99990010120050001.tif		2013-07-24	2013-07-24	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/4817	4817	4818.jp2	/scbooks/image/4818.jp2
Page 51																																asc9999001012		]  I I    &lt;  POSTSCRIPT.  The evils of which we complain, and the reliefs  that we require, may be summed up as follows.  First, We complain that the duties have been increased to an inordinate degree, insomuch that  the proprietor would gladly receive the sums that  he pays to Government, in lieu of the profits that  he acquires by the sale. Secondly, That a war duty  has been continued during fifteen years of peace.  Thirdly, That the foreign ceded colonies have introduced a vast quantity of additional slave grown  sugar to the market. Fourthly, That the public  are taught to believe that they are made to pay  high prices in order to support the grower and  not the revenue. Fifthly, That an interested body  of persons connected with the East India trade  are desirous of seeing their own sugar admitted,  on the pretence that it is produced by free labour,  but which is really not the case, and even if it  was, it is grown on the soil of foreigners, from  whom it is purchased.    Sixthly, That every little  i 	asc99990010120051001									8	600	52050404 Bytes	3453	5023	2406732257	RGB	asc99990010120051001.tif		2013-07-24	2013-07-24	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/4818	4818	4819.jp2	/scbooks/image/4819.jp2
Page 52																																asc9999001012		XT  50  act of oppression is trumpeted throughout the  country, as if tyranny was a monopoly as well as  sugar. And lastly, That our property is rendered  insecure and unsaleable by the constant agitation  of a question, which if carried into execution,  would involve its comparative barrenness, rather  than by any unproductiveness of its own.  The remedies that may be proposed are, First,  To reduce the duty very considerably. Secondly,  To augment the prospect of sale by admitting  sugar into the distilleries. Thirdly, To throw  open the trade in rum with a lower rate of duty  to Scotland and Ireland as well as to England.  Fourthly, To establish if possible a freer intercourse between the United States and the West  Indian Islands. And lastly, that Parliament  should declare, in accordance with its own acts  and the repeated assurances of its most distinguished members, that to emancipate the Negro  by any law passed in this country, without the  concurrence of the colonial legislatures, and without purchase, is in direct violation of its recorded  faith, and nothing better than a deliberate robbery. That it is more politic to support the  grower of an article than to levy a tax to his ruin,  seems indisputable. Sugar has become a necessary. The political economist informs us,  that taxes on necessaries fall partly on the pro-  SL.  / 	asc99990010120052001									8	600	54353484 Bytes	3571	5072	2327588684	RGB	asc99990010120052001.tif		2013-07-24	2013-07-24	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/4819	4819	4820.jp2	/scbooks/image/4820.jp2
Page 53																																asc9999001012		T  51  ducer and partly on the consumer. We are both  producers and consumers. If a tax on an article  causes a rise in its price, and that rise places it beyond the reach of some of the community, the diminution of a tax must operate by placing it within  the reach of more.of that community. The consumption of coffee was quadrupled after the duty  was taken off. If a portion of the duty on sugar,  (say 7s.) was taken off, the price to the consumer  might fall from 50s. to 43s. But the lowness of  price would cause increased consumption, and  the influx of consumers would generate competition, which competition would tend to raise the  price (say 5s.) to 48s. The duty being 20.?.  would give the producer 28s.; but it is better that  the consumer should pay 48s. than 50s., and  better that the producer should get 28s. than 23s.  A great increase of quantity from the ceded colonies, and the inability to extend cultivation in  the old ones, might perhaps somewhat alter the  complexion of the case; and when we were told  in 1825, that the admission of the French sugars  of the Mauritius need not alarm the WestTndian  proprietor, for that the amount would only be ten  or twelve thousand hogsheads, we little expected  that in 1828 the return would be double that  number. We were also told that the exclusion of  rum from Ireland mattered not, because the native  i  I 	asc99990010120053001									8	600	51962844 Bytes	3452	5016	1166719107	RGB	asc99990010120053001.tif		2013-07-24	2013-07-24	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/4820	4820	4821.jp2	/scbooks/image/4821.jp2
Page 54																																asc9999001012		52  spirit would always command the market, and if that  was to be the consequence, there would surely be  no reason for not admitting it.  That all the  colonies will ultimately abolish  the flogging of females, from a sense of its indelicacy ; that they will admit slave evidence,  because no possible evil can result from it when the  judges  and juries are not slaves; that they will  promote religion,   not only because it prevents  crime, but because it is their duty as Christians ;  and that they will attend to the coloured population, because it will increase their own security,—  I have not the smallest doubt.    But whether they  do or do not, it is neither a proof of our wisdom  nor of our good faith to resort to those violent measures, which, with the exception of the mere subject of dispute, would be pari passu the same that  animated the zeal of our patriots here before the  American war.    But the one body is weak, and  the other was powerful.   The end may be thought  to sanctify the means, and the friend to civil liberty  may   see   no   reason  to   keep   faith   where  the  object by breaking it is deemed to be desirable.  The increase of the coloured population is a circumstance of peculiar interest.    We have seen  that where a black revolution has taken  place,  they, the mulattoes, became the leading people.  We see that they still continue to be so, and that 	asc99990010120054001									8	600	55606512 Bytes	3639	5092	1096984453	RGB	asc99990010120054001.tif		2013-07-24	2013-07-24	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/4821	4821	4822.jp2	/scbooks/image/4822.jp2
Page 55																																asc9999001012		53  they entertain the same jealousy towards the  blacks, that we do towards them. Is it not then  the height of impolicy to force them into a connection to which they are universally disinclined,  and which will, one day or other, become a serious evil, rather than by placing them gradually  on a footing with ourselves, to create a defensive  alliance which may prove a security to us in our  hour of need ? I cannot but think that the encouragement of a white population, which, if industrious, would produce the various minor articles,  and the assisting it by lessening the restriction on  trade, would be ultimately most beneficial. How  far mechanical force might be used to supply the  place of manual labour, and the cane cultivation  be kept up, is matter for inquiry. If any such  means should be discovered, it would be the  greatest blessing to the islands to be freed from  the incubus of their black population. Something  might be done. At present we are distinctly  verging towards that euthanasia of West Indian  Empire, a Mulatto Government.  s1  CHARLES WOOD AND SON, PRINTERS,  Poppin's Court, Fleet Street. 	asc99990010120055001									8	600	49592412 Bytes	3284	5032	148667719	RGB	asc99990010120055001.tif		2013-07-24	2013-07-24	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/4822	4822	4823.jp2	/scbooks/image/4823.jp2

Page 3																																asc9999001015		GENERAL   MEETING.  18th May,  1833.  " Unanimously Resolved,  " That Mr. Barrett and Mr. Burge be requested to permit the Speeches this day  made by them to be printed." 	asc99990010150003001									8	600	58430208 Bytes	3571	5452	54995523	RGB	asc99990010150003001.tif		2013-07-24	2013-07-24	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/4827	4827	4828.jp2	/scbooks/image/4828.jp2
Page 4																																asc9999001015		MR. BARRETT'S SPEECH,  AT   A   GENERAL   MEETING   OF   THE   WEST-INDIA   BODY.  My Lord Combermere,  I have to move, for the adoption of the meeting,  if it shall think fit, a Petition to the House of  Lords. We have already assented to address the  King, to whom we look up as our last hope and  refuge, should the two Houses of Parliament be  deaf to our remonstrances. These measures are  a part of those which it has become necessary to  resort to, in defence of our dearest interests,—  threatened with immediate and total ruin by His  Majesty's Ministers. The indignation of the House  and of the country has been invoked upon our  heads by the Principal Secretary of State for the  Colonies. As the official organ of Government, he  has denounced us to the world, as holding our fellow beings in hopeless slavery; as inflicting upon  them great cruelties; and as stubbornly refusing  to listen to the voice of the people of England,  which has long and loudly demanded the melioration of their condition.  I was under the gallery of the House of Commons when Mr. Stanley made the speech which  i 	asc99990010150004001									8	600	58833304 Bytes	3596	5452	2342427891	RGB	asc99990010150004001.tif		2013-07-24	2013-07-24	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/4828	4828	4829.jp2	/scbooks/image/4829.jp2
Page 5																																asc9999001015		introduced his resolutions for Emancipation. I  had in other times been a witness of the debates,  and I had heard Ministers of the Crown bring forward measures affecting the interests of particular  bodies; but I must declare, from all that I had  ♦seen, and much more that I had read, I never  could have imagined that an official organ of the  Government would have allowed himself such latitude of vituperation and high colouring as was  indulged in by the Right Honourable Secretary.  It was the address of the Public Prosecutor against  the Prisoner at the bar, instead of the well-balanced Charge of the Judge, weighing carefully  the evidence on both sides, and endeavouring  to allay and not excite the feeelings. From  the beginning to the close of Mr. Stanley's  speech, he proceeded from one topic of reproach  to another; holding up the Colonists to universal  odium, declaiming against their contumacy, their  insolence, and their barbarities. Nor was he content with general assertions :—fortunately for us,  fortunately for truth, the Right Honourable Secretary endeavoured to support his accusations by  a reference to facts. He laboured, with all his  eloquence and ingenuity, to make his audience  believe that the Colonial Legislatures had proudly  and scornfully rejected the advice of Parliament  to mitigate the condition of their Slaves ; that  they had disdainfully contemned the admonitions  and warnings of the King's Ministers; and had  met the general cry of the British people for  Emancipation with  contempt  and  defiance.    If 	asc99990010150005001									8	600	57914068 Bytes	3545	5444	911042349	RGB	asc99990010150005001.tif		2013-07-24	2013-07-24	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/4829	4829	4830.jp2	/scbooks/image/4830.jp2
Page 6																																asc9999001015		the Local Legislatures have stood still while all  around them were in motion, they may deserve  some punishment for their obstinacy and their  folly; but the fact is not so: and if the meeting  will honour me with a small portion of their time,  I will show how cruelly those bodies have been  maligned in the speech of the Right Honourable  Secretary. In the observations I am about to  make, I may be compelled to meet the violence of  his language by expressions less measured than I  would wish to use when speaking of a gentleman  of Mr. Stanley's station and character. I will not  say that he has wilfully misrepresented us. It is  evident that he entered the Colonial Office ignorant of our institutions, and ignorant he has remained. His prompters have taken advantage of  his ignorance, and have put into his mouth the  grossest mis-statements. But while I can find  some apology for his want of knowledge, I can  find none for his want of candour and fairness.  As if the act of spoliation he contemplated was  not sufficiently dreadful, at the instant that he  proposed his project to plunder us of our property,  he consigned our name to everlasting infamy.  Hundreds of thousands of petitioners, and the  multitude of electioneering pledges, had not done  enough to prejudicate our cause; but the Right  Honourable Secretary must crown our injuries,  by borrowing the errors, the prejudices, and the  abuse of the petitioners, and adding to their effect  the powerful weight of his eloquence and autho- 	asc99990010150006001									8	600	59476528 Bytes	3640	5445	2901775167	RGB	asc99990010150006001.tif		2013-07-24	2013-07-24	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/4830	4830	4831.jp2	/scbooks/image/4831.jp2
Page 7																																asc9999001015		rity. It had been more humane and just, more  courageous and statesmanlike, to have thrown his  official mantle round the Colonists: but the Secretary thought otherwise.  If Slavery is an offence which ought to be discontinued, it is an offence common to the nation.  The army which conquered Jamaica, which first  garrisoned and then settled that island, carried  with them no slaves: they were planters before  they became slave-owners. Slaves were sent to  them in English ships ; torn from Africa by English  dealers and spoilers. English laws promoted the  traffic, and English capital maintained it. So  greedy, in those days, was this country of the  trade in Man, that shortly after the Restoration, a  grant of land in the colony (of Jamaica) could only  be obtained on condition of cultivating it by Negro  Slaves. The soldier carried to Jamaica nothing  but his arms; when he became a planter, he had  no resource but his own strength and industry.  He did not go in search of the Negro to Africa;  the Negro was brought to him : and the King of  England, by and with the advice of his Council,  compelled him to purchase, if he desired to escape  from the condition of a daily labourer, and aspired  to be an owner of land and a freeholder. Thus  the planter became a slave-proprietor not by the  choice of his will, but by the force of law. It is  not fair,—it is not honest,—it is unjust and cruel  for the people of England to reproach the planter  with the unavoidable consequences of their own 	asc99990010150007001									8	600	62608976 Bytes	3790	5505	1390598433	RGB	asc99990010150007001.tif		2013-07-24	2013-07-24	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/4831	4831	4832.jp2	/scbooks/image/4832.jp2
Page 8																																asc9999001015		act, and to load him with obloquy at the moment  that they are about to make him the victim of  their guilt.  The Colonial Secretary admitted the vastness  of the interests which are involved in this question : he admits, that on its successful settlement  depend the lives and fortunes of a large proportion of our fellow-subjects, and the welfare, both  spiritual and temporal, of 800,000 slaves. By a  hasty, an imperfect, or ill-considered measure, the  numerous body of persons dependent on the Colonies, who reside in England, may be ruined; the  free inhabitants of the Colonies may be massacred,  or be engaged in civil war with the newly-emancipated slaves; and those slaves themselves, that  we design to civilise and to make happy, may be  driven back to the barbarism, the vices, and the  sufferings of savage life. None of these events  can happen without inflicting on England a heavy  loss in wealth, in commerce, in reputation, and in  substantial power. The Right Honourable Gentleman is not only aware of the hazard that hangs  upon this " mighty experiment," as he terms it,  but he perceives " the influence that its successful or unsuccessful issue must have on millions of  foreign subjects." Vast and terrific is the responsibility assumed by the Right Honourable Gentleman. Uncontrollable and unavoidable ought to  be the circumstances which compel him to play  for so deep a stake ; and most cautious and  guarded, and almost unimpeachable, should  be 	asc99990010150008001									8	600	60592528 Bytes	3688	5475	499437089	RGB	asc99990010150008001.tif		2013-07-24	2013-07-24	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/4832	4832	4833.jp2	/scbooks/image/4833.jp2
Page 9																																asc9999001015		6  the plan, which is to pass through so many perils;  a plan which is meant to confer a great boon, but  may inflict boundless and intolerable wrong.  The overwhelming necessity which, in the opinion of the Right Honourable Secretary, demands  the incurring of these dangers, is, to use his own  words, " the universal expression of feeling which  pervades the country, that Slavery should be abolished." The Right Honourable Gentleman adds:  " There never was a time when the determination  of the people was more absolutely or more irresistibly expressed, because it was founded on that  deep religious feeling, on that solemn conviction  of principle, which admitted of no palliation or  compromise, and which pronounced itself in a  voice to which no minister could be deaf." *  The petitions and desires of the people are not  to be lightly regarded, nor are they to be granted  without inquiry. It is the duty of Parliament to  resort to those sources of knowledge which are  closed to the general access, and to weigh those  results which the people overlook, and especially  when, as the Right Honourable Gentleman has  declared, the fate of millions of foreigners may be  influenced, and consequently our external relations implicated by our experiments. The petitions of the people, however universal, are not the  irresistible plea for legislating in this matter, which  warrants the Government in exposing ourselves  * The quotations from Mr. Stanley's speech are taken from  the Times newspaper.  * 	asc99990010150009001									8	600	61913728 Bytes	3765	5480	1485376	RGB	asc99990010150009001.tif		2013-07-24	2013-07-24	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/4833	4833	4834.jp2	/scbooks/image/4834.jp2
Page 10																																asc9999001015		&lt;-..:; -3  and foreign nations to the misfortunes which the  Right Honourable Gentleman describes as sure to  follow unsuccessful legislation. I know not if the  remark of Mr. Stanley was directed to any particular foreign state; but this I know, that the Cabinet of Washington is watching the progress of  events in Jamaica; its emissaries are in the island.  The late disputes between North Carolina and the  General Government would not so peacefully have  been arranged, but for the jealousy and apprehensions with which the slave-holding states regard  the Emancipation mania of this country.  On this subject I will read to the meeting an  extract from a pamphlet written by an eminent  American. It is entitled, " The Address of the  Washington Society to the People of South Carolina," and is printed at Charleston.  " It has been truly said that South Carolina could  not dispense with a standing army to defend her  from a danger at once so imminent and appalling,  that it becomes us no longer to shrink from its examination . The British West Indies are about to become  an Archipelago of free blacks. That nation, which  is to be the ally of South Carolina, is strenuously  engaged in emancipating the Slaves in her Colonies ; and the moment we place ourselves under  her protection, as we will and must do, if we secede from the Union, the philanthropic projects of  that people will be extended to us ; and we shall  find it no easy matter, with the aid of the small  army which we can afford to pay, to preserve our 	asc99990010150010001									8	600	59265392 Bytes	3598	5489	3825478261	RGB	asc99990010150010001.tif		2013-07-24	2013-07-24	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/4834	4834	4835.jp2	/scbooks/image/4835.jp2
Page 11																																asc9999001015		property and maintain domestic tranquillity. Look  at what is going on in England, where pledges are  exacted from the candidates for Parliament, to  make a commencement in the great work of  Emancipation. Look at what is passing near us in  the British West-India Colonies, where servile war and  desolation have been let loose upon those once peace-  ful and flourishing islands."  I pretend not to judge of foreign politics : it  may be our British policy that the United States  should develope her vast resources, and reign the  dominant power in the New World. Let this delirium of philanthropy continue to rule our councils, and the dominion of the United States will  have no other limit than their own moderation ; a  virtue, by the bye, of which their short republican  history affords not a solitary example.  The Right Honourable Gentleman has attempted  to prove the guilt and folly of the colonist in resisting Emancipation, by citing passages from the  debates of the House of Commons. These speeches  were delivered near thirty years ago, on the abolition of the Slave Trade. It is not very clear that  the speeches of parliamentary orators are the best  guides either in morals or in politics. Authoritative axioms are laid down to serve some immediate  purpose; and if, in the recorded speeches of the  same member, contradictions and inconsistencies  are not to be found, which indeed seldom happens, contradictions at least are sure to be found  in the speeches of the opposite party.    The Right 	asc99990010150011001									8	600	61552288 Bytes	3765	5448	2247248977	RGB	asc99990010150011001.tif		2013-07-24	2013-07-24	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/4835	4835	4836.jp2	/scbooks/image/4836.jp2
Page 12																																asc9999001015		9  Honourable Gentleman has not been very fortunate  in his search for great names to back his argument,  even in the immense mass which comprises the  debates of the House, where every subject has  been discussed, and in every possible way. Mr.  Wyndham said—" He wished for nothing more at  present than the abolition of the Slave Trade; but  he did not hesitate to say that when the proper  period arrived, and the consent of other powers could  be obtained for its abolition, Slavery itself ought not  to be suffered to exist amongst the institutions of  any civilised state." Mr. Wyndham's evidence is  worth nothing to Mr. Secretary Stanley; for not  only is the consent of foreign powers not obtained  for the abolition of Slavery, but the Slave Trade  itself is pursued to as great an extent, and with  more cruelty than ever. The last treaty for the  extinction of this horrible commerce was very  lately signed ; but the trade is the more inhuman  and exterminating, because it is without the regulations of lawful commerce. France has reluctantly assented to another treaty to perfect her  former stipulations; but neither treaties nor fleets  will guard the coasts of Cuba and the Brazils from  fresh importations of African Slaves. Out of one  hundred and six ships which left the Havannah  in 1832, ninety-seven returned in safety, richly  freighted with cargoes of that unfortunate race.  The period which Mr. Wyndham hoped for is still  distant. The horrors of the Slave Trade have not  abated.    Slavery yet prevails in every European 	asc99990010150012001									8	600	59853448 Bytes	3645	5472	1308300850	RGB	asc99990010150012001.tif		2013-07-24	2013-07-24	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/4836	4836	4837.jp2	/scbooks/image/4837.jp2
Page 13																																asc9999001015		:'  10  colony, and no European power is prepared to  join with us in its extinction. Another authority  of the Right Honourable Secretary is Lord Gren-  ville: his Lordship said, on bringing forward his  motion for abolition in 1807, " that the first step  from slavery to freedom was effected by the slaves  becoming prsedial or attached to the land, and that  from thence they ascended to liberty." Will the  Right Honourable Secretary say, that the Colonies  have been invited to attach the slaves to the soil ?  or, will he not rather allow that the interests of  the British creditor have not, up to the present  time, permitted that this first step to liberty should  be taken by the Colonies ?  Mr. Secretary Stanley's plan goes far beyond  attaching the Negroes to the soil. They are at  once to enter on the exercise of all the privileges  of Englishmen: they are, even during their apprenticeship, to serve on juries, and in the militia.  Mr. Stanley enlists Mr. Fox in his argument,  and quotes but a single passage from that great  man's speeches:—" The abolition of the Slave  Trade will lead to the abolition of Slavery in the  West Indies." True, Mr. Fox looked to the abolition of Slavery itself, but not by the sacrifice of  national faith and justice. The Right Honourable  Secretary can produce no passage from Mr. Fox's  speeches, which can be interpreted to approve of  such an act of spoliation as that which Parliament  is called upon to sanction. So far is Mr. Fox  from lending the force of his character and opi- 	asc99990010150013001									8	600	60328624 Bytes	3701	5432	1390760808	RGB	asc99990010150013001.tif		2013-07-24	2013-07-24	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/4837	4837	4838.jp2	/scbooks/image/4838.jp2
Page 14																																asc9999001015		1  11  nions to this measure, that in a debate on a motion  of Mr. Francis for regulating Slavery in the Colonies, (I forget the words, it is so long since I read  the passage,) he (Mr. Fox) said it was the duty of  Parliament to advise and admonish the Colonies  to ameliorate the condition of their slaves; but if  the Colonies regarded not the admonition, the only  course left to Parliament was to leave them to the  evil of their ways. On another occasion this  statesman exclaimed, that to legislate for the Colonies was " monstrous in conception and impracticable in execution."  It will be seen by the quotations from these  speeches of Lord Grenville, Mr. Wyndham, and  Mr. Fox, that those statesmen had but an uncertain and distant glimpse of Negro freedom; nor  can the Right Honourable Secretary adduce other  Parliamentary evidence to support his view of the  subject, till the year 1823. In that year, for the  first time, and not before, as the Right Honourable Secretary would intimate, did the nation declare by the voice of Parliament, that Slavery  should cease in the British Colonies. Exactly  ten years since, and not eleven, as the Right  Honourable Secretary had said, were the Colonists  warned that the principle of abolition was recognised by Parliament. But the Colonial Secretary, in referring to Mr. Canning's memorable  Resolutions, has omitted to notice the reservation  of the rights of property. His right of property  in his Slaves being reserved, in these Resolutions, 	asc99990010150014001									8	600	59151808 Bytes	3597	5480	2351330661	RGB	asc99990010150014001.tif		2013-07-24	2013-07-24	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/4838	4838	4839.jp2	/scbooks/image/4839.jp2

The Right Honourable Secretary, having  mustered these authorities, breaks out into a strain  of angry declamation against the Colonial Legislatures : in a voice of passionate reproach he exclaims-—" Those Resolutions declared that Parliament looked confidently forward, through the Local  Legislatures adopting efficient measures of legislation, to the final termination of the system of Colonial Slavery, too long in existence. They had  more than eleven years' experience of the effect  upon the Colonial Legislatures of that emphatic  expression of the wishes and voice of Parliament  and the Mother Country, conveyed in the tone  of friendly admonition, and strengthened by the  voice of authority,—and what was the result?  The Colonial Legislatures were deaf to the voice  of friendly expostulation: they seemed to set  at defiance the voice of authority." True,  Parliament looked with confidence to the Local  Legislatures for the extinction of Slavery, but not  at the sole risk and loss of the Colonists. The  Right Honourable Secretary, in dwelling on the  expectations of Parliament from the Colonial Assemblies, abstains, no doubt undesignedly, now,  and on all other occasions, from quoting that most  vital part of the resolutions, which reserves the  rights of property. Had the Right Honourable Secretary reflected on the duties which the  Local Legislatures had to perform, together with  the true intent and meaning of the resolutions of  1823,—which resolutions have never been revoked  or remodelled, he would have expressed himself  with less of violence and bitterness against those  bodies. The reservation of the rights of property  was renewed by the Lords in 1826, and by the  Commons in 1832. Unless it can be shown that  Parliament has taken proper measures to protect  the Colonies from the ruin of their fortunes, the  Colonial Legislatures are rather to be commended  for their calm and resolute resistance to the wild  innovations of the Colonial Office, than denounced  for contumacy and insolence.  The Right Honourable Secretary, in his philippic against the Local Assemblies, resorts to a  letter of Mr. Burke addressed to Mr. Dundas in  1792; and the value of the quotation consists in  the opinion of Mr. Burke, that the " Laws of the  Colonies are nothing worth, for they do not carry  with them the executory principle." This citation  serves as a preamble to the remarkable assertion  that " the Colonies have done little to mitigate the  evils of Slavery, and that the little they have done  wants   the   executory  principle." Were the Colonial Assemblies  capable of passing laws to blind and mislead the  people of England, they would deserve the odium  which the Right Honourable Secretary has cast  upon them. But the fault of these bodies seems  to have been, in the eyes of the Right Honourable  Secretary's predecessors in office, and in his own,  that they have refused even a pretended and outward submission to their authority, but have man-  &lt; fully and openly fought the battle of their con  stituents, keeping clear of dishonest evasion, and  avoiding also undistinguishing opposition to the  views of Government. There is a paragraph in  the speech of the Right Honourable Secretary not  applicable to men who affect a hollow and insincere compliance with the behests of superior  power. His words are—" The Colonial Legislatures are deaf to the voice of friendly expostulation ; they seem to set at defiance the voice of  authority."
