Wm, Parke, Gustos of the Parish of St. Ann, his family,  and a number of the resident gentry of the  county, to a very large body of the Apprentices^ and others of the coloured population*  on laying the first Stone of the new Church,  St. Paul's, Annandale, the 7th April, 183S.  There was something^ peculiarly interesting  on the occasion to every well-wisher of this  Colony. The Church, which will be one of the  largest in the Island, will be built principally  by the labor of the negro and other coloured  classes, voluntarily bestowed*  The Honorable Robert Johnston, formerly a  a Member of Council in this Island, had been an  absentee for many years, but lately returned to'  take possession of Annandale, and some other  Estates, in St.- Ann's, which descended to him 	asc99990010030002001											56717638 Bytes	3544	5333	4175268124	RGB	asc99990010030002001.tif		2013-07-30	2013-07-30	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5124	5124	5125.jp2	/scbooks/image/5125.jp2
Page 3																																asc9999001003		on the recent demise of his brother.    He found  a large tract of country, and an accumulating  population, without any Church or other adequate means of moral and religious instruction;  and it became a principal object with him, during a short stay among us, to afford these ines-*  timable benefits to his immediate tenantry and  neighbours.    He gave up a sufficient portion  of ground (three acres) from his estate, which  he vested by deed in the diocesan, in perpetuity.     He  consented to  furnish  the entire  building materials, and to aid the work by pecuniary assistance.     His intention and plans  being made known to the Bishop, met with his  entire approbation; and his Lordship promised,  with ready  alacrity,   to assist the  undertaking from funds placed  at  his disposal.    Mr.  Johnston's next application was to the House  of Assembly, and he was equally successful, a sum  of £300 being liberally granted ; nor were the  Parochial Authorities of St. Ann's to be out-  clone in forwarding so laudable a design ; they  voted in aid a sum of £500, the entire grant of 	asc99990010030003001											55663226 Bytes	3525	5262	2065951612	RGB	asc99990010030003001.tif		2013-07-30	2013-07-30	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5125	5125	5126.jp2	/scbooks/image/5126.jp2
Page 4																																asc9999001003		s  the Assembly to the Parish, and, in the most  gratifying manner, accompanied their grant by  a unanimous vote of thanks to Mr. Johnston,  for his zeal in so good a cause.  With this cooperation, and with the means thus  liberally afforded, the work was commenced,—  all would, ho we ver, have been wholly insufficient  but for the personal exertions of the spirited and  intelligent proprietor. The ground and materials were found, but the labour was wanting.—  He called together the apprentices on his estates, and, reasoning mildly with them on the advantages that would result to themselves, in a  religious and moral poir\t of view* from the contemplated establishment, he succeeded in coira-  pletely enlisting their feelings in the good  cause. The better provided, furnished small  sums in aid; while others agreed to give their  labour gratuitously in their own time. In the  coufse of a very short period no less than 1200  days were subscribed I and most cheerfully in  the result, was this labour bestowed.  The work was begun on Saturday the 10th of  March; and so earnest and sincere were the ef- 	asc99990010030004001											57623542 Bytes	3535	5432	1857581310	RGB	asc99990010030004001.tif		2013-07-30	2013-07-30	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5126	5126	5127.jp2	/scbooks/image/5127.jp2
Page 5																																asc9999001003		6  forts the apprentices made, that in one day 46  people cleared about four acres of virgin, unopened woodland. Their numbers during each  week since have gradually but considerably increased; and on the day on which the Rev.  Henry Browne delivered the following plain  but admirably adapted discourse, from 800  to 1000 of the population pressed forward to  hear the word of the living God, and to see laid  the Foundation Stone of a temple devoted to  His service—the superstructure of which they  felt an honest pride in knowing, was to be the  result of their own gratuitous efforts.  The result of that day's labor was full of  interesting promise; nor was the promise unper*  formed. The news of the proceedings spread  in every direction through the neighbourhood,  and from a circuit of 8 and 10 miles were to be  seen flocking, on the following Saturdays, volunteers, ready and eager for the appointed  work; nor was theirs the tardy and painful toil  of forced, and compulsory servitude;—all were  zealous in the cause"—-active, laughing, joking,  ajid endeavouring to outvie e^ch other in their 	asc99990010030005001											54796206 Bytes	3455	5285	3956106513	RGB	asc99990010030005001.tif		2013-07-30	2013-07-30	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5127	5127	5128.jp2	/scbooks/image/5128.jp2
Page 6																																asc9999001003		individual efforts. Children of tiny growth, and  the old in their decrepitude, joined the strong  and the healthy. One common feeling seemed  to pervade them all, and great indeed was the  moral lesson recorded. May it be read with  the interest it deserves, not in this country  alone, but in the Parent State, and throughout  the civilised world. It will teach the Proprietors of Jamaica's soil, that the aptitude for labor  in the apprentice, where properly directed, may  be fairly relied on—it will teach the misinformed  of the mother-country, that their exertions for the  amelioration of the slave have not been attended  with the uncertain results they have been led to  believe,    It will shew the civilized world that  " The poor Indian who%e untutored mind  Saw God in clouds, or heard him in the wind,"  has so far improved in his social condition, as  to press forward in hearty demonstration of  his acknowledgment of the revealed word.  Towards the end of the present discourse are  some extracts from an Address of the Bishop of  this diocese. They refer in language pathetically impressive and beautiful to the necessity of building churches of adequate size and  appropriate  ornament.     This  has not been 	asc99990010030006001											53826238 Bytes	3444	5208	2206035810	RGB	asc99990010030006001.tif		2013-07-30	2013-07-30	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5128	5128	5129.jp2	/scbooks/image/5129.jp2
Page 7																																asc9999001003		overlooked or neglected by Mr. Johnston, and  the proportions and characteristics of the new  church with reference both to its external and  internal arrangements, are calculated to afford  ample space for the large community at present left without any opportunity of public  worship, and not unfitting the sacred purposes  to which it is to be dedicated.  Jamaica owes her thanks to Mr. Johnston, for  the spirited manner in which he has conducted  this undertaking;. Happy indeed would it be for  this land, in her impending trials and difficulties,  if the owners of extensive properties would imitate the example of the proprietor of Annandale* by furnishing a benighted population with  the means of improving their social relations, by  that most unfailing and unerring medium—the  diffusion of the truths of Christianity.  " Go little Book from this my solitude—  I cast thee on the waters—go thy ways ;  And if as well I deem, thy vein be good,  The world will find thee after many days."    W. C. M.  * Since the above was written, it is most gratifying, to have to announce, that the example has been followed, and nobly too by the  wealthy owner of Eltham—Benjamin Scott MoncriefF, Esq. This  Gentleman has liberally vested land in the Bishop and his successors  for building a Church at Ocho-Iiios, and has aided the undertaking  by pecuniary assistance. From the funds at his disposal, the Lord  Bish,op of the Diocese has again proffered his ready and substantial  aid, and the principle first called into action by the intelligence of  Mr. Johnston, has been again successfully evoked—the gratuitous  labour of the apprentices, being largely and with the greatest alacrity  subscribed. 	asc99990010030007001											55076458 Bytes	3455	5312	3407437921	RGB	asc99990010030007001.tif		2013-07-30	2013-07-30	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5129	5129	5130.jp2	/scbooks/image/5130.jp2
Page 8																																asc9999001003		■  My Christian Friends,  In the absence of the Rector of the parish,  whose prerogative it would have been to address you, it becomes my pleasing duty to say  a few words on the present most interesting  occasion; an occasion which I may safely say  has been the means of calling forth some of the  best feelings of every class in this community.  For here I see our respected Gustos and his  family ; several gentlemen who occupy important situations, and rank high in the estimation of this community, and of the country at large, together with many respectable  inhabitants of the neighbourhood, all manifesting a deep interest in the novel and patriotic  undertaking of this day, an undertaking which  is calculated to promote the best interests not  only of those who shall hereafter be the more  immediate partakers of the benefits to be derived from it, but of the island at large, from the  encouragement and impulse which it tends to  impart, at this most important period of our island's history, to the efforts which are now in  progress for its improvement and happiness.  When I look around me, and see so many in  this Assembly for whose temporal as well as  spiritual welfare I feel the deepest interest, I  cannot help warmly declaring, that this day is  the happiest I have experienced since I have  come to dwell amongst yon, as your lawfully  ordained minister.  ; ' 	asc99990010030008001											55204046 Bytes	3486	5277	3865749016	RGB	asc99990010030008001.tif		2013-07-30	2013-07-30	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5130	5130	5131.jp2	/scbooks/image/5131.jp2
Page 9																																asc9999001003		10  When we recall the circumstances of thfe  country in days gone by, and compare what it  was, scarcely a church in the land, and still  less a spiritual worshipper, with what it is at  the present hour ; in some measure testified by  the transactions in which we are now occupied,  have we not cause to thank God, and take courage from the evidence we possess, that the  long night of irreligion is passing away, and  that the gospel, with all its benign influences,  and happy results, has dawned upon us : this  is the Lord's doing, and marvellous in our eyes!  May the scenes in which we have been engaged this day, be vividly impressed upon all  our minds ; and may the example of the lady  who has kindly honored us with her countenance and assistance on the present occasion,  be a means of exciting a feeling of lively interest for this good cause, in the minds of all our  fellow-parishioners.  My friends, we are not called together this  day to engage in political discussions which  " gender strife;'' to ascertain, or decide, when  the period of the apprenticeship shall have its  termination—thank God, that question has now  been settled, and set at rest by those who are  appointed by the law of God and man to decide ;  but we  are here  to-day  to devise  a means  whereby all of us, whether rich or poor, white or  black, master or servant, may be delivered from  more  than Egyptian bondage—I  mean the  bondage of sin.    We  have just seen laid the  foundation stone of a temple to be erected in 	asc99990010030009001											57213870 Bytes	3559	5357	3756154181	RGB	asc99990010030009001.tif		2013-07-30	2013-07-30	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5131	5131	5132.jp2	/scbooks/image/5132.jp2
Page 10																																asc9999001003		11  these mountains for the worship and service of  the only true God, wherein the pure word of  truth may be announced ^ which alone is able  to make the sinner wise unto salvation, through  faith which is in Christ Jesus. T&e spot on  which we stand, and on which the Church is  to be erected, is a rock : May this be eiablem^  atical of the preaching which shall evermore be  heard within its sacred walls, and of the spiritual worshippers who shall therein be assembled, proving indeed to be a ekurchbuiliupon  the sure foundation, Christ Jesus, the rock of  ages, against which the gates of hell shall not  prevail.  The Word of God earnestly exhorts utnotto  neglect the duty of " assembling ourselves to*  gether, as the manner of some is ;*' and more  especially the Psalms of David are Ml of expressions indicative of his love for the worship  of his God in the great congregation, aftd so  anxious was he to provide, and appropriate a  fit place for the observance of this duty, that  we find him exclaiming in the words of the  Psalm which has been selected for the service of  to-day, " I will not enter into the tabernacle of  my house, nor climb up into my bed ; I will not  suffer mine eyes to sleep, nor mine eyelids to  slumber, neither the temples of my head to take  any rest, until I find out a place for the temple  of my Lord, &n habitation for the mighty God  of Jacob."    Let us endeavour to follow this  bright example ; let us not be satisfied with an  occasional effort, but let us systematically, and 	asc99990010030010001											54242730 Bytes	3437	5259	4021028568	RGB	asc99990010030010001.tif		2013-07-30	2013-07-30	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5132	5132	5133.jp2	/scbooks/image/5133.jp2
Page 11																																asc9999001003		w  constantly promote whatsoever may tend to enlighten and to raise our fellow-men from " the  gall of bitterness and bond of iniquity."  Constituted as society is here below, it is indispensably necessary that worldly distinctions  should be maintained for its well-being, but  which, alas ! in consequence of our fallen nature  are too apt to engender pride within us. It is  well then, that in the House of Prayer, and when  kneeling at the altar of our Lord and master,  and partaking of the elements of a dying Saviour's love, where the rich and the poor, the  master and servant meet together, we are reminded that in heaven there are no distinctions;  that all, of whatever rank or station here, are  cared for by the great preserver of all, and  shall be eternally provided for hereafter in  everlasting mansions by the same Lord who  putteth no difference between us, but is rich in  mercy unto all that call upon him. My friends  let us bless God for the sabbath, and the pious  occupation of its sacred hours which he has enjoined upon us, and which the advantage of a  House of Prayer enables us to improve, by reminding us all of our dependence upon our  God, and of the obligation which binds us in  obedience to his word and Will, who has declared that " those who honor Him he will honor,  and that those who despise Him shall be lightly  esteemed."  A large portion of our population is immersed in ignorance; it is a duty therefore  manifestly incumbent upon the more enlight- 	asc99990010030011001											38485304 Bytes	3508	5357	497136358	RGB	asc99990010030011001.tif		2013-07-30	2013-07-30	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5133	5133	5134.jp2	/scbooks/image/5134.jp2
Page 12																																asc9999001003		13  ened to provide means for their spiritual in*  st ruction, and the presence to-day of so many  respectable apprentices, the class to which  I now more especially allude, coming forward  so cheerfully to cooperate on the present occasion, affords encouragement for the hope that our  efforts may not be altogether unproductive of  good, but that we shall have the happiness of  beholding them, ere long, crowding with reverence and attachment to Saint Paul's Church, at  Annandale, to offer prayer and praise to the  Gracious Giver of all Good.  And here I cannot forbear to remark how  laudable is the solicitude manifested by Mr.  Johnston, the gentleman with whom has originated this good work, that the sacred edifice to  be erected on this spot should be, as far as possible, worthy of the high and holy purpose to  which it is to be dedicated; and surely it is a  duty incumbent upon Christians in thejconstruc-  tion of their places of worship to use the best of  materials, skill and workmanship unto which  their means can reach ; and I am sure that  many who now hear me, concur in the opinion  that it reflects disgrace upon professing Christians to be more solicitous for the adornment  and beauty of their private dwellings, than for  those buildings in which we bend before the  throne of the Great Eternal. In the more forcible words of our venerable and respected  Bishop, " to allow, from any motives of false  economy, these edifices erected to the Glory of  God, either from deficiency in point of size, or 	asc99990010030012001											55197734 Bytes	3449	5333	1132029922	RGB	asc99990010030012001.tif		2013-07-30	2013-07-30	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5134	5134	5135.jp2	/scbooks/image/5135.jp2
Page 13																																asc9999001003		14  from a want of moderate unpretending exterior  decoration, to degenerate into a coarse baldness  unworthy of ' the habitation of God's seat, and  the place where his honor dwelleth,' is neither  consonant with our feelings of veneration for  things sacred, or with our principles of good  taste, or a sense of propriety/'  ■*■ Let, then, all those distinguished characteristics, those usual accompaniments of our sacred •diflces, which are connected with the  earliest impressions of our childhood, and are  the pleating source of the most delightful asso*  ciations, be duly resp€c£ed by us. The tapering epifc^ bosomed high in tufted trees, which  seem* to lift up our hearts to those purer, and  brighter regions to which it points; the majestic tower, a solid embtora of that sure and steadfast fliith, built on the foundation of the apostles  and prophets, Jesus Christ himself being the  chi#f corner-stone ; th« cross, to remind us all  of our lot, and helpless condition, till he, who  was nailed to it made a full, perfect, and suffix  ciant sacrifice, oblation, and satisfaction for the  sin^pf the whole world. If the feet of him that  bringeth good tidings, that: publisheth peace,  that bftngath good tidings of good, that pub*  lisheth i&Tvation, are declared to be beautiful  upon the mountains : so surely are the sounds  of the sabbath bell soothing and delightful to  our ears, which, on the day that the Lord  hath made and consecrated to himself, penetrate the deep recesses of the fore3t or swell  along the cultivated vale.    They  are precious 	asc99990010030013001											54854722 Bytes	3460	5283	2446299179	RGB	asc99990010030013001.tif		2013-07-30	2013-07-30	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5135	5135	5136.jp2	/scbooks/image/5136.jp2
Page 14																																asc9999001003		15  sounds, for they invite us to devotion, they call  us off from things temporal to things eternal,"  they remind us that life and immortality have  been brought to light through that Gospel  which we preach, and by which the God of  heaven has vouchsafed to lead his erring creatures to glory and to happiness.  When I cast my eye around this majestic  scenery, the lofty forest trees towering over our  heads^ the verdant pastures spreading beneath  our feet ; I think I cannot better conclude this  address than in the beautiful and appropriate  words of the venerable prelate already quoted,  4t amidst all this awful sublimity of nature, these  multiplied and stupendous monuments of the  Divine Artificer, in all their vast and gigantic proportions, in variety endless; matchless in beauty,  in fertility inexhaustible, beyond the power of  the Botanist to number up their tribes—from the  cedar tree that is in Lebanon, even unto the  hyssop that springeth out of the wall, keeping  as it were, a silent and perpetual Sabbath where  mountain mists, a morning sacrifice, ascend as  incense to the Lord of Day ; let it no longer be  our reproach, that of all God's various works,  the only production which pines and withers  here, is Man. But without education, and devoid of ail religious principle, Man is not only  sickly, and stunted, but a noxious production.  He must necessarily remain in his original and  unregenerated state, unles grafted into the  true vine, thereby partaking of its fatness, and 	asc99990010030014001											57335806 Bytes	3552	5379	52415479	RGB	asc99990010030014001.tif		2013-07-30	2013-07-30	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5136	5136	5137.jp2	/scbooks/image/5137.jp2
Page 15																																asc9999001003		16  putting forth new leaves and fruit not naturally  his own. But can we possibly contemplate unmoved these affecting scenes around us ? Shall  the last and noblest of God's creation, made a  little lower than the Angels, and destined for a  glorious immortality, shall he pass heedless on  and with more than the cold indifference of a  Gallio, " care for none of these things?" O,  God forbid! Let it not be found that "professing  Christians" care for none of these things. Let  it not be said of us, as the natural inference to  be drawn from our conduct, that God is not in  all our thoughts. In proportion then as we enjoy the blessing of God upon our labours, as we  prosper in this world's things, let us take care  that we at the same time extend the courts  of the House of our God ; that we lengthen our  cords, and strengthen our stakes, not for our own  credit, but for his glory, for the increase, and  edification of his Church. May God give us  the heart to love his worship ! May God make  us to be glad when it is said unto us, ** Let us  go into the house of the Lord."  On Mr. Browne's conclusion the company  assembled, were addressed by the Hon. Robert  Johnston, the proprietor of Annandale, and the  projector of this laudable undertaking; by the  Hon. the Custos; by Hamilton Brown, Esq.  Member of Assembly for the Parish ; and by  John Woolfrys, Esq. Special Justice for the  district. 	asc99990010030015001											57776734 Bytes	3576	5384	2691358755	RGB	asc99990010030015001.tif		2013-07-30	2013-07-30	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5137	5137	5138.jp2	/scbooks/image/5138.jp2
Page 16																																asc9999001003		17  The discourse of the Rev. H. Browne was  unanimously voted to be published.  On  the   conclusion of the business of this  most gratifying morning, a large proportion of  thecompany retired to partake of the hospitality  of Mr. Johnston, at Annandale House.  The following inscription was placed in a  sealed bottle, and enclosed in the Foundation  Stone :—  St Paul's Church,  Annandale,  In the Parish of Saint Ann,  JAMAICA,  Anno Domini 1838.  Being the first year of the reign of our Most Gracious Sovereign  QUEEN VICTORIA,  And the fourth year of the Emancipation of the Slaves in all her  Colonies, by the magnanimity of the  British Government.  Governor of Jamaica—Sir Lionel Smith, K. C. B.  Bishop—The Honorable  and Right Reverend ChristopherJLips-  comb, D. D.  Chief Justice—Sir Joshua Rowe, Knight.  President of the Council—Honorable William Rowe.  Speaker of the Assembly—Honorable Richard Barrett.  Custos of the Parish—Honorable William Parke.  Members of Assembly for the Parish—Hamilton Brown and Samuel  Boyd Barnett, Esquires ^  This Church was built partly by the voluntary contributions, in  labour and money, of the apprentices of this and the adjoining properties, amounting to upwards of one thousand days, and about two  hundred pounds ; partly by voluntary donations ; partly by a  grant of the Honorable House of Assembly, of three hundred  pounnds ; and partly by a grant from the Lord Bishop from funds  at his disposal for building Churches and Chapels.  The site and materials for the Building were the liberal gift of  the Honorable Robert Johnston, the proprietor of Annandale, the  originator of this laudable undertaking.  The Foundation Stone was laid on Saturday, April 7th, 1838, by  the Lady of the Honorable William Parke, Custos of the Parish.  The Church to be dedicated to the service of Christ, the Redeemer.  The Rev. George Wilson Bridges, Rector.  The Rev. Thomas C Rose, Island Curate.  The Rev. Henry Browne, officiating for the Rector.  The Rev. John Henry Gegg, M. Page 17																																asc9999001003		18  ST. PAUL'S CHURCH, ANNANDALE.  We have much pleasure in giving publicity  to the following Resolutions passed at a meeting of the Vestry at St. Ann's, on the 9th instant, aliko worthy of the liberality of the Vestry, and gratifying to the feelings of Mr. Johnston, and the supporters of the proposed Church  at Annandale.  Ve9try Room, St. Ann's, April 0. 1838.  IN VESTRY.  Resolved, That the sum of five hundred pounds, placed at  the disposal of the Vestry of the Parish of St. Ann, by the Hon.  the House of Assembly, for the erection of Churches and Cha*  pels, be applied in aid of the new church to be erected at Annandale, in the Parish aforesaid.  ResoWed, That the thinks of the Parish i3 due to Robert  Johnston, Ksq. respecting his endeavours to erect a new church  at Annandale. Page 20																																asc9999001003		21  %* It may not be unacceptable to the general reader to state the locality of the Annandale property ; its central position for a  Church and Township, now in successful operation, the fertility of the soil, and the extraordinary salubrity of the climate. Annandale is  situated on the easternside of the parish of St.  Ann, about eight miles north of the Moneague,  and the same distance from St. Ann's Bay,  fronting; the great road leading from Kingston  to Montego-Bay, and about 60 miles from each.  The distance from the sea is from two to six  miles, and its elevation about 2200 feet above  its level: though so highly elevated, the whole  surface forms a pleasing and gently undulated  outline surrounded by an amphitheatre of picturesque mountain scenery, traversed in every  direct ion by excellent carriage roads. The  property of Annandale forms two sides of a  square, extending due east about three miles,  by one in breadth, and northerly about the same  extent, and stretching within two miles of Ocho  Rios Bay. The situation selected for the church  and town, possesses peculiar advantages. It  is the centre of a richly cultivated and populous district. It is also the centre to six Public  Roads, viz.:—  The Road  to the Moneague leading  to Spanish-Town 8 Miles  The Road   by Shooters.hill   to   Saint  Ann's  Bay - - 8 Ditto  The Road by Tydenham to  Brown's  Town -  The Road to Pedro's District  The Road to Ocho Rios Bay 7 Miles  The Road  to St.  Mary's by White  River - - - 8 Ditto  Attached to the Church will be an extensive? 	asc99990010030020001											55364200 Bytes	3440	5363	2655536203	RGB	asc99990010030020001.tif		2013-07-30	2013-07-30	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5142	5142	5143.jp2	/scbooks/image/5143.jp2
Page 21																																asc9999001003		i  space allotted for a Public Manual Labotif  School, upon the plan now in successful operation iu various parts of the United States*  where the scholars are taught to labour and  study two hours alternately from sun-rise to  nun-set.  The climate of this district is more alike to  that of a northern than a tropical one. It is  marked by two distinct seasons of summer and  winter. In the winter months from November  to April, the thermometer averages in the  morning and afternoon about 64° (at this season, March, 59°) so that a blanket is desirable  at night on the bed, and fires very often necessary; during the summer months, the mornings and evenings are still cool, and the thermometer averages at noon about 78°, at which  time the air is light and cooled by strong seu  breezes. Vegetation all the year round is vigorous and luxuriant, so much so that St. Ann's  lias been aptly denominated* the " Garden  of Jamaica."  The Parish of St. Ann, contains the largest  number of apprentices of any parish in the island, viz. 25,182, independent of the great number of free people of colour, European emigrants, and the resident gentry. Within a  circle of 8 miles arouud the Church and pro-  posed town of Annandale* a greater population  will be found than in any similar space in the  island, with the exception of the towns, and  Plaintain Garden River,  FINIS. 	asc99990010030021001											56082022 Bytes	3464	5395	870373294	RGB	asc99990010030021001.tif		2013-07-30	2013-07-30	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5143	5143	5144.jp2	/scbooks/image/5144.jp2

Special Collections	Special Collections Books	ASC9999			asc9999001003						Text	image/tiff	http://catalog.library.miami.edu/record=b4394660~S11													2013-07-30	2013-07-30	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5145	5145	5146.cpd	/scbooks/supp/5145/index.pdf
Page 1																																asc9999001005		TACTS  RESPECTING SLAVERY.  In the United States in 1820, there were 1,528,452  Slaves. Their number is doubled in less than twenty years.  We have now about 2,000,000. In 1840, they will amount  to 3,000,000; in 1860 to 6,000,000; and in 1880 to 12,  000,000.  They are fast concentrating at the extreme South.—In  1800, the number of slaves in Maryland was 107,707 and  in 1820, 107,398. In Georgia in 1800 there were 59,699,  and in 1820, 149,656. In Mississippi in 1800 there were  3,489, and in 1820, 32,841 ; Georgia almost three times as  many, and Mississippi nine times as many in 1820 as in  1800. |  Will not that part'of the country come under the complete control of the blacks 1 They are fast gaming upon  the whites, and unless some powerful means are speedily  taken to prevent it, we shall have a nation of blacks nearer  than St. Domingo.  Slavery is ruining the domestic industry of the southern  country. — Slave labor under no circumstances can be  brought into competition with free labor. Free labor can  be hired in the free States for the interest of the money  vested in Slaves, at the high price, which they have borne  for the cultivation of cotton and sugar, including the cost  of taking care of them. Millions of acres of land in the  slave holding states have been left as irreclaimably barren. 	asc99990010050001001											36279054 Bytes	2841	4254	2494950432	RGB	asc99990010050001001.tif		2013-07-30	2013-07-30	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5146	5146	5147.jp2	/scbooks/image/5147.jp2
Page 2																																asc9999001005		M FACTS RESPECTING SLAVERY.  The most prosperous counties, in every respect, in Maryland and Virginia are those, which have the fewest slaves.  The slave population either checks or drives out the free  white. The white population of Maryland and Virginia, for  thirty years past, increased at the rate of 30 per cent, but  in the United States generally including those states at  more than 150 per cent. In 1790 Maryland and Virginia  had more than one fifth of the whole free population of the  republic, but in 1820 only one ninth. The slave states are  fast losing their comparative power and resources. The  valuation of the houses and lands of New York and Pennsylvania under the United States assessments—the principle of valuation being the same in all—was more than  $600,000,000 ; whereas the aggregate of the houses and  lands and more than 1,000,000 of slaves added thereto of  Maryland, Virginia, North and South Carolina, Georgia,  Tennessee and Kentucky, with a much larger area of land  and more than double the number of inhabitants was less  than $520,000,000, or nearly one sixth less than those two  states."*  Does it not become the southern states, and the nation to  look at these facts, and look at them steadily ? They could  be multiplied an hundred fold, if necessary. The southern  states are fast losing their comparative power and resources.  and is not Slavery the one, the only cause ?  Slavery keeps up a most atrocious domestic trade in the  souls of men.—For a few years past, slave labor in Maryland  and Virginia has been unprofitable. In consequence, slaves  have been raised in great numbers for sale and transportation.  The Baltimore papers have said repeatedly that the trade in  that city was brisk. In the city of Washington slaves are  deposited as a favorable place for sale. During the last session of Congress several hundreds were sold. The jails  were not sufficient to contain them, and literally there were  two or three pens to receive the surplus. In the year 1817,  8000 slaves by actual computation were carried into Georgia  from the north-slave holding states. In seven months of the  year 1825, 1500 slaves were sold at the market of New Or-  Niles' Register. 	asc99990010050002001											36345426 Bytes	2880	4204	3644640062	RGB	asc99990010050002001.tif		2013-07-30	2013-07-30	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5147	5147	5148.jp2	/scbooks/image/5148.jp2
Page 3																																asc9999001005		FACTS RESPECTING SLAVERY. d  leans. In all the states slaves are liable to be sold for debt.  When their master dies they are often put up at auction—  always if his estate is insolvent. In one of the " Georgia  Journals," in 1826, 56 slaves are advertised for sale; m another 63, in a third 142, in a fourth 144.* In the Richmond Inquirer of the 21st of January, 1826, is one advertisement offering for sale 60 negroes — stated to be a  picked parcel, consisting of men, women and children. On  the supposition, that there are 150 newspapers published  weekly in the slave holding states, which is only one fourth  of the number published in the United States, and each  newspaper advertises 60 negroes, then 9000 will be sold  weekly, and allowing three weeks for the length of an advertisement, 126,000 will be sold annually.  These auctions are frequented not so much by planters  as negro drivers. The business is carried on systematically. Markets established ; correspondencies kept up ; chains  and hand-cuffs forged^ and men trained to be very expert in  the examination of human bodies, male and female.  So earnest are they as very often to kidnap a free negro,  and if he cannot show his credentials of freedom, the black  skin is a sufficient crime, and he is lodged in jail; and unless some one appears to rescue him, he is sold into interminable bondage to pay his jail fees. This can be done under  the sanction of the laws of most of the slave states. Well  might Jefferson tremble for his country. Well may an A-  merican blush to open his mouth in boast of his country's  free institutions. All the injustice we ever suffered, or ever expected to suffer from every nation under heaven, would  not amount to what is inflicted in one month on our slaves.  Seize a free man, imprison him unjustly, and then sell him  said and body to pay the expense of your iniquity I an abomination, which would not be tolerated a moment in the most  despotic country in Europe. Be it remembered, that the  laws of the United States sanction it in the District of Columbia, as well as the laws of the individual states. God  will be just and holy if He pours out on us the last unmixed  A paper printed at Milledgeville. 	asc99990010050003001											36895102 Bytes	2863	4293	4019937719	RGB	asc99990010050003001.tif		2013-07-30	2013-07-30	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5148	5148	5149.jp2	/scbooks/image/5149.jp2
Page 4																																asc9999001005		FACTS RESPECTING SLAVERY.  vial of his wrath as He did on Babylon, because she ha5  " traded in the souls of men."  Slavery dooms 2,000,000 of minds to ignorance and debasement.—In the slave code of Virginia, as revised in 1820  and stated by a Virginian to be the law of the state at the  present time, we find the following enactments verbatim.  '" All meetings of slaves, or free negroes, or mulattoes, mixing and associating with such slaves, at any school or schools  for teaching them reading and writing, either in the day or  night, under any pretext whatever, shall be deemed and  considered an unlawful assembly, and the offender or offenders shall be punished, at the discretion of any justice of the  peace not exceeding twenty lashes."—iC If any white person, free negro, mulatto, or Indian, shall at any time be  found in company with slaves at any unlawful meeting, such  person, being thereof convicted by any justice of the peace,  shall forfeit and pay three dollars for every such offence to  the informer, recoverable with costs before such justice, or  on failure of present payment shall receive on his or her  bare back twenty lashes well laid on."  The laws of the southern states prohibit robbery, adultery,  and murder, under severe penalties, and yet consign half the  population to the lowest degradation, a state always prolific  of those sins, and of every othei-. In fact, one law commands  what another forbids and punishes. It is said that these  laws against education are only designed to prevent disorderly meetings of slaves. But why does a planter bring forward as a reason for not instructing his slaves, a prohibitory  law ? why is there such a universal fear that the slaves may  become enlightened 1 but especially, why are so few actually taught to read? It is stated on good authority, that in  one of the counties in Georgia, where slaves enjoy as many  privileges as in any other section of the country, not four  slaves in a thousand can read. Carry this calculation through  the 2,000,000 of slaves, and you have a most frightful proportion, whose minds are blank and waste. The slaves in  the large towns, who are instructed, form but an insignificant share of the whole number. The minds of the immense majority are in ruins.    The whole surface of their 	asc99990010050004001											36972186 Bytes	2893	4257	1475634402	RGB	asc99990010050004001.tif		2013-07-30	2013-07-30	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5149	5149	5150.jp2	/scbooks/image/5150.jp2
Page 5																																asc9999001005		FACTS RESPECTING SLAVERY.  society, in a moral view, is a cheerless desert, like u the  field, which God has cursed,"   " for the book of knowledge fair  Presented with an universal blank,  And wisdom at each entrance quite  Shut out."  What would you say, men of New England, if government  should doom half of your children to hopeless ignorance ?  What would be the state of society ? Would you suffer it a  moment ? No, you reply. But—do to others as you would  be done by yourselves. Your part of the country, your fathers, your ships were the main instruments in introducing  Slavery into this country. Upon you then a portion of the  dreadful guilt rests.  Slavery prevents the establishment of families.—Marriage  is the origin of our most endeared relations. The christian  religion has defined it, and rendered the relation indissoluble. It has thrown around it the sanctions of the divine  law, and fixed upon it the seal of the divine approbation.  Both reason and revelation pronounce it sacred. All history testifies that, as this institution is regarded or neglected,  nations are corrupt ot pure, exalted or debased. The first  step towards the overthrow of all morality and religion in  France, was the infamous declaration, that " women had  been too long under the tyranny of parents and husbands"  Now, among the slaves of our country, marriage is rarely  solemnized. Yet their natural increase, is annually more  than forty thousand. From childhood to youth they are ac*  customed to see each other in a state of nudity. The first  blush of modesty is her last. They indulge the vague in~  tercourse of youth, without reproach. From the age of puberty, their appetite is gratified without restraint. In this  ignominious practice many of the planters lead them on.  The degraded females generally esteem it an honor to be  thus noticed by their masters ; but if they resist, the master  uses his right of property in the slave,^ to force a compliance  with his wishes, to any extent his impatient appetite may  demand. They know no law but inclination—no higher  object of domestic life, than mere animal gratification,  They are husband and wife, not because God has said, " A  man shall leave his father and mother, and cleave to his 	asc99990010050005001											36024330 Bytes	2827	4245	1091439669	RGB	asc99990010050005001.tif		2013-07-30	2013-07-30	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5150	5150	5151.jp2	/scbooks/image/5151.jp2
Page 6																																asc9999001005		FACTS RESPECTING SLAVERY.  wife," but because they happen to be in the same hut. Father and mother ! what can they know of parental authority  or filial obedience ?—Those who have introduced them into  the world, are owned by different masters. They live six,  ten, or twenty miles from each other. If the slave visits his  wife at all, he must get a ticket from his master, or go on  Saturday night, wearied with the labours of the week and  smarting under the lash of the patrol. Slaves have no property in their wires or children. They look upon their offspring as the absolute property of their masters. Separated  from them, they cannot complain, for complaint is vain, and  sorrow equally so ;—but have they no natural affection ? can  they not feel a bitterness of soul 1 Those slaves, who come  together on the same plantation, continue the connexion no  longer than it suits the pleasure or caprice of the parties. If  the wife is unfaithful, the husband leaves her to her favourite ; and he in turn uses the same licentious privilege. If  the husband is false, the wife quarrels with his paramour—  the lash comes in to end the strife. Is there no criminality  in all this ? or can that state of society which takes away  the name of crimes, change their nature and elude the  threatened vengeance of Heaven ?—" Whoremongers and  adulterers God will judge."—Thus marriage is reduced to  the vilest concubinage.—This passion burns up every moral  sentiment. Among the slaves it is inflamed by the most  lascivious songs and wanton gestures, and indulged without  restraint. Those who are cast out as the mere refuse of this  lawless indulgence, open their warehouse of infamy, and  traffic with the devotees of pleasure. Foreigners and young  men from the North, released from the watchful care of parents and friends, descend to the lowest depth of this iniquity. This fact accounts for the mortality among them,  far better than attributing it to the burning climate.  Virtuous and enlightened females of our country, can you  contemplate without emotion this extreme degradation of  your sex ? Here are several hundred thousand females, who  might be the ornament of happy families, who might cluster  around them all the sweet charities of life, and at last go to  a heaven of purity and love. But what is their condition ?  life is a scene of suffering and sin—the grave a black and 	asc99990010050006001											37476334 Bytes	2941	4245	956697029	RGB	asc99990010050006001.tif		2013-07-30	2013-07-30	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5151	5151	5152.jp2	/scbooks/image/5152.jp2
Page 7																																asc9999001005		FACTS RESPECTING SLAVERY.  dismal abode—an anti-chamber to some awful place beyond. Look at this, and let your hearts bleed, and let  your hands do something for their relief. To Christianity  you owe every thing. Extend it then to these poor creatures, who know nothing of its influence.  Slavery ruins the sold.—In comparison with this, all the  preceding considerations are nothing. We could bear to  think of ignorance, of a waste of social feelings, of crouching servility, of a hard life and unlamented death, if we had  any reason to believe, that the undying soul was safe—but  slavery is directly opposed to Christianity. The christian  keeps the sabbath. In the southern cities the morning of  the Sabbath is the market day of the slaves, and in the  country, the Sabbath is a day of sleep, visiting, and crime.  Prayer is the breath of the christian; but can*the slaves  pray, to whom the sabbath is a day of amusement—to whom  the Bible is a sealed book—who see continually the most convincing evidences that they are regarded as destitute of souls.  The command of God is, " thou shalt not steal,"—the planters say that an almost universal vice among their slaves is  pilfering—that nothing is safe, unless secured by an iron  bolt—this is not because the African of all men has a peculiarly thievish disposition, but because he has strong temptations. He has little or no property of his own. If he is  hungry he must steal. He has no character to support in  his own neighbourhood, or if he has he may be sold and  driven to another quarter of the country. For these reasons  he is almost of necessity brought into the class of those who  shall not inherit the kingdom of God. Into heaven there  shall enter nothing that defileth. Into that holy place can  he enter, who has habitually broken the sabbath, who has  been continually guilty of petty theft, who has made himself an instrument of sensual gratification, or who has maintained one of those houses whose steps lead down to hell—  can he mingle with the notes of seraphim, who has passed  his probation in singing the song of obscenity and lust 1  Slavery ruins the soul.—For two hundred years there has^  been a fearful rush of these poor creatures, dark and unholy, into the gates of eternity. Of 2,000,000 now alive the  great majority will find the same tremendous doom ; yet not  till they have given birth to other thronging millions.—But 	asc99990010050007001											34366366 Bytes	2707	4229	1014091818	RGB	asc99990010050007001.tif		2013-07-30	2013-07-30	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5152	5152	5153.jp2	/scbooks/image/5153.jp2
Page 8																																asc9999001005		8  FACTS RESPECTING SLAVERY.  where will the dreadful guilt lie, when Jehovah arises to  judgment? In whose skirts will be found the blood of  these slaughtered souls ? Will it not rest on you, who hold  in one hand the keys of knowledge, and with the other  bind and doom the immortal mind to perpetual ignorance ?  You, who profess to be the disciples of him, who saw the  devoted city and wept over it and said, " If thou hadst  known ?"--you, whose tables are loaded with luxuries, bought  with a price, even the eternal life of undying souls ?—  Judge ye.  05^ It is expected, that the Colonization Society will petition Congress, next winter, to appropriate funds from the  national treasury for the colonization of free blacks and e-  inancipated slaves. It is a debt we owe to Africa. We  owe it as a nation. Will not the northern Representatives  favor the measure ? Will not the people, as a body, support  them in so doing ?  (U^ A proposition will also be made to abolish slavery in  the District of Columbia. A member from Pennsylvania is  pledged to introduce the subject. As long as no measures  are taken to abolish slavery in that District, the whole nation, in the face of the world, are violating the dearest rights  of man, and sanctioning a system of radical injustice. Shall  it be so any longer \ Will not the people of this free country speak in a tone that cannot be misunderstood ? It is  their solemn and immediate duty.    Is ij not ? 	asc99990010050008001											36753318 Bytes	2887	4241	921131202	RGB	asc99990010050008001.tif		2013-07-30	2013-07-30	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5153	5153	5154.jp2	/scbooks/image/5154.jp2

Slavery -- United States; African Americans -- Southern States	Books	[United States : s.n.]		1830-1840					E441 .F33 1830	33849022	8 p. ; 20 cm	eng	mpc					http://merrick.library.miami.edu/digitalprojects/copyright.html	University of Miami Libraries. Special Collections	Special Collections Books	ASC9999			asc9999001005						Text	image/tiff	http://catalog.library.miami.edu/record=b3053931~S11													2013-07-30	2013-07-30	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5154	5154	5155.cpd	/scbooks/supp/5154/index.pdf
Page 1																																asc9999001010		[No. 9.] Read and circulate.  THE BRANDED HAND.  Walker resided in Florida with his family from 1836 until 1841. He  then removed to Massachusetts because he would not bring up his children among the poisonous influences of slavery. While in Florida, the  colored people whom he employed were treated as equals in his family,  much to the chagrin of the slaveholders of that region. In 1844 he returned to Pensacola in his own vessel. When leaving, seven of the slaves  who had in former years been in his employ, and were members of the  church with which he communed, begged to go with him. He consented.  When out fourteen days, a Southern sloop fell in with and seized them.  Prostrated by sickness, he was confined in a dungeon, chained on a damp  floor without table, bed or chair. He was in the pillory for an hour, pelted with rotten eggs, branded S. S.—slave stealer—in the palm of his right  hand, by Ebenezer Dorr, United States Marshal, fined #150, and imprisoned eleven months.  THE BRANDED HAND.  BY JOHN G. WHITTIER.  Welcome home again, brave seaman ! with thy thoughtful brow and gray,  And the old heroic spirit of our earlier, better day—  With that front of calm endurance, on whose steady nerve, in vain  Pressed the iron of the prison, smote the fiery shafts of pain !  Is the tyrant's brand upon thee ?    Did the brutal cravens aim  To make God's truth thy falsehood, His holiest work thy shame?  When, all blood-quenched, from the torture the iron was withdrawn,  How laughed their evil angel the baffled fools to scorn!  They change to wrong, the duty which God hath written out  On the great heart of humanity too legible for doubt!  Theyj the loathsome moral lepers, blotched from foot-sole up to crown,  Give to shame what God hath given unlo honor and renown!  Why, that brand is highest honor!—than its traces never yet  Upon old armorial hatchments was a prouder blazon set;  And thy unborn generations, as they crowd our rocky strand,  Shall fell with pride the story of their father's branded hand! 	asc99990010100001001											57291234 Bytes	3541	5391	1870994277	RGB	asc99990010100001001.tif		2013-07-30	2013-07-30	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5155	5155	5156.jp2	/scbooks/image/5156.jp2
Page 2																																asc9999001010		■■■■■■■■■■■I  34  As the templar, home was welcomed, bearing back from Syrian wars  The scars of Arab lances, and of Paynim scimetars,  The pallor of the prison and the shackle's crimson span,  So we meet thee, so we greet thee, truest friend of God and man!  He suffered for the ransom of the dear Redeemer's grave,  Thou for His living presence in the bound and bleeding slave ;  He for a soil no longer by the feet of angels trod,  Thou for the true Shechinah, the present home of God!  For, while the jurist sitting with the slave-whip o'er him swung,  From the tortured truths of freedom the lie of slavery wrung,  And the solemn priest to Moloch, on each God-deserted shrine,  Broke the bondman's heart for bread, poured the bondman's blood for wine;  While the multitude in blindness to a far off Saviour knelt,  x\nd spurned, the while, the temple where a present Saviour dwelt;  Thou beheld'st Him in the task-field, in the prison shadows dim,  And thy mercy to the bondman, it was mercy unto Him!  In thy lone and long night watches, sky above and wave below,  Thou did'st learn a higher wisdom than the babbling school-men know;  God's stars and silence taught thee as His angels only can,  That, the one, sole sacred thing beneath the cope of heaven is MAN!  That he, who treads profanely on the scrolls of law and creed,  In the depth of God's great goodness may find mercy in his need 5  But wo to him who crushes the SOUL with chain and rod  And herds with lower natures the awful form of God!  Then lift that manly right hand, bold ploughman of the wave !  Its branded palm shall prophecy, "Salvation to the Slave!"  Hold up its fire-wrought language, that whoso reads may feel  His heart swell strong within him, his sinews change to steel.  Hold it up before our sunshine, up against our Northern air—  Ho ! men of Massachusetts, for the love of God look there !  Take it henceforth for your standard—like the Bruce's heart of yore,  In the dark strife closing round ye, let that hand be seen before!  And the tyrants of the slave land shall tremble at that sign,  When it points its finger Southward along the Puritan line:  Wo to the State-gorged leeches, and the church's locust band,  When they look from slavery's ramparts on the coming of that hand!  Jonathan Walker is now free, and will be in Philadelphia at the time of  the Fair. A public meeting will be called which he has consented to address. His history is deeply interesting. It is published in a book of 119  pages, and for sale, price 25 cts. at the Anti-Slavery Office, 31 North Fifth St.  As he is not expected to remain long with us, those who wish to see his  branded hand and to hear the tale of his wrongs and persecutions, ought  to be in the city at the time, ftemember thelSth, 19th and 20M days of  December ! Let them be devoted to the slave whether you come to the  city or not. 	asc99990010100002001											55686318 Bytes	3424	5419	1958836595	RGB	asc99990010100002001.tif		2013-07-30	2013-07-30	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5156	5156	5157.jp2	/scbooks/image/5157.jp2
Page 3																																asc9999001010		35  LINES,  BY JAMES RUSSELL LOWELL,  On reading of the Capture of certain Fugitive Slaves near Washington,  The following spirit-stirring lines were elicited by one of those deeply  interesting, but too soon forgotten, events which must sometimes occur in  a country where one portion of the inhabitants holds another portion in a  state of bondage. A party of about seventy slaves, burning with the love  of liberty, that boast of Americans, made a bold effort to obtain their freedom, by escaping from their masters. Not having been blessed, probably,  with the example of many practical exhibitions of Christianity, nor having  breathed an atmosphere of love and good will to man, and having doubtless, often heard glowing expressions of the sentiment that it is a " glorious  thing to fight for one's liberty," it is not greatly to be wondered at, that  they armed themselves to resist any efforts which might be made to recapture them. As might have been anticipated, their attempt proved a failure*  A few, indeed, escaped, but the greater part were retaken, or murdered in  the contest with their pursuers. It is passing strange that such deeds, done  in the nineteenth century, in a land which calls itself "Christian" and  boasts of being the freest nation on earth, do not awaken the people to a  knowledge of the character of their institutions. The rights of these men  were not cloven down by a mob, in the violation of our laws and constitution, but in accordance with them. Every foot of this broad land, pro-  tectedby our Federal Constitution, is the slaveholder's hunting ground, and  upon it, with that parchment in his hand, for his wrarrant, may he seize and  re-enslave his trembling victim. When will the fires of freedom kindle in  the breasts of this nation ? so that they shall respond with a long and loud  Amen, to the call of our poet, " 0, fling it to the wind!—the parchment  wall that bars us from the least of human kind." Sadly recreant to God  •must a human spirit become, ere it loses sight of the glorious and ennobling  truth, that " Man is more than Constitutions," and that the " traitor to  Humanity is the traitor most accurst." The call to come up to the help of  the slave, against his oppressor, in the might and majesty of moral power,  has gone abroad to this people, and happy are they who have risen up at  the sound, and betaken themselves to the work.  Look on who will in apathy, and stifle, they who can,  The sympathies, the hopes, the words, that make man truly man;  Let those whose hearts are dungeoned up with interest or with ease.  Consent to hear with quiet pulse of loathsome deeds like these:  I first drew in New England's air, and from her hardy breast  Sucked in the tyrant-hating milk that will not let me rest;  And, if my words seem treason to the dullard and the tame,  'Tis but my Bay-State dialect—our fathers spake the same !  Shame on the costly mockery of piling stone on stone  To those who won our liberty, the heroes dead and gone,  While we look coldly on, and see law-shielded ruffians slay  The men who fain would win their own, the heroes of to-day I  Are we pledged to craven silence? 0, fling it to the wind.  The parchment wall that bars us from the least of human-kind—  That makes us cringe, and temporize, and dumbly stand at rest,  While Pity's burning flood of words is red-hot in the breast? 	asc99990010100003001											54537522 Bytes	3377	5381	2406454618	RGB	asc99990010100003001.tif		2013-07-30	2013-07-30	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5157	5157	5158.jp2	/scbooks/image/5158.jp2
Page 4																																asc9999001010		36  Though we break our father's promise, we have nobler duties first;  The traitor to Humanity is the traitor most accurst;  Man is more than Constitutions; better rot beneath the sod,  Than be true to Church and State while we are doubly false to God ?  We owe allegiance to the State, but deeper, truer, more,  To the sympathies that God hath set within our spirits's core,  Our country claims our fealty; we grant it so, but then  Before Man made us citizens, great Nature made us men.  He's true to God who's true to man; wherever wrong is done  To the humblest and the weakest, 'neath the all-beholding Sun,  That wrong is also done to us, and they are slaves most base,  Whose love of Right is for themselves, and not for all their race.  God works for all:   Ye cannot hem the hope of being free  With parallels of latitude, with mountain range or sea.  Put golden padlocks on Truth's lips, be callons as ye will,  From soul to soul, o'er all the world, leaps one electric thrill.  Chain down your slaves with ignorance, ye cannot keep apart,  With all your craft of tyranny, the human heart from heart.  When first the Pilgrims landed on the Bay-State's iron shore,  The word went forth that Slavery should one day be no more.  Out from the land of bondage 'tis decreed our slaves shall go,  And signs to us are offered, as erst to Pharaoh.  If we are blind, their exodus, like Israel's of yore,  Through a Red sea is doomed to be, whose surges are of gore.  ■  'Tis ours to save our brethren, with peace and love to win  Their darkened hearts from error, ere they harden it to sin;  But, if man before his duty with a listless spirit stands,  Ere long the Great Avenger takes the work from out his hands.  *  The Akti-Slavetit Bugle is published every Friday at Salem, Columbiana County, Ohio. AFRICA in general  S there is nothing more furprizing  and delightful in Voyages or Travels,  than beholding the different Habits,  Cufloms, Dieting, and Religion of the different Natives ; fo there is none I believe,  wherein that Difference can be fouftd,fo much  as here. Talaavers are their Courts of Judicature*  where the principal or elderly Men amongft  them meet in a Ring or under a Lodge,  to fettle the Differences that arife amongft  themfelves, or with the Fa&ories ; the frequented are in relation to Trade. Each fa-  lutes the other at meeting, by a Bend of the  Elbow, and raifing his Hand to his Face.  When they have heard what each Party has  to fay, they determine by Vote, who has  the Reafon of the thing on their fide, and  fo punilh, or acquit. For Fornication, the  Party (whether Manor Woman) is fold for  a Slave. If a white Man lies with another's |  Slave, he is bound to redeem her at a current Price. THE incomparable Sir Ifaac Newton  folvesall the Phenomena of the Tides  upon the fole Principle of Gravity, The  Earth, Sun, Moon, and all the celeftial Bodies,  fays he, have a Gravitation towards theii  Centers^ in proportion to the quantitys of  Matter in each of them. Our Earth being  within the Adivity of the Sun and Moon's  Attradions 5 the fluid part of this Globe, the  Ocean, feels it, and neceffarily fwells: and  this, by taking off or abating the force of  Gravity, wherever the Moon is perpendicular  in the Ecliptick; whereby the greater Pref-  furc of Gravity without, carries the Water thitherward, &c. (See the Theory of the  Tides, Philofi Tranfaii.) From thefe light Obfervations, I think it  may be concluded, Firft, that in all Places,  Currents and Tides have a very great affinity.  That it is principally the Formation of the  Lands drives them into the one or the other ;  if contraded between two Shores lb as to  form a Channel, the diurnal Elevation of the  Ocean, by the Attradion of the Moon, will  make there a Tide, rapid in proportion to it's  Breadth, Depth, and Sea it is open to: And  if an open Coaft, as Guinea, thofe Tides become Currents. Tornadoes, by the Spaniard called Trava-  does, are in no part of the World fo frequent  as at Guinea. They are fierce and violent  Gufts of Wind that give warning for fome  hours by a gradual lowering and blackening  of the Sky to Windward whence they come,  accompanied with Darknefs, terrible Shocks  of Thunder and Lightning, and end in Rains  and Calm. They are always off ftjore, between the N. and N. E. here, and more Easterly at the Bites of Benin, Calabar, and  Cape Lopez, -, but although they are attended  with this favourable Property of blowing  from the fhore, and laft only three or four  hours, yet Ships immediately at the appearance of them furl all their Sails and drive before the Wind,  We have fometimes met with thefe Tornadoes two in a day, often one 5 and to (hew  within what a narrow Compafs their effefts  are, Ships have felt one, when others at ten  Leagues diftance have known nothing: Nay,  at Anamaboo (3 or 4 Leagues off) they have  had ferene Weather while we have fuffered  under a Tornado in Cape Corfo Road. By difcourfing on this particular Branch, I  do not pretend to a Sufficiency of giving  full Directions ; the Natives Alteration and  Diverfity of Tafte are Obftacles with the moft  experienced : It's only within my Defign to  give a general Infight to fuch as are Strangers,  .and a Rule to improve upon by fuch as are  not. The Tortuguefe were the firft  Europeans that fettled and built Forts here,  tho' now the leaft concerned, paying their  Tribute to the "Dutch for Leave: What remains of theirs is to the Southward on the  River Congo at Loangode St.Taul, and the  Iflands, where they keep Priefts to teach their  Language to the Natives, and baptize without making Chriftians.  1. Page 166																																asc9999001002		Brafil, and the Weft-Indies. 151  Cuftom to fignify at the fight of any Ship^linea  by a Smoke, and is always looked on as an  Invitation to Trade 5 but as each is alterable  among them from the Chance of War, the  Omiffion fhews they decline it, or are out of  Stock.  This Change of Circumftance found on  differentVoyages,proceeds from weak and bad  Governments among themfelvcs, every Town  having their own Cabiceers or ruling Men,  (or it may be three or four in Confederacy)  all fo jealous of the others Tanyarring,  that  they never care to walk even a mile or two  from home without Fire-Arms; each knows it  is their Villanies and Robberies upon one a-  nother that enables them to carry on a Slave-  trade with Europeans 3 and as Strength fluctuates, it is not unfrequent for him who fells  you Slaves to-day, to be a few days hence  fold himfelf at fome neighbouring Town i  this I have known.  The fame way of reafoning anfwers for the  Tanyarrs and Murders fo frequently between  them and us, and never that I heard with the  French or Tortuguefe. I now proceed to our Method of Trade,  and fhall futn the Rules of it up, under the  • head of Interlopers. Private trading Ships  bring two or three Boats with them upon  this Coaft for Difpatch, and while the Mates  go away in them with a proper Parcel of  Goods, and Inftrudions into the Rivers and  By-places, the Ship is making good her  Trade at others near hand.  The Succcfs of a Voyage depends ftrft, on  the well forting, and on the well timing of  a Cargo. Secondly, in a Knowledge of the  places of Trade, what, and how much may  be expeded every where. Thirdly', in dramming well with Englijh Spirits, and conforming to the Humours of the Negroes.  Fourthly, in timely furnifhing proper Food  for the Slaves. Fifthly, in Difpatch; and  Laftly, the good Order and Management of  Slaves when on board 5 of each, a Word or  two. IVORY is a Commodity fold all the  Coaft over, but, like the Slaves? more in  fome parts than others, and fupplicd thence  to all the Weftern World. It is in Teeth or  Screvelios. The Bay is well ftored with  Fifh, and the Country affords Plantains, Goats,  Fowls,and particularly grey Parrots, all cheap 3  but their principal trading Commodities are  Wax in Cakes, and Honey, exchanged with  us on eafy terms, for Linnen, Calicos, Stuffs,  Pewter Spoons, Knives, &c, and it is the  Seal of all Bargains, to take hold of one a-  nother's Hands and fay, Palaaverfuquebah. The Natives are harmlefs and inoffenfive,  never fell one another. Their familiar Salute at meeting, is by  clapping their hands two or three times, to  one another. To a Superior, (the Cabiceer^  or the Aged) they bend the Knee, railing firft:  their Hands to the out-parts of their Shoulders  or Arms, then patting the other's Hands gently  three times, they cry Chamba at each time,  and retreat with three times clapping their  own hands: toprofefs an extraordinary  Friendfhip to you,they raife your Hand as high  as they can reach.  Many of them have borrowed Names  from the Europeans that put in here, and are  pleafed when you will adopt them to wear  fuch a Cognizance of your Remembrance;  they do not follicit this Favour till after feveral views, that they feefomething to be ad^  mired, or that the Perlon asked, has a fancied  Sympathy of Temper, or likenefs-with thenv  felvcs. A Vo y a g e to Guinea,  They have all good Arms, and knowing  the Spanifh Clemency, defend themfelves  defperately, if attacked $ which has happened  feldomer than at Campechy, and always by  Sea*  A Servant, which is the firft Step with Seamen into the Trade, is hired at a Tun of Logwood per Month, and has one Day in feven  for himfelf, making together about 10/. a  Month to him $ hence, if thoughtful and  fober, they in time betome Matters, join  Stock, and trade independently. They have  a King, chofe from among their Body, and  his Confortis ftiled Queen, agreeing to fome  Laws by common Confent, as a Guide to  them. They are incredible Tempefts of  Wind, whole Fury, neither Ships, Mafts,  Trees, or Buildings can refift. They come  a Day or two before the full or new Moon  next the Autumnal Equinox, and give Warning by a preceding unufual Swell of Water.  They are of no great Extent, but blow within  a Chanel as it were, one Ifland feeling it,  when the next (within 20 Leagues perhaps)  has no Share; and are, if not peculiar, rarely  met with out of the Weft-Indies. This Nifus, or refitting Motion to the Defcent of Bodies,  is no*-only perceptible in the Lead, but more fenfibly declares itfeif, firft* in that black or green Skim, feen fometimes on the Surface (even fmclling) afcer long Calms, the  Product of fome inteftine Motion.  2. That Divers, or any floating Bodies, emerge with  great'.r Force than they funk.  3. Mr. boyie's 20th Experiment obferves, that a glafs  Bubble let open into the Receiver, on the Exfuction of the  Air, the Water in it manifeftly rifes a greater Height ■&gt; con-  fequentlythe Expaniion and Rarefaction of the Air by the  Heat of the Sun, makes room for this Spring in the Water,  to exert itfeif; and therefore the Tides themfelves would  more difficultly yield to thediftant Attractions of the Sun  and Moon (I fhould think) without adding to that Theory  this conjoined Force, or natural Propenfity of the Sea, to  fwell before.  Inrefpedfc to finking the Lead, alfo may be added, a greater  Coldnefs, and a greater Saltnefs of the Sea, in proportion to  the Depths j (both which are very probable,) and will create  a greater Buoyancy,or Reiiftance to finking,as wilHikewift  the drawing out a greater Quantity of Line, (lefs apt to demerge.) So that although falling Bodies in Air, have their  Velocities encreafed, the nearer they approach the Earth, yet  contrarily in Water, it diminifhes with che Defcent.  R Cor-  257  1721  May 18. Page 13																																asc9999001001		HKvJftKv,  y.  per, on y fit passer quelques femmes blanches,  pour y favoriser la population blanche; mais a  cette epoque les vertus de ces femmes qui pas--  soient ainsi les mers, paroissoient plus que sus-  pectes; et leurs mariages avec les blancs n'eurent  pas tout le fruit qifon s'en etoit promis. Les  blancs leur preferoient des filles de couleur; et  ceux qui ne prenoient pas ce dernier parti, se  choisissoient des femmes parmi leurs esclaves,  poursoigner leur menage et leurs personnes; ils  en faisoient leurs femmes, sous le titre de mena-  gere. Des qifelles avoient des enfans avec leurs  maitres, elles devenoient libres, ainsi que lenrs  enfans, qui etoient toujours eleves comme les  enfans libres. La facilite avec laquelle on obte-  noit alors des terres incultes, les mettoit a portee  d'en donner a chacun de leurs enfans.  Tel a ete letat des gens de couleur libres aii  second age de la colonie.  Jusques-la on n'avoit point con'nu le prejuge  contre cette classe d'hommes libres. Page 25																																asc9999001001		I  16  Un certain degre de melange de sang blanc, qui les  confonde avec les blancs, par la couleur de Fepi-  derme. Entrons dans des details.  Pour prouver les inconveniens de cette me-  sure, il est necessaire de bien expliquer ce qu'on  entend par degre de couleur dans les colonies.  Le produit du blanc avec une ncgresse , se  nomme mulatre. Et c'est le premier degre.  Le produit du mulatre , ou premier degre avec  le blanc, s'appeile quarteron. Et c'est le second  degre.  Le produit du quarteron, ou second degre,  avec le blanc , s'appelie tierceron, ou troisieme  degre.  Le produit du tierceron ou troisieme degre,  avec le blanc, sappelle metis, ou quatrieme  degre.  A ce degre, la couleur de Fepiderme est par-  faitement la meme que celle des blancs, les plus  blancs de la pcau. Nous enverrons a Saint-Domingue un homme impartial, et en etat de juger  quel est le plus instruit, de Labadie, ou de P. B.  F. Laborde : si c'est le premier, P. B. F. Laborde  perdra son argent, et il appartiendra a celui qui  aura fait le voyage; si c'est au contraire P. B. F.  Laborde , qui est le plus instruit , mon argent  sera perdu. Je defie P. B. F. d'accepter ce pari. S'il  refuse*, il est juge.  Les commissions honorables dont Labadie a  ete revetu, prouvent Fidee qu'on avoit de son  intelligence. Labadie a 6t6 commissionne de  lieutenant dans la milice;et, en cette quality, a  tres-bien servi dans la guerre de 1749 et 1757. Observations sur l'origine et les progrès du préjugé des colons blancs contre les hommes de couleur : sur les inconvéniens de le perpétuer  la nécessité, la facilité de le détruire  sur le projet du Comité colonial, etc.				Raimond, Julien, 1743?-1802?	Brissot de Warville, J.-P. (Jacques-Pierre), 1754-1793; Rosner, George W.		"Julien Raymond -- or Raimond as he is identified elsewhere -- (1743-1802?) served as a 'depute' to the Revolutionary Government, representing the people of color of Saint Domingue. These 'Gens de Couleurs' of the French colony had been given full rights as French citizens following the overthrow of the monarchy.  However strong protests from Haiti's white planters inevitably led to a rescinding of those rights.  The result was the uprising in Haiti led by Toussaint L'Ouverture."-- Swann Auction Galleries ; Lettre de J.P. Brissot à M. Raymond -- Origine du préjugé des blancs contre les hommes de couleur des colonies -- Lettre de M. Raymond à J. P. Brissot. ; Bissainthe, M. Dict. de bib. haitienne, 7545 ; U.M. Special Collections copy 8vo, rebound in modern marbled boards with leather label up the spine; Purchased with funds from the George W. Rosner Library Fund; This item was digitized with the support of the Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Florida Quality of Life Grant, 2013.
