Page 13																																asc9999001017		tXTKODTCnO^U  1«  April, a .Committee of the House of Assembly decided what had been the causes of the insurrection : and after charging the British Government,  and the Anti^Slavery Society, and the systems of  all the Sectarians, and the Slave-holders themselves, then it is asserted, as another eftuse, tliafe  i^ie preaching of the Missionaries, and particularly  of the Baptists, " had produced, in the minds o£  the slaves, an impression that they could not serve  both a temporal and a spiritual master;'--that jfeV  that there wa& this general mistake made by the  negroes, all over the island, just before Christmas,  because, just at that time almost all the Ministers  had been preaching upon this subject, so as to be  misunderstood. Whether this was their crimer  or a casual coincidence, is not clearly stated.-—  But as there has not been any proof adduced tm  establish the charge, many even of the Colonists  have rejected it as inadeqiiate for the confirmation^  of guilt.  Those, therefore, who have professed to rest  their accusation upon evidence, have adopted different language. It i&a serious fact, some of them  have said, that in the Western part of the island,  a Bible was found with, the corners of the leaves  turned down, against the history of the Jewish  wars. But even this* if true, has not been considered sufficient by all. Seine, who are in no  respect friendly, have thought it defective,, as  a proof, that any one of the preachers had really  been employed in urging his hearers to battle, or  in teaching them the military tactics of the Bible.  ►And it may perhaps have been recollected that  their most favourite* Clergymen must sometimes  * See at page 117 a specimen of this class ; and itmay be dremed  worthy of notice perhaps, that the 8th of Joshua, the particular Chapter respecting which much accusation was brought against the iVJim-  sjotmries, was the appointed Lesson for Wednesday the 14th of M?.rrh„  *a& ^vastken read by the Clergyman in'Muntcgo-Bay Church, 	asc99990010170013001											55821834 Bytes	3459	5377	3010398832	RGB	asc99990010170013001.tif		2013-08-12	2013-08-12	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5787	5787	5788.jp2	/scbooks/image/5788.jp2
Page 14																																asc9999001017		IT  INTRODUCTION*.  read these dangerous histories, as the appointed  Lessons of the Day. Others therefore have asserted, that the rebellion had its rise in the dissatisfaction of the slaves ; and that this dissatisfaction was produced by the habit which the Missionaries have of shaking hands with the people.  This symbol of courtesy, it has been reasoned, has  given the slaves a notion of equality with the  whites ; and, after imbibing the consciousness of  self-importance, through this free-masonry mode  of communication—after learning, through the fingers, that they were as good and as wise as the  free, they have devised their ruinous plan for becoming free! Unfortunately for this argument,  a great number of the slaves, who had the most  frequent opportunities of shaking hands with the  Missionaries, were the most strenuous and the  most successful in their exertions to suppress the  insurrection ; and on the contrary, an overwhelming majority of the slaves, who actually rebelled,  had never shaken hands with any Missionary on  the island.  Persons, who are not influenced by the com-  mon prejudice against Missionaries, will no doubt  at first suppose that these charges are too ludicrous to have been gravely advanced. But the  fact is, that men of sense, and of Colonial reputation, have employed them, as though satisfied of  their truth. It may have been, because that having begun a war with the Sectarians, the most contemptible auxiliaries have been considered better  than none. Or perhaps, these charges may have  been heedlessly thrown out, in reckless despair  of finding any of a more serious cast. After  perusing what is here detailed, the reader will  perceive that something in the shape of vindication was demanded among the guilty assailants to save them from mutual recrimination. — 	asc99990010170014001											62713162 Bytes	3791	5512	1110202085	RGB	asc99990010170014001.tif		2013-08-12	2013-08-12	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5788	5788	5789.jp2	/scbooks/image/5789.jp2
Page 15																																asc9999001017		iNTriODUCTION. - f  For though this is the nineteenth century of the  Christian Church, and though Jamaica is called a  Christian Island, in the following pages he will  find British Gentlemen accused to their faces of  resorting to perjury and bribery to effect the legal  murder of the innocent; and assemblies of British  Gentlemen united for the avowed purpose of taking away the lives of the preachers by violence;  and he will also find professedly Christian Magistrates encouraging with their presence, and by  their own efforts inciting to the entire destruction  of places that had been only employed for the  worship of God ! That it could not be proved  that these places had been otherwise employed,  or that the Missionaries had done more than preach  the Gospel, was, at the time, considered an additional reason for vehemence in the outrage. And  there need not therefore be much surprise at any  ulterior efforts, however ridiculous or base, to justify such enormities, or at least to palliate them  with excuse.  There have, however, been some, who, though  not at all more reasonable or moderate, have expressed their dissatisfaction with these charges, and  have not shewn any hesitation in declaring them  to be unfounded and unjust. They have said,  V If the Missionaries had really been guilty of  preaching sedition, either directly or indirectly, it  must have been possible to prove it;" and the  habit of shaking hands, they have thought too trivial to have excited all the burnings and the war.  Disdaining, therefore, such a skirmishing mode of  attack, they have made a straight-forward thrust  at what they thought the heart of the Baptist  Missionary Society in Jamaica. They have  maintained that, with the system of the Society,  and its doctrines, there was inseparably interwo-  -ven a rebellion-stirring quality ; ami tlmt^ therefore* 	asc99990010170015001											54715044 Bytes	3398	5365	3045386705	RGB	asc99990010170015001.tif		2013-08-12	2013-08-12	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5789	5789	5790.jp2	/scbooks/image/5790.jp2
Page 16																																asc9999001017		TI  INTRODUCTION.  of its prosperity an insurrection was the natural  result. It is true, they have sometimes seemed  at a loss whether to attribute the principal evil to  the faith, or to the system;—with the firmest purpose for fixing the crime upon the one, or the  other, there has been very much vacillation in de^  termining to which it belonged. But they have  kept within their own prescribed limits, and only  suffered themselves to be driven from the system  to the doctrines, and from the doctrines to the  system.  As the present Work is intended for the perusal of enemies, as well as friends, it may not be  inappropriate here to notice some general features  in the sentiments and conduct of the Missionaries,  who have been so unceremoniously accused,—  There will, at least, be one advantage secured.—  Those who reproach them in future, may be able  to say with truth, that they are not indulging in  abuse upon a subject of which they are perfectly  ignorant.  . And for the information of those who have said  so much of what has been termed " the system"  of the Baptist Missionaries, it may be observed,,  in the first place, that, compared with the definite and unalterable arrangements of some other  Denominations of Christians, they have no precise  system for the management of the Churches under their care. The Society in England does not  enforce obedience to any particular and specified  plans of Church-government. With the regulations of the New Testament for his guide in important matters, every Minister, having the help  of his Church, is expected to arrange according to  the best of his judgment in common affairs.—  There is, respecting the New Testament instructions, a general uniformity of opinion/ or  there 	asc99990010170016001											61935594 Bytes	3744	5512	4203326513	RGB	asc99990010170016001.tif		2013-08-12	2013-08-12	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5790	5790	5791.jp2	/scbooks/image/5791.jp2
Page 17																																asc9999001017		INTRODUCTION.  VH  could not exist, in a distinct form, such an association as the Baptist Missionary Society. And,  possibly, tire consequent agreement in practice  among the Baptist Missionaries, may be a portion  of this "mischievous system." As there is not  any thing in the formation and superintendence  of a Church, that they have any inducement to  conceal, if the reader will be patient a little, he  may be let into the arcana of this combination,  that has been so freely charged with complots,  ahd anarchy, and blood !  The Baptist Missionary Society is composed of  a number of Christians in England, who are desirous of sending Baptist Missionaries, to preach  the Gospel in those parts of the world where it is  particularly needed. To attend to the business of  this voluntary union, there is a Committee of  Ministers and Gentlemen chosen annually at the  Society's general meeting. This Committee receives applications from persons who are desirous  of being employed as Missionaries ; and most of  those who are accepted, before leaving their native  country, spend a few years in one of the Baptist  Academies, instituted for the education of young  men for the Ministry. When the period for acquiring a theological and moderate classical education has expired, the Missionary is sent abroad,—-  not to interfere with politics, but simply to preach  the Gospel of Christ—not to engage in any secular employ for emolument, being desired to  look to the Society for his support. If the people  to whom he preaches are able to contribute any  thing, what they give at first is generally employed in purchasing premises; and if they are  ultimately able and willing to support him, tte  Committee gladly use their own resources for  sending the Gospel in some other direction. But,  indeed, the Society hfts also often rendered consir 	asc99990010170017001											55115942 Bytes	3421	5368	1721772182	RGB	asc99990010170017001.tif		2013-08-12	2013-08-12	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5791	5791	5792.jp2	/scbooks/image/5792.jp2
Page 18																																asc9999001017		Vhi  INTRODUCTION,  derabie assistance-- in procuring suitable buildings ; and, as a proof ot this, it may be observed,  that besides the contributions of the Churehea  here, the last Annual Reports shew that during  the two preceding years, ending in May, 1882,  the Committee had expended more than fourteen  thousand pounds sterling on the Mission to Jamaica.  But the Missionaries thus engaged, and sent  forth, having fixed themselves in those places where  it has appeared to them and the Committee that  there is the prospect of being useful, all opportunities for giving religious instruction are diligently  improved : and when any persons give satisfactory evidence of believing the Gospel, then they  are baptized ; and these baptized believers, be  they few or many, are called a Church. The  Members of this Church meet together at stated  times for the public worship of God, and for attending to the Ordinance of the Lord's Supper.  And as soon as the number of Members has so  much increased as to render it desirable, one, or  two, or more, of the best, are chosen by themselves, from among them, to be Deacons. The  duties of these Deacons chiefly consist in reporting who, among the poor, are fit persons for receiving pecuniary help—carrying the bread and wine  to the Members at the time of the Lord's Supper  —visiting the sick—making the public collections  —and giving private instruction, to explain what  the preacher has publicly taught. Men, qualified  for the performance of this work, are " looked  out" for, and, when found, are appointed to the  Station, without any regard to their complexion,  or their political state.  But,  besides these Deacons, as a Church increases, an I indeed for  securing its increase, it 	asc99990010170018001											61465380 Bytes	3723	5501	1748565219	RGB	asc99990010170018001.tif		2013-08-12	2013-08-12	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5792	5792	5793.jp2	/scbooks/image/5793.jp2
Page 19																																asc9999001017		ixtBOiDueiftoN,  to  is commonly thought right to appoint other assistants, who are*" denominated Leaders. Their  employment is to help the Minister, by inducing  &g many as possible to attend his preaching'—-by  watching over the conduct of the Members and  Inquirers or candidates for Membership-—and by  meeting with them in small companies for wor*  Biiip, mutual examination, and the reading of  the Scriptures. If a Leader h guilty of conniving  at sin in any one of the Members, he is, according to the degree of the offence, subject to censure,  or removal from his Station, or exclusion from the  Church : and when a person is desirous of being  baptized, some one of the Leaders is expected to  be able to bear testimony to the excellence of  his conduct.  The charge that the Missionaries promoted (ha  rebellion, by selecting their Leaders from tlw  Drivers on h'states, is as true as many of the other  charges, having ignorance or malice as their source;  and con best be met fey a simple denial, that has  a large supply of proofs, if required, lite Leaders, like the Deacons, are -no/-selected on account  of having any "civil authority,*' but because of character—because of superior piety. It is true, that  in the Churches throughout the Island, there am  Leaders who are Drivers ; but there have also been  some instances of Leaders made Drivers, who  have found the work of giving religions Instruction, to their fellow-slaves, incompatible with the  business of flogging theni, and who have therefore  requested that other Leaders might be placed in  their stations ; and there have been some instances  of Leaders-preferring to work with the hoe through,  the day, rather than stand still with the whip;  and many instances of Leaders having no il civil  mithdriW- on their Estates; and many of Drivers  being- Enquirers, .under Leaders on tkeiii^&Mfc* 	asc99990010170019001											55412292 Bytes	3451	5350	2759022821	RGB	asc99990010170019001.tif		2013-08-12	2013-08-12	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5793	5793	5794.jp2	/scbooks/image/5794.jp2
Page 20																																asc9999001017		% INTRODUCTION.  tates, who had no " civil avdhority ;&gt;' and many of  Drivers ■ being • Members, under Leaders on' the  same Estates, who had no " civil authority ;" and  many of slaves without ".civil authority" being  Leaders on their own Estates, and ako on other  Estates in the neighbourhood, not for want of  Drivers, but of good men, ■sufficiently, eminent in  excellence, to be appointed m examples to th^  rest.  It is proper, however, to observe here, that the  Leader's office is not considered necessary in the  constitution of a Church. Among, the Baptist  Churches, in England, Clashes and Leaders are  very Utile known. And at the commencement of a  new Station here, the" Missionary is at liberty,  either to appoint Leaders, or not, as may appear  to him raoBt eligible for ensuring mccem. A similar remark may be made respecting the Tickets  which have been given—to Members, as a token of  Membership, and for preserving regularity at the  Ordinance of the Lord's Supper-—and to Enquirers, that they might he brought more particularly  under the Minister's instruction and care.  This is a Sketch of what has been called, " tlm  mischievous and dangerous system/'  The distinguishing doctrines of the Baptist Missionaries, however much maligned, are to be found  in the Articles of the KstabUshed Church. An  ability to subscribe to all those Articles is not pro*-  f essed by any of the M i ssiouari es; in d eed, there is not  any formulary among them to which they are expected to subscribe. A belief in the general teneta  of the Baptists-is avowed by them all at the time  of entering •the Ministry; and with this very general agreement*, each one is left to adopt that  mode of- phraseoU^gy which may appear to hitiA  JSBBBBBBBBSBBBBBB6S& 	asc99990010170020001											61503450 Bytes	3724	5503	90215130	RGB	asc99990010170020001.tif		2013-08-12	2013-08-12	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5794	5794	5795.jp2	/scbooks/image/5795.jp2
Page 21																																asc9999001017		t^tnoDVCTios.  XV  most closely accordant with the revelation of God*  But by this Want of particularity, there is nothing  lost among those men who have endeatb tired to  vilify the doctrines that are believed. With abundant opportunities for learning the truth, they  have long been in the habit of refusing to learh ;  and of rejecting every thing respecting Missionaries, Unless it condemned them. Te£&gt; vain, or  too guilty to ask the preachers what they considered truth ; and tc&gt;o tenacious of reputation among  kicked associates, to be seen in a Baptist Chapel,  listening to the truth, they have pertinaciously  doomed themselves to ignorance ; and in this state,,  not wishing to know either what was received, or  what was rejected, have secured the illimitable  range afforded by both for expatiating in slander.  But the preaching of the Missionaries may, iri  a general mantier, be easily described ; and as the  religious services are public, any one may ascfer-  tMn with what degree of accuracy the representation is given. The end for which the instruction  is imported, is the salvation of the souls- of those  who hear it. This is the great object of the Preachers; and to accomplish this, they strive to convince  those who attend, that they are sinners, and need  a Saviour ; and that the Lord Jesus Christ, who:  suffered death for the guilty, is the only Saviour;  and that repentance for sin, and faith hi Him, is  the only method by which the guilty can obtain:  forgiveness here, and an entrance into fleaven: hereafter ; and then, upon those who profess to believe the message, the Preachers constantly enforce  the necessity of holiness, both in heart tikd in life.  They are satisfied that these are the conspicuous  features of the Gospel, and therefore feel it a duty  to make them prominent in ail their ministrations.  They hAve been richly encouraged to do so ; for  through the "blessing'of God,   these very truths' 	asc99990010170021001											54695830 Bytes	3407	5349	2587223305	RGB	asc99990010170021001.tif		2013-08-12	2013-08-12	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5795	5795	5796.jp2	/scbooks/image/5796.jp2
Page 22																																asc9999001017		xi*  IXTRa&8CTIO&gt;%  have been the means of bringing thousands ofth#  slaves "from darkness to light, and from the  power of Satan unto God."  A concise history of this extraordinary success  occupies the first Chapter, and is given with as  much regard to the order of time, as is deemed  consistent with clearness, in narrating what were  often contemporaneous events. In the perusal,  the Christian reader will see much cause for gratitude to the " Giver of every good," who lias in  this instance, as in many others, distinguished the  weak, and the base, and the despised ol this world,  "that no flesh might glory in His presence." It  is now necessary to observe also, that this success is  the more surprising, as it has been continued  from the beginning of the Mission to the time of the  insurrection, and throughout the Island, in defiance of obstructions, which no power, except the  power of God, could ever have overcome. The  present persecutions are far from being the first  obstacles in the way of religious improvement.--  Except in Kingston, among the majority of the  Colonists, opposition has been made, with very  little intermission, from the first time that the  Gospel was brought to the Island. It is true, the  opposition has been habited in different garbs, to  be adapted to the time; sometimes, proceeding on  an open course with avowed hostility; at other  times using double language to deceive, and taking  a circuitous path to ensnare ; and sometimes assuming the appearance of the most fettered and  parsimonious toleration ; but in one shape or another, it has been almost constantly engaged. Long  before the rebellion broke out" there was only  wanted the excuse, not the readiness of mind, for  a united effort to expel all the Missionaries from  the Country Stations. It had long been the general custom, if a proposition came from the Bri-  5&BS5S8SBB83589S8859SS 	asc99990010170022001											61842874 Bytes	3733	5520	4118638573	RGB	asc99990010170022001.tif		2013-08-12	2013-08-12	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5796	5796	5797.jp2	/scbooks/image/5797.jp2
Page 23																																asc9999001017		iWtUQUVQTlON,  XJ#  fish Government, and was disapproved by the  House of Assembly, to attribute its origin to some  party in England with which the Missionaries were  connected ; or if any crime was committed, or any  accident happened, in the Island, to accuse the  " Sectarian Preachers" as the cause.  And as these charges were often made in the  public prints, and without any shadow of proof,  the most distant reader, who has a little acquaintance with human nature, will at once perceive  that they could not have been the only attempts to  hinder the Missionaries, nor the most injurious.  They arose out of a confirmed and general system  of resisting the progress of the Gospel—a.system  which was so comprehensive as to include all the  irreligious laws, and customs, and passions, of the  people as its support; and at the same time so ramified as to meet the Missionaries at almost every  step. It would be impossible to particularize  every description of obstacles; but as a recent  Committee of the House of Assembly has challenged the truth, it seems necessary to make  known at least a part of it, that those who honestly enquire for intelligence, may have some within  their reach, respecting the state of the Island, up  to the time of the insurrection.  ■  The almost invariable practice of the Attornies„  and Overseers, and Bookkeepers, living in fornication, has been a great obstacle to the progress  of the Gospel, because, in the judgment of the  slave, it has placed the conduct of almost all the  white people whom he knew, in direct opposition  to the instructions of a solitary Preacher. Kefus-  ing to give the slaves permission to marry, sometimes when the man and woman desiring marriage  have belonged to the same property, and often  because they have not, has been another great  I 	asc99990010170023001											55738168 Bytes	3459	5369	1065753513	RGB	asc99990010170023001.tif		2013-08-12	2013-08-12	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5797	5797	5798.jp2	/scbooks/image/5798.jp2
Page 24																																asc9999001017		Xlf  iNfftdDBCtloSr.  obstacle, as it has frequently made the person  who professed to think good conduct of great importance, an example of wickedness to a whole  Estate that thought it a trifle. The Sabbath Markets, sanctioned throughout the island, and Estate's work of all kinds, commonly done on the  Sabbath, form another great obstacle, as the slave  has been regularly compelled into the habit of  transgressing one of the plainest commandments  of God. Allied to this, as an obstacle, is the irregularity of giving to the slave his days, and the  insufficient number of those days, if even regularly  given; asthe consequence is, that there are very few  of the slaves on estates whocanever think of attending a Place of Worship more than twice in a month;  afrd very many who have to content themselves*  with once. Refusing to give the Missionary permission to go upon the Estates has been anothef  obstacle, as it lias perpetuated superstitions,  which, by a few unrestrained visits, he might easily have destroyed. To these, it may be added,  that many slaves have been punished for their religion ; and the possibility of punishing, under  such a charge, certainly deserves a place ifr the  class of obstacles to the progress of the Gospel, &$  it is not likely, until Attornies and Overseers are  better men than the present race, that there will be*  many Estates upon which, for any great length of  time, this very serious coiltroul over conscience  will not be abused.  It may be remarked, that all this, and much  more, would have been laid before the "Beligiou^  Obstructions and Improvement Committee ;" but  scrtne of the Missionaries, though trifled with at  lafge respecting the employment in which they  were engaged before entering the Ministry, were  not allowed to give the evidence with which they  were prepare?!?* upon the subjects specified; and 	asc99990010170024001											62770780 Bytes	3800	5504	4048543257	RGB	asc99990010170024001.tif		2013-08-12	2013-08-12	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5798	5798	5799.jp2	/scbooks/image/5799.jp2

Page 26																																asc9999001017		NARRATIVE,  4*c. 4'c-  CHAPTER I.  A Sketch of the Baptist Mission in the Island of Jamaica, from lis commencement,  to January, 1832.—Shewing its Origin and Progress, with the Names of all the  Missionaries who have been employed—the time of their arrival—and the Stations they occupied.  THE Baptist mission, in Jamaica, was commenced in the  year 1814. The first missionary sent out by the Society in  England was the Rev. John Rowe, a member of the Baptist  Church at Yeovil, in Somersetshire^ who was educated for  the ministry, under the late Dr. Ryland, at the Baptist College*  Bristol.  He sailed, with Mrs, Rowe, on the 31st of December, 1813,  and arrived at Montego-Bay, February the 23d, 1814, where  he was kindly received by the Hon. Samuel Vaughan, a Gentleman of liberal sentiments, who was anxious to afford his  slaves religious instruction, and who was then employing on  his estates, for that purpose, Mr. Moses Baker, a Iree person  of colour, who had a congregation of five or six hundred persons.  Falmouth, the intended scene of his future labours, was  visited by Mr. Rowe, shortly after his arrival in the Island.  He found an almost total disregard of Religion, with violent  prejudice against Dissenters. One or two individuals, to  whom he had letters of introduction, received him politely*  but gave little encouragement to the work of his mission.—  Speaking on the general state of morals, Mr. Rowe says, i( it  is seldom that any one possessed of the least degree of morality, on first coming hither, can behold the general contempt  in which religion is  held without horror and distress.     I 	asc99990010170026001											55337740 Bytes	3440	5360	232785419	RGB	asc99990010170026001.tif		2013-08-12	2013-08-12	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5800	5800	5801.jp2	/scbooks/image/5801.jp2
Page 27																																asc9999001017		have been assured of this by some, who say, on their first  coming our, they felt thus, but they are now reconciled to that  neglect of religion, which custom sanctions!"  Mr. Rowe waited on several neighbouring magistrates,  who did not oppose his preaching ultimately, bur spoke of the  prejudice against religion, and recommended his opening a  school. But just as his prospects of usefulness began to brighten—-  as prejudice was yielding to the mild influence of Christian  principle—the favour of several leading characters (as far as  toleration went) conciliated—and the constitution of himself  and Mrs. Rowe, supposed to be inured to the climate, it  pleased God, by one of the mysterious operations of his  hand, to terminate his labours and his sorrows, by removing  him from a scene of profanity and vice to a state, where the  wicked cease from troubling, and the weary are. at rest.  Not only in the sight of God is the death of the righteous  precious, but they are often had in remembrance by those who  dislike their religion. Various testimonies of respect to Mr.  Rowe were sent from Falmouth to the society in England,  by persons of influence in that town. One of the Secretaries  was assured that "Mr. R. was much respected by the Gustos  and many inhabitants of Trelawny, as a man of worth and  piety, and perfectly suited for the office he was appointed to  till."  Mrs. Rowe returned to England, shortly after the death of  her husband.  Prior to Mr. Rowe's death, Mr. Lee Compeer, a member of  the church of Halstead, in Essex, was sent out to Jamaica as  a Baptist missionary. As the best remedy ior these evils, it was deemed  desirable by the Committee, that a Baptist missionary'should  settle amongst them, and teach them the way 'of God mora  perfectly. Accordingly Mr. Compeer was directed to remaiii  in Kingston. He obtained a license to preach, and on Lord's  Day, July the 6ih, 1810, formed a church, and administered  the Ordinance of the Lord's Supper to about two hundred  communicants? who had been previously baptized. Mr.  Compeer commenced a course of expository preaching, h'ghly  calculated to benefit his hearers, by leading them to more  clear and scriptural views of the way of salvation, it is not to  be supposed that his situation was without .difficulty ; his  Communications to the Society shew that, from the prejudice  prevailing against missionaries, the ignorance of the peop!e,  and the party spirit which existed, he was sufficiently tried.  But as his hearers began to appreciate and enjoy his labours,  he appears to have been much encouraged and delighted in his  work. On one occasion he says, " 1 felt as I never felt before;  while speaking of the sufferings of Christ, i could willingly ha\e  died in the pulpit ; I enjoyed an unusual degree of utterances-  accompanied with an agonizing desire of plucking souls as  brands from the everlasting burnings." Many appeared to  be benefited by his labours ; but; amidst these pleasing and  successful exertions, his health declined so much, that in ISIJ  he resigned his charge in Kingston, and his connexion with  the mission. He removed to the United States of America,  nhere he still continues to exercise th* Christian Ministry ;  a 2 	asc99990010170028001											54952484 Bytes	3416	5360	457773963	RGB	asc99990010170028001.tif		2013-08-12	2013-08-12	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5802	5802	5803.jp2	/scbooks/image/5803.jp2
Page 29																																asc9999001017		■OBHHB0H  4  und has been   usefully employed amongst   the Indians   N  Georgia.  Mr. Compeer had frequently urged the Society to send out  more labourers, and his strong representations of the peopled  destitute condition, accompanied with their own earnest requests, induced the Committee to look out for another person  to send on the Jamaica mission.  Mr. James Coultart, who had been a student at Bristol,  having expressed his desire to engage in missionary labour,  was appointed, and solemnly set apart for the service on February the 7th, 1817, at Bristol, where he embarked with  Mrs. C. March the 14th, and after being detained above a  month by contrary winds, they sailed for Kingston, where  they landed May 9th. The people greatly rejoiced in the arrival of another missionary, and Mr. Coultart was favourably  received by the magistrates and other influential persons. His  arrival was very opportune, as the reduced state of Mr. Compeer's health rendered him unable to discharge the increasing  duties of the Station. Mr. Coultart soon took charge of the  congregation, which was becoming large and attentive—-many  appeared to hear the word with gladness, and to feel its renewing power. The set time to favour Zion was at hand : and  as the doctrines of the Cross were faithfully and affectionately  exhibited from Sabbath to Sabbath, the spirit of God accompanied his word, and made it abundantly efficacious in demolishing the strong holds of sin, and establishing righteousness and peace in the hearts of the people. Great numbers  were added to the church, who had given pleasing evidence  of a change of heart.  In addition to the duties of their Station, Mr and Mrs.  Coultart commenced a school; chiefly with the view of instructing the children of members in the church; thus  their hands were full of useful and interesting labour, and  a scene of grateful employment seemed to open before  them. But God, who sets one thing over against another,  had severe trials in reserve for his servants. In about five  months after their arrival, Mrs. C. a most pious and valuable  woman, was removed by death ; and the health of Mr. C.  was so much impaired that he was forced to return home for  a season to recruit it. While in England he visited many  Christian friends in different parts of the Kingdom, and oh^  rained help towards erecting a place of worship in Kingston.  In the mean time two other missionaries were ^appointed for  Jamaica, namely, Messrs. Christopher Kitching and Thomas  Grodden.    They were designated at Fronie, July the 30th, 	asc99990010170029001											62230066 Bytes	3753	5525	195823281	RGB	asc99990010170029001.tif		2013-08-12	2013-08-12	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5803	5803	5804.jp2	/scbooks/image/5804.jp2
Page 30																																asc9999001017		- 1  1818. Mr. Kitching, at a previous period, was preparing to,  enter into connexion with the London Missionary Society %  but on reading the account given by Messrs. Judson and Bice,  of the reasons which induced them to become Baptists, while  on their passage to the East-Indies as missionaries, under the  direction of the American Board of Missions, he changed his  views on the Ordinance of Baptism, and ultimately became  connected with the Baptist Mission. He studied for the ministry under Dr. Steadman, President of the Baptist College,  Bradford  Yorkshire.  Mr. Kitching was appointed to occupy the station in Kingston till Mr. Coultart's return. He sailed early in August,  and arrived on the 18th of September, 1818,  The Lord prepared the hearts of the people to receive him  with great kindness, and set an open door before his servant,  so that the labours of Mr. K. were attended with the most  evident and pleasing success ; two or three additions were  made to the church during his short sojourn in Kingston.  Early in the following year, 1819, Mr. and Mrs, Godden  proceeded on their mission to Jamaica. They sailed from  King Road on the 28th of February, and, after a favourable  passage, arrived at Fort-Royal on the 9th of April. Mr.  Kitching had visited Spanish-Town, and, found a few poor  people there belonging to the denomination, who greatly da-  sired a minister to settle amongst them. Mr. Godden we  to Spanish-Town shortly after his arrival, in company v  Mr. K. to ascertain the eligibility of commencing a mission  there, and if necessary, obtain a suitable house for the purpose. A house was hired, and on Sabbath morning, July  11th, 1819, Mr. G. commenced his missionary labours by a  discourse on Matthew xxii, 42.—" What think ye of Christ ?n  Much interest was excited, many flecked to hear the word,  and appeared to benefit thereby. With such pleasing prospects before him, Mr. G. entered on his work in Spanish-Town,  in all the buoyancy of hope ; But no human enjoyment is without alloy ; his valuable partner, soon after the birth of her first  child, was taken with fever, and died on the 15th October, 1819.  An account of her death was communicated shortly after to the  Society at home by Mr. Kitching, in the last letter he ever wrote  them. Little did that devoted missionary think his own dissolution so near at hand. Intending to remain in Kingston only  till the return of Mr. Coultart, Mr. K. visited Manchionea],  in St. Thomas in the East, in the month of October, with $  view of forming a new Station there, should such'a step meet  the approbation of the Committee. 	asc99990010170030001											54257722 Bytes	3359	5382	1962264693	RGB	asc99990010170030001.tif		2013-08-12	2013-08-12	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5804	5804	5805.jp2	/scbooks/image/5805.jp2
Page 31																																asc9999001017		1  Mr. Kitching returned to Kingston, and while attending oft'  * sick friend, appears to have taken the yellow faxvv, which  terminated his useful life on the "19th of December, 181.9,  about eight hours after the death of his infant child. Of his  xeal, prudence, and usefulness, the most honourable testimonies were borne by those who were well acquainted with him.  A friend, writing from Kingston to the Committee shortly  after his death, remarks—4" Thus ended the short career of  Christopher Kitching, the most useful, laborious, and faithful  Baptist Preacher that ever visited this part of the world.'*  Mrs. K. left the island shortly after Hie death of her husband,  and returned to her friends in Yorkshire.  The health of Mr. Coultart having been much improved  hy his residence for some months in England, he returned to  Jamaica with Mrs. Coultart soon after Mr. Kitching's death.  In 1820 the church in Kingston increased exceedingly, and  the people greatly exerted themselves towards the purchasing  of premises, and erection of a suitable place of worship.—  This was accomplished under the superintendance of Mr.  Coultart, whose arduous exertions were amply compensated  by the success which accompanied them.  In the same year, Mr. Godden formed a church at §pa&gt;  rush-Town, with very pleasing indications ol success. On  May the 7th, 1320, he thus writes:—,( Baptized twenty-two  persons in the river before seven o'clock ; returned home and  preached to a full house; gave the right hand of fellowship  to the newly baptised, accompanied with a short address to  each. In the evening administered the Lord's Supper to  about two hundred persons, forty-three of whom I have had  the pleasure of baptizing : our place was crowded, we had not  half room." On the evening of July the 1.7th, the building  occupied by Mr. Godden as a dwelling-house and chapel,  was entirely destroyed by fire, supposed to have been the  work of an incendiary; this catastrophe interrupted Mr. Gs.  labours for a season, but other premises were obtained in a  more eligible part of the town, on which the present suitable  chapel was erected. Here Mr. Godden continued to labour, and  though often in ill health, commenced one or two subordinate  Stations, at one of which there is now a flourishing church.  The Mission continued to prosper beyond the most san-  gnine expectations of the Society ; and on the 27th of January, 1822, Mr. Coultart opened his new chapel, in Kingston,  capable of accommodating nearly two thousand persons.'—  This soon became well filled with hearers, not only on the  Sabbath, but even on a week-day evening. 	asc99990010170031001											62043674 Bytes	3767	5488	135732234	RGB	asc99990010170031001.tif		2013-08-12	2013-08-12	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5805	5805	5806.jp2	/scbooks/image/5806.jp2
Page 32																																asc9999001017		Early in this year, (he church, in Kingston, sent out a  missionary to another part of the island. We have previously  mentioned Mr. Vaughan'sdesire to obtain religious instruction  for his slaves, and his employing.Mr. M. Baker for that purpose, but whoMrom age and infirmity, was now unable to  continue his labours.    Anxious to carry on what had been so  "advantageously commenced, Mr. V. applied to the society  for a person to reside on his estates, who could instruct the  negroes, and also engage in some secular employ. A suitable  individual, was found in the person of Mr. Henry Tripp, a  carpenter, who was connected with the church, in East  ivHieen Street, and had rendered very important services to the  mission. Being sanctioned by the Society, he engaged to  make trial of the situation, and was accordingly recognized as  a missionary early in 1822, and proceeded to St. James's,  where he successfully laboured till the death of Mrs. Tripp,  which induced him, on account of his family, to dissolve his  .-.connexion with the Society, and return to England.  In the early part of 1822, • Mr. and Mrs. Tinson left  England as missionaries to Jamaica, They sailed from London on March the 24th, and after a pleasant passage, landed  at/Mora.ht-Bay, May the 31st.    It w7as the wish of the Com-  ,.miUee that Mr. Tinson should settle at Mancbioneal, in St.  'Thomas' in the East; accordingly he repaired thither as early  as possible, in company with Mr. Coultart, for the purpose  of taking such preparatory steps as were deemed requisite to  .obtain a licence at the ensuing Quarter Sessions of that parish.  "They waited on several of the most influential inhabitants,  who expressed their approbation of the undertaking, and promised their aid in obtaining that legal permission for Mr. T.  which was considered necessary prior to his entering on the  work of his mission. At the appointed time Mr. T, ap^  peared in the Court-House at Morant-Bay, presented his  papers, shewing his connexion with the Society in England,  his education for the ministry, and his ordination as a mis-  sionary to Jamaica. One of the magistrates, Mr. Fanton,  said the documents were quite satisfactory, and that a licence  ought at once to be granted ; but the Custos, Mr. P. Robertson,  remarked that he " had nothing to say against the papers, or  Mr T. individually, but he saw no use. of so many preachers ; that they had one Sect in the parish already, and he  could mot admit another ; or by and bye, they would have a  shipload out, and the parish would be inundated with Sectarians !"  Mr. T. not being permitted to preach at Manchioneal, pro* 	asc99990010170032001											54811678 Bytes	3399	5373	3087295955	RGB	asc99990010170032001.tif		2013-08-12	2013-08-12	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5806	5806	5807.jp2	/scbooks/image/5807.jp2
Page 33																																asc9999001017		ceeded to Kingston, where he received ail earnest request tm  settle with a body of professing Christians, who, for many  years, had been chiefly under the instruction of Mr. George  Liie, a respectable black person, connected with the American Baptists in Georgia, which place he left for Jamaica,  about 1780, on account of the American war. He preached in  and about Kingston from the year 1783, and his labours were  evidently blessed to the salvation of souls. Several now living,  who adorn the doctrines of their Saviour, were amongst the  early fruits of his ministry. About the time of Mr. T's,  arrival in Jamaica, there was some dispute between him and  a part of the people, who wished a missionary to take thus  oversight of them, and this led to Mr. Tinson's settling in  Kingston. He met with no difficulty in obtaining a licence,  which, having been procured, he commenced his labours in  that city, August 25th, 1822.  Towards the close of this year, Mr Thomas Knibb was  sent out by the Society in England, either for Mancbioneal,  or to superintend the school connected with the church  in East Queen Street, Kingston, and assist Mr. Coultart, as  might appear most advisable to the missionaries on the  island. He landed at Kingston in company with Mrs. K. on  the ,9th of January, 1823. After mutual consultation, it was  thought best for him to remain in Kingston. He entered at once  on the duties of the school, and feeling the most lively interest  in the eternal, as well as the present, welfare of his pupils, he  threw all the energies of his soul into the work, and soon fell  a sacrifice to his exertions. The school prospered exceedingly under his fostering care ; nor was it in the school only  he laboured with success ; he preached often both in Kingston and Port-Royal, where preaching had been commenced  in a private house by the missionaries from Kingston, in  1822. His manner was plain, faithful, and earnest; and frequently would he plead with sinners like a man standing on  the verge of eternity, with whom every consideration was  absorbed in his all-engrossing solicitude tor the salvation of  souls. In the recollection of many his memory is precious.  The extent of his usefulness can only be known in that day  when God shall render unto every one according to his works.  He died, after a short illness of three days, on the 25th of  April, 1824. His widow returned to England in delicate  health, and died at Northampton the 31st of January, in the  year following, leaving an orphan son to receive that attention  from others the parents were not permitted to bestow. Page 38																																asc9999001017		in  13  This induced Mr. Burchell to think of residing on the Bay, with  a view of establishing a new Station in the town, from which  the gospel might be more readily disseminated through tin;  adjacent parts. He hired a house, obtained a licence, and  commenced preaching, dividing his labours between Montego-  Bay and Crooked-Spring, giving every alternate Sabbath tc  to  each place. On the Bay he was greatly encouraged in his  wprk, the fields appeared white unto the harvest, the precious  grain waiting to be gathered in ; and here, on the 20th o( February, 1824, he formed a church of twelve members. His labours were abundantly blessed, and the interest excited was so  great, that the room hrstoccupied as a place of worship was soon  found to be far too small to accommodate half the people who  flocked to hear the word of truth. A larger house was taken,  still the congregation increased so as to require more room,  and many not only heard the word with gladness, but received  it with joy* so that the church increased in proportion to the  numbers who crowded to hear.  Mr. Burchell commenced one or two other Stations, iu hope  of obtaining from home more missionary labourers (or that  part of the island. On condition that a missionary should  be settled at Ridgeland, an estate in Westmoreland, premises  were offered the Society, by a wealthy proprietor who was  friendly to religious instruction, on the most advantageous  terms, at not more than one third of their value. These  were purchased in 1826. In the early part of that year, Mr.  Bluebell's ill state of health compelled him to visit England.  During his absence Mr. Mann arrived, and, as before  noticed, proceeded to Montego Bay, shortly after his arrival.  He took charge of Mr. Burcheli's Stations, superintending  them with acceptance and usefulness, till his return, which  was in January, 1827, when he found the churches both at  Montego-Bay and Crooked-Spring, in a \ery pleasing and  prosperous state, the meetings for worship well attended, and  the members walking in peace and brotherly love.  While Mr. Burchell was in England, an appeal was made  to the British public, on behalf of the Station at Montego-  Bay, and Mr. Burchell returned after a short sojourn in his  native land, with the means of erecting a suitable place of  worship, which he soon afterwards accomplished.  After Mr. Burcheli's return, Mr. Mann continued for some  time to co-operate with him in the general duties of the mission, until a new Station was formed in Falmouth, where hundreds of persons had been anxiously waiting for religious instruction. It will be remembered that the first Baptist missionary from  England, who settledat Falmouth, was Mr. Howe, who finished  his course there, after he had just begun to clear the moral  wilderness without being permitted to witness the progress of  its cultivation ; bur. he laboured not in vain—prayer for the  church of God, offered in humble reliance on his word, cannot  l&gt;e lost ; the blessings sought may be long delayed—ihe supplicant may forget his own petitions, and they may seem to he  buried in oblivion ; but God will not forget them, and though  years may roll over the place of their interment, tbey shall  rise from the dead, and live in the experience of redeemed  sinners yet unborn, and thus the good man, though dead, yet  speakeih. Mr. Mann, in a letter from ..Falmouth, dated July  ifee 20t;hj 1827, thus speaks of Mr. Rowe's labours in that  town.  ; V It will be gratifying to you to learn, that, after the num*  her of years which have elapsed since this Station was partially commenced by o-ur lamented brother, Ml Howe, wewero  still able to^ trace the eflects of his instructions. Some  were found whom we have good reason to believe are subjects, of Divine grace, and who have since been baptized,  who date their first serious impressions to Mr. Howe's teaching. The seed which was then scattered, though for a time  apparently lost, has been silently and imperceptibly springing  up, though under many disadvantages, and we trust that it  will bring forth fruit unto eternal glory." The church at  Falmouth, consisting of about forty members, was formed iti  May, 1827, by Mr. Mann, who continued its pastor till his  death. In the beginning of this year, the mission sustained a great  loss in the death of Mr. Mann, a most, indefatigable missionary,.-  and one, whose success was proportionate to his disinterested  endeavours. Under his care the church at Falmouth increased  greatly. lie visited several estates; and formed.-two new  churches, one at Bio Bueno, and another at Stewart's Town,  These churches werebot'h formed the year previous to Ids death,  which took place on Cambridge estate, in Trelawny, whither,  he had gone to preach, February 17th, 1830, .Mr. Mann was an  excellent Evangelist, beseemed to delight in breaking up tho  fallowground. lie was a plain,honest, uncompromising preacher*  of the gospel; and of such a frank and generous temper, that he  seldom failed to conciliate esteem wherever lie went. But while  he was thus cheerfully toiling in the moral wilderness, in the preparatory stages of its cultivation ; it pleased God, who deemed,  him faithful, putting him into the ministry, to remove him bom  the scene of his interesting labours, and give to others the  more pleasing task, of ingathering the fruits of Ids arduous  exertions. But not only in that part of the island did a Divine blessing  attend the ministry of the word, a proportionate measure of  success accompanied the preaching of the Gospel in nearly all  the other Stations, as will appear by the tabular view, given  at an association held in Falmouth, April 1831. A second  school room had been erected, expressly for girls, in connection -with the church, East Queen street. In the early part of  1830 Mr. Burton left that church, but continued to preach  in the city till the 4th of November, when he sailed for England, to confer with the Committee on his future plans of  operation. Mr. Clarke continued to superintend the school,  in East Queen street, and the church was chiefly supplied  during this year, by Mr, Coultart, its former pastor.  In June, "1830, Mr. Josiah Barlow7, member of a Baptist  church, in England, came to this island in a medical capa*„  city. He practised for some time as an assistant to a medical  gentleman residing a few miles from Kingston ; and having  on his arrival become acquainted with Mr. Coultart. be spent  most of his Sabbaths with the church in East Queen street ;  and as Mr. C's. health was much impaired, he was desired to  render occasional assistance in conducting prayer-meetings,  and other services connected with the Station.  As Mr. C. was necessarily in town the greater part of his  time, and consequently the church at Mount Charles bemg  frequently destitute, he encouraged Mr. Barlow to visit that  Station as often as convenient, which he did with acceptance;  and this led to a proposal, that he should lelinquish the me«  dical profession, and take charge of the school in East Queen  street, which Mr. Clarke was about to resign, and continue  his services on the Sabbath at Mount Charles, or elsewhere,  as occasion might require. About this time, Mi. Flood was desirous of seeking some colder climate for the restoration of his  health, which was greatly debilitated by icpeated attacks of  fever; and at a meeting of all the missionaries held at St. Ann's  Bay, on the 10th of Feb. 1831, it was recommended that Mr. 	asc99990010170043001											63257736 Bytes	3824	5512	1227894897	RGB	asc99990010170043001.tif		2013-08-12	2013-08-12	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5817	5817	5818.jp2	/scbooks/image/5818.jp2
Page 44																																asc9999001017		Flood should return to England as early as convenient, and  that Mr. Barlow should supply his Stations fill his return,  unless any new arrangement should be made by the Society  in England. Mr. Flood left the ljth of April, 1832, and Mr.  Barlow took charge of the Stations, which he still continues  to superintend, and under his pastoral care, both churches  have increased and continue to walk in the enjoyment of  Divine ordinances.  In the beginning of the year, 1830, Mr. Tinson opened a  new Station at Yatlahs, about nineteen miles from Kingston ;  and on June the 27th, formed a church of sixty-eight members, thirty of whom were dismissed from Hanover-street  church, and thirty-eight baptized on the occasion.  Mr. Burton returned from England March the 25th, 1831,  and shortly after proceeded to Mancbioneal,. where the Society  had long wished to send a missionary. Mr. Burton purchased  premises, and entered on his missionary labours in St. Thomas  in the East, with considerable encouragement, though not without difficulties : He visited several parts of that, and the  neighbouring parish, and was received with gladness among  the poor, who were hungering for the bread of life.  In April this year, (1831), a most interesting meeting was  held at Falmouth and Montego Bay, of all the missionaries on  the island, except one ; when from the accounts given by each  missionary, of his respective Stations, it appeared that the  clear increase of members in all the churches, during the preceding year, was nearly two thousand.  Annexed is a tabular view, as given at this meeting of the  Annual Association, held on the first and five following days  of April, 1831, presenting a correct statement of the Baptist  churches, then in the island of Jamaica, shewing also the  additions, deaths, exclusions, &c. with the clear increase,  during the previous year, Mr. Taylor's churches only, excepted; that account includes two years.  In the following Table, no notice is taken of Stations where  churches were not formed at the time it was given. There  were several subordinate Stations, at some of which churches  were formed shortly after. Page 46																																asc9999001017		21  35.  During the Association, two missionaries were ordained,  namelv, Mr, William Whitehorne, and Mr. Thomas F. Abbott.  The former, Mr. Whitehorne, a native of Jamaica, was bred  to the study of the law ; but becoming seriously impressed  with the subject of religion about the year 1820, he was  induced to think of relinquishing his legal profession,  and of entering the church. With that view he went, in the  beginning of 1830, to reside with a clergyman in -the parish  of Portland, and study for the ministry. While pursuing his  theological studies, his mind became occupied on the subject  of believers baptism, and conceiving immersion to be the only  scriptural mode of administering that ordinance—that it was  positively enjoined by the Saviour—and a prerequisite to  scriptural church-fellowship, he was led 10 seek connexion  with a Baptist church ; and on J uly 4th, 1830, was baptized by  Mr. Flood, at Annotto-Bay, and received as a member of the  church there.  Still desirous of being engaged in the ministry, he was affectionately recommended by the Baptist missionaries to  communicate on the subject with the Society in England.—■  He wrote to the Committee ; but before an answer could be  received, the missionaries strongly urged him to engage at once  in missionary work, as more labourers were greatly needed,  while the number and strength of those already employed,  were very inadequate to the duties devolving upon them.  About this time, Mr. Angas,' one of the Committee in Em-  gland, was deputed to visit the mission in Jamaica. Mr.  Whitehorne's case was submitted to him, and he iully acquiesced in the proposal, that he should at once proceed to occupy some Station. This was entirely approved of by the  Society in England. Mr. Whitehorne was ordained at Falmouth, April the 1st, 1834, and returned to take full charge  of the Stations at Rio Bueno and Stewart's Town, where he  had been labouring for a short time before.  Mr.Abbott, who was ordained at Montego Bay on the 4th  of the same month, was formerly a member of the Baptist  church at Taunton, in Somersetshire, England. Me had been  requested by the church, in 1827, to direct his attention to  the ministry, and was about to enter the Academy at Bristol, for that purpose ; when an attack of illness rendered it  advisable for him to suspend all such engagements, and  repair, without delay, to a warmer climate, lie proceeded  to Jamaica, where he landed, April the 1st, 1828, and  finding the climate very favourable to his health, he determined  to   continue,   and entered   on  a   commercial   eu- 	asc99990010170046001											56445046 Bytes	3488	5392	2137937918	RGB	asc99990010170046001.tif		2013-08-12	2013-08-12	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5820	5820	5821.jp2	/scbooks/image/5821.jp2
Page 47																																asc9999001017		22  gagement, which proved highly advantageous in a temporal  point of view. Such, however, was the prejudice that existed  against missionaries, and so confidently were statements circulated to their disadvantage, that many months passed away  before Mr. A. felt disposed to seek any intercourse with them.  At length he visited the Baptist chapel at Falmouth, and  quickly found how unjust were the ideas he had been taught  to cherish respecting the missionaries, lie sought a connexion  with ihe church, then under the pastoral care of Mr. Knibb,  was received as a member, and sometime after renounced a  lucrative employment that he might engage in the ministry of  the gospel amongst a people he had previously avoided.  After his ordination he proceeded to take charge of the  Stations at Lucea, and Green Island, where he continued to  labour with encouraging success till December, 1831.  These Stations had been commenced by the General Bap-  tist Missionaries, who had now relinquished their mission jo  Jamaica, and the building belonging; to them at Lucea was  rented by our missionary, Mr. Abbott. But while the mission  was thus re-enforced by labourers raised up on the spot, it  was also called to sustain some heavy bereavements this  year, in the death of two missionaries, and the departure of  several, on account of ill health.  On the 7Ji of April, Mr. Cantlow sailed for England, his  medical adviser assuring him that his immediate return was  necessary for the preservation of life. Providentially for his  church, Mr. Kingdon, formerly a student at Bristol, who had  come to Jamaica for change of climate, in December, 1830,  kindly consented, at the request of the missionaries, to stay  and superintend Mr. Cantlow's Station, till his return.  Circumstances, however, over which he had no con-  troul, rendered his departure also necessary in about three  months—he sailed on the 1st of August, leaving the church  at Crooked Spring under the care of Mr. Knibb.  We have previously observed that the church in East  Queen Street was chiefly supplied by Mr. Coultart after Mr.  Burton resigned it ; but as Mr. C's. health was greatly impaired, he could not think of resuming the Station, and application was made to the Committee in England to send out a  suitable person to take the oversight of the church. Mr. John  Shoveller, junior, who had been along time usefully employed  as a minister of the gospel in England, and was much respected  in the denomination, being desirous of engaging in missionary work, offered his services toihe Committee, he was thank- 	asc99990010170047001											62759238 Bytes	3816	5480	595933934	RGB	asc99990010170047001.tif		2013-08-12	2013-08-12	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5821	5821	5822.jp2	/scbooks/image/5822.jp2
Page 48																																asc9999001017		23  Hilly accepted, and desired to proceed as early as possible to  Kingston, to take the church in blast Queen Street, lie was  designated as a missionary in Meeting-House Alley, Portsea,  February the 23d, 1831. lie sailed shortly after, and arrived  in Kingston April the30th. Mr. Coultart was preparing to leave  the Island, and Mr. S. entered on his important and arduous  duties almost immediately. lie enjoyed good health, was  greatly delighted with his prospects of usefulness, and very  soon a large addition was made to the church of upwards of  one hundred and fifty, to whom he administered the ordinance  of Baptism. He commenced a week evening lecture, in which  he endeavoured to render science subservient to religion, with  a view of benefitting the more intelligent part of the community. This lecture was well attended; many, who on no other  occasion would enter a Dissenting chapel, crowded to hear  it ; but before he bad matured his plans of usefulness, it  pleased the Great Head of the church to take him from this  land of sin and death, to those abodes of purity and joy, in  which the inhabitant shall never say I am sick. He was attacked with fever about the 9th of December, and died on the  12th, and on the morrow his mortal remains were interred in the  vault of the chapel, East Queen Street, where a few days before he had preached the Gospel of Salvation to a listening  multitude, many of whom were then sorrowing that they  should see his face no more. His death was without extacy,  but tranquil and happy; with a calm and holy confidence in  the finished work of the Redeemer, he rested wholly on Him in  whom he had believed, assured that he was able to keep him  in the last conflict; and though walking through the Valley of  the shadow of death, he feared no evil, for his rod and his staff  they comforted him.  May the 17th Mr. Burchell was compelled to visit England  for a season, partly wiih a view to settle some family affairs,  intending to return as early as possible. He left his church  at Montego-Bay, principally under the care of Mr. Gardner,  who supplied it in connexion with Messrs. Knibb and Kingdon ; and Mr. Abbott took the oversight of the church at  Gurney's Mount.  About this time Mr Burton, who had gone to reside at  Manchioneal, formed a church there of 78 members, chiefly  connected with the churches in Kingston , but unable to attend for religious worship. During this year Mr. Nichojs extended his labours to  Brown'sTown, a new settlement in the interior, about seventeen  miles from St. Ann's Bay ; he met with much encouragement,  obtained premises, opened them for religious worship, and in  June formed a church of forty-four members ; twenty four  dismissed from St. Ann's Bay, one from Falmouth, and nineteen  baptized at the Station.  But while the hearts of the missionaries were cheered bv the  success which attended their labours, they were called to  mourn the death of a promising coadjutor, Mr. John Griffith,  who was only permitted to look on the field of labour, and  taken to join the assembly of the blessed. He had been a  member of the church in Cannon Street, Birmingham, where  he was de^gnated to missionary service, February the 21th,  ]831, and sailed May the 20th.
