But notwithstanding this diminution of labourers, prosperity continued to attend every department of the  mission up to i he end of the year, when the awful catastrophe  which will be detailed In the following pages, took place.—  Large additions had been made, or were about to be made,  to most of the churches. A new chapel at Salter's Hill was  ready for opening, other Stations were being formed, and  every missionary's time and strength were taxed to the utmost, in the delightful employment of"publishings  perishing sinners.  tion to 	asc99990010170049001											62535304 Bytes	3808	5472	3758336668	RGB	asc99990010170049001.tif		2013-08-12	2013-08-12	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5823	5823	5824.jp2	/scbooks/image/5824.jp2
Page 50																																asc9999001017		CHAPTER IT..  Commencement of the Rebellion.—Mr. Knibb deprecates it, in writing, to Messrs.  Abbott and Whitehorne.—Mr. Whitehorne warns his people against it.— Report  of "free-paper" having arrived, contradicted by Mr. Knibb and his Deacons.—  On Chistmas Day Mr. Gardner preaches against insubordination. — Reason of  the small attendance at our Chapels on that day.—Mr. Knibb unites with Mr.  Blyth to undeceive the NegToes.— Assembling of several Ministers in the disturbed districts accounted for.—Their .efforts, at the opening of Salter's Hill  Chapel, to remove the false impression..—Their efforts and circumstances at  Falmouth.—They are required to enlist in the Militia.—Messrs. Knibb, Abbott,  and Whitehorne arrested and sent to head quarters.—Anxiety of their wives.—  Their cruel treatment while under arrest.—Their release on bail.  1  In this flourishing state of our mission, God was pleased to  permit an event to take place, which materially interrupted  its progress, by exciting a furious persecution. The enmi(y  of nearly all the white inhabitants of this country against religion had long been en flamed by our success, and only a pretext was wanting to attempt the banishment of every faithful  minister from the land. At length this pretext was found—a  fearful rebellion broke out among the slaves—and the enemies of God lost no time in denouncing the missionaries as  its principal cause, and raising against them the popular; fury.  All Evangelical ministers have been charged with some participation in this crime, for the Christian ministry itself, not  the men, has formed the real object of hatred ; but as we  merely undertake to tell our own tale, the following statement will be nearly confined to circumstances relating to ourselves.  rl he first ofour missionaries, who received intelligence of even  a suspected rebellion, was Mr. Knibb, stationed at Falmouth,  and at that time also supplying the pulpit at Crooked Spring,  vacated by the absence of Mr. Cantlow, in England. lie  was informed, that on Friday, December 18, 1831, the negroes on Salt Spring estate, near Montego-Bay, shewed  symptoms of insubordination. He quickly communicated Ihis  information, in terms severely censuring such conduct, to Mr.  Abbott, at Lucea, by whom the report was entirely discredited ;  and also to Mr. Whitehorne, at. Stewart's Town,*who noticed  the circumstance to his congregation at that place on the following Sabbath.    After the regular sermon,.a large concourse  D 	asc99990010170050001											56056098 Bytes	3464	5392	3844944409	RGB	asc99990010170050001.tif		2013-08-12	2013-08-12	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5824	5824	5825.jp2	/scbooks/image/5825.jp2
Page 51																																asc9999001017		26  of slaves, together with several Tree persons, being present as  usual, Mr. W. most earnestly entreated the people, if such rebellious proceedings were really going on, not to engage in them;  and urged the most solemn reasons to dissuade them from  such a course. On Saturday, December 24, Stephen James, a  slave on Chatham estate, Trelawny, went to Mr. Knibb, at  Falmouth, and informed him that the people were saying,  •" Free-paper was come out, and they would not work after  Christinas/' Mr. Knibb, together with Lewis Williams, (a  tree black), and Thomas Levermore, (a free coloured person), deacons of the Falmouth church, had much conversation with him about this matter. At first the man seemed  quite convinced the report was correct; but being undeceived  by their assurances to the contrary, he said " he would go  home and tell the people that Mr. Knibb had contradicted  the report, and that they must return to their work after the  holidays, or else they would be excluded from the church."—  He did this, and it is believed his statement had the effect of  undeceiving the other negroes on the estate, and preventing  their revolt. On Sunday the 25th, in consequence of this  information from the Chatham negro, and the rumours which  were afloat, Mr. Knibb called a church-meeting at Falmouth,  and addressed the members on the subject. He plainly contradicted the report of the u free-paper" having arrived, and  strenuously exhorted them to return quietly to their work after Christmas, and influence others to do the same—urging  on them Christian motives to obedience. On the same forenoon, Mr, Gardner called the attention of his congregation  at Montego-Bay to this matter, by addressing them on the  good fruits which religion required from its professors. His  text, Lukexiii. G, afforded him ample scope; and he applied it  as much as possible to the circumstances then existing,—urging on the slaves the great importance of their bringing forth  fruit corresponding with their Christian profession and privileges—and insisting especially on the duty of obedience to  their masters, and the avoidance of every thing like insubordi-  •nation. So pointed was his discourse, that Robert Gardner,  afterwards colonel of the rebels, expressed to one of the  deacons of the church his determination to return to his  work peaceably after Christmas, in consequence of what he  then heard. According to his confession to Mr. Watson,  Presbyterian minister of Lucea, he was afterwards prevailed  on, though reluctantly, to change his mind, and take a leading part in the rebellion. When in prison he said to Mr.  Gardner, alluding to tlii's sermon, "\our word melt we? we no  hold up our head." 	asc99990010170051001											62678802 Bytes	3800	5496	1722529474	RGB	asc99990010170051001.tif		2013-08-12	2013-08-12	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5825	5825	5826.jp2	/scbooks/image/5826.jp2
Page 52																																asc9999001017		In this manner the missionaries situated near the seat of the  threatened evil, endeavoured, to I he best of their power and  influence* to avert it. But it was matter of regret to them,  that the attendance at their chapels on that Sabbath was  comparatively small, because it. being Christmas Day, the people were detained at home by their managers, to receive their  Christmas allowance; which, they say, they were told they  would forfeit, if they did not go themselves to receive it.  This they believe was designedly done, to prevent their attendance at chapel. Happily for the missionaries,, therefore, if the good effect of their warning addresses was circum*  scribed, the fault is not chargeable on them.  On Monday the 26th, Mr. Blyth, Presbyterian missionary,  called on Mr. Knibb, in Falmouth, to converse with him  about this apprehended evil, which had now assumed a very  serious aspect, and become matter of notoriety, and alarm.  Mr. Blyth remarked " that there was pressing danger, and that  nothing hut their united efforts could avert theevtt in their district—that the slaves were impressed with the belief that  their freedom had been sent from England." Mr. Knibb expressed his willingness to assist in every way possible, to prevent the evil anticipated. Mr. Blyth said he had been endeavouring to undeceive the negroes at Orange Valley, (an  estate which he visits, and on which he has a number of  members), but they refused credence to him ; and he had then  asked them if they would believe Mr. Knibb, to which they  replied in the affirmative—so that he had called to request  Mr. Knibb to let him make use of his name. Mr. Knibb readily assented, and even offered to go with him on the estate,  though he had an engagement at Montego-Bay. Mr. Blyth  thinking it would be sufficient to make use of Mr. Knibb's  name, the latter proposed to send Lewis Williams (already  mentioned) on one of his own horses, with the joint messages  of himself and Mr. Blyth, to their people on Orange Valley  and other estates. Mr. Blyth highly approving of this plan,,  it was instantly executed.  In the evening of this day, Messrs. Knibb, Whitehorne-,,  Gardner, and Abbott, met at Montego-Bay, on their way to  Salter's Hill, where a new chapel was to be opened on the  following morning. Mr. Nichols, from St.,Ann's Bay, would  have been with them, had not illness prevented his travelling  farther than Falmouth. We understand that the circumstance  of several missionaries assembling in the heart of the disturbed  district, at this critical time, excited suspicion of their having  had some share in concerting the plot, To remove this suspicion, it is only necessary to observe, that they met in pui&gt;  i) 2 	asc99990010170052001											55503878 Bytes	3440	5376	1261559836	RGB	asc99990010170052001.tif		2013-08-12	2013-08-12	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5826	5826	5827.jp2	/scbooks/image/5827.jp2
Page 53																																asc9999001017		■HHBBHHHBHnH  OQ.  stianee of a resolution passed nearly three months before, at  a Quarterly Union meeting, held at Falmouth, fixing Tuesday in the Christmas week for the opening of the chapel,  because that was the anniversary of the laying of the foundation stone.  Early in the morning of Tuesday the 27th December, the  day appointed at that meeting, the missionaries proceeded to  Salter's Hill, eight miles from Montego-Bay, to engage in the  interesting service of dedicating a new building to the worship  'of God. They diligently availed themselves of this opportu -  jiity of conversing with the negroes, to counteract the dangerous consequences likely to result from their mistaken notion about the " (ree paper." For this purpose Mr. Knibb,  in particular, went among them very much, taking with him  Mr. Samuel James Vaughan, a deacon of the church at  Montego-Bay, that they might not possibly misunderstand  what he said. A large congregation assembled, and Mr.  Gardner preached a sermon appropriate to the occasion,  from the words, u And there they preached the gospel." In  speaking of the effects produced by the gospel, he introduced  some strong and plain remarks,, bearing on the reported evil  intentions of the slaves, and wholly condemning them; and  in concluding his discourse, exhorted them to walk worthy  of the gospel—appealing to the reciprocal affection existing  between them and their absent pastor—and reminding them  of the obligations to holiness under which they were laid by  their high profession and their hope of eternal happiness.—  Mr. Knibb being their temporary pastor, and better known  to them than the other missionaries present, it was agreed  lhat he should deliver an address to the slaves, more directly  on the subject of the expected revolt. After the sermon he  accordingly addressed them from the pulpit, nearly as follows :—  "My dear hearers, and especially those of you who con -  si an tly attend at the chapel, and are members of Crooked  Spring, or other Baptist churches, pay great attention to  what I am about to say. It is now seven years since I left  England to preach the gospel to yon; and when I came, [  made up my mind to live and die to promote your spiritual welfare. Never did i enter the pulpit with such painful feelings  as at present. Till yesterday I had hoped that God had  blessed my poor labours, and the labours of your dear mU  luster, now in England for his health, who loves you and  prays for yon, and who tells me that he hopes soon to return  to you. But I am pained to the soul to hear that many of  you have agreed not to go to your work after Christmas ; and 	asc99990010170053001											63349542 Bytes	3824	5520	3342787800	RGB	asc99990010170053001.tif		2013-08-12	2013-08-12	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5827	5827	5828.jp2	/scbooks/image/5828.jp2
Page 54																																asc9999001017		29  Hear it is too true. I learn that some wicked persons have  persuaded you that the King has made you free. Hear me,  I love your souls.—1 would not tell you a lie for the world.  What you have been told is false—false as hell can make it.  ] entreat you not to believe it, but go to your work as usual.  If you have any love to Jesus Christ, to religion, to your ministers, to those kind friends in England who have given money to help you to build this chapel, be not led away by  wicked men. You are too ready to listen to and believe  what they tell you, instead of coming to your minister, who  you know will tell you the truth. God commands you to be  obedient to your master; if you do as he commands, you  may expect his blessing; but if you do not, he will call you to  an account for it at the Judgment day. If you refuse to  work, and are punished, you will suffer justly; and every  friend you have must and will turn his back upon you."  Mr. Knibb spoke in this strain for about half an hour.—  Much dissatisfaction was manifested by some of the slaves at  this address, and many murmurs were heard. This plain contradiction of their error—this sudden dashing of their fond  hopes of freedom—overcame their patience, and called forth  the bad passions of their nature. They said that M Parson  Knibb had no business to meddle with the free paper—that  the white people had bribed Mr. Blyth to tell lie, and that  Mr, Blyth had given Mr, Knibb half the money to keep free-  paper from them" So angry were they with Mr. Knibb, for this  interference to frustrate their intentions, that they declared  they would have maltreated him, had he not had so many  ministers with him. Having remained at the chapel an hour  or two after the service, exhorting the people to resume  their work, the missionaries returned to Montego-Bay, pained  at heart to observe the little good effect their remonstrances  were likely to produce, and dreading what might occur on  the morrow.—On that night the burning of properties commenced.  On Wednesday the 28th, the rest of the party urged Mr.  Gardner to return home to Savanna-la-Mar, to prevent the  danger to Mrs. Gardner's life, which, from her critical situation, alarm on his account might cause her, when she should  hear of the rebellion. He complied with their wish ; and  the same forenoon, having first consulted M r. John Manderson,  a gentleman of property and a magistrate of Montego-Bay, as  to the safety of travelling through the interior, proceeded on  his journey. The others returned to Falmouth, among whom  were Mr. and Mrs. Abbott; the appearances of danger in the  interior, presented this day, having compelled him to abandon  mm 	asc99990010170054001											55715218 Bytes	3448	5384	1643153065	RGB	asc99990010170054001.tif		2013-08-12	2013-08-12	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5828	5828	5829.jp2	/scbooks/image/5829.jp2
Page 55																																asc9999001017		30  the idea of performing his intended duties at Shepherd's Hall,  on the ensuing Sabbath.  At Falmouth the missionaries had frequent opportunities of  discountenancing the rebellion, which had now furiously  broken out ; and there also they experienced no ordinary  portion of mental suffering. Just about the time of their arrival, three slaves from Green Park estate, named Joseph  Henry, James Virgo, and Lewis Atherton, members of the  Falmouth church, brought down from York two rebels, whom  they had captured while attempting to burn Green Park.—  Henry and Virgo went to Mr. Knibb, and related this circumstance; stating that the magistrates had rewarded them with a  doubloon, and given them a pair of handcuffs, with authority  to go and do the like again if necessary. They asked him  whether they had done right, as they had been taunted for  faking up their own colour, by some irreligious negroes,  who said they did it for money. Mr. Knibb commended their  conduct, and strongly urged them to go on defending their  master's property, and capture as many rebels as they could.  ■—This evening a special prayer-meeting for the Divine interposition to restore peace, was held at the Wesleyan chapel;  when the Presbyterian, Wesleyan, and Baptist missionaries  united in prayer. A meeting for the same purpose was  held at the Baptist chapel the next evening.—During the  remainder ofthe week, the missionaries exerted all their influence to induce their people to be quiet and mind their work. Mr.  Knibb sent a message by Mr. Waddell, Presbyterian missionary, to his people on Carlton estate, under the attorneyship  of Robert Cron, Esq. and they saved the property. As opportunities offered he likewise sent messages to other properties, and otherwise exerted himselfsuccessfully. A slave from  Arcadia estate, named J. M'Anuff, or Nicholas Brodie, who  had gone to Falmouth, as he stated, with the luggage of one  of his managers, called on Mr. Whitehorne, his minister, and  w7as urged to be faithful. Another from Lancaster, named  William Simpson, called on him ; who was in like manner  exhorted to constancy, and told that the whole report of the  free-paper having arrived was untrue.  While thus exerting themselves to promote the public  peace, solicitude for the ark of God, and anxiety for their  own safety, led them earnestly to implore divine aid.  The week' now under review, was to them truly memorable ;  its vicissitudes, its forebodings, its anxieties, and its supports,  have leit, an impression on their hearts which time can never  efface. There were together at Mr. Knibb's house, himself and  Mi:s. Knibb, Mr, and Mrs.. Abbott, Mr.'and Mrs. Whitehorne* 	asc99990010170055001											62364910 Bytes	3792	5480	2720149242	RGB	asc99990010170055001.tif		2013-08-12	2013-08-12	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5829	5829	5830.jp2	/scbooks/image/5830.jp2
Page 56																																asc9999001017		31  Mr Samuel Whitehorne (from Kingston), and Mr. and Mrs.  Nichols—in all nine —occasionally joined by Mr. and Mrs.  Waddell, and Mr. Box. The circumstances of the country  rendered travelling so dangerous, that they were precluded  from separating, though some of the brethren anxiously desired to visit their respective stations on the ensuing Sabbath.  For seven days, therefore, this Christian party continued unbroken, and was then dissolved only by the hand of power.—■  . Doubtless it was a kind dispensation that they were thus thrown  together, when Christian counsel and sympathy were so  much needed. At this time all was confusion abroad. The  families of proprietors, overseers, and others from the country, were hurrying into town for safety ;—military expresses  were hastening in all directions ;—and repeatedly large bodies  of slave-prisoners of both sexes, taken in rebellion, or suspected of rebellion, passed Mr. Knibb's residence on their  way to the Guard-house. Perplexing reports were continually brought to the missionaries that thei/ were blamed as the  promoters of the mischief;—that all the captured negroes  were closely questioned whether their minister had not told  them they were to be free at Christmas;—and especially that  a full determination was manifested to implicate Mr. Knibb,  as the resident minister. They knew their innocence,  but they knew also the probable power of promises or  intimidation to elicit from the unhappy prisoners statements  which were untrue. Such reports, therefore, could not fail  to induce a lively solicitude respecting the event, especially  in the case of Mr. Knibb, whose family of three small children added much to the weight of his own care, and excited the  tenderest concern of his friends. But they remembered there  was Onk who knew the heart, and restrained the wrath of  man, and to Him their eyes were directed.  At length the dreaded day came when Martial Law was  proclaimed, which took place at Falmouth on Saturday, December 31. To this exent the missionaries, and especially  their wives, had looked forward with deep interest; expecting  that, when ail power was transferred from the civil to the  military authorities, their rancorous enemies would take advantage of this opportunity, either to place them in the front of  the battle, or, on very slight grounds of crimination, to subject  them to the unceremonious decision of a Court-martial. The  first intimation of martial law was given them by a soldier,  who went into Mr. Knibb's yard, and seized a saddle for the  King's service. From this hour' they were not certain for a  moment but that their own persons might be required, nominally and professedly for the same service, but really  for the 	asc99990010170056001											55198388 Bytes	3416	5384	3678417989	RGB	asc99990010170056001.tif		2013-08-12	2013-08-12	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5830	5830	5831.jp2	/scbooks/image/5831.jp2
Page 57																																asc9999001017		32  gratification of their enemies' malignity. Again, therefore,  they betook themselves to the word of God and prayer, entreating to be prepared for the unknown result.  Nothing further transpired that day, and on the following,  which Was Lord's day, January 1st, two public prayer-meetings were held in the chapel, at seven and eleven o'clock, A.  M. to implore the restoration ofpublic tranquillity, theguidance  and protection of the military, and the preservation of slaves  professing religion from uniting in the rebellion. During the  forenoon service, Mr. Knibb addressed the congregation in a  very solemn and pathetic strain, contradicting the report respecting freedom, and warning and entreating the slaves to  continue faithful and diligent. Just after this service, Mr.  Denoon, a non-commissioned officer, with four privates, regularly armed with fixed bayonets, went to Mr. Knibb's house,  with orders to conduct the missionaries immediately to the  Guard-house, to enlist in the militia. Messrs. Nichols and  Whitehorne, the only two who had reached home, promptly  obeyed, and under this escort proceeded to the Court-house.  This officer behaved with great civility, particularly to Messrs.  Knibb and Abbott, whom he afterwards met in the street,  and requested to go to the Court houseby themselves, while he  and his men proceeded on other duty. After waiting in the  officers apartment of the Guard-house, evidently to the satisfaction of those gentlemen, an hour and upwards, to see Colonel Cadien, Major Nelson thanked them for attending so  promptly, and merely requested them to shew themselves  there at eleven o'clock every day, by way of good example, to  others, till orders might be received from Sir W. Cotton, the  Commander in Chief, deciding how they were to be disposed  of. Thus dismissed they returned home, to the great joy of  their partners, and numerous friends, who had collected about  the house, anxious to know what was to be done with the  ministers. The next day they went to the Court-house at  the appointed hour, but then the scene was changed. Having  again waited a -full hour, the Colonel told them u they had  heller join themselves to some company /" They were astonished at this suggestion, afier what had transpired the day before ; especially as no intimation was given of any orders respecting them having been received from the Commander  in Chief. However, they did not refuse, but simply remarked " they presumed they were liable to serve, from having  been so called upon ; but they had always been under the impression that all ministers of the gospel were exempt." Being  told they must serve, Mr. Abbott joined the Artillery, and  Mr.   Knibb   the   4th   Company,    under   Captain Chrystie. 	asc99990010170057001											63125284 Bytes	3816	5512	1853424817	RGB	asc99990010170057001.tif		2013-08-12	2013-08-12	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5831	5831	5832.jp2	/scbooks/image/5832.jp2
Page 58																																asc9999001017		S3  Mr. Whitehorne claimed the rank he had formerly held  in the militia, and was desired to send for his Captain's  commission; and Mr. Nichols, on account of ill health,  was granted a passport to return to St. Ann's Bay.—  Messrs. Knibb and Abbott, having first been commended to  the Divine protection went on guard at five o'clock that afternoon, as required. Mr. Knibb was allowed to return home,  being unwell, but Mr. Abbott spent three hours of the night  (from ten till one) in pacing about as a sentry^ and the remainder in trying to take rest on a table in the Guard*house) vexed  with the filthy conversation of the wicked.  Tuesday, January 3, was a still more eventful day. Deeply  impressed with the incompatibility of taking up arms with the  ministry of the gospel, they had drawn up a memorial to his  Excellency the Governor, praying for exemption from military service \ and had given it to the Colonel, for his inspection, previously to sending it to Spanish-Town. While anxiously waiting for his opinion, which was promised that forenoon, Captain Paul Doig, with his drawn sword, attended by  two armed blacks, went up to Mr. Knibb, who was on duty  at the Guard-house, and said, u Take this man into custody—■  this is all he has got by preaching /" Captain Chrystie somewhat more politely required Mr. Abbott to deliver up his  sword, and stated u that the Colonel had ordered him to put  him under arrest /" Both Were placed in the ball-room, then  used as a barrack, under a sentry. Mr. Whitehorne, hearing  of their confinement, went to them, and was himself detained  by the sentry, u by orders," as he said. In an hour or two  after, Captain Chrystie officially stated, " that the Colonel  had received such intelligence from Mont ego Bay, as had  induced him to decide on forwarding them to head quarters  ■—for which purpose a conveyance would be ready in half an  hour." They asked permission to see their wives for a few  minutes, or to write to them, but were refused. They were  merely allowed to set down on paper a list of articles required in the canoe,—(for this was the conveyance provided,)  1—and to send a message, requesting their wives to proceed to  Montego Bay by h*nd.—-When these scraps of paper and  hasty messages were received, the females were thrown into  great hurry and alarm. This was a stroke they had not anticipated ; and their being unable to obtain any correct account of the nature of the charges laid against their husbands^  greatly increased their anxiety. One of them indeed, remarked, that while she felt it to be a heavy trial, she preferred the present crisis to the continual anxiety of having her  gi 	asc99990010170058001											55503892 Bytes	3440	5376	4150530352	RGB	asc99990010170058001.tif		2013-08-12	2013-08-12	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5832	5832	5833.jp2	/scbooks/image/5833.jp2

With indescribable solicitude they  hastily prepared for their journey, and about noon proceeded  to Montego-Bay. As they entered that town, their already  agonized feelings met with another severe shock, in witnessing the dead body of a negro, covered with ball wounds and  blood; and they were soon told that the next day the missionaries would share the same fate.—At about half past eleven  A. M. (their pockets having been previously searched for  arms I) these persecuted men were marched through the  town of Falmouth, to a wharf at some distance, under a military guard of a serjeant and four privates, duly armed, accompanied by a considerable concourse of people, both  friends and foes. On their embarking in the canoe, an Artillery ofhcer of the militia, mounted on some elevation,  Waved his hat, and -vainly tried to raise a cheer at their departure; but a perfect stillness was preserved. This was  about twenty minutes before twelve—the canoe was open, and  they were unprotected from the meridian sun. A7o charge had  heen alleged against them, and the cause of this grievous treatment they knew not, further than the general clamour of their having promoted the rebellion. This uncertainty greatly augmented their sufferings, seeing they were  unable to calculate on their approaching situation, beyond  the rational expectation of as much ignominious pain as their  malignant foes might dare to inflict. By their guard they were  treated civilly, but were annoyed by the frequent use of lan^  gmige revolting to a Christian mind. Having spent seven  hours in this open canoe, they reached Montego-Bay, where  a scene of great horror presented itself. The houses which  had so recently adorned the neighbouring hills were now in  flames, and the confusion and noise of war prevailed. Two  men of war were lyingnear the town, and guard-b jats were [dying  about; and, at a little distance up the land, flashes of musketry  were seen, announcing that the angel of death was abroad.—•  On their landing, at seven o'clock at night,, they were first  marched to the Court-house^ under their armed guard as before^  and then to the lodgings of Sir WiUoughby Cotton, (he Major-  General, situated exactly opposite the house which their afflicted  wives had reached some hours before. While they waited  in the street before his door, full half an hour, their wives  came out to see them, bringing a little brandy and water, as  they had taken no food since the morning. On entering the Court-house, the  officers and men surrounded them, tittering the most horrible  execrations, literally gnashing upon them with their teeth,  and glorying in the hope of glutting themselves with their  blood, which they declared would be shed on the morrow.—-  The missionaries soon discovered here, that they were considered answerable for the crimes of the slaves —crimes in  which they had had no participation, and which they had used  their best exertions to prevent. Mr.  Abbott was feeling a severe pain in his back, heightened above  its usual degree by fatigue and anxiety; he mentioned this  to Mr. Whitehorne, and wished to shut the window behind  him ; when this man, pointing his bayonet at Mr. Abbott,  said, "HoJd your tongue, yon rascal; don't speak to that other  prisoner again, or I'll give you the bayonet ; and 1 won't  speak to yon twice either, you villain." In the presence oi  such a man, they dared not attempt to refresh, themselves with  either food or sleep ; but rested their heads on a liar which  was before them, endeavouring to compose their minds to their  situation till the morning, But it was not the will of God that  they should spend the night in this place; for between ten  and eleven o'clock, a deliverer, whom He had most unexpectedly  provided, went to their aid. This was a gentleman named  JJoby, Collector of his Majesty's Customs at that port, an old  acquaintance of Mr. \\ hitehorne's, who, hearing of his impri*  sonment, hastened a( that late hour to his assistance. He  made his way into the jury-box, and presenting his hand,  kindly oiTered to do ^hate\er he could to make his situation  more comfortable, and to obtain his release ; observing;, how-  ever, that he did not wish to interfere with the course of justice, if the missionaries had beet! guilty of any crime. The intoxication  of some, the violent wrangling of others, the horrid impreca*  at ions of ail—-officers as well as men—the discordant buzz of  voices, of every tone, harmonising only in the utteranqeof oaths  and curses—all these mingling with (he loud military calls and  commands, and the clang of arms, produced an effect most appalling. It was so horrible to these missionaries particularly as  their minds were much employed in the contemplation of  eternity, which seemed on the eve of opening upon them, and in  prayer to 'hat threat Being whom they expected soon to behold,  {hat they could not renins, the agor;Uii)g reflection; « What at} 	asc99990010170061001											62731762 Bytes	3829	5459	2746498617	RGB	asc99990010170061001.tif		2013-08-12	2013-08-12	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5835	5835	5836.jp2	/scbooks/image/5836.jp2
Page 62																																asc9999001017		37  awful hell it would be, to be obliged merely to view this scene  for ever! but how unspeakably dreadful, to be an associate in  such abominable wickedness !" At length, after indefatigable  exertion, Mr. Roby obtained an order for their release for the  night; and at twelve o'clock conducted them from that awful  scene of impiety and cruelty to a grateful asylum at the Custom-house. Thankful indeed were they to their Heavenly  Father, for this providential deliverance from such society ;  and they saw further cause for thankfulness, when afterwards  assured by a gentleman, who visited the place about two o'clock  in the morning, that it had then become so bad that their lives  would certainly have been sacrificed, had they remained there  till that hour 1 Early next morning Mr Roby visited their  wives, for the purpose of relieving their anxiety, and of conducting them to their husbands ; and at his office they all had  the unexpected happiness of once more breakfasting together.  Yet their anxieties, as to what this day might bring forth,  were still very intense; their enemies having repeatedly told  them they would be shot or hanged? and they themselves  being unapprised of the ground on which they had been arrested. But just after breakfast they were further relieved,  when their kind and active friend, Mr. Roby, presented them  with the following document, which he had procured froir^  Mr. Custos Barrett:—  The Major General having placed William Knibb, William Whitehorne, and T. Abbott at my disposal, arid there being no specific information lodged against them, I have determined that they shall be  released, cm condition that, each of them find a security to the amount  of £.50 that be will not leave the town of Montego-Bay, and will be  ready to appear when called on —the security to be entered into before  any Magistrate.  (Signed) RICHARD BARRETT, Custos.  Montego-Bay, Jan. 4th, 1832.  While perusing this gratifying document, their hind friend',  Mr. Manderson, whose services were now peculiarly needed^  made his appearance. This gentleman and Mr. Roby at  once tendered their security for Messrs. Page 63																																asc9999001017		w  CHAPTER III.  Mr. Gardner's reasons for/Icaving Savanna-la-Mar.—On his journey he falls  gmong the Rebels, and ts compelled to return.—He is arrested at Savanna-la-  Mar, and taken prisoner to Montego-Bay, but released on bail.—Arrival of  Mr. Burchell.—His imprisonment onboard the Blanche and Gailand-Grove,  \ —His discharge, and intention of departing for America. - He and Mr. Gardner  are apprehended, and committed to gaol at Montego-Bay.  On Tuesday, January 3d, the same day that Mr. Knibb and  his companions wereuirrested at Falmouth, Mr, Gardner set  out from Savanna-la-Mar, for Montego-Bay ; and the adventures of his journey, being of such a nature as to have created  unpleasant suspicions respecting his motives for taking it, we  are required to state his reasons for leaving home, During  Mr. Burcheli's absence in England, Mr. Gardner, as has been  stated, divided his labours between Savanna la-Mar and Montego-Bay; and having preached at the former place on the  preceding Sabbath (January 1st), the usual time had re*  turned for his going to the latter. Besides this expectation of preaching, he was desirous of seeing Mr, Jjurebelt as  soon as he could after his arrival, which had been for some  days expected5; indeed he did not know but he might have  arrived already, lie was ignorant of the real state ot things,  both at Montego-Bay, and on the road s. he knew not, tnr ex-  ample, that the chapel had been converted into barracks ■  nor that the high road between that (dace and Savanna-da Mar  "was occupied by the rebels, in consequence oi the militia having abandoned their posts, Influenced, therefore, by such  reasons as would at any other time have induced him to leave  home, and not knowing that any obstacles to travelling existed on the road, he started on his journey at nine A.M. on the  forementioned day. The following narrative of this day's ad-,  ventures, committed to writing by himself, shortly after their  occurrence, will be read, with interest.  "I left Savanna-la-Mar at nine o'clock onTvtesday morning  Janupry 3d, (or Montego-Bay. J saw nothing wrong till I  came to Haddo, which was smoking; 1 saw two or three ne-^  groes sitting about, but said nothing to them. On pursuing  my course, I saw Mackiield in ruins—no smoke was issuing  from it    At Hambie, Mrs. Hudson afterwards told me it was 	asc99990010170063001											62929998 Bytes	3832	5472	3041338996	RGB	asc99990010170063001.tif		2013-08-12	2013-08-12	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5837	5837	5838.jp2	/scbooks/image/5838.jp2
Page 64																																asc9999001017		fired on Monday, in the middle of the day. I drove on t'M  J came in sight of Knockalva, before I felt myself in any danger. As 1 approached the gate, 1 saw a great number of negroes on the hill, armed with maschettes, making way towards  me. This excited my fears, and immediately I set my horsed  off at full gallop. Upon coming up to a gap in the wall, near  the gate, a negro came over with a cutlass, and cut at the  traces of the outrigger horse, and at me, but missed ; he  canght the bridle of the horse on which the boy was riding,  but the horse pulled him down, so the boy escaped ;■ he still  pursued me, and others were behind him. A gun was fired I  believe as a signal. 1 soon came up to Ramble, where was a  free brown woman, named Hudson, who knew me and came  out at the gate to stop me ; but in consequence of being exceedingly alarmed, 1 continued driving at full speed. The  negroes were still running after rne. Mrs.1 Hudson interceded  for me, saying 1 was ' Parson Gardner,' and did not wish to  injure them. By her intreaties they were prevailed on to say  they would not hart me. She requested a negro, who was  mounted on a very good horse, to follow me, and hail me, and  desire me to return. This she told me afterwards. 1 continued driving most furiously till I came to (he middle of  Burnt Ground, when 1 heard the negro call me by name, and  say, if 1 went forward I should be killed, but if I returned they  would protect me. I stopped my horses and asked, ' Who told  you my name f He said, * The brown lady;' I replied *I  must go to the Bay, and cannot return ;' he continued urging  me to return, but I drove on. I had not driven many yards,  before I saw a black company near Burnt Ground gate,  armed in the same way as the negroes I had passed. A gun  was fired—my boy urged me to return, saying, 'They are negroes, we shall be killed massa/ I think there must have  been two hundred in number. Upon this 1 got out of my  chaise and turned my horses, (could not sitting), and hailed  the negro who had called me ; upon which he pulled up hi-s  horse. 1 asked him to come to me; he said Ire could not. I  said, 'Stop, and 1 will come to you ;' but he walked his hors-e  slowly before me, till some of his companions came up. Then  they came close, and spoke very friendlyf and said, ' Don't  fraid, massa, we no hurt you \ we no know you when you pass \  we have not seen a buckra this way this week past.' By tins  tune Mrs. Hudson came up. I shook hands with her and  many of the negroes, and spoke as cheerfully as I could, to  suppress their ill-feeling and hide my fears. ' Don't be fraid,  massa,'  they said  again, ' Massa drive so hard we  think hiin 	asc99990010170064001											55021772 Bytes	3400	5392	4127392048	RGB	asc99990010170064001.tif		2013-08-12	2013-08-12	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5838	5838	5839.jp2	/scbooks/image/5839.jp2

Mrs. Hudson got into the*  chaise with me.—1 walked my horses gently back to Ramble  —all the negroes were round my chaise ; One of them gave me  my umbrella stick, which fell from the chaise while driving so  furiously. I gave him a maccaroni, and said, * You see I mean  you no harm.' Till this they had their maschettes drawn, theri  they put them down. Upon arriving at Ramble the yard was  filled, and I shook hands with a vast number. They said they  would guard me down the hill. They took my horses out of  the chaise, and cooked some yam and salt pork for me. This  was between twelve and one. I said to those who said they  would guard me, 'Don't take these things (meaning the maschettes) with you, I don't likethem.' This I saw did not please  them, so I said no more, i told them I had not much money  with me, but would give them all I had, if they would not let  any body hurt me. They examined my chaise, put it in a shed*  and my horses into the pasture, and said, 'If the black set  see them, they will think you busha hid here, and so fire the  place.' \ said to the young man who rode after me,' Why did  not you come up ?' Answer, ' Was fraid you have pistols.*  They said 'Stay here, we go look out and tell the guard—then  they let you pass ;' and assured me they would not hurt me*  for they had * kissed the book not to hurt any parson.7 They  took my hat, (being a white one), and said, 'This is no parson's  hat, it busha's hat, you should travel in black hat and gown*  then we know you, and let you pass.' This they repeated  several times. They said they were guarding parson Reid's  house. He is Curate of Westmorland, and lives in the interior.  Upon   this  they all   went  away.      Mrs.   Hudson said, ' If  S'ou humour them, I don't think they will hurt you ; but if I  lad not been here, they would have murdered you.' I  was left at the house, and did not dare to go without their  consent. Whilst I was waiting, four men came from the  Burnt Ground company to be sure who 1 was; they knew  me, and told me no one should hurt me. 1 was kept there  in suspense for three hours. Mrs. Hudson said they were  gone to look for their Captain, to obtain his consent to let me  pass ; he is called Colonel Gardner, and belongs to Greenwich.  •—A thin orown man came on horseback, and said,  'Tell massa not to fear, the guard will soon come.' Between  three and four o'clock my horses were put in the chaise, and  1 again started for Westmorland. 1 stopped at Knockalva  gate, whence the men were to come to guard me down the  hill ;  there my fears were afresh excited by the behaviour of  the  they evidently were not of one mind about let- 	asc99990010170065001											63905416 Bytes	3880	5488	2024574544	RGB	asc99990010170065001.tif		2013-08-12	2013-08-12	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5839	5839	5840.jp2	/scbooks/image/5840.jp2

As  1 proceeded homeward* I saw the military at their posts at  Dry Works and Water Works. Grant came to me from head ' quarters,  which were opposite ; I briefly related my adventures, and  said I would see him again ; it being necessary for me to go  home at once* to relieve Mrs* Gardner's mind, as she knew  1 was returned, my servant having been sent forward.—-  I had been in my house but a short time* when three of  the Town-guard Called on me, saying Dr* Distin requested me to go to head quarters, and give information  of what I knew. Grant and Capt Braine being in the room, and  also an officer of his Majesty's ship Blossom* I gave a  full account of all that had transpired. About noon on Thursday* January 12, Captain   Huggup  and Serjeant Whitelock rode into the yard of Mr. .Gardnei's  residence, at Savanna la-Mar, the former to the front door,  and  the latter to the back ; and on seeing him as he passed  the hall window, Serjeant Whitelock loudly called out in an  authoritative tone, «' You are my prisoner, Sir !"   Mr. Gardner  met Captain Huggup at the front door, who after some few  remarks, became gentlemanly in his behaviour towards him.  Bis   private   correspondence  was  demanded,   and   Serjeant  Whitelock was to see that he produced it.    This being done;  it was sealed up by Captain Huggup and himself. Mr.Gardner  was then taken to head quarters,  where he was told that he  was apprehended by  order of Sir W. Cotton, and after remaining there some time, Serjeant Whitelock said, "Fie must  go to the Court-house that night, as he could not go over  with him to Montego Bay, till the next morning."    Upon  Mr. Gardner's requesting Captain  Owen, of the   Blossom,  to  allovy   him   to   return   to  his   residence   for  the   night,  he kindly replied, " No doubt it will   be most in accordance with your feelings to return home; Lieut. Allen will go  with you, and 1 will send a guard for the night; for 1 must do  my duty."    An officer was therefore sent to stay in the house,  and six sailors from the vessel paraded about it till the morning    Serjeant Whitelock then called, and taking Mr. Gardner  into his custody,   they travelled together in  Mr. Gardner's  chaise .to- Montego Bay.    On   arriving  there, Mr.  G.   was  taken to Major Coates, President of the Court Martial; who  declared, " that it was without his knowledge he was brought  ~ver; all &gt;ie had said was, that if he was a dangerous character, he ought to be taken into custody,"    After some hesitation among the members of the Court Martial, Mr. Gardner  was taken to Mr. Custos Barrett * who said to him, " You are  aware, Sir, of the deposition which the slave Phillip, of Mackfield, made against you ?" Mr. Gardner replied, "No, Sir; I  know not the cause   of my apprehension."     Major Coates  then read the affidavit,  which, as nearly as Mr. Gardner can  remember, was to this effect: "That he (Mr. G.) had been up  into the disturbed districts—that'he took him (Phillip) into his  chaise, gave him money, and said he had done well." With the  permission of the Custos, Mr. Gardner then related his adventures on the 3d inst. as already detailed, and contradicted this  deposition.    Being required to enter into recognizances to ap*  pear when called Tor, Mr. Manderson again most generously 	asc99990010170067001											62839358 Bytes	3832	5464	4131343368	RGB	asc99990010170067001.tif		2013-08-12	2013-08-12	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5841	5841	5842.jp2	/scbooks/image/5842.jp2
Page 68																																asc9999001017		43  came forward, and gave bail in the sum of £.100. He was  then " let go, and vyent to his own company ^taking up his  abode with his missionary friends at Jackson Town, the upper part of Montego-Bay.  Mr, and Mrs. Burchell had been absent from this country  since May 17th, 1831, and were expected to return about  Christmas, in company with Mr. and Mrs. Dendy, new missionaries, in the ship Garland Grove, Captain Pengelley.  The arrival of that vessel was therefore anticipated, both by  friends and enemies, with impatient anxiety. God having  made Mr. Burchell a preacher of righteousness to several  thousand souls, at different stations in that district, and prospered his labours to a wide extent, he had naturally and unavoidably acquired a large measure of influence. On this  account some of the Rebel Chiefs, it was said, had freely  used his name, in the furtherance of their own designs; and  this unfortunate circumstance, or at least the report of it, had  greatly increased the hatred of the sufferers against him, as  the supposed author of their misfortunes. So deep had this  hatred become, and so fixed appeared the determination of  many to be avenged on him, that the missionaries on shore  were told on all sides, if he could be got at, there was little  doubt he woidd be assassinated.  On Saturday Jan. 7th, after a tedious voyage, the Garland  Grove arrived, having on board the expected friends. Before  comingto an anchor, she was hailed by a boat from his Majesty's  frigate Blanche ; when an officer went oh board, and demanded of Captain Pengelley a list of his passengers. Having  perused it, he asked for Mr. Burchell, and required him to  accompany him on board the Blanche ; without giving the  slightest hint of the reason or purpose of this proceeding, in  answer to Mr. Burcheil's inquiries, beyond the indefinite reply, " It is Martial Law." Great vigilance was shewn to secure him ; for, besides the officer and four men despatched  to the Garland Grove, Mr. Middlemist, master of the Blanche,  and a party under his directions, were sent near the shore, to  prevent his escape in one of the Garland Grove's boats! To  the Blanche frigate, therefore, Mr. Burchell was conducted  as a prisoner; instead of enjoying, as he had naturally expected, a delightful interview with his friends, after the irksome  fatigue of a tedious voyage. But agreeable as such an inreiv  view would have been to all parties, the pain of its prevention  was greatly relieved by the consideration of his personal sak&gt;  £ 2 	asc99990010170068001											55704282 Bytes	3432	5408	2304384834	RGB	asc99990010170068001.tif		2013-08-12	2013-08-12	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5842	5842	5843.jp2	/scbooks/image/5843.jp2

Page 70																																asc9999001017		45  that my papers should be sent to the Custos, the Hon. "Richard  Barrett, whoWas authorized to examine them. My portable  desk was therefore brought up, and in the presence of Lieut.  Lake, Mr. Middlemist, and myself, the seals were broken, and  every manuscript paper was taken out. Mr. M. at first put aside  every thing printed; but Lieut. Lake went to the Captain, and  returned, saying, that Captain Burnett said, every thing, manu*-  script, printed publications, or books must be sent. Consequently, the printed papers before put aside, were now taken,  and books, including a New Testament. The whole was  wrapped in a paper, tied up, and sealed, and then forwarded.  H Monday 16th, and Tuesday 17th, Very unwell.—To-day  (IJlh), not having had an opportunity of going upon deck  since Monday the 9th, I stated to Captain B. this afternoon  that I was unwell, and was suffering from my confinement,  and should therefore be glad to be permitted to go on deck  for a few minutes, to have the benefit of the fresh air; which  was allowed.  ft Wednesday ]8th—Captain Burnett said lie had received a  note from the Commodore, stating, that by desire of the Custos, I was to be removed on board the Garland Grove. I asked  if the Custos had returned my papers, as he held all my accounts, private as well as public, and I had no memorandums  of the same left with me. He replied, they would be returned in due time.—During the eleven days 1 have been thus kept  a prisoner on board the Blanch frigate, 1 have received no  information of the reason or cause of my apprehension and  imprisonment ; though, during this period, 1 have been deprived  of all intercourse with any person but Mrs, B. and the servants and sentry. I have been permitted to go on deck but  twice, for the benefit of fresh air; and one of those times, under guard of a marine with a drawn bayonet. Even during  the night, a marine was pacing backward and forward my  apartment, and the very cot in which 1 was lying.  H Friday 20th, on board the Garland Grove.— Mr. Delisser  and Mr. Manderson came on board. I asked Mr. Manderson  what was the cause of my apprehension, and if he could inform me what charge there was against me. Be replied, that  there was no charge at present &gt; aiyl that Mr. Custos Barrett^  who was examining my patters, had informed him, that hitherto he had fownd nothing amongst them, which \\\ the least degree implicated me, nor which one planter would not write k&gt;  another."—Ob this day and the following with the permission  of Captain Pengelley, Mr. Burchell was visited by some of  the missionaries ami their wives from the shore.   Thirteea 	asc99990010170070001											55703856 Bytes	3432	5408	1203929899	RGB	asc99990010170070001.tif		2013-08-12	2013-08-12	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5844	5844	5845.jp2	/scbooks/image/5845.jp2
Page 71																																asc9999001017		46  days had elapsed from his arrival, before he-could enjoy this  privilege; and as the granting it on this occasion brought  down on the worthy Captain a reproof from some in authority, it was not repeated.  In this situation, a prisoner for an unknown cause, Mr. Burchell continued till February 10th, when Captain R received  from Mr. Custos Barrett the following-official document :*  4&lt; Montego-Bay, 10th February, 1832.  "Sir—You are hereby authorised to release from detention! the  person of Mr. Burchell.  " RICH4RD BARRETT, Custos.  " To Capt. Pengelley, ship Garland Grove."  Captain Pengelley and Mr. Roby called on the missionaries  on shore, shewing the above document, and recommending that  Mr. Burchell, being now honourably discharged, should immediately quit the island, in an American vessel, just about to  sail. Captain F. very reasonably pleaded, that the interests  of his employers, as well as his own, had already suffered from  his kindness to Mr. Burchell, and were likely to be further  injured by his remaining longer on board ; in fact he plainly  intimated, that he must shortly quit the ship. On the other  hand, the popular feeling against Mr. B. was excessively strong,  particularly since it was found that he would not be brought  to trial; indeed it was the unanimous opinion of all the missionaries' friends, who had opportunities of mixing with the  people, that his life would not be safe on shore. Various  threats were uttered against him, of which the following  will he sufficient to shew the bitter feeling which  existed. Captain Shibles, of the American vessel Robert and Rowland, stated, that he heard one gentleman say,  " that he would not go home until he had got Mr, Burcheli's  heart's bloodT'J Captain Barnett, of the army, informed  Mrs. Renwick, on the 4th of February, "that Mr. Burchell  would not he able to laud, as he, Capt, Barrett, had learnt  the day before that the inhabitants would shoot him, if he  landed !" All the missionaries at MontegoBay, therefore, concurred in opinion, that Mr. Burchell should proceed to America; and that by doing it openly and publicly, after Mr. Custos  Barrett's declaration, there would be no compromise of character. Page 72																																asc9999001017		41  arrangements with the American, and with the consignees of  the vessel, Messrs.■ Wark and Dewar. The latter gentlemen  hesitated to enter into this agreement, and proposed a postponement of his departure till the sailing of another vessel in  the ensuing week; to which Capt. P. would not consent.—  They then asked to wait till Monday or Tuesday; but the  Captain declining, they said they would apply to the Custos,  and afterwards give an answer.  During the forenoon of Saturday the 11th, Mr. Burchell was  engaged in preparing for his intended voyage, and Captain P.  had gone ashore to obtain the final answer of the consignees ;  when, about two o'clock, a boat came alongside the Garland  Grove, with Mr. Sidney Levieri, the head-constable, and two  subordinate constables. He enquired for Mr. Burchell, and  politely stated (hat he came from the civil authorities, to take  him before them at the Police-Office ; producing a warrant  signed by Mr. Joseph Bowen, Justice of Peace, for the apprehension of Messrs. Burchell and Gardner, on the following  charge, contained in the affidavit of Samuel Stennett, a free  persons of colour, which was recited in the warrant, viz. ** That  Mr. Burchell had said to him (Stennett) and other leaders  of the Baptist Society, to go among the negroes in the country, and tell them that freedom was theirs; and that they, the  negroes, must fight and pray for it, and they will get it. And  further, that he had heard parson Gardner say the same."—  Further particulars we supply from Mr. Burcheli's and Mr*  Dendy's memoranda. Mr. Burchell writes, " I stated to Mr. Le-  vien the plot against my life, and requested him to tarry till Capt*  Pengelley returned, as he was then expected every minute ;  he replied, 'he could not do that, and as he came by order of  the civil authorities, I had no reason to fear.' On urging my  request, he stated,1 The fact is, Mr. Biirche/I, this would not  HAVE  BURN DONE,   IF THEY HAD NOT HEARD YOO WERE GOING  away, you hare no need to be under any alarm? Mr. Levien  allowed rite to change one or two articles of clothing, when  he said ' he could remain no longer, and I must go.' Mr.  Whitehorne accompanied me in the boat."  This parting from his family and friends, on board, was  deeply affecting; because they could entertain no other expectation than that he would be murdered as soon as he reached  the shore. "My heart was so full," writes Mr. Dendy in  his memoranda, "that F could not open my lips, even to say  fctrewell.    Mrs.  Burchell was in a mental agony, and I  be-  gony,  heve not one of us was far from that state of mind.    We as  sisted her into the cabin \ when we all fell upon our knees, and  # 	asc99990010170072001											55492826 Bytes	3424	5400	3926030036	RGB	asc99990010170072001.tif		2013-08-12	2013-08-12	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5846	5846	5847.jp2	/scbooks/image/5847.jp2
Page 73																																asc9999001017		-  m  Called upon the Most High. I never was at such a pra^ef  meeting before ; the Lord assisted me much in my supplications 5  while the tears ran profusely down my cheeks upon the floor.—  Mrs. Burchell frequently responding to my petitions, in the  greatest distress of mind. After prayer I assisted Mrs. Burchell in rising from her knees, for she seemed almost fixed5  she said she felt the burden removed, and relief to her troubled mind ; but still her feelings were in a state of great ex*  citement, and we could scarcely keep her from fainting. After  a short time she became a little more composed, and expressed  her confidence in God, I proposed that the 91st psalm  should he read, and after that the 46th—the psalm to which  good Martin Luther used to resort when in trouble. From  these precious portions of the Holy Word we had previously  obtained much consolation ; and now we found them very, very  precious."  The Hearer of Prayer was graciously pleased to protect Mr.  Burchell from apprehended death, on his arrival at the beach;  though a multitude of foes had collected together, awaiting  his landing. The scene is thus described by himself. u On  landing, the most ferocious and savage spirit was manifested  by some of (^what are called) the most respectable white inhabitants, that ever could have occured amongst civilized society,  They began to throng around me, hissing, groaning, and  gnashing at me with their teeth—some with water in their mouths  to spit upon me. Had I never been at Montego Bay before, I  must have supposed myself among cannibals, or in the midst  of the savage hordes of Siberia, or the uncultivated and uncivilized tribes of central Africa. Some cried out, "Have his  blood:" others u Shoot him:" others, uHang him." But as  theyattempted to approach, several coloured persons surrounded me, and dared them to touch me ; and 1 am fully persuaded, had it not been for the protection afforded me by the  coloured part of the population, natives of Jamaica, I should  have been barbarously murdered,—yea, torn limb from limb,  by my countrymen,-—yea, by enlightened! respectable!!  CHRISTIAN BRITONS! 11  "On arriving at the Police-Office, I found, with many other  persons, Mr. Joseph Bowen, who signed the warrant, and was  one of the men who, I had been intormed, had sworn to .effect  my death—the one .who had threatened to Mr. Man-  derson the day the chapel was demolished, that the house of  any person should come down that protected the missionaries—and one who was present at, though a magistrate, if not  active in,  pulling down the chapel. The commitment being made out,  we were both brought to the common gaol, by the constab'es  and a guard of the militia, who humanely kept us from the  throng of persons, and from all insult. The guard consisted  of coloured persons, to whom we fell ourselves indebted. Page 75																																asc9999001017		50  Marks, Mr. Jump, Mr. John Ball, and Mr. Dewar, refused to  do it. The Foreman, Mr. T. Such an affidavit was procured, and  its natural consequences followed : but it is plain, as Mr. Le-  vien observed, " that this would not have been done, had they  not heard that Mr. B. was going to leave the island."*—  Thus were innocent missionaries committed to prison by the  very two men who had uttered the threats against the missionaries when the chapel was destroyed, and participated in  that act!  Three days after their imprisonment, an intelligent friend,  and one of the Grand Jury of the special Slave Court, visited  them in their confinement, and assured them that on the very  next day after their commitment, some of the party against  them stated, in conversation with him, that "they feared they  had overshot the mark, as if, on trial, they could not convict  Messrs. Burchell and Gardner, after preventing Burchell from  leaving the island, the colony would suffer more than from any  other act, as the case of oppression would appear so much the  greater:" they therefore proposed to him, " to act with Messrs.  .Burchell and Gardner's friends in effecting their escape, particularly Burcheli's." He replied "that he would do no  such thing, as he was sure Mr. Burchell and his friends were  too honourable to act in such a manner." This gentleman  then added to the missionaries, " You must therefore expect  that they will make heaven and earth meet, to bring evidence  to convict you!"  In writing this day (February 14), to our Secretary, the  Rev. John Dyer, they made the following solemn and affecting declaration of their innocence.  Mr. Burchell.—" I can and do most solemnly assure you,  that I am as innocent of having any connexion with, or knowledge of, this unhappy insurrection, as an infant child ; and do  most solemnly assure you, that neither directly nor indirectly  have I been connected with it; still I am committed to gaol—and  what kind of trial can I expect from people thus seeking my  life, thus thirsting for my blood ? O 1 my dear Sir, pray for  me—pray for us: we need indeed an interest in your prayers,  and in the prayers of the Christian Church in Britain. None  kuow, none can tell our sufferings,   they are  bitter, bitter  t For full particulars of this affair, we refer the reader to No. 5. of the Chris*  tian "Record, page 131, 	asc99990010170075001											62445346 Bytes	3808	5464	3942095181	RGB	asc99990010170075001.tif		2013-08-12	2013-08-12	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5849	5849	5850.jp2	/scbooks/image/5850.jp2
Page 76																																asc9999001017		WE  Truly I know what it is to say, "My tears have been my meat  day and night." We fear not any fair and impartial investigation on trial; we have no cause : for unless evidence, such as  may be extorted by the threat of the gallows, or by perjury,  brought about by the promise of life to those who have actu  ally deserved death by actual rebellion—or perjury, by promise of large reward to the unprincipled, be brought against  us, our innocence must and will appear as the sun at noonday."  Mr. Gardner.—" No means, as far as we can judge, have  been left unemployed, to implicate us as the cause of the present rebellion : but I can appeal to that God who has protected me to the present hour, that I am as innocent as my  dear little child, which I have never been permitted to see,  and do not know that I ever shall; and I believe all my suffering brethren to be as innocent as myself." With this consciousness of having done nothing "worthy of death or of  bonds," these missionaries had to look forward to their trial,  at the ensuing Assize Court; and what justice they could expect; the reader may judge.  &lt;o2 	asc99990010170076001											55831878 Bytes	3440	5408	3240383905	RGB	asc99990010170076001.tif		2013-08-12	2013-08-12	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5850	5850	5851.jp2	/scbooks/image/5851.jp2
Page 77																																asc9999001017		CHAPTER IV.  Various Occurrences at Montego-Bay.—Mr. Roby expresses his sentiments respecting Sectarians and their Preaching.—False statements of the Cornwall  Chronicle.—For conducting Family Worship, the Brethren are eited for Preaching;—They are suspected of communicating with Reb-els.—The Custos and Mr.  Jioby advise them all to quit the Island.—Visit and conversation of Colonel  Lawson.— Demolition of the Chapel, by Magistiates and others.—In personal  danger, the Missionaries flee to his Majesty's ship North Star.—Persecution of  Mr. Roby on their account.—Mr. Burchell and the others discharged from their  Bail.—They Memorialize the Governor, respecting the destruction of Chapels.—  Public Meeting for the Expulsion of the Baptist Missionaries from the Island.  Before we present the reader with the sequel of Messrs.  Burchell and Gardner's imprisonment, we must detain him  with the relation of several occurrences, claiming a place in  our narrative, which happened at Montego-Bay, prior to that  result.  Immediately after the release of Messrs. Knibb, Whitehorne, and Abbott, January 4th, their friend Mr. Roby very  candidly expressed his sentiments respecting u Sectarianism."  Be informed them, that very great prejudice existed against  them, because many of the rebels who had been taken were  Baptists. He observed, that many charged the missionaries  with having intentionally excited the slaves to rebellion ; but  he thought they were innocent in intention, though he believed, that by an injudicious selection of texts, (such as Fight  the good fight of faith. If the sou make you free, ye shall  he fee indeed, &c.) and by dealing too much in the abstruse  doctiines of the Bible, the Sectarians had done a great deal  of mischief, and had misled the slaves. lie let the missionaries know, that as Sectarians he " most cordially hated  them," for that he was "a staunch churchman"—that his  love of justice constrained him to interfere on their behalf—  that popular clamour ran very high against them, but he  should consider them innocent till proved guilty—and much  more to the same effect. Such sentiments as these, with singular candour and precision, this gentleman repeatedly exu  pressed, in his subsequent interviews with the missionaries;  and in justice to him, as well as the public, we have felt bound  to relate them. 	asc99990010170077001											62575774 Bytes	3816	5464	1076377635	RGB	asc99990010170077001.tif		2013-08-12	2013-08-12	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5851	5851	5852.jp2	/scbooks/image/5852.jp2
Page 78																																asc9999001017		53  On Saturday, January 7th, the following account of their  arrival at Montego-Bay, appeared in the Cornwall Chronicle,  a newspaper edited and published in that town by Mr. Alexander Holmes :  " On Tuesday last, a party of the Trelawny militia brought down  to head-quarters Messrs. Whitehorne, Knibb, and Abbott, Baptist  missionaries, on a charge of refusing to do duty in the militia. They  were lodged in the main guard, at the Court-house, till released from  military durance by order of the Custos, sanctioned by another order  of ids Excellency Sir W. Cotton. The application was made by Mr,  Itoby the Collector of his Majesty's Customs, who stated that. Mr.  Whitehorne was a particular friend of his ; and the responsibility of  their appearance rests on the security of Mr. Moby, who has placed  himself under the following clause ot the Rules and Articles of War:  " XXXIII Clause.—' Any person having charge of a gaol or guard"  house, who shall not receive or (safe as mentioned in the immediately  preceding article) detain in custody, any prisoner or offender sent,  delivered, or conveyed to him for custody, by authority, shall suffer  such punishments as either a General or Regimental Court-Martial  shall award, not extending to life.'"  This statement, containing two falsehoods, appears to have  been written partly to supply the omission of Colonel Cadien,  at Falmouth, who had •• unreasonably sent prisoners, and not  withal signified the crimes laid against them ;" and partly to  gratify an old private spleen against Mr. Roby. The Editor,  being an officer of the St. James' Regiment, and on the spot  at the time, was, most likely, aware that the missionaries were  not "brought down on a charge of refusing to do duty in the  militia;" that before their release they had been handed over  to the civil power ; and that two other gentlemen besi ies Mr.  Roby had given bail for their appearance. These were the  real circumstances of the case; and if Mr. Holmes did not  know them when he wrote, (which is nn improbable supposition, as three whole days had elapsed, and the business had been  the subject of public canvass on the Bay,) he ought not to  have written so positively. But whether he knew them or not,  it is clear his statement contains two falsehoods ; for it ig not  true that the missionaries were taken to Montego-Bay {,on  a charge of refusing to do duty in the militia"—nor is it true  that " the responsibility of their appearance" ever rested on  the security of Mr. Roby. In this instance, therefore, Mr.  Holmes must admit, that his statement is proved to be "false,  and unworthy of credence." Another statement, contained \\\  the very same number of this paper, again places the veracity  of the Editor in a doubtful point of view:  " For instance, when it is known, as will be proved, when the proper  season arrives for the institution of a commission to inquire into th*  real causes that have given rise to this insurrection among our hither-  i 	asc99990010170078001											56140672 Bytes	3464	5400	4254041672	RGB	asc99990010170078001.tif		2013-08-12	2013-08-12	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5852	5852	5853.jp2	/scbooks/image/5853.jp2
Page 79																																asc9999001017		54  to quiet and contented negroes, that a clergyman of the Baptist persuasion advised the negroes, not to attend to the doctrines of Christianity, inculcated by the clergyman, nor of any of the ministers of the  Established Church, as they were their enemies and deceivers, and opposed to their ever obtaining their freedom, it will easily be believed  what effect so talismanic a charm would have on the minds of this  credulous people, by thus destroying all confidence in their hitherto  respected religious instructors.''  The prosecutions against the several missionaries terminated  without the production of this promised evidence—but why ?  There can be no question that such a piece of evidence would  have told with immense force against the missionaries ; and  there can be as little question, that had the Editor of this paper been in possession of such, or known where it was to be obtained, when he penned the above passage, he would not have  failed to have laid it before the Attorney General, " when the  proper season arrived." But in this he did fail, and what is  the Inference? Why, that no such evidence existed, and therefore Mr. Holmes asserted what had no foundation in fact.  "Whether this false assertion was intentionally made, to gratify his noted inclination to defame missionaries ; or when  written, honestly believed by him, we must leave Mr. Holmes  to determine ; but either way, we fear he must admit that in  this case also his statement is proved to be "false, and unworthy of credence."*  On Lord's day, January 8th, public worship being imprac*&lt;  ticable, the missionaries assembled the family of the house in  which they lodged, for a devotional exercise; the whole com**  pany, including themselves and their servants, consisting of  twelve to fifteen persons. In addition to prayer, a sermon  was read, and they ventured to sing a hymn or two. But  this quiet and peaceable attempt to keep holy the Sabbath  day, was not allowed to pass, without an effort to make it a  punishable act. For on Tuesday the 10th, Mr. Roby received  a message from Major Coates, by a constable, requiring him  to produce the missionaries at the Court-house; in consequence of which he hastened to their lodgings, informing  them that their attendance was required at the Court-house  directly, but for what purpose he knew not. He kindly accompanied them ; and after waiting there some time, Major  Coates told them, he had received information that Mr. Knibb  * See Editorial remarks of the "Cornwall Chronicle" of May 19th 1832, on  the Missionaries1 letter inserted in the Kingston Chronicle, and Jamaica Watchman, of February 25th, wherein they are boldly challenged to show that any  statements concerning them, made in that paper, have been proved false. 	asc99990010170079001											62034980 Bytes	3792	5451	3341787511	RGB	asc99990010170079001.tif		2013-08-12	2013-08-12	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5853	5853	5854.jp2	/scbooks/image/5854.jp2
Page 80																																asc9999001017		55  hod been prcaeliing to a large concourse of negroes on Sun*  dav morning, in the house at Jackson Town, and it was not  licensed! Mr. Knibb stated that he had not preached—  that they had merely held family prayer, at which five or six  friends were present, with the servants of the house ; and that  he had rkad a printed sermon. The complaint appeared  so truly ridiculous, that even Mr. Coates, who will not be  suspected of having borne them any affection, at once dropped the subject.  The missionaries were so closely watched in this situation,  that for several weeks they did not venture to leave their  lodgings, even to take exercise, through apprehension that  some evil might be made of it. And when from necessity  they adopted a plan of obtaining, in their own yard, what is  so essential to health, they understood it was spoken of as  vnfeeling towards those who were suffering around. With  far more justice, they found occasion for similar remarks on..  the dances given at this time about MontegoBay; and on  Commodore Farquhar and others who visited them !* Near  their lodgings was a remarkable cave, which, some weeks after  their caption, they ventured to visit, in open day-light. This  little circumstance they were informed excited considerable  suspicion, from an idea that there must be rebels in the cave,  with whom they were in communication. Though Mr. Gardner bad given bail only " to appear when called for," and was  not confined to any spot yet, when he signified his wish to  Mr. Custos Barrett, to go round by water to Mrs. Gardner, he  was told that if he attempted to quit Montego-Bay, he  should be put under arrest!  On the 22d January, Mr. Roby called on them, and slated  that he had just had an interview with Mr. Custos Barrett,  when the latter had given it as his opinion that the missionaries would not be able to remain in the island ; and added,  that he advised them to take their departure as soon as possible. Mr. Roby inquired it he intended this to be mentioned to them, when Mr. Barrett requested him to mention  it, and gave him to understand that permission would be  granted by the proper authorities for  the departure of any  * Balls were also given at Port-Antonio and Mancbioneal, in the midst of  punishments and executions. 	asc99990010170080001											55585960 Bytes	3440	5384	2693505584	RGB	asc99990010170080001.tif		2013-08-12	2013-08-12	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5854	5854	5855.jp2	/scbooks/image/5855.jp2
Page 81																																asc9999001017		5G  -vessel which might be conveying them away.* This advice  Mr. Roby joined in, and enforced with many arguments; but  the missionaries would not entertain it for a moment. Conscious of their innocence, and ready to stand the test of any  trial, they would not listen to advice, a compliance with which  would have justly laid them under strong suspicions of guilt.  They remembered their duty to the Society that sent them  out, and to the destitute churches in the island, which looked  up to them for instruction. They urged these and similar arguments to Mr. Roby, without convincing him ; and he concluded with the remark, " that he feared they wished to become martyrs for discord's sake."  On the morning of the 30th, the missionaries were visited  by Dr. George M'F. Lawsou, sen. Colonel of the St.. James*  regiment, attended by Captain Gray. He entered their lodging without any ceremony, and standing in the middle of the  room, asked for Mr. Gardner, who thereupon advanced. Gardner.—" Yes, and I will explain the reason.—Owing to  the number of members, Mr. Burcheli's absence, and my  having to attend at Savanna-la-Mar, ii is impossible to give  all out at once, therefore we commence for the new year iu  December.
