Page 83																																asc9999001017		58  think of going on board. We were very sorry to hear that  Captain Pengelley had been reproved on our account, and at  once determined not to repeat the visit. We are old friends  of Mr. Burcheli's, and wished to have the pleasure of shaking hands with him after his long absence."  Martial Law was withdrawn on the 5th February, and intimation was given to the missionaries that Dr. Lawson, the  younger, was going about, endeavouring to form a mob, for the  destruction of the Baptist Chapelat Montego-Bay. Not much  apprehension was entertained, however, that the inhabitants  would be so lost to all good feeling, as to yield to such a proposal;  hut the next day, more certain indications were apparent. Mr.  lvoby, having been informed of it, proceeded, as he stated to the  missionaries, to the Court-house,, where he fell in with the  Custos, and Dr. Lawson, tire elder. He declared his errand  to both. The Custos was quite incredulous, and said he could  do nothing, unless Mr. Roby would make an affidavit that  the act was about to be committed: he could not do  this, but offered to swear that he had been informed,  and verily believed, it was contemplated. The Custos  deemed this insufficient to warrant his taking any measures  for preventing it, but spoke of the civil and military powers  being close at hand. Dr. Lawson was very much offended at  the slur cast upon the inhabitants of the town by Mr. Roby,  and even termed it a "libel," calling to Mr. John Coates, who  was by, to notice it. Within an hour of this interview, the  work of destruction was begun, Mr. Roby again proceeded  to the Court-house, but both the Custos and Dr. Lawson  were awt of the way. The rioters met with no interruption  from civil or military powers, though the heads of both had  been forewarned of what was intended : indeed the principal  actors were eleven magistrates, and numerous officers in the  militia * By two o'clock, that large building was razed to the  ground.  The missionaries then received information, from several sources, that an attack was meditated on their persons  and lodgings. Towards evening their kind friends, Messrs,  Lewin, Roby* and Manderson, urged them to quit their lodgings for the night at least. The last stated that Mr, John  Coates, Justice of the Peace, had said (% he would not be in  one of those  missionaries shins to night i on any account f —  f See'iSh'aptti IX, 	asc99990010170083001											62676986 Bytes	3839	5440	2696375874	RGB	asc99990010170083001.tif		2013-08-12	2013-08-12	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5857	5857	5858.jp2	/scbooks/image/5858.jp2
Page 84																																asc9999001017		59  and that Mr. Joseph Bowen, another Justice of the Peace,  had said, "he would destroy am/person's house, who dared to  give a night's shelter to any of them" Mr. Manderson, notwithstanding this threat, pressed them to go to his house, and  even make it their home. They accepted his kind invitation  thankfully, and were soon convinced that the information  they had received was not groundless; for they heard that the  mob actually proceeded towards their lodgings, armed with  bludgeons, fee* but finding they had escaped, retreated. As  ii was considered dangerous for them to remain on shore for  the night, Mr. Roby kindly offered to go on board some of  the vessels in the harbour, and endeavour to obtain protection.  The Captain of the Christian,* of Glasgow, and the Carshal-  ton Park, of London, were both afraid to receive them, de-  pending as they did on the inhabitants for a cargo. The  former recommended Mr. Roby to seek protection from the  American Captains: to which he replied he never would, as long  as a British flag was flying in the harbour. Our indefatigable  friend then immediately proceeded to his Majesty's ship  North-Star, the only man of war in port, whose Captain, the  honourable ——-Trefusis, appeared unwilling to receive them;  but said, ''that if they were in danger, he was bound to afford  protection to any of his Majesty's subjects." This permission  to go on board, a King's ship, for the saving of their Jives,  though apparently less free and cordial than some may conceive  due from one of his Majesty's subjects, to others seeking protection from a band of assassins, they were glad to accept; and accordingly, about six o'clock, went on board: where they were  kindly treated by the officers of the ward-room, who had cots  slung for them on the main-deck, and otherwise pro  vided for their necessities. There they rested in grateful security, again admiring the gracious and wonderful deliverance:  wrought for them. Jkiiovah, in whom they trusted,'thus  again interposed to preserve his servants from death, and.  show that their blood was precious in his sight. Let i\)n^e remarkable proofs of his faithfulness and care be recorded k&gt; bis  praise; and let them operate as supports to our faith, jmI incentives to others to reverence and put their trust in Hrm.  Early the next morning, the first Lieutenant brought a  message from the Captain, whom the missionaries had not  yet seen; that they must prepare to go on shore, as he could no  longer afford them an asylum. They requested, and obtained  lia.msRiou, to remain till Mr. Roby's arrival. Page 85																																asc9999001017		GO  to the Captain ; who stated that he wished them to remain on  board till lie had communicated with the Custos; because,  as they had been once under his protection, he felt bound to  obtain the pledge of the civil authorities for their future  safety. Some communication accordingly took place with  the Custos; and then (he missionaries were informed by Mr.  Roby, that the Custos had engaged to protect them, it was  understood that the feeling on shore had very much subsided, but that there was still a jjood deal of animosity expressed towards Mr. Knibb: the Captain was therefore re-  ijuested...to tat him remain another day: which he acceded to.  Messrs. Whitehorne, Abbott, and Gardner returned lo their  lodgings, without meeting with any molestation. It is worthy  of notice, that before leaving the vessel, the first Lieutenant  informed, the missionaries, " thai at one period they were prisoners, as he had received orders not to suffer their depar„  lure."  The kind part which Mr. Rcby had acted towards the missionaries, from the beginning, had for some time evidently  been giving offence to the people of Montego Bay ; this day  the feeling broke out; and an effigy, which had been prepared  10 represent Mr. Burchell, was suspended on the gallows, in  the market-place, with the letters R. f Y. stuck on it; (lie  cause of Mr Roby's reproach being announced in the pithy  sentence, u The Baptists' friend."  in reference to this gentleman, we will add an extract from  the Cornwall Chronicle, of Saturday February 18th, which, in  the words of the incomparable Courant, "speaks volumes for  Jamaica justice.'*  '* A meeting- of the inhabitants took place at the Court-house here,  on Sat unlay last, his honour the Custos in the chair. Several propositions for a volunteer Town-guard had been projected by several  gentlemen, but one seemed to bo the most popular, and was carried  without much discussion as to its cfhYieney. It divides the inhabitants of the town into seven parties of thirty, each having a leader or  captain. This enables the respective companies to serve one night a  week. Their duty, so far as it has been defined to Us, seems to be patrolling the streets, avenues, and outskirts of the town. Mr. Rohjf^  the Collector of his Majesty's Customs for this port, appeared at the  meeting', on the list of which he had formerly enrolled his name ; but  , xevvral gentlemen having expressed a determination not to serve, if the  liame of Mr. Roby was retained on the list, he came there to explain,  and to inquire the reason of such a determination ; but his inquiry  was overruled by the meeting-, and Mr. Itoby was thus necessitated to  withdraw his name. We understand that his manifesting so decided a  regard for the Baptists, in becoming thmr security, and in intermcU- 	asc99990010170085001											62930086 Bytes	3832	5472	231834852	RGB	asc99990010170085001.tif		2013-08-12	2013-08-12	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5859	5859	5860.jp2	/scbooks/image/5860.jp2
Page 86																																asc9999001017		(it  fifing with the affair of the Meeting-house, has rendered this gentleman so obnoxious to the public*" ,  That a gentleman, by birth and education, of considerable  standing in the community, and holding a high office m .his  Majesty's service,—or that any person, indeed, whatever his  rank,-— should be considered unfit to associate with the inhabitants of Montego-Bay, in guarding the town, because his sense  of justice had led him to treat several missionaries as innocent  men, tiil proved guilty, to exert himself for the preservation  of their lives from a mob, and to seek the interference of the  proper authorities to prevent so gross a breach of the peace,  as occurred at the demolition of the chapel; exhibits, in a  striking light, the moral degradation of those people, as well  as the moral courage of the two or three individuals, who per-  severingiy resisted them in behalf of the missionaries.  1  At this time the spirits of these missionaries w^ere revived,  and their hopes excited of soon returning to the people of  their .charge, by the receipt of the following official document,  releasing Messrs. Page 87																																asc9999001017		Several places of worship having by this time been laid in  ruins, and much private property belonging to the missionaries destroyed, stolen, or injured, chiefly by the militia, they  addressed a memorial to His Excellency the Governor, then at  Montego Bay, representing their grievances, and imploring His  Excellency's interference, to put a stop to these unjust and  illegal measures. To this memorial a prompt reply was addressed by His Excellency's Secretary, stating that this petition  had been anticipated by His Excellency, as would appear by  the Proclamation just promulgated through the island, a copy of  which was enclosed, which is given in the Appendix, No. 1.  So little respect, however, was felt for the Representative  of Majesty, by the inhabitants of Montego Bay, that very  quickly after this seasonable and excellent Proclamation had  been posted up about the town, several copies were torn down;  and, under one posted up in the Court-house, was written,  M Whoever gives information respectingtbe above, shallentitle  himself to be tarred and feathered1"  One more occurrence must be introduced, to shew the determined opposition to the gospel manifested in that parish.  The inhabitants "raged and imagined a vain thing,0 and some  of their M rulers took counsel together against the Lord and  against His Anointed ;" hoping that by joining hand in hand  in Anti-Christian Union, they might for ever exclude faithful  missionaries from among them. For this purpose the following notice appeared in the Cornwall Chronicle of March  3d, 1832.  " In consequence of a requisition addressed to me, as senior magistrate, very numerously and respectably signed, requesting me to  call a meeting of the freeholders and other inhabitants of this parish  for the purpose of expressing their determination to prevent hereafter  a re-introduction of the Baptist sect into this parish, and to recommend our Representatives to use their exertions in the Honourable  House of Assembly, to expel them from the island, 1 do hereby convene the same meeting at the Court-house, in this town, at one o'clock  on Monday next, the 5th inst.  (Signed) " THOS. JOSEPH GRAY.  /Senior Magistrate."  On Monday, March 5th, pursuant to the above advertisement, the meeting was convened; when the principal speakers  were Messrs. Lawson, jim. Coates, and Grignon, the two latter being magistrates. A few resolutions, expressive of then'  abhorrence of religion and its propagators, were proposed  and canied; and in the course of the meeting the following 	asc99990010170087001											62024310 Bytes	3799	5440	3385465223	RGB	asc99990010170087001.tif		2013-08-12	2013-08-12	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5861	5861	5862.jp2	/scbooks/image/5862.jp2
Page 88																																asc9999001017		G3  remarks, among others equally inflammatory and violent,  were made : Mr, Gray said, alluding to the destruction of the  Baptist Chapel, "lie regretted he was not present at the time,  as he would have joined heart and hand, with his fellow parishioners, in destroying it." Mr. Coates spoke to the following  effect. "That they (the meeting) must get rid of the Baptists ;  that they must petition the Honourable House of Assembly,  -and if petition would not do, they must use other measures for  expelling them ; that the voice of the people was for expelling them, and the voice of the people vxis above any  law; that they must make laws of their own; and that they  (the people) would not beat rest until all the Baptists were  sent off the island." He then added/in reference to the Wes-  leyans, " that he thought they would not be allowed to preach ;  that Mr. Murray ought to be informed of it ; that it would be  at the risk of his life if he did so, as he was sure, if he attempted it, he would be murdered:" or words to that effect.  The facts related in this chapter, present various illustra-.  tions of that dreadful hostility against religion, which the missionaries have had to encounter; but, surprizing as they must  he to every lover of justice, the half of such proceedings  have not yet been set forth. 	asc99990010170088001											55518134 Bytes	3441	5376	3535626387	RGB	asc99990010170088001.tif		2013-08-12	2013-08-12	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5862	5862	5863.jp2	/scbooks/image/5863.jp2
Page 89																																asc9999001017		CHAPTER V.  Bribery and Perjury discovered against Messrs. Burchell and Gardner.—Theif  • Memorial to the Governor.—Pieparation for their trials.—The Assizes commence.—Indictment against Mr. Knihh.—The witnesses for the Crown.—True  ' Bills found.—Mr. Burcheli's bill ignored.—Mob assemble to assault him.—His  rescue and removal to his Majesty's ship Ariadne.—At the instance of the  Chief Justice and others, he consents to leave the island.—Interview of Mr,  Whitehorne and Mr. Forsyth with kim on hoard.—His deparluie for America.—A Deputation of his friends wait on the Chief Justice.—The sentiments of  his Honour respecting him.  Only three days elapsed from the date of Messrs. Burchell  and Gardner's committal to prison, before the iniquity of  that measure began to appear ; though it was not made known  to the missionaries, till ten or eleven days from that date.  The young man, Samuel Stennett, on whose affidavit they  ■were committed, had been among the rebels, and had given  himself up. to a magistrate eight or nine days before the affidavit in question was made. He disclosed to him nothing  whatever concerning Messrs. Burchell and Gardner, nor had  any steps been taken to bring them to justice ; and Stennett  was set at liberty. But from the time of his affidavit he was  secured in custody, partly in the gaol, and partly among the  prisoners at the Court-house, under a guard. He is represented  as having borne the image of misery and wretchedness, and  some persons said he did not appear likely to live until the  Court. On the 14th of February hegave utterance to the cause of  his distress; he sent for his uncle, Mr. Geoige Scott, a respectable person at Montego-Bay, and declared to him, that he  had sworn falsely against the missionaries, and had been  bribed to do so!! Between this time and the 20th, the uncle  informed Stennett's mother, who proceeded to Mr. John  Manderson, and related the intelligence she had received to  him, in the presence of Captain Sergeant, of the ship Isabella,  and Mr. James Baker, lately arrived from London. On  Wednesday Mr. Manderson was called upon to attend the  Court house, on some business relative to the prisoners there.  Among them was Stennett, who approached Mr Manderson,  and iu the presence of the sentry began to relate his tat3  Mr. Manderson desired him to cease for the present; aod 	asc99990010170089001											61925844 Bytes	3784	5453	112271968	RGB	asc99990010170089001.tif		2013-08-12	2013-08-12	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5863	5863	5864.jp2	/scbooks/image/5864.jp2

This not succeeding, a warrant was issued  against him, by Joseph Bowen, Esq. founded upon the deposition of a free person of colour, named Samuel Stennett, who  stated 'that Mr. Buschel! had said to him, and other leaders  of the Baptist Society, to go among tlie negroes in the country,  and tell them that freedom was theirs, ami that they must  light and ['ray for it, and they will get it : And further, that  he had heard Parson Gardner say the same.' "lrRANCts Gardner,  f Montego-Bay Gaol, Feb. 25, 183:2."  , The missionaries heard at Montego-Bay, that some communication was made from the Governor to the magistrates  there, in consequence of this Memorial ; of what nature is not  known. If it was by way of inquiry as to the truth of the allegations, it is rather singular that any necessity for such inquiry should have been considered to exist, as Mr.Manderson,  named in it, was.at the seat of government, and at hand to  corroborate the material allegation. No relief whatever  was afforded, and the two prisoners had to submit to the discomfort of a gaol, for several weeks after the sole evidence  on which they were imprisoned had been nullified.  No other expectation now remaining, Chan that the case  would be brought into Court, the friends who were at large  endeavoured to make the most of-their means and opportunities for preparing for the trial of the two missionaries in  prison, as well as for that of Mr. Knibb, in case the strenuous  endeavours which it was known were being made to obtain  some colour of evidence against him also, should meet with  success. The difficulties attending this preparation can only  he known by those who have been placed in a similar situation.    The slaves had not recovered from the panic occa- 	asc99990010170092001											56168488 Bytes	3478	5381	3483435119	RGB	asc99990010170092001.tif		2013-08-12	2013-08-12	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5866	5866	5867.jp2	/scbooks/image/5867.jp2
Page 93																																asc9999001017		m  stoned by the despotic proceedings of Martial Law. It was  only by stealth that most of those who were spoken to, ventured to come to the missionaries; and they had very limited  means of information, as to the faithful among'their people  in the disturbed districts ; for the statements relative to the  reception of Mr. Knibb at Falmouth, and of the threatened  reception of Mr. Abbott at Lucea,* plainly shew that it would  not ha\e been safe for the missionaries to have travelled about  in search of evidence. Notwithstanding all obstructions,  however, they succeeded in obtaining such a mass of evidence, as set their minds comparatively at peace. They felt  that the Divine Being would not leave them unprotected ; the  surmounting of ffrei ^difficulties, in this respect, was regarded as  an earnest of future assistance and deliverance in time of need.  On the 3d of March the hearts of the friends were cheered  by the arrival from Kingston of their legal adviser, Mr. James  Forsyth, Attorney at Law ; in whom they found not only an  intelligent, zealous agent, but a pious, fervent disciple of their  common Lord , with whom, even in the transacting of business, they could hold Christian communion. He entered  upon his work, not as the hired defender of prisoners against  prosecutors, but with the conviction that the latter were only  the blind agents of Belial, staking at the cause of the Redeemer through his servants, and with the determination to  use his utmost ability to overcome the enemy.f  On Monday, the 12th March, the Cornwall Assize Court  commenced, the then Chief Justice, the Honourable George  Lowman Tuckett, presiding. His opening charge to the  Grand Inquest J is given Jri the Appendix, No. IV. The  jnissionaries augured well from its impartiality. The list of  the prosecutions, and of the witnesses in support thereof, were  called over in open Court. It was thus that the first intima-  ftori'was received by Mr Knibb, or his friends, that a prosecution existed against him. The witnesses against him were the  very same whose evidence Mr. Custos Barrett had declared contained u nothing to support a criminal prosecution," with this  difference, that Samuel Stennett was omitted, and the name of  Venture^], a slave from Lima, w7as added. And against Mr. Burchtll, the last, individual  only was mentioned. Slill the Attorney General, the Ho-  liourable Fitzherbert Batty; expressed his determination to  send in an indictment against Mr. Burchell, on that evidence.'  It is scarcely necessary to state, that " true Bills" were  fotmd by the Grand Jury, consisting as it did almost entirely  of white persons, who resided in the disturbed districts, most  of whom had suffered more or less by the rebellion,and nearly  all of whom had prejudged and condemned the missionaries.*  When the evidence adduced on the trial of Mr. Gardner, the  result of that trial, the fate of the indictment against Mr.  Knibb, coupled with the Attorney General's declaration, and  thatalready given of Mr. Custos Barrett, and the circumstance  we are about to relate concerning the Bill against Mr. Burchell, are considered, we shall be justified for insinuating that  they were deeply prejudiced men, and therefore that their  bringing in •&lt;• true Bills" against the missionaries was a necessary consequence of the Bills going before them.  On Wednesday, the 14th March, the following incident occurred, which we cannot relate better than in the language of  a gentleman who was present, and published it in the Watchman Newspaper of 31st March, in a letter signed * Equitas,'  the whole of which letter is worthy of notice.  "In the course of the trial of the soldier, for the murder of  the negro, Trim, the Attorney General stated that he was sorry to interrupt the proceedings of the Court, but he had received a message from the Grand Jury, as to some information  which they required, respecting a Bill then before them. r| he  Chief said, /Let the Grand Jury come into Court, and state the  request.' They then came up, and the Foreman said to the  Court, they were at a losshow to proceed with the Bill in the  case of.Mr. Burchell, as the only tvifness to support it had  confessed himself perjured. * Gentlemen,' said the Judge, ' I  have nothing to do with the matter ; it is for you to judge of  the credibility of any witness in support of a Bill. If it were  a point of law, upon which you sought my advice, 1 would he  happy to give it toyou to the best of my ability ; but this rests  entirely with yourselves. Ifyou wash my advice asan individual,  1 would say, without hesitation, that a person who has  confessed himself perjured is not entitled to credit, and it  would be highly improper to receive his testimony.' A Juror then addressed the Attorney General, and inquired what  was to be done with the Bill, as there was no other witness to  * See the statements of Ventureixud Paih, in the Christian Record ,.&gt;ft&gt;. V*p.l2&  fl  I 	asc99990010170094001											56575984 Bytes	3487	5406	364718156	RGB	asc99990010170094001.tif		2013-08-12	2013-08-12	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5868	5868	5869.jp2	/scbooks/image/5869.jp2
Page 95																																asc9999001017		70  support it? Gentlemen,' said the Attorney General, * why  the same as you would do with any other bill; throw it out—  irrite on it ignoramus.1 f But,' said the w?iseaere, &lt; how can we  ignore a Bill, when there is no evidence before us to support it!"  The Grand Jury were then 'reluctantly obliged to write  "ignoramus" on the Bill, and Mr. Burcheli's discharge w-as ordered. In the course of the afternoon he proceeded from the  gaol to the house at which Mrs, Burchell and some more of  the friends lodged. Here he jiad a most affecting meeting:  with his numerous friends, who crowded in upon him in great  numbers, eager to see him once more, and to ^prfes thejjs  congratulations, till he was quite overpowered, and compelled to say that he could receive no more till the morrow. But  the morrow afforded no such opportunity—his friends were  seeing him for the last time.  • in consequence of various reports of an intended assault  on Mr. Burchell, several friends of colour determined to  guard the house, and about dusk posted themselves in the  lower part of it. Intelligence had been received that a large  number of white persons, chiefly Jews, were seen assembling  in a house at the lower pari; of the town. About seven o'clock,  indications of an attack began to appear. A Captain Lacy„  oft he brig Mygeia, in his overanxiety toascertain Mr. Burcheli's  lodgings, accosted one of that gentleman's friends, a respectable coloured female, and insulting her, he was severely beaten  by a friend of hers who was near. In a little time the body of  assailants made their appearance, but seeing persons in the  house, and a large opposing party having assembled without,  they seemed at a loss how to proceed. The friends of Mr.  Harebell waited until ihe others should   commence  acts of  fa  s soon as  aggression, and merely stood on the defensive.  Mr. Lewin heard of what was beginning, he started off in search  of a magistrate ; and having occasion to pass by Mr. Roby's  house, informed him of what was going forward. That gentleman forthwith proceeded on the same errand as Mr. Lewin,  and succeeded in procuring the attendanceof Mr. Ewert, a  magistrate of Moritego*-Bay. In the mean time Mr. Lewin,  having fallen in with Mr. Watkis, Barrister at Law, was con-*  ducted by him to the Chief Justice, who immediately hastened  to the spot, and used every exertion to disperse the mob.  Finding them, however, inattentive to his voice, he went towards the Court-house, in order to obtain military aid.  The local authorities, we understand, manifested considerable  indifference in the matter ; and indeed two of them, while sit-  'ting in the lodgings of Mr Burchell, opposed this-proposition 	asc99990010170095001											63403644 Bytes	3895	5424	2457890958	RGB	asc99990010170095001.tif		2013-08-12	2013-08-12	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5869	5869	5870.jp2	/scbooks/image/5870.jp2

Military aid was  obtained, and at about ten o'clock Mr. Burchell was conducted by the Chief Justice, Dr. Lawson, and Mr, Heath,  to the beach, where he embarked in a boat, and proceeded to his Majesty's ship Ariadne, Capt. Phillips, t)]en lying  in the harbour of Montego-Bay ;~ by which means he was  again preserved from the murderous designs of his foes. In the course of the  forenoon, the mission a nesjiavingheard t hat these a u tl.orii ies had  proceeded on board, and being apprehensive that in Mr, Burcheli's agitated state of mind he might be easily persuaded to act  hastily, desired Mr..Dendy to go on board, and request him to  determine on noshing, until he could converse with his brethren. About three o'clock, while Mr. Forsyth, t he.Attorney, and Mr. Whitehorne, were busily engaged with the defence of the other two missionaries, the latter received a note  from Mr, Burchell, by an officer of the Ariadne, requesting  an immediate visit from him and Mr. Forsyth ; and the officer stated that he would convey them on board, and mentioned that Mr. Burchell was about to proceed (he believed)  to Kingston. They went accordingly in the Ariadne's boat  to the ship ; on entering which, they found that they were to  speak to Mr. Burchell only in Captain Phillips' presence,—  Mr. Burchell informed them that lie had promised to sail for  America, that evening. Page 97																																asc9999001017		.72  jn ii detached manner, (being often interrupted by Captain  Phillips,) the grounds on which they and the brethren on shore  regretted this decision ; viz.. that if he remained, his enemies,  having made an unsuccessful attack, and ascertained the  strength of his friends, would be afraid of attempting another  assault ; while their success, in sending him away, would probably excite them to adopt similar measures for procuring the  departure of the rest.** While uttering these sentiments, the  Captain forbade his expressing his opinion, and repeatedly said,  that if Mr. Burchell wished to hear such remarks, he w*s at  full liberty, but it must be on the beach, to which be should  be conveyed at a moment's notice, if he desired. Indeed this  gentleman had plainly told Mr. Burchell " that so long as he  (Mr. Burchell) followed his advice, he should receive his  protection ; but when he (Mr! Burchell) acted by himself, he  shou'd consider himself no longer bound to afford protection." Having entered into the engagement, Mr. Burchell  did not feel himself at liberty to withdraw from it ; and leaving the apartment for a few minutes, hastily wrote down the  reasons which had induced his decision, and which were those  urged by the Chief Justice—viz. the imminent danger to his  life, if he landed—the probable effusion of human blood  between the contending parties—and the probable evil bias  which his continuance on the island, and especially on the  'Bay, might have on the trials of Messrs. Gardner and Knibb,  then pending. These reasons, whether well founded or not,  were certainly important, and involved no sacrifice of principle or honour. Had he not been influenced more by regard  to the lives of others, and the public peace, than by consider-  at ions of personal comfort or safety, we are convinced Mr,  Burcheli would not have acceded to the urgent recommendation of the Chief Justice, the Attorney General, and D\\  Lawson, to leave the island. Having consented to leave, he  wrote some document, expressive of his having done so without constraint. Arrangements were made for his departure  —an American vessel, vvhich had recently arrived, being  chartered for the purpose of conveying him to the United  State*.  * This statement of tacts is very different from the tale put forth by the hafer*  of the missionaries — that these two gentleman went to the ship, to persuade Mr.  Burchell to come on shore, in order to have a trial of strength ! So far from their  having such a design, or even from volunteering a visit, they were actually sent  for by the Captain, and conveyed in one of the Ariadne's boats to the ship. Page 98																																asc9999001017		73  On Friday morning, March IGih, Mr. Burchell left the  shores of Jamaica for New-York, sixfy^sevendays after his arrival from England — a period spent in the most haiTassingcircum-  siances, calculated to wear out hoth body and mind. The  Master whom he served left, him not without support, nor  permitted him to fill into the hands of (hose, who, like the  Jews that sought the life of Paul, were lying in wait to kill him.  On Saturday, March 2-ith, Messrs. Samuel James  Vaughan, John Chambers, and Thomas Levermore, as a  deputation from Mr. BurchelTs friends,waited on his Honour  the Chief Justice, to thank hira for his kind interference to  protect Mr. Burchell from the mob, who had agreed to tar  and feather him ; an indignity which, according to Jamaica  usage, would have terminated in his death! His Honour, on  that occasion, was pleased to express honourable sentiments  of Mr. B's. character, lie remarked, that it was a fortunate  circumstance that he was on {lie spot, or else no doubt Mr.  Burchell, by that time, would not have been in existence,  and many other lives would have been lost; that Mr. Bur*  chell left Montego-Bay for New-York by his own will ;  that he never saw a man's mind more composed and peaceable than Mr. B's. His Honour informed them, he had  heard on good authority, that tar had been purchased, and  that some person was to go on board, professing to act as a.  friend, and advise him to come ashore ; when they were to  tar and feather him, and set him on fire! On receiving this  information, he had gone on board with the Attorney Gene-,  ral, and advised Mr. Burchell not to come—that Mr. 13. immediately remarked, he had no desire to go on shore ; and  being told there was a vessel to New York, said, that was  the place he wished to go to ; and though it was a very short  notice, and part of his things were on board the Garland  Grove, and part on shore, he would get them ready. His  Honour reminded these friends how near the gallows in the  market-place was, and how easily-Mr. B's. adversaries could  have taken him from them, and executed him !  The Christian reader will unite with us in devout thankfulness to God, who preserved and delivered His servant from  murderous enemies, doubtless for the furtherance of the  Gospel. And he will unite with us in cherishing the hope,  that when our brother shall have promoted the cause of religion and humanity in America, and his native land, as far as  -Divine wisdom may approve, he may be permitted to return  to Jamaica ; and under the auspices of extended toleration,  recommence his labours, 	asc99990010170098001											56574980 Bytes	3496	5392	925937664	RGB	asc99990010170098001.tif		2013-08-12	2013-08-12	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5872	5872	5873.jp2	/scbooks/image/5873.jp2

Governor, Council, and Assembly-of this island, in such case  made and provided, and against the peace of our said Lord the King*,  his Crown, and dignity. -  "That the said Francis Gardner, being such wicked and evil-disposed person as aforesaid, and further contriving' and intending as  aforesaid, heretofore, to wit, on the fourth day of December in the said  second year of the reign of oar said Lord the King, at the parish ofSh  James, in the County of Cornwall aforesaid, feloniously, maliciously,  and advisedly did endeavour to excite and stir op divers negro and  other slaves, whose names to the Jurors aforesaid are at present unknown, to commit traitorous and rebellious practices, for the purpose,  by force and constraint, and otherwise than by lawful means, of effecting a change in the state and condition of the slaves of this island,  as by law established, contrary to the act of the Governor, Council,  and Assembly of this island, in such case made and provided, and  against the peace of our said Lord the King", his Crown, and dignity. 	asc99990010170099001											62377616 Bytes	3813	5451	3821487338	RGB	asc99990010170099001.tif		2013-08-12	2013-08-12	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5873	5873	5874.jp2	/scbooks/image/5874.jp2
Page 100																																asc9999001017		*&lt; And the Jurors aforesaid, upon their oath aforesaid, do further  present and say, that the said Francis Gardner, being* such wicked and  evil-disposed person as aforesaid, and further contriving and intending-  as aforesaid, heretofore, to wit, on the fourth day of December, in the  said second year of the reign of our said Lord the King, at the parish  of St. James*, in the County of Cornwall aforesaid, feloniously, maliciously, and advisedly did endeavour to excite and stir kj&gt; divers  negro and other slaves, whose names to the Jurors aforesaid are at  present ■•unknown, to engage 'ina conjederacy, combination, and conspiracy, for the purpose, by force and constraint, and otherwise than'by  lawful means, of effecting a change in the state and condition of the  slaves of this island as by law established, contrary to the act of tho  Governor, Council, and Assembly Of this island, in such case made  and provided, and against the peace of our said Lord the King, his  Crown, and dignity."*  We have hinted at the difficulty encountered in preparing fur  the defence. No assistance was furnished by the document  we have set before the reader; for the inspection of it will  show, that; the charge it contains was most vague and indefinite. An indictment is supposed to inform, and in general  does inform the accused of the specific offence for which he  is to be tried, so that, he may prepare to meet it: and,  from the consideration manifested by the Legislature, in providing that a person charged with treason should be furnished  with 'd.copy of his indictment, cojiirary to the practice in every  other case of felony, It is natural to suppose that they in*  tended him to be made belter acquainted with his alledged  offence an this than in any other case. The fact is, however,  that the foregoing document -furnished no. single clue to  the nature of (he ''endeavour/' whether by word, gesture, or  otherwise, to the persons on whom it was practised, or even  to the time of its occurrence, or the parish in which it occurred. For though the 4th of December and the parish of  St. James, are mentioned, yet, on the authority of the professional persons employed, we can inform the reader, that  these data did not confine .the prosecutor in ihe least, and  th.aj an offence alledged to have been committed in any other  month, or parish in Cornwall, might have been brought  forward under the indictment!  The prisoners, Messrs. Knibb and Gardner, had not received the benefit of the means, ordinarily afforded to the  accused, of learning the nature of the charge, and evidnece  against them. The committing magistrate usually examines the  witnesses, in the presence of the accused, before his committal to prison for trial. "that  he found nothing therein to support a criminal prosecution.0  The Attorney General was not limited to the witnesses,  whose names were called out on the first day of Court, nor  M'as he bound to give a list of his witr^esses ; so that the accused  Mere uncertain whether there were not other witnesses, whose  names were not so called out. In preparing therefore for their  defence, they had to anticipate, underfhe system of persuasion,  intimidation, and bribery, already notoriously practised, the  possibility of sedition being laid to their charge, not only at  each of the Stations where they had ever preached) but also  of (hose at which they had not.  Paradoxical as it may seem that their innocence should rank  among the obstacles to their defence, yet. so it was that their  unconsciousness of having uttered any thing seditious at any  time or place, hindered them from selecting one ; whereas,  had they been only even partially guilty, their own consciences would have suggested the time and place, and thus put  them upon their guard. If was therefore necessary to be  prepared with hosts of witnesses from Falmouth, Savanna-la-  Mar, Salter's Hill, Shepherd's Mali, and Montego Bay, to  meet every contingency.  Messrs. Gardner and Knibb were arraigned, the first on  Tuesday the 13th, and the latter on the following dav ; and  the trials were fixed to take place on the ensuing Monday,  (the 19th). Great exertions, therefore, had io be made, in  preparing the notices to the witnesses, and having them properly warned. Though a great number of them were at the  distance of ten, twenty, thirty, and some nearly forty miles  from Montego Bay, in different directions, and though the  summoning of most was not effected until Saturday the 17th,  yet, on the appointed day, upward* of three hundred witnesses,  of different classes, joyfully assembled to testify in favour of  the missionaries.  Numreous innocent slaves from estates in the midst of the  disturbed district, and beyond its limits, cheerfu'ly attended  on this occasion, eager to give evidence in favour of I he perse? 	asc99990010170101001											62785000 Bytes	3840	5448	2614741650	RGB	asc99990010170101001.tif		2013-08-12	2013-08-12	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5875	5875	5876.jp2	/scbooks/image/5876.jp2
Page 102																																asc9999001017		77  cnted missionaries ; and for several days, to the great annoy*  ance of our enemies, continued to display exactly the reverse  of those feelings winch they would naturally have manifested,  had the missionariess led them into trouble by exciting false  hopes of freedom. A great number of free coloured persons  of respectability attended with the same readiness, many  possessing slaves, and many having lost all they were worth  by the incendiaries—glad to come forward in defence of the  accused, and prepared to state, not on the authority of rumour and hearsay, but from their own personal hearing, and  knowledge, and experience, the nature and tendency of the  doctrines advanced, and the discipline maintained, by their  calumniated ministers.  The disadvantages and discouragements under which these  missionaries came to trial were very considerable, and required  no ordinary faith' in the Divine Protector. Let the reader  remember, that the Jurors attending at the Montego Bay Court,  are collected from the several parishes in the county of Cornwall, in which the rebellion had occured ; viz. Trelawny, St.  James, Hanover, Westmorland, and St.Elizabeth; and in which,  consequently, the passions of the slave-holders in general had  been aroused to the highest pitch of violence ; and that the  Baptist missionaries were the chief objects against whom that  violence was directed.—Let him remember that in each of the  four first named parishes the white inhabitants, of whom principally the Juries are still composed, had pronounced our condemnation, among other methods, by the destruction of our  chapels.—Let him remember that while the missionaries were  in gaol, and within a few days of their trial, the inhabitants of  Montego-Bay, and the parish of St. James, including many of  the .lurors, had declared, in a public resolution, " That the  Baptist missionaries had 'wickedly abused the indulgence granted to them by a liberal and tolerant Government, and under  the pretence of preaching Christianity, engendered discontent  in the breasts of our slaves, and roused rebellion, and all the hideous crimes which have marked its course."-—Let him remenv  hex that the Grand Inquest not only had, in the exercise of its  own functions, found "true Bills" against two Baptist missionaries, and placed them upon trial for their lives, on what they  were pleased to term " a mass of evidence which had come before them," but which, as will be seen,when brought before the  public Court, dwindled away into the most contemptible nonsense—but had further arrogated to themselves the office of the  Petit Jury, and on the exparte evidence, such as it was, before  tiiem, bad, in a congratulatory address presented to the Chief 	asc99990010170102001											56612756 Bytes	3488	5408	2385676933	RGB	asc99990010170102001.tif		2013-08-12	2013-08-12	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5876	5876	5877.jp2	/scbooks/image/5877.jp2
Page 103																																asc9999001017		78'  Justice on the20th March, endeavoured to prejudice the case  of the accused, by " expressing their conviction that the Baptist missionaries had, in a culpable degree, been the cause of  the late rebellion." Letour reader further bear in mind, that one  of the Judges who was expected to preside, and did in fact preside at the trial, was Dr. George M'Farquhar Lawson the elder,  whose attempt to oppress, and whose sentence of condemnation,  we have already narrated--oneofthe parties, whose names stand  recorded in connection with that of William Wilson of Success,  in the Christian Record, No. V. p. P28, and the father and  abettor of the individual whose name is so intimately asso-  ciated.with that of Samuel Stennett.-—Let him also know, that  they were soon made to understand, that from the Crown Officers no courtesy would be shewn to proscribed Baptist mis*  sionaries—-a determination strictly adhered to subsequently, and  evinced by the careful concealment of the intention to prosecute Mr. Knibb, and by the studious withholding of any hint as  to the place where the crime was allegedtohavebeen committed.*  The reader, keeping all these things in view, will agree with us  that little dependence could be placed by the accused on human  strength. Happily, how,ever their reliancewas founded on a rock,  the providence and faithfulness of God, under a sense of their  innocence of the matter laid to their charge, and of the justness of their case. The instruments to whom they looked for  an impartial trial were the Chief Justice,f and the Jurors  from among the coloured population ; but as, owing to the  irregular manner of empannelling Juries in this island, the number of persons of this class included in them, is far less than  the number of whites, though the numerical superiority  is considerably the other way, there was no reason to expect that many persons of this description would be on the  trial.  * We do not wonder at the policy which actuated these gentlemen. It would  be toomuch to expect thatthose whose success in life depends on the favour bf'thfc  very persons who are our enemies, would hazard that favour by even the appearance of kindness to us. And even though such persons as Attorney-Generals may  be somewhat independent in pecuniary matters, of the people in question, yet the  risk of incurring general dislike and neglect —the fear of public detestation,"and of  exclusion from convivial entertainments, must necessarily exercise a powerful influence.  t The conduct, of this gentleman before and at the trial, as well as all we have  ever heard or seen of him, both as a Barrister and Chief Judge, constrain us to record our humble testimony to his uprightness, independence, and firmness, in acting up to his sense of right. To his assurance to the Grand Jury of Cornwall,  that he would " follow no other guides but his oath and the law," all must allow  him to have faithfully adhered. 	asc99990010170103001											63284832 Bytes	3848	5480	2403530064	RGB	asc99990010170103001.tif		2013-08-12	2013-08-12	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5877	5877	5878.jp2	/scbooks/image/5878.jp2

He  stands indicted on an Act passed by the Legislature of this  island the Uth of December 1823, entitled ' An Act for the  more effectual prevention of treason, treasonable conspiracies,  and seditious meetings, for preventing the administering or  taking of unlawful oaths, and for other purposes relating to  seditious meetings.' Gentlemen of the Jury, the second  Section of this Act is as follows :—  "That if any person or persons whatsoever, after the day of  the passing of this Act, shall maliciously and advisedly endea-  * The»e are gentlemen of colour, 	asc99990010170104001											56539040 Bytes	3499	5384	1049305847	RGB	asc99990010170104001.tif		2013-08-12	2013-08-12	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5878	5878	5879.jp2	/scbooks/image/5879.jp2
Page 105																																asc9999001017		80  Your to excite or stir up any free person or slave to commit  any act of insurrection or rebellion, or make, or endeavour  to make, any rebellious or traitorous assembly, or to commit  any traitorous or rebellious practice, or to engage in any confederacy, combination, or conspiracy, for the purpose, by  force or constraint, or otherwise than by lawful means, of  effecting a change in the state and condition of the free  people or slaves of this island, as by. law established, or by  force or constraint, of compelling the Governor, or person exercising the functions of Governor, and the Council and Assembly of this island, or either of them, to consent to grant  or agree to such change, or iu order to put auy force or con*  straint upon, or to intimidate or overawe, the Governor, or  person exercising the functions of Governor, and the Council and Assembly of this island, or either of them, being  legally convicted thereof, then every such person and persons, so as aforesaid offending, shall be deemed, declared,  and adjudged to be guilty of felony, and shall suffer death  without benefit of Clergy: Provided always, That nothing;  herein shall cause a forfeiture or corruption of blood.'  4i Gentlemen of the Jury—It is upon this section of the  Act that the prisoner has been indicted, and you will observe/  that the indictment contains three counts. The first charges  the prisoner with having feloniously, maliciously, and advisedly endeavoured to stir up and excite the slaves to rebellion, for the purpose of effecting a change in their state and  condition. The second count charges the prisoner, with  having feloniously, maliciously, and advisedly endeavoured to  stir up and excite slaves to commit traitorous and rebellious  acts ; and the third count, which differs from the others  only in terms, charges the prisoner with having feloniously,  maliciously, and advisedly endeavoured to stir up and excite  the slaves to engage in rebellious combination and conspiracy.  " Gentlemen, I have had the honour of addressing you  before on the meaning and extent of this Act, but as some of  you may not have heard me on that occasion, 1 shall again  call your attention to these particulars.—You must be satisfied, Gentlemen, in the first place, that the prisoner did endeavour to stir up and excite the slaves to rebellion ; and in  the second place, Gentlemen, you must be satisfied that he  did do so feloniously, maliciously, and advisedly; that is, he did  it, knowing what he was doing and saying at the same time.  You must remember, the words of the Act are, if he11 shall endeavour" to stir up and excite. It is not necessary for me to show  that the prisoner did succeed in stirring up and exciting a rebel- 	asc99990010170105001											62751012 Bytes	3840	5445	986659065	RGB	asc99990010170105001.tif		2013-08-12	2013-08-12	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5879	5879	5880.jp2	/scbooks/image/5880.jp2
Page 106																																asc9999001017		81  lion, but that be did endeavour to do so. You must, therefore,  take into consideration all the circumstances of the case,  from which you are to determine whether lie did endeavour  to stir up and excite to rebellion or not. 1 shall call vour  attention to a case which was tried in England, Rex vs. Fuller.  You will observe that the words read are nearly the same as  those in the Act of ibis island, which is copied from this  Flngiish Act. The individual was a soldier who was seduced  from his allegiance, and you will observe that the means  used, and the mauner of the inducement, were endeavours to  en (ice the soldier from his allegiance.    You will perceive by  . the answer to the objection, which I shall now read, that  the question rested entirely on the word endeavour.—Now,  Gentlemen, you wall, after considering all the circumstances,  and taking them in their connexion, form your own conclusions as to whether the prisoner did endeavour to excite  rebellion or not ; and if you are of opinion that he did, it will  be your duty to find the prisoner guilty.  ■" Gentlemen, (here is another requisite necessary in this  case, that the prisoner did endeavour to stir up and excite to  rebellion, advisedly, taking into your consideration also the  character which he holds ; for if he should  have addressed a  ! portion of his congregation in terms calculated to exite then*,  to acts of insubordination, you will conclude, he must have  done &o advisedly. I am quite sure you will dispel from your  minds ail prejudice'whatever against the prisoner; and if any  ot you are of the Baptist persuasion, you must not think that  I am prejudiced against him. I have no feeling of prejudice  myself. 1 have a feeling of toleration towards all sects of religion, and classes of persons ; but if you think him guiltv,  although you may be of that persuasion, you will not hesitate  to find a verdict against him. And, if any of you have suffered  by the late rebellion, I am satisfied you will not allow that, in  the slightest degree, to prejudice you against the prisoner at  the bar. In forming your verdict, you must be guided by the  evidence which shall be brought before you, and by that  alone. 1 shall now proceed to call the evidences on the part of  the Crown, as 1 consider this case worthy of inquiry.  ^ Chak-lks RrciD, aslave toUnity Hallestate, St. James, sworn. His Hon. the Chief Justice—" But, surely, that is another  circumstance ; and it must be the .same fact or circumstance  at the same time, witnessed by two slaves, or by one and a free  person. The words of the Act are quite clear." The  Learned Judge read (lie act, and inquired if the case cotdd  be carried any further ?  Mr. Attorney General contended that the act to be established against Mr. Gardner was that of "endeavouring to excite rebellion," and that two different expressions used  on two different days, and proved by two different  witnesses, were only (acts of one endeavour, and therefore the evidence adduced met the terms of the Act. He  was about to read a case tried in England, whenHis Honour  the Chief Justice observed, " No case tried in England can  overturn a positive enactment of the Jamaica Legislature,  which requires two slaves to corroborate the same fact ; but  these are not the same. You may as well say that because A  sees a man commit: a robbery in one lane or street, and B  sees him commit another robbery in another street, they can  prove the same lact."  Mr. Attorney General.—"But I cannot shew the fact on  the same day."  His Honour the Chief Justice.—"Then you cannot go on." (These remarks  of the Chief Justice were made with reference to the conduct  of those persons who, after the acquittal of Mr, Leonard;  Walker, a few days previously, of the charge -of exciting the  slaves to rebel, hissed the Jury, and otherwise disturbed the  decorum of the Court.)  i Mr. Gardner was -then released, and proceeded to his lodgings, attended by a concourse of friends of every description,  who showed by their demeanour that their joy at the result  of this affair was great beyond expression.  rJ ne case of Mr. Knibb was not brought forward in Court,  the Attorney General choosing to enter a nolle prosequi.  While the missionaries and  their friends felt thankful   to-  God   for  this deliverance  from  "unreasonable  and   wicked  men,"  it was jusily  a  matter of regret to  them,  that  they  were prevented from bringing forward their defence ;  because  they were thus deprived of an opportunity of adducing in open 	asc99990010170111001											62574134 Bytes	3832	5441	1376353484	RGB	asc99990010170111001.tif		2013-08-12	2013-08-12	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5885	5885	5886.jp2	/scbooks/image/5886.jp2
Page 112																																asc9999001017		87  .Court, by numerous and respectable witnesses, a real "mass  of evidence," exonerating them from the crimes laid to their  charge, and  ascribing the unhappy insurrection to its true  causes.  The evidence of Reid and Murray, as detailed in the forego-  in" report, is in substance the same as that published in the  Cornwall Chronicle oi: the 24th March. The comment of  Mr. Alexander Holmes, the Editor of that paper, (who, the  reader must remember, is one of our bitterest foes), is worthy  of noiice. It succeeds some remarks, on the trial of a Mr.  Alfred Smith, a white man, tried a few days before, on a charge  of being concerned in the rebellion ;  on which occasion " the  ,Attorney General threw up his brief, and said he would not  press the prosecution further."    They are as follows:  "The representations against Mr. Smith had been considered  as strong in proof as those of holy writ. There is no mode  of reconciling these matters, but on the ground of the disor*  dered—almost disorganized state of the public mind, occasioned by the horrors by which we were recently surrounded.  That Mr. Smith has been a martyr to the times ; that he has  suifered iu feeling, in character, and in finances, no man can  doubt; but we trust-he will console himself with ihe acquittal he has had, and feel grateful for the (air measure of British justice, which has preserved his life and restored lm  character. Yesterday the trial of Mr. Francis Gardner, Baptist minister, took place immediately after the sentence was  passed on the five prisoners convicted the preceding day.  The witnesses that were brought forward on the part of the  Crown completely failed in tjieiii proof against Mr.  Gardner; and the Attorney General, as in ihe case of Mr.  Smith, declined to proceed further."  It is scarcely necessary for us to remark on the glaring  absurdities stated by the two poor creatures who were employed to substantiate the long talked of charges against the  •missionaries. We cannot, however, dismiss the matter without  some notice of them.  Mr, Gardner is said by both to have stood up in his pulpit,  during the public services of the Sabbath forenoon, when the  chapel was; crowded with slaves and numerous free persons,  (many of these, let it be remembered, being themselves slaveholders), and, in a plain and intelligible manner, informed the  slaves that they "were free, they must sit doxon in their  own houses, and not mark after Christmas,—when buckra  come to trouble them, they must know what to say to  buckra—[hey  ixiu'i! go and lake  their free ii buckra would  m 	asc99990010170112001											57695730 Bytes	3560	5400	2181808242	RGB	asc99990010170112001.tif		2013-08-12	2013-08-12	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5886	5886	5887.jp2	/scbooks/image/5887.jp2
Page 113																																asc9999001017		88  not give it therm" These witnesses heard it on different da}rsv  under similar circumstances—each flatly contradicts the other,,  relative to their being together at chapel—each only heard it  once, Reid on a Sunday in the month before Christmas  -Day, and Murray on Christmas Day. But though this extraordinary discourse arrested the attention of Reid, yet he  treasured it up in his own breast, never whispered it to his  fellow7 slaves, and, in fact, did not think of it again until all of  them had M sat down," nor did he then mention what he had  heard. He still presened silence, and it was only when conducted into a private roam below the Court-house, by Dr.  George M'Farquhar Lawson, junior, on occasion of his (Keid's)  being brought in as a witness against some of his fellow slaves,,  that he, for thi: first time, divulged this wonderful secret.  It is a singular coincidence, that each witness mentions the  name of George Miller, from Unity Hall, as being present  with him ; ami yet so far from that person being brought forward in corroboration of either, he was, providentially, one of  the witnesses (the only one from Unity Hall estate) summoned on behalf of Mr. Gardner.  Among all the numerous auditors on the two occasions, not  . one could be found to support the testimony of ihese witnesses*  On the contrary, a crowd of the regular attendants at the  chapel, intelligent fvee persons and slaves, were present in  Court, ready to contradict their statements most flatly.  But w7e insult the commonsense of our readers, by so sen*  ous a notice of this evidence. Let them only notice those  parts of it printed in Italics and capitals, and the monstrous  absurdity of it will not fail to strike them. We feel sure that  we speak truth, when we say, that every person present, from  the Chief Justice down to the lowest constable, including our  enemies and the Grand Jurors, (for many of each were .there),,  entertained   the same opinion ;  viz.   that  a  more  frivolous,  , nonsensical case never wasted the time of a Court of Justice.  It proved to the fabricatorsand promulgators of the gross falsehoods uttered against our Body, a most unhappy " throw7;" for  it has established the fact, that the component parts of the  boasted "mass of moral evidence" cannot stand the test of a  public scrutiny. Had Keid and Murray and Stennett been  shot, as soon as their depositions were made, their "dying declarations" too might have been trumpetted about the conn-  .try; but the rash attempt of our enemies to obtain the conviction of some Missionary, as a ratification of their base assertions and lawless proceedings, has redounded to their  shame and defeat.    The result of this dial, and the ignomi- 	asc99990010170113001											63008334 Bytes	3848	5456	3342397935	RGB	asc99990010170113001.tif		2013-08-12	2013-08-12	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5887	5887	5888.jp2	/scbooks/image/5888.jp2
Page 114																																asc9999001017		89  nions exposure of Stennett's subornation, even if no other proof  existed, warrant the conclusion, that had our enemies dared to  confront us with every one of their executed witnesses, we  should not only have convicted them of falsehood, out of their  own lips, but have elicited confessions that would have fastened upon others of their sanguinary instigators crimes which  have already condemned the names of some of them, and  will render them odious to their own posterity.  It was not to be expected that men who could resort to  expedients, such as we have detailed, for injuring their fellow-creatures, possessed manliness and ingenuousness enough  to acknowledge their error, and our innocence. No, it was  more consistent with their previous practice, to invent new  calumnies, with which to cover their defeat. Accordingly,  these productions have been numberless; and we should have  enough to do to contend with every gratuitous slanderer, who  seeks popularity and money from the vitiated materials of  which this community is principally composed, by vituperating innocent missionaries. We think it well, however, now and  then to take advantage of a flagrant untruth, not on account  of its own weight or importance, but merely for the purpose of  occasionally giving the world an example of the character of  the men who slander us. Such an occasion presents itself  in the case of a rather confident writer in the Courant of the  2d of April, under the signature of" Querist," from Montego  Bay, on the subject of the trials in question. That the writer is  one of the leading persecutors, chapel-breakers, and suborners of perjury at that place, is quite clear ; and therefore it i*  the more necessary that his character should be exposed.  •—The first part of the letter concerns Mr. Gardner's journey through the interior, and is an attempt to prove, that had  the evidence, which was not adduced, been adduced, he would  have been convicted of all that was desired. This part of the  letter has been so ably answered in the Christian Record, No.  IV. p. 101 to 105, that we will refer the reader for the charge  and refutation to that work, with this remark, that if any portion of evidence was suppressed by the Attorney General, it  must have been with the concurrence, or through the oversight, of Mr. William Stanford Grignon, the parish Solicitor, by  whom the trial was conducted, and. who prompted the Attorney  General as to the jurors he should challenge, and sat by and  instructed him during the whole trial -t but the well known,  thorough missionary-hatred of this gentleman is ^sufficient 	asc99990010170114001											56496082 Bytes	3508	5366	258313897	RGB	asc99990010170114001.tif		2013-08-12	2013-08-12	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5888	5888	5889.jp2	/scbooks/image/5889.jp2
Page 115																																asc9999001017		90  guarantee, that he left nothing undone that he could do to  convict Mr. Gardner.—The .passage affecting Mr.. Knibb,. to  which we refer,.is this :— f} Knibbs was not put upon his trial.  I do not know what were the charges against him, but I can  relate the following circumstance. The Rev. Mr. Blyth, the  Presbyterian Minister for Hampden Church, left this island  .during .the course of last year ; the slave portion of his con-  (jregcdion attended Mr. Knibbs, during his absence; and on, |&  return, shortly before Christmas, they called upon him to  know if they were to be free after the holidays. He replied,  No; and said he had just come from England, and had heard  nothing about it. They appeared offended at him, and he demanded from them the author of their supposition, when they  answered, parson Knibbs, .Knibbs, hearing that this fact  had come to the, knowledge of Mr. Blyth, immediately sent  messengers about to say that he did not mean to tell them  that they were to be free, and that they must return to their  work. My information on this subject has been derived from  two or three, who heard it from Mr. Blyth. "  In reply to this, we need only give the following extract  from Mr. Blyth's letter on the subject, published in the  Courant of 13th April. " During my absence from the country, Divine Service was performed in my Church every alternate Sunday by the Rev. Mr. Waddell, so that few, if any, of my  congregation attended Mr. Knibb. None o( my people asserted that they had heard him (Mr. Knibb) say, that they were  to be free, but that some of the Baptist people informed them  Jie had told them so." M Mr. Knibb did not hear accident  tally' of these reports having reached me, but directly from  myself. Although not previously acquainted with him, /  failed on the second day of the Christmas holidays, and inr  formed him of what had been stated to me; when he most  decidedly denied having at any time said that the slaves had  got their freedom; and, in my hearing, gave directions to one  of .his people to go immediately to several estates where he  had members, to warn them against having any connexion  with the insurrection, and threaten, with immediate exclusion^  all who might be found implicated in it."  Shortly after the trials, Messrs. Knibb, Gardner, Abbott^  .Whitehorne, and Dendy, with their wives, left Montego-Bay  by water, in different vessels. The largest party very narrowly  escaped shipwreck ; but all, through the gracious care of Pro-*  v dence, safely arrived in Kingston. And all the missionaries  having assembled there, and in Spanish-Town, special meetings  were held for prayer and praise,, on account of the eminent  mercies.'we had experienced, ^ 	asc99990010170115001											61611764 Bytes	3773	5441	3235662641	RGB	asc99990010170115001.tif		2013-08-12	2013-08-12	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5889	5889	5890.jp2	/scbooks/image/5890.jp2
Page 116																																asc9999001017		CHAPTER VII.  Proceedings at St. Ann's Bay.—Arrest and release of 1M&gt;, Nichols.—Visit of Adjutant Cocking and others.—Military searches.—Foirmtion of the Colonial  Church Union.—A farce acted at the Court-house.—Mr. Nichols forbidden, by  Lieut. Colonel Johnston, to convene any meeting,- -Attack on his Chapel.—Thai,  matter taken to the Peace Office.—Obtaining no protection, he escapes la  Town.—Destruction of the Chapels.  It .will be remembered, that at the commencement of the disturbances, Mr. Nichols was one of the missionary party at,  Falmouth ; and that on account of indisposition, Colonel,  Cadien granted him a passport to return to St. Ann's Bay, his  place of abode. With this document he left Falmouth, on.  Tuesday, January 3d, and, with his wife and infant child,  reached home the next day, unmolested. He found (he.  parish of St. Ann in perfect tranquillity, excepting the dis-.  turbances created by the militia; the slaves being every;  where at work as usual. The first Sabbath after his return,  was his regular day for preaching at Ocho Rios, eight miles  from St. Ann's Bay ; and though he was ill able to preach,,  he was desirous ol meeting the people as usual ; but the dissuasion of a friend, and the seizure of his horses for the King's  service, prevented* He therefore addressed to the church'  and congregation, which he expected to assemble as usual, a,  letter of affectionate counsel, urging their continuance in a  course of peaceable and obedient conduct. This letter was;  read to them by one of the members, and it is hoped iiad a.  good effect. Being prevented from proceeding thither, he  determined to conduct service at home; but in this also he  was disappointed ; for on the Sabbath morning, between eight  and nine o'clock, a military guard was dispatched to conduct  him to the Guard-house. They found him at breakfast, and  meditating on Col. iii. 22—25 from which passage he was  just about to enforce the obedience of servants to their  masters. Without hesitation he accompanied the., guard*'  which consisted, of an Ensign and four privates, armed with,  drawu sword and fixed bayonets, and was politely received at  the Court-house by Lieut. Colonel Johnston, who had the  command, and told he was at liberty to send for-any thing he  pieced from home, to promote his comfort. But being in-  M 2 	asc99990010170116001											57646428 Bytes	3536	5432	1384154088	RGB	asc99990010170116001.tif		2013-08-12	2013-08-12	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5890	5890	5891.jp2	/scbooks/image/5891.jp2
Page 117																																asc9999001017		92  formed by that gentleman that he was not wanted to perform  military duty, he was at a loss to conceive for what reason  his presence had been required.    When the time of dinner  Came, he was allowed to go  home  under a   guard of two  privates, and to be absent one hour.    In the afternoon the  Lieut. Colonel and Captain  Walker went to him, and proposed releasing him oil bail,  i! he could obtain two responsible Europeans, to become his sureties ; and they added, that  if he failed to procure bail, he sbould nevertheless be allowed  to go home to sleep, a guard being  placed   on  his house.  Application was consequently made to two gentlemen, one of  whom declined, but the  other offered to become the  sole  security to any amount.    However, the matter being discussed  at  the officer's dinner-table,  the whole proposal was overruled, as it was then determined that in Martial Law no bail  could be taken ; contrary  to   the decisions in the cases of  Messrs, Knibb, Wrhitehorne, and Abbott, Mr. Gardner,  and  Mr. Barlow.     He was also informed, that though the officers  Mere desirous of showing ail leniency, they could not, consistently with their duty, allow him to go home for the night,  but he might send   for his bed.    This was accordingly done,  and he rested pretty comfortably on the floor, in a room at  the back of the main guard-room.    Just as he had retired to  rest, one of the officers gave him (not officially)  the first intimation he received respecting the cause of his detention.  He told him that information had been lodged against him  by Colonel 8. W. Rose, of the Middlesex regiment of horse.  This is one of the two magistrates removed from the Commission  of the  Peace  by Sir  John Keane, for their persecution of  Messrs. Whitehouse and Orton, Wesleyan missionaries, and  restored by the Earl of Bel more.    The information was to  this effect: That a woman living at Cardiff Hall, who had  lately bought herself free, was told by Mr. Nichols she was a  fool for buying her freedom, as she would soon have obtained  it for nothing.     This was the accusation,  on which it appeared Mr. N. had  been arrested ; ami   perhaps the  reader  may coincide with the gentleman who mentioned it to him,  in terming it •* a foolish charge."    The  next  day he continued in confinement, hearing nothing more of the charge,  till live or six o'clock ; when, soon after he had returned from  dinner, guarded as before, and was expecting another night's  lodgings in that place, Captain Walker informed him,   "that  some charges had been brought forward, in which he was1  concerned; but Colonel Johnston and  himself .having consulted with  Mr,   Raffingtou, ibe  Cierk ol the Peace, they 	asc99990010170117001											62285872 Bytes	3815	5440	95230628	RGB	asc99990010170117001.tif		2013-08-12	2013-08-12	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5891	5891	5892.jp2	/scbooks/image/5892.jp2
Page 118																																asc9999001017		m  were not clear upon the matter; and therefore they had  tome to this determination—-that if Mr. Nichols would  give them his word of honor, that he would hold no  nightly meetings, nor leave his house, during Martial Law, and  would report himself there every day at twelve o'clock, they  would release him." Feeling no objection to these terms, lie  was* released accordingly, and heard no more of the allegation.  Of his treatment by the officers, either during his close custody, or at his daily appearance at the Court-house to report  himself, for thirty days afterwards, he had no reason to complain ; indeed some of them treated him with marked civility.  This was well ; for though he had done no wrong, he was then  in the power of those who could have adopted a different  course with impunity. Respecting the truth of the alleged  offence, Mr. Nichols has no recollection of having made  such a remark to any persoiiy nor is it probable *, for he never  discouraged any slave from buying his freedom, and at that  very time had recently lent one of his members the sum of  £10. to assist him in a similar object.  Although during the existence of Martial Law, Mr. Nichols  held no meetings whatever, suspicions of the contrary \\ ere  indulged, and vigilance was exercised to ascertain the fact.  On one occasion, about eight o'clock in the evening, four men,  dressed in regimentals, walked up into the Chapel, professing  to think, because a lamp was burning, that a meeting must  have been held. So far from conducting any service, Mr  Nichols was retiring to bed, and this single lamp was burning  to light the family in passing into the residence, which closely  adjoined the Chapel on the same floor. But though informed  of these circumstances, one of the party, Adjutant Cocking,  spoke to Mrs. Nichols, who went out to meet them, in a very  high and peremptory tone, making various inquiries respecting the domestics, advising her *' as a friend" to take care  what was done, and declaring u. that if any religious meeting  were discovered there, either by night or by day, not a stick  of the Building should remain, and he himselj tcou/d be the  first to come and set fire to it I11 After this extraordinary speech  they walked down stairs, Mr. N's. servant attending them  with a light ; and having examined the lower part of the  premises, took themselves off. But this was moderate and  gentlemanly conduct, compared with the gross insults which  this party offered Mr. Whitehouse, at the VVesleyan Chapel,  that same evening.  It was in these and similar exploits, that the valour of these  soldiers was most cocwspicuous.
