Page 119																																asc9999001017		94  observed a detachment of the militia, on horse-back, .passing:  his house with speed, as though setting out on some import-?  ant military expedition ; and on inquiring their object, learn|  they were proceeding to some neighbouring property, to search  the Negro-houses for fire-arms, and examine slaves. On one of  these occasions, Captain Walker, with a party under his direction, whom he first regaled at his own property, Shaw Park, without suffering an examination of his own people, proceeded  to Great Pond estate, where they found two brothers named  Paisley, one a Baptist, the other a Wesleyan. These men  they brought forward, and inquired of them very strictly,  " If their ministers had not told them they were to serve  but one master, Jesus Christ, and not to work for their  owner." When they both repeatedly declared to the contra?  ry, they were asked if they would swear to it; and on their  answering that they could safely swear to it, with a clear  conscience, the book was produced, and each of them required  to kiss it. But will the Christian world believe it ?—even after  this they were tied, and taken to St. Ann's Bay, about ei^ht  miles distant, as prisoners ; where they were detained at. the  Guard-house a day or two, again closely examined, and when  falsehood^could not be elicited from them, dismissed. Some  other proprietors, as well as Capt. Walker, who had religious  slaves, refused to have their own properties searched in this  military manner; affirming that their people had done nor  thing amiss, and therefore they should not be exposed to such  treatment. And one Overseer, if not more, whose people  wrere attentive to their duty, kindly advised them to conceal  any books, or benches, or any thing else they might possess^  pertaining to a negro class-house, lest such a search should  be made among them, and their property and persons should  sustain injury.  flaying persevered in efforts to criminate the missionaries  till all hope of success had fled, another scheme was invented,  by which it was hoped to expel them all from the 'island,  whether guilty or nqt. Men in power in (his parish now der '  termined to attempt things on a larger scale, and hoped, by a  formal union, to accomplish an object which had hitherto  been found impracticable. A meeting was therefore called  at St. Ann's Bay, January 26th, from which resulted that  famous compact, entitled "'Tins Colonial Church Union,"!1  In furtherance of the object of this meeting, the following  paper was placarded at several places on the Bay, and printed  in some of the island Journals:—  * See Appendix No. V, 	asc99990010170119001											63216078 Bytes	3872	5440	3503389430	RGB	asc99990010170119001.tif		2013-08-12	2013-08-12	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5893	5893	5894.jp2	/scbooks/image/5894.jp2
Page 120																																asc9999001017		m  ^Inhauitants of Jamaica !  ''Your danger is great!■■ If you have discovered the source  ,of\ our disease, lose not a moment in expelling the poison  from your veins. Bally round your Church and Kirk, before  it is too late, and defend yourselves fronri ail who attack them ;  the preservation of your wives, your children, your properties,  your houses, nay, of your very lives, demands it. A Colonial  Church Union is all you want to unite the friends of the  colony in a defence which must then succeed."  About this time, and in conformity with the spirit and object of this Union, a circumstance of an amusing nature  transpired at the Bay. One of Mr. Nichols* members, a free  black, who was serving in the militia, went to him with evi^  dent concern, inquiring whether ua law," which he said had  just been passed in the Court-house, " could stand." Mr.  Nichols smiled, and on inquiring into so singular a matter,  the man explained as follows: That about an hour before,  severalcompanies of the militia, consisting of whites, coloured,  and blacks, were called together in the Court-house ; when  Captain Walker came forward with a paper in his hand, which  he read to them, and wished to know if they would all agree  to. This paper contained nothing less than a proposal to  send off the island every Dissenting Preacher, of every colour i  but its meaning was expressed in such " high buckra language,"  that scarcely one of the blacks, and very few of the coloured  men understood it. The object of obtaining the consent of  the militia to such a proposal, we suppose must have been to  secure their co-operation, in case it should be necessary to  send away the missionaries by force. As soon as this paper  was read, aud put to tie vote, the Light Infantry n en (a  very depraved and mischievous company, under Captain  Drake), joyfully assented ; one or two coloured men,  who understood the matter, declared they never would agree  to such a measure ; but the majority of the others fell  in with it, and consequently the proposal was said to be carried. After this farce was concluded, however, many of the poor  fellows were sadly chagrined at what they had done ; for when  they came to understand the affair, they declared they had been  altogether deceived ; they really thought, that as money was  very scarce, and their pay was not forthcoming, the paper had  been intended to inquire if they would agree to take out part  of their pay in articles of clothing, such as a pair of shoes, a  hat, &c. &c. After such an exhibition, who could feel respect  for Mr. Walker, though a magistrate, and member cf Assembly  f°l that parish ? If. men would be respected, they must be  respectable,  /  u 	asc99990010170120001											56683720 Bytes	3504	5390	338150217	RGB	asc99990010170120001.tif		2013-08-12	2013-08-12	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5894	5894	5895.jp2	/scbooks/image/5895.jp2
Page 121																																asc9999001017		96  Mr. Nichols had not been prohibited, except by Adjutant  Cocking, from holding religious services in the day tune, and  the cause of his not assembling a congregation for three Sabbath forenoons, arose chiefly from ill health. But finding  his strength sufficiently restored, he contemplated preaching  on Sunday forenoon, February 5th, and acquainted Colonel  Johnston with his intention, in the following letter :—  " Baptist Chapel House, St. Anui's Bay, Jan. 27,1832  "Sir,  " Since the proclamation of Martial Law, I have hitherto refrained  from holding any religious service, or calling any meeting whatever  of my congregation. But, provided you see no material objection, f  wish to recommence, on Sunday next, the usual forenoon worship in  this chapel; and to hold a similar service every Sunday forenoon, so  long as the obstructions imposed by the present state of public affairs  shall prevent my attending to my other Stations, In your communications with me, I have understood your restrictions to be confined to  nightly meetings; but to obviate any doubts which might possibly  arise in other minds, and to prevent any unpleasant occurrence, I  l»ave deemed it advisable to consult you on the subject. Waiting*  the favour of a reply,  ** I am, Sir, your most obedt. servt.  " SAMUEL NICHOLS.  «• To Col. Johnston."  Reply.  " Head Quarters, St. Ann's Bay, Jan. 27, 1832.  " Sir,  "I have it in orders from Major General Cox, to forbid your assembling any congregations of free or slave subjects, during the pre-  sea {disturbances.  " I am, Sir, your obedt. servant,  " J. JOHNSTON,  " Lieut. Colonel, commanding St. Ann's Regiment,"  Under this prohibition, unjust as it always appeared to  him, Mr. Nichols did not attempt to preach, or assemble any  congregation. Page 122																																asc9999001017		97  hibition must have originated in some other feeling than a  desire for public tranquillity—even, in the same spirit, of hostility against religion, which soon afterwards broke out in open  violence.  Frequently were vulgar expressions of haired and evil in  tention heard by Mr. Nichols/from persons -passing his house,  which he disregarded ; and repeatedly lie was told of male,  voient expressions being used by several of the militia-officers,  against the missionaries generally ; but these had become too  common to excite much notice. No sooner, however, did the  news reach the Bay, of the feats performed in destroying the  chapels at Falmouth, Rio Bueno, and Brown's Town, than  thehaters of religion meditated destruction therealso, and commenced with a shameful and outrageous attack on our chapel. This took place on Friday, February 10th, at about iea  o'clock at night. Mr. and Mrs. Nichols were just retiring to  rest, and a candle was burning in the hall, when they were  suddenly alarmed by a violent knocking, with some heavy in-  strument, at the front door of the chapel; evidently not for  admission, but for the purpose of bursting it open. After a  few blows Ihe door gave way, when a number of persons  rushed up the chapel-steps, and at the same moment some  others entered the chapel by another -flight of steps, at that  end of the building appropriated to a residence. Instantly  as they entered, they commenced dashing to pieces the windows and pews. Two large sashes in the centre of the chapel were wholly dashed out, and every other window but  one, broken it a pieces. Four pews were entirely demolished,  and all the materials, together with a number of benches,  thrown out at the windows. During these depredations, Mr,  and Mrs. Nichols, with their infant child, a female servant,  and two other children, had fastened themselves into the bed  room, separated from the chapel only by a thin boarded partition, where they were expecting every instant to be broken  in upon and murdered. Unable to send out for assistance,  Mr. Nichols threw up the window, and cried " Murder, mur-  the trial of Wm. Rae, the chief rebel, belonging to Unity Valley, we are at a loss  to know, unless it is to bring him off dear. Page 123																																asc9999001017		98  der!" About (his time Mr. W. S. Barker, a magistrate  residing on the Bay, alarmed at the noise, hastened to the  spot, and ordered the depredators, in the King's name, to desist; immediatelysending to the main Guard-room for assistance. Lieut. Smith, with several of: his men, promptly attended ; but as they entered by one door, it is supposed the depredators escaped by the other. The building was thus saved, for  the present, from entire demolition, and the lives of its inmates  preserved. This attack was most furious and daring; it is  difficult to convey any adequate idea of it to the distant reader.  The assailants must have known that Mr. and Mrs. Nichols were in the house. They made no attempt at secresy,  and the peaceable inhabitants of the Bay were alarmed beyond expression at the dreadful noise; some concluding that  the persons wilhin would certainly be murdered, and others  supposing that another insurrection had commenced.  A singular and rather suspicious circumstance attended this  outrage. When the guard went from the Court-house to  quell the disturbance, their muskets were not loaded, nor had  they ihe means of loading thenrif necessary ; for Lieut. Smith  told Mr. Nichols, that in the course of that very day, all the  I)a 11-cartridge had been taken away from the men on guard.  We shall not attempt to account for this unusual occurrence,  but suspicions were expressed on the spot, that the attack was  not altogether unexpected by those who had the direction of  the military operations, and that this precaution had been pur~  posely taken. As Martial Law had ceased two days before,  and Party Law been substituted,the military were then under  the control of the Civil Power, as usual.  The next day, Mr. Nichols made oath to the circumstances,  before Thomas Raffington, and Wm. S. Barker, Esquires, at  the Peace Office. He also cited three witnesses, who bore testimony against four men (two belonging to the Light Infantry company, and two attached to the St. Ann's Troops,) whom they  saw at or near the Chapel at the time, and believed to have  been engaged in the mischief. But the Magistrates professed  to consider their evidence insufficient to warrant, the apprehension of the accused. They said, indeed, that they would not  decide the case, but would refer it to a full bench of magistrates, who were expected to sit in course of the ensuing week,  and the result should be made known to Mr. Nichols; but  he heard no more of the matter. Three days afterwards the  whole building was demolished, before the expected sitting  took place; and it does not appear that the magistrates ever  concerned themselves again respecting this businesst    At the 	asc99990010170123001											61485756 Bytes	3766	5440	212281171	RGB	asc99990010170123001.tif		2013-08-12	2013-08-12	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5897	5897	5898.jp2	/scbooks/image/5898.jp2
Page 124																																asc9999001017		Peace Office, Mr. Nichols perceived an evident leaning in favour of the perpetrators, and desire to bring the evidence of  the deponents to nothing. He introduced a person who had  that morning found in his grass-piece a cloak, supposed to  have been left behind by one of the depredators in his flight.  This cloak would probably have been used by the police of  any better country than Jamaica, as a clue to discover its  wearer; but here, as its wearer was perhaps known well  enough, Mr. Raffington turned the whole into ridicule, and  dismissed the witness without a single question.  Often have Dissenting missionaries been convinced, that  much of the antipathy existing against them in this country,  arose from ignorance of their sentiments and discipline, and  of the general question of dissent. A rare specimen of this  ignorance was exhibited on this occasion, and that by a person from whom better things were expected. Mr. Nichols  was astonished when he heard Mr. Raffington, Clerk of  ihe Peace and Court, Clerk of the Vestry, Solicitor,  and Town Clerk, ask the several witnesses, as they came  forward to be sworn, " What are you? are you a Pro*  testant, or are you a Baptist?" In very good keeping,  one of them replied, with great earnestness, " No, Sir! I  always attend the Church of England!" He was neither a  Baptist, nor a Protestant, but a Church of England man !  Finding that no practical measures were taken by the Au*  thorities, to bring the depredators to punishment, they and  their accomplices were emboldened for further outrages.  They openly gloried in what they had done, and were eager  to complete the work of destruction. Remarks were publicly enough made the same day, of a nature to warrant the  conclusion, that they would not be satisfied till the Chapel  was demolished, and that the tone of feeling against Mr.  Nichols was increasingly malignant. All hope of usefulness  for the present, being now cut off, and the personal danger to*  himself and family apprehended to be very serious, he determined on quitting the place, to seek refuge in town. Jn this  resolution he was confirmed by a conviction, arising from the  painful experience of the preceding night, that his presence  in the building would not save it from demolition ; and by  the apprehension, that he would probably be murdered, on a  second attack, to prevent his becoming a witness. In the  forenoon, at the Peace Office, Mr. Raffington had promised  to send a guard, to protect the premises at night, so long  as guards might be continued at the Court-house ; but when  the evening came, no guard appeared ; and on application to  n'2 	asc99990010170124001											57278806 Bytes	3550	5376	584630374	RGB	asc99990010170124001.tif		2013-08-12	2013-08-12	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5898	5898	5899.jp2	/scbooks/image/5899.jp2
Page 125																																asc9999001017		100  a magistrate, it was with difficulty Mr. Nichols could obtain  one single man. This, of course, was very inadequate protection • and having no free people connected with the chapel, who were in circumstances to protect, he was obliged to  leave the premises unguarded. Having therefore caused his  books and apparel, with part of his furniture, to be hastily  removed to friends houses, on the same evening, and obtained  lodgings for that night, he started early on the Sabbath  morning, with Mrs, Nichols and their infant, for Spanish  Town ; where, after great suffering experienced by the latter  on the road, the effect of Friday night's alarm, they safely arrived the next afternoon, and met with a cordial reception from  Mr.Taylor, at our mission-house. They only who have dwelt  among enemies, can estimate the suffering experienced in a  situation, where every distant voice is conceived to express  some mischievous design, and every footstep to indicate the  approach of a foe:—They only can appreciate the pleasures  of safety, or anticipate with suitable emotions that eternal  blessedness, in which shall be felt  " No rude alarms of raging foes-  No cares to break the long repose/'  The next day, Tuesday, February 14th, our mission pre*  mises at St. Ann's Bay, together with the Wesleyan Chapel,  were entirely demolished, in the forenoon, and the materials  stolen. And in the afternoon, some of the same party who  committed this outrage proceeded to Ocho Rios, and burnt  the two chapels there. After these depredations, Messrs.  WhitehouseandWood,Wesleyan missionaries,and Mr Nichols,  were hung in effigy, under a shaddock tree on otir chapel ground  at the Bay ; but afterwards the figures were taken down, by order  of Mr. Custos Cox, and were exhibited elsewhere. The next  day, Wednesday, February 15th, the rioters and their friends  assembled on the Ray, and held a general meeting of the  Colonial Church Union; when several Resolutions were  passed, the fifth of which bound the Union to support and  protect the cliapel-breakers*!  * For these Resolutions, sec Appendix, No. V» 	asc99990010170125001											61784238 Bytes	3792	5429	1145314002	RGB	asc99990010170125001.tif		2013-08-12	2013-08-12	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5899	5899	5900.jp2	/scbooks/image/5900.jp2
Page 126																																asc9999001017		CHAPTER VIII.  Arrest of Mr. Barlow.—His confinement at Buff Bay.—He protests against his  treatment, and appeals to the Governor.—Sentiments of Lieut. Shenton.-—  Means resorted to for convicting Mr. Barlow.—Mis release on bail.—Correspondence with Mr. Custos Bell.—Two Overseers violently enter the Chapel.—  Circumstances relative to Mr. Bui ton, at Manchioneal.—Examination of Mrs.  Brown and her house.—Accusations elicited by punishment.—Visit of Mr.  Panton and others.—Citation of Mr. Taylor in Spanish Town.  Mr. Barlow, who occupies the Stations at Annotto Bay and  Buff Bay, in the absence of Mr. Flood from the country, experienced no interruption in his work till Friday, January 6th,  when, being   peaceably   engaged  at his   residence,  he   was  visited by Lieut.   Shenton, and   two   privates of the Surry  Regiment of   Horse.    They   approached   him   with   drawn  swords, and the officer told him he came to arrest him in the  King's name.    He asked on what grounds; when the officer  replied, he was not at liberty to inform him, but he supposed  Mr. Barlow was not at a loss to imagine the  cause.    Mr.  Barlow then called to some negroes employed by him, and  told them to leave their work, and he would give them a pass,  that they might not be molested in returning to their master,  who lived at several miles distance.    On which Lieut. Shenton told him, he could not allow him to write any thing, unless he saw it; nor could he suffer him to communicate with  any   negroes.     Having,   by  the  consent of this  gentleman,  changed his dress, Mr. Barlow accompanied his military at-,  tendants; and as they passed through Annotto Bay, he saw  one of the members of the church, a slave, belonging to Mr.  Bond, and a most confidential servant to his  master.    This  poor man appeared much dejected at seeing his minister under a guard of soldiers, and iu passing, Mr. Barlow said to  him, in a low voice, u Now, John, do not forget to pray that  the Lord will be a wall of (ire round about me;" alluding to  a passage of Scripture from which he had preached the week  before.    The Lieut, appeared very angry at this remark,  and  observed, " He knew it was a figurative expression, but in the  present excited state of the negroes,  Mr.  Barlow  must  be  aware it was  a   very dangerous one.     Mr.   Barlow  replied  ''that it was a Scriptural expression/ that he had but a short 	asc99990010170126001											56938222 Bytes	3525	5382	1269451207	RGB	asc99990010170126001.tif		2013-08-12	2013-08-12	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5900	5900	5901.jp2	/scbooks/image/5901.jp2
Page 127																																asc9999001017		102  time before endeavoured to explain it to his hearers—that he  was not aware of the negroes in that neighbourhood being in  a state of excitement—that the expression was not likely to  produce such an effect, because the man to whom it was uttered, who was a truly good man, though a slave, would not  misunderstand its meaning !" However, this gentleman insisted on the impropriety of Mr. Barlow's thus expressing  himself, being under arrest, and that unless he gave him his  word not to speak to any negroes again, he would take measures to prevent him. Mr. Barlow replied, he could make no  such promise, because it was his earnest desire to be remembered in the prayers of God's people, especially under circumstances of a distressing nature. On arriving at Buff Bay,,  this officer drew his sword, and ordered his men to do the  same; and, after a little parading to and fro, conducted Mr.  Barlow to the main Guard-house, and gave him in charge to  the officer of the guard ; when a chair was brought him, and  a centinel placed on either side of him. Beingsoon compelled,  by.the sickening effect of thenoise and smoking ofthe soldiers,  to request the officer to have him removed into a quiet part  of the house, he was, after some delay, marched into a room  filthy in the extreme, as though just cleared of a company  of drunkards to make way for him.  He had not been long in this situation, the centinels standing with fixed bayonets in the room, before he was visited by  Major Gray, Captain Baugh, and two or three other officers  Major Gray told him, ' that being the officer in command, he considered it his duty to have him brought thither  in consequence of information he had received, that the doctrines he was in the habit of preaching, tended to excite the  negroes to rebellion ;" especially, said he, ivhen I hear such a  dreadful expression as *' a wall of fire ;" thus making use  of information obtained after Mr. Barlow's arrest, as a prin*  cipal reason for his being arrested ! Mr. Barlow told him  that the expression, well understood, contained nothing  dreadful, nothing alarming; but on the contrary, to the  Christian mind, it was a source of great consolation and hap*  piness. But although the Major stated that he had known  his Bible well from his youth, he declared that Mr. Barlow, in employing this phrase, could have had no other intention than " to set the negroes to burn and destroy the whole  country, and drive all the inhabitants into the seal" He  also said something indistinctly, (his anger having apparently  deprived him of the power of distinct articulation), about  prrivate and nightly meetings with the negroes ;   to which 	asc99990010170127001											62137464 Bytes	3808	5437	3615069609	RGB	asc99990010170127001.tif		2013-08-12	2013-08-12	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5901	5901	5902.jp2	/scbooks/image/5902.jp2
Page 128																																asc9999001017		103  Mr. Barlow replied, that as to meeting with them in the  evening, it certainly was (rue, for he considered it his  duty, as a Christian minister, when unable to speak to  them in the da}/, owing to their engagements for their  masters, to embrace any opportunity of doing so after  the toils of the day were over; but with regard to any  thing like privacy, he denied it altogether, as the chapel-  doors were thrown wide open, persons of free condition were  as welcome to attend as the bond, he had no cause to be  ashamed of the gospel of Christ, and whatever he had said to  any slave, or assembly of slaves, he was not afraid to repeat  in the Major's presence, as well as in the presence of his brother officers, or, if called upon to do so, even in the presence  of their King himself. The Major, however, seemed to have  decided that Mr. B. was a traitor, and his wrath appeared to  have overpowered his reason. Captain Baugh here interrupted, by saying to the Major, "-Well, we did not come to  argue with Mr. Barlow to night ; our object in coming, addressing Mr. Barlow, was to see that you be made as comfortable as circumstances admit of." He then asked Mr Barlow  if he wanted any thing to make him comfortable; and as it  was late, Mr. B. signified his wish to be provided with a bed,  which they promised should be sent. He was then shewn into  a room rather cleaner and more airy, and his visitors left  him ; but the promise of a bed not being fulfilled, he was left  to rest as he could.  About eight o'clock the following morning, some of Mr.  Barlow's friends sent his breakfast ; and from that time till  five o'clock in the evening, no one was allowed access to him,  not even his servant to bring him a drop of water ; so that he  became, in a close room, almost faint for want of refreshment.  Shortly after five he was visited by Major Gray and Lieut.  Colonel Moody ; the former apologized (or his abrupt be ha*?  viour and departure the night before, attributing it to a violent throbbing of the heart, with which he was seized, and  which continued for two hours. Lieut. Colonel Moody  then presented Mr. Barlow with a pap&lt;rr for his perusal,  stating that it contained the Colonel's order respecting him,  which was to the following effect ; viz. that all his wants  should be attended to, that his servant should have free access to him throughout the day, that any two of his friends  should be allowed to visit him at one time, from six in the  morning till six in the evening, subject to the observation of  the officer on guard ; but on no consideration was he to be  allowed to correspond with any one, or to have the use of pen  I 	asc99990010170128001											57595718 Bytes	3569	5377	3775853839	RGB	asc99990010170128001.tif		2013-08-12	2013-08-12	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5902	5902	5903.jp2	/scbooks/image/5903.jp2
Page 129																																asc9999001017		104  or paper. The Lieut. Colonel also told Mr. Barlow that his  door shotdd be closed at night. But in defiance of the regimental order, and of an assurance given Mr. B. by the officers, his friends were repeatedly denied access to him, between  the hours specified, although no one was with him at the  time. His friends, when \isiting him, were sometimes ordered to leave, under the plr.a of being about to change the  guard. It was frequently the case, on such occasions, that  the officer of the guard came into the room, and remained  there until his friends left. Whether these departures from  the aforesaid order are to be attributed to the officers of the  guard, or to their superiors, is not known ; but from whatever authority or cause it proceeded, Mr. Barlow found every  thing done to make his situation as irksome as possible. By  night his rest was disturbed, by the pacing of a centinel in his  room ; and by day he was exposed to insults from the common soldiers. On one occasion,, a private soldier asked the  centinel at Mr. Barlow's door, and in his hearing, u where is  the wild beast now P" u Oh ! here he is," was replied, and a  conversation of a very provoking and insulting nature ensued,  evidently intended for his hearing. When the centinel happened to be a white man, he was allowed to hold profane conversation with any person he could get near him ; but if any of  the soldiers of Mr. Barlow's congregation approached his door  to speak to him, they were ordered off by the officer on  guard.  About nine o'clock one evening, after Mr, Barlow had been  an hour in bed, he was visited by Lieut. Shenton and Captain  Swire, who told him they had come in consequence of information given the Colonel by a white serjeant, that during that  day, Mr. Barlow had offered him two dollars, (value about  eight shillings), to allow a broion serjeant to take his place  in guarding him, that he might then be able to make his  escape! Mr. Barlow replied that the information, whoever  had given it, was a barefaced falsehood ; and assured them,  that no conversation of the sort had taken place; that he had  said nothing at all to the serjeant on guard about money, or  about browns or whites. He then explained a circumstance  from which this charge was supposed to have arisen, and the  officers appearing satisfied, said they would make known the  explanation to the Colonel, and hoped by this means to avert  the order^ for a more close and rigorous confinement, which,  in consequence of this allegation, he was about to issue.  Mr. Barlow heard nothing more of this matter officially ;  but this circumstance, added to the many inconveniences 	asc99990010170129001											63270360 Bytes	3864	5456	2421350580	RGB	asc99990010170129001.tif		2013-08-12	2013-08-12	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5903	5903	5904.jp2	/scbooks/image/5904.jp2
Page 130																																asc9999001017		|¥riva lions, and insults, lie was daily experiencing, constrained  him to address a letter to the Colonel, on the subject of his  imprisonment. For this purpose he requested that gentleman, through the medium of a friend, to allow him the use  of pen, ink, and paper. In his benevolence, the Colonel  thought proper to send a Lieutenant with half a sheet of  paper, stating this was the most he could suffer him to have;  and Mr. Barlow then wrot$ the following letter:  li To the Colonel, and Officers of the St. George's MiUtid&gt;  assuming to he a Court of Inquiry into iny conduct,  4'Sirs,  " On Friday morning last, yon dispatched a Lieutenant and two  privates of the Surry Regiment of Horse to my dwelling-, fifteen milei  from hence, giving them instructions to bring me forthwith, by force  of arms, to answer charges preferred against me, and said to he of a  seditious nature. I have, ever since my arrival here, been in close  confinement, debarred from all the sweets of liberty, the deprivation  from which has been deeply embittered by the ignorance in which I  am kept of the unrighteous causes of my imprisonment. I hereby  enter protest against those acts of violence, against the injustice of  inflicting penalties ere overt scrutiny has been made, before I have  been confronted with my accusers, and before having been heard iu  defence, I hereby inform you that, if you do not. this very afternoon  bring me to public trial, I. shall lay before his Excellency the Governor  and Captain General of this island the particulars of your dealings to*  wards me, and shall appeal to him for release.  **I am, &c. and no opportunity afforded him of confronting his accusers, if such there bo,  nor of replying to their accusations, if such have been made.  44 That your petitioner, thus subjected to an arbitrary, rigorous",  and unjust imprisonment, is suffering in bodily health ; and, what is  to him of much nearer concernment, altogether precluded from the  fulfilment of his duties as a teacher of religion.  44 That your petitioner verily believes, that from the strong current  of prejudice against him and his missionary brethren, by which the  better feelings arid judgments of his captors and jailors appear to be  completely carried away, neither justice nor mercy can reasonably be  expected in their dealings towards him ; and that he appeals to his  past and present sufferings, in proof of the correctness of this his settled persuasion.  44 That confiding, nevertheless, in the innoceney of his hands, your  petitioner represented his grievances to those who inflicted, and who  have the power to redress them, with the hope that an opportunity  might   be afforded   him,   by   public trial,   of  hearing and   rebutting  whatever accusations malignant or niikhiAtrin** ^ — ■  laid to his charge.  whatever accusations malignant or misjudging men may have falsely  uiucis euner ror his public trial, or his imn  charge from imprisonment, as your Excellency may deem expedient,  44 And your petitioner, as in duty bound, he/'  This petition was graciously received, and some communication passed from the Governor to Major-General Yates,  when that gentleman ordered Mr. Barlow's discharge. The real cause of this demur, after the receipt, by the  Officers who held him in confinement, of Mr. Barlow's discharge through the intervention of the Captain-General, ig  disclosed by the following conversation. When Dr. Prince*  informed Lieutenant Shenton that Mr. Barlow was about to  send in a protest to the Court of Inquiry, against the behaviour  of its members towards nimself, Mr. Shenton, who used to  attend and give counsel in the proceedings -of that Court,  though he had not been elected an Examiner, observed, u I  should think they wont receive it," ■** Then," said Dr. Prince,  u there will be found a way to make the Governor acquainted  with the matter, in the form of Appeal." 44 Even then," rejoined Mr. Sltenton, 44 the Governor rmist apply to us for  copies of the evidence and proceedings, and some time must  be consumed in the correspondence, which will serve our turn,  far our object is to keep Barlow a prisoner during Martial  Law." As soon as Mr. Shenton uttered this, Dr. Prince told  Urn he would make use of this confession. Mr. Shenton  seemed to betray a sense o^ having given an advantage, and  attempted to nullify it by saying that lie spoke in his own  name only. This was related by Dr. Prince to the said Court,  soon after it occurred in the Troop guard-room, and was, at  his request, entered iu the minutes of examinations made.  Mr. Shenton is one who has accepted the office of executing  justice, and maintaining truth in the parish of St. George ; but  his unfitness for this high office is painfully indicated in ths  fallowing circumstance: It was noticed in Mr. Shenton'*  hearing, that at the Council of War, held to consider the expediency of continuing Martial Law, the Governor had borne  a testimony to the inoffensive and guiltless conduct of tha  missionaries, and had exonerated them from any share in the  causes exciting the insurrection ; upon which Mr. Shenton  remarked, l* That is but his (Earl Belrnore's) opinion ; for my  part," continued he, 4&lt; 1 think it would be best to take out all  the missionaries, placing them in a ring, with the Governor in  the midst, and so shoot them all together!"  These minutes of examination, if produced, would display  some of the unfair means  used to convict Mr*   Barlow   of  Reaching and teaching sedition ; such as, by seeking to leara  *iat sentiments he had in private expressed to his friends and  4& 	asc99990010170132001											57610712 Bytes	3560	5392	536882982	RGB	asc99990010170132001.tif		2013-08-12	2013-08-12	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5906	5906	5907.jp2	/scbooks/image/5907.jp2

In  those minutes might be traced the efforts that were employed  to make Dr. Prince declare his sentiments on those subjects,  which were suspected to be of a seditious nature ; and then,  as Mr. John Jacob Stamp, Member of Assembly for St.  George's, signified, it would be allowable to identify Mr. Barlow's opinions with those of his intimate friend 1  At length, on Friday January the 20th, being the 14th day  of his confinement, Mr. Barlow received the following note  from the Colonel.  " Head Quarters, Buff Bay, Jan. 20th, 1832,  **Tlie Rev. Jnsiali Barlow,  44 I have received directions from Major-General Cox to release  you from your confinement, on your giving bail to appear when required. You will therefore he pleased to name your sureties, and, if  approved of, I shall immediately issue orders that you be liberated.  The bail required is two sureties, £.150 each, and yourself in £.300.  44 I have the honour to be, &c.  (Signed) " PHILLIP JACQUET, Col. S. G. Ii."  Bail having been found, and the period of its obligation,  limited to three months, Mr. Barlow was accordingly released. Although Mr. Barlow was thus treated, because suspected of being a sower of sedition, w-e are happy to record  that during the continuance of Martial Law, not a single act  of insubordination was delected among the slaves in either of  the parishes from which his congregations were formed.—-  Where then shall we find even a pretext for his arbitrary and  ■unjust imprisonment?  Shortly after the suspension of Martial Law, information  was received that several individuals were projecting the destruction of the Annotto Bay chapel, in consequence of  which Mr. Barlow immediately wrote to the Custos the following letter. The meeting alluded to therein was convened  to consider and adopt the best plan for deporting all suspected  missionaries from the Colony.  " To the lion. John Bell* Custos and sen. Magistrate of St.  George..  44 Annotto-Bay,. 2 o'clock, February 23, 1^32.  "Sir,  " I have just received positive and authentic information, from a  gentleman arrived from Fort-Maria, of two attempts having been  made to execute a projected plan for the demolition of the Baptist  Chapel at that place, and of Resolutions having been publicly declared to destroy the one at this Bay.  *' Seeing how very generally the spirit of intolerance and destruction is raging, and how it threatens to come into operation within your  jurisdiction, I beg leave, in accordance with the proclamation of his  Excellency the Governor, under date of 3.3th February, to call upon  j on to take such measures as shall effectually protect the premises 	asc99990010170133001											62823964 Bytes	3848	5440	56761003	RGB	asc99990010170133001.tif		2013-08-12	2013-08-12	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5907	5907	5908.jp2	/scbooks/image/5908.jp2

(Reply)  "'Rev. Josiah Barlow,  44 Sir,  44 I've to acknowledge tlie receipt of your letter of yesterday's date, ,  which came to hand at eight o'clock last  evening.    I  shall  use such  means as are at my disposal to prevent any outrage from being committed on the Baptist Chapel at Annotto-Bay, and  I do hope that no-  individual in this parish would be base enough to make the attempt.  44 1 cannot close this letter, without commenting on the last sentence  of your's   to this effect?'—'It is by no means improbable   that   the  meeting, to be holden to day, will issue in the outrage dreaded.' We are happy to add, the dreaded evil did not occur ; but  that there existed a disposition to follow the example of the  Leeward parishes, we have no doubt ', and from the circam-  stances which manifested this disposition, we select the following wanton aggression, wholly misrepresented, as usual?:  in the "Jamaica Courant."  One Saturday evening in April, Mr. "Barlow observed  two white men walk up to the chapel door, \vhich one of  them attempted to open ; but finding it locked, they tried to  throw up a window. He then approached them, and found  one forcing the chapel door. While Mr. Barlow was quite  near, though unobserved, this man exclaimed, "Where is the  Parson? call the Parson, I want to see the Parson." Mr.  Barlow accosted him, saying, "I am the Parson, Sir, what  do you want with me?" He replied, that u he wanted to  hear him preach." Mr. B. remonstrated with him on the  impropriety of his conduct, in thus bursting open the dour ;~  and informed him that it was not the time for worship. Not  satisfied, he insisted on Mr. Barlow's preaching immediately;  * We must not omit to thank Mr. Bell for the acknowledgement implied in this  remark, namely, that all Gentlemen of respectable character are above even a  moment's suspicion of committing such outrages, and consequently that the persons who did commit them, in various parts of the island, have pioved themselves  destitute of character. In this sentiment we perfectly coincide with Mr. Bell ;  hut what will be said to it by the many Magistrates, and Commissioned Officers of  the Militia, who are well known to have engaged in such demolitions at..Moatcs,*-  Buy,. Lucea, Falmouth,, St,. Page 135																																asc9999001017		no  &nd, without ceremony, collared him, declaring with an oatfi  that he should preach, and quickly forced him, with  considerable violence, against the door ; so that he found  himself necessitated to call his strength into action, to guard  against being" thrown on the ground. Whilst thus grappling  iij self-defence, a brown man came in, arui made the man let  go his hold, but not till he had struck Mr. B. a violent blow  in the face. The affray was ended by (he interference of Mr.  Barlow's friends, among whom was T. Onn, Esq. a magistrate, for whom he had sent. Before this Gentleman he  made an affidavit of the facts ; when he learnt that his assailant Was a Air. Rankin, overseer of Koningsburgh estate, and  his companion a Mr. Duncan, overseer of Aleppo estate,  both situated in the parish of St. Mary. Mr. Barlow was informed that Mr. Hankin left the Bay threatening to return at  night and destroy the chapel. We add, with pleasure, that this  threat was not carried into execution, and that Mr. Barlow  has since been allowed to prosecute his labours without interruption. Ihe specified time of his bail having long since  «xj)ired, he has been honourably acquitted of any participation in the suspected offence.  We proceed to narrate two or three circumstances pertaining to Mr. Burton, and his Station at Manchioneal.  Before Martial Law was proclaimed, he had not heard that  freedom was either talked of among the slaves, or expected ;  not an individual had ever uttered to him a word respecting  such a subject. At the time that the militia were ordered to  ihe several Stations in St. Thomas in the East, he was on a  journey to Kingston ,; and after the demand for missionary  4)lood was set up, he hurried from Kingston, before finishing  his business, to beat home in readiness, in case the military  tribunal at Mancbioneal might require him. He did not, how«  &lt;ever, arrive at his house, before some of the white gentlemen  began to circulate a report that he had concealed himself, or  had fled. Though the house in which Mr. Burton resided,  called Belle Castle, atad which forms the chapel, has not been  destroyed, it has been made quite evident jhat the same  inveterate prejudice existed at Manchioneal as at other places,  £ind the same unjustifiable eagerness to convict and condemn  ihe missionary. Jn proof of this spirit, let the following facts  speak. Early in Martial Law, Mrs. Brown, at whose house  Mr. Burton had been in the habit of preaching occasionally,  w.as mni for by the Court Martial. Page 136																																asc9999001017		Ill  aiding on her own property, six or seven miles from.the B$y,  hike had been confined only five days when she was taken from  her house with her infant ! and in this state of debility was  detained about a week at Mancbioneal. The professed object  of taking her from her house, wasto elicit criminating evidence  against the missionary. After her dismissal, and while she  yet remained at the Bay because of weakness, Mr. Panton, late  Acting Attorney General, and three other magistrates, went to  her house to search it. They said their object was to find  the u free paper/' which they supposed Mr. Burton might  have left. The house door was broken open, and the locks of  boxes were forced. The beds were searched, and some barrel Jed  flour was examined, as also a barrel of pork, someofthe meat  being taken out to see if the " free paper" was between the  pieces ! ! Miss Duncan, who resided at the house, was struck  in the face by Mr. H. W. Speed, a magistrate, during the  examination, because she spoke the truth respecting some of  his slaves ; and Mrs. Brown's mother wras struck repeatedly,  and knocked to the ground ! On their departure, erne of these  gentlemen took away the hymn-book, which Mr. Burton had  been accustomed to use, and to the present time it has not  been returned.  ft is not certain, that, during the existence of Martial Law,  all who were examined respecting the insurrection, were asked  whether the missionaries had stimulated them to rebel ; but  with very many this was the case, and especially at the time  of inflicting punishment. Three or four of those who were  bystanders, because of being upon guard, have declared, that  when a portion of the appointed flogging had been inflicted  upon anyone, it was customary to stop, and, with threatening,  to inquire of the sufferer, whether the minister had informed  him the slaves were to be free. One of the most respectable  of these informants also said, that the threatening and the  punishment were, in his opinion, quite sufficient to induce  many of the slaves to criminate, unjustly, a father or a mother.  As might be expected, some of them did accuse Mr. Burton  of having told them in public they were to be free ; but they  are persons who, it can be proved, have never once attended  his ministry, since he went to Mancbioneal.  During the time of Martial Law, Mr. Panton, before mentioned, with several gentlemen, rode from the Bay to the mission  house; and arriving there some time after dark, quietly surrounded the place, and, by a circuitous path, Mr. Panton and  Mr. McWilliams entered by the only unfrequented door. It  was the evening on which, before Christmas, the weekly ser- 	asc99990010170136001											57955248 Bytes	3592	5376	2716318155	RGB	asc99990010170136001.tif		2013-08-12	2013-08-12	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5910	5910	5911.jp2	/scbooks/image/5911.jp2
Page 137																																asc9999001017		112  vice had been held. The professed object of the visit was to  ascertain the nature and exact situation of lights, which the  gentlemen said had been seen from the Bay, very near the  mission premises, and which had been answered by similar  .lights in the mountains. Mr. Panton, after having inquired what number of lights were used in the house, at what  time the inmates retired to rest, and in what part of the house  the lights were kept, also asked very particularly respecting  George Affleck, the head driver of Llaining estate, who a few  days before had been shot on the Bay, as a ringleader in the insurrection in St.Thomas in the East. Mr. Burton informed him that^  Affleck generally attended public worship at Belle Castle, every  other Sabbath, but was not a member of the church ; and explained to him that a member was one who had been baptized,  and who received the Lord's supper, but that Affleck had never  attended to either. Yet, particular as Mr. Panton's inquiries  were, and particular as was the information which Mr. Burton communicated to him, it has since been reported that  George Affleck was a member of the Baptist church, and the  principal leader! These facts are sufficient to show, that Mr.  Burton's not having been criminated as an instigator of' the  rebellion, cannot be ascribed to disinclination or negligence,  on the part of those gentlemen who were entrusted with such  examinations*  We shall conclude this chapter by relating the following  circumstance, which occurred to Mr. Taylor, at that time the  officiating minister of our chapel in Spanish Town, during a  Sabbath evening service. Just as he had closed the prayer before sermon, a white man, of notorious character, named Har-ts-  horne, charged him publicly from the gallery, in the most  vociferous manner, with having prayed that the Governor  might have wisdom. On the following morning Mr. Taylor  v as cited before a bench of magistrates, to answer to the  charges contained in three affidavits, made by Mr. Hartshorne  4andtwo of his associates. Two of these affidavits were rejected  as contradictory, and Mr. Taylor was examined on Mr. Harts*  home's only. In addition to his having prayed for the Governor,  Mr. Taylorwas charged with fnvingprayed seditiously; that he  had said in his prayer, 44 you are to be slaves and barbarians no  longer; something has been done, for you, but not enough ;. you  must now be free." Page 139																																asc9999001017		CHAPTER IX.  Numerous Places of Worship destroyed, with the principal persons engaged.—•  Other Chapels attacked or threatened.—Losses and grievances experienced by  the Missionaries.—Estimate of the loss sustained.—Stoppage of Letters.  Wk now come to record the gross outrages against God and  His people, committed in the destruction of numerous Places,  of Worship. In the course of our Narrative, we have already  had occasion to notice, in a cursory manner, several such acts  of violence; further particulars of those acts, together with  an account of several others of like description, we shall now  detail. We shall relate them in the order of time when they  occurred, beginning with those chapels which belonged to the  Baptist Missionary Society.  The first chapel destroyed was situated at a place called  Salters Hill, in St. James, about eight miles from Montego  Bay. It was a large, substantial building, newly erected for  the accommodation of a numerous congregation, previously  assembling at Crooked Spring, and opened for Divine Worship the very day, on the evening of which the insurrection  commenced. This edifice, consisting of chapel and dwellings  house, was set on fire, during Martial Law, by a party of the  St. James' militia, under the command of Lieutenant F. B.  Gibbs, Royal Navy, on half pay, and Captain George Gordon.  It is worthy of notice, that this chapel was used only once, on  which occasion the greatest exertions were made by the missionaries to prevent the threatened revolt of the negroes ; and  that though the rebels were much annoyed thereby, yet they  spared the chapel during the work of devastation around ;  but the white people, whom those exertions were designed  and calculated to benefit, wantonly and deliberately burnt it  down.  On Tuesday, February 7th, when the St. Ann's Regiment  were about to quit Falmouth, Mr. John W. Gayuer, a magistrate and ensign, and Adjutant Samuel Tucker, commanded  the men to break down the chapel preached in by Mr.  Knibb, (which they had occupied as Barracks during Martial  Law), and themselves set the example. It was completely  demolished. The Baptistry, situated in the chapel yard, was  previously filled up m h filth, by  the Workhouse negroes, 	asc99990010170139001											62101510 Bytes	3815	5424	2912697486	RGB	asc99990010170139001.tif		2013-08-12	2013-08-12	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5913	5913	5914.jp2	/scbooks/image/5914.jp2

And on this occasion, a cenotaph, erected in the wall of the Vestry, to the.  memory of our departed brother Mann, the former pastor, was  torn down and dashed to pieces, by those who could trample,  with equal carelessness, on the rights of the living and the relics of the dead ! Page 143																																asc9999001017		1  118  Nichols, and burnt ihe chapel there. It was the property of  Mr. Thomas Williams, a married man, with a large family, by  whom the injury will be severely felt. The (ire communicated  with an adjoining house, which was also burnt down.  On Sunday, February I9l.h, the last act of destruction was  committed at Green Island, when the chapel, supplied by  Mr.'Abbott, was burnt down.  Awful indeed are the devastations here recorded! Satan  has been permitted to enter the Sanctuaries of God, not, as  usual, to defile, but to destroy. It was a rare liberty allowed  him, and zealously improved, as though his activity were  proportionate to the length of his confinement and the shortness of his liberation. Long restrained to a great degree,  and by a superior power, from wonted acts of spoliation, his  rage at the success of the Gospel had become madness; and  when for a season his trammels were removed, he arose  mighty and furious, and led on his vassals, as maniacs escaped  from their cells, to plunder the defenceless, and scatter the  church. Tiiis was his hour, and the power of darkness.  This was his opportunity to. rally his subjects, already drunk  with the blood of the Saints, and urge them to demonstrate  •their relation and allegiance to himself "the angel of (lie  tettomiess pit, whose name in the Hebrew tongne is Abaddon, (a destroyer), but in the Greek tongue, hath his name  A'poHym*/] Great is the mischief which has been done, at  ihe instigation of this adversary. Not satisfied with having  seduced many professors of religion to unite in his diabolical  scheme of rebellion, and then succeeded in bringing to untimely death many others, guiltless of any participation in that  crime, he was envious-of the happiness enjoyed by those who  remained to frequent the houses of God, and therefore laboured but too successfully to annihilate these sources of  comfort. Poignant and lasting is the grief thus occasioned.  Thousands of tears-have already been shed over the ruins of  those sacred places where prayer was wont to be made—■  where instruction was imparted to the ignorant and those who  were out of the way—and where the consolatians of Christ  alleviated the miseries of life. Very many of the people thus  deprived, were faithful to their masters during the lamentable  insurrection,'1"" and many defended their property at the risk of  their own lives ; and what is their reward ?  Worship-  beside, to  heir  P!  aces  of  -dearer to many of them  than all  they possessed  the payment for which they had cheerfully contri-  •See Clmslian Record, No-, VII* 	asc99990010170143001											61336208 Bytes	3768	5424	2835708222	RGB	asc99990010170143001.tif		2013-08-12	2013-08-12	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5917	5917	5918.jp2	/scbooks/image/5918.jp2
Page 144																																asc9999001017		119  bided of their little earnings, are razed to fire ground, and  t h e i r m i n ist e rs d ri \;e n (V o m a m o n g t h e m ! T11 ese ac ts o £ c r u e I  injustice bear a relation to eternity ; the sighs and tears they  have occasioned, are gone up for a memorial before God ;  and we tremble for the situation of their perpetrators, when  he shall come down to reckon with them. " Father! forgive  them, for they know not what they do 1"  The work of destruction terminated at Green Island, but  not the disposition to destroy ; for this was manifested -after-*  wards, in most; parts of the island, not excepting Spanish  Town and Kingston. This diabolical spirit was kept alive,  and excited by the Jamaica Courant and other newspapers,  till plots were actually forming for the destruction of all the  "Sectarian" chapels in those towns. A paper for signatures,  of persons to unite in these outrages, was carried about In  each place, and some names were obtained. But these plots  being discovered, the friends of religion and justice took the  alarm, and formed a guard at their respective chapels, as well  as appealed to the Civil Authoriries for protection. These  means produced the desired effect, the mayor of Kingston,  (Thomas Legal Yates, Esq.) issued a Proclamation against  such proceedings ; and the intended depredators were prevented from involving themselves in further disgrace, and  their towns in civil war.  In Spanish Town, Mr. Hartshorne (mentioned in p. 112.)  went about with his companions soliciting assistance for this  object. This was proved by two persons, who deposed be*  fore a bench of magistrates, that Mr. Hartshorne had strongly  urged them to join his party, and that they were to attack the  chapels in the night. He was then compelled to enter into a  bond of £.100, to keep the peace, and find two sureties for £.50  each. There was another of our chapels in the country which  very narrowly escaped destruction ; we refer to Mount Charl&gt;fs,  in St. Andrew's, which was barbarously attacked at about ten  o'clock on the night of Friday, April 6th, by a mob of white  rnen chiefly overseers and bookkeepers, armed with bayonets,  swords, pistols, and muskets. As they approached the house,  they howled like a company of savages, and between the gate  of the premises and the house, they met with a watchman, a  poor, old, faithful, free negro, who was about to give an  alarm; and though he was unarmed, they fell upon him wi'h  their swords, cutting him severely in several parts of his  head and body, and one of them with a bayonet stabbed him  in Ids side. When they got to the inhabited | art of the chaq  pel-house; they broke open the door, and tired in at it.-— 	asc99990010170144001											58385232 Bytes	3616	5380	3703270767	RGB	asc99990010170144001.tif		2013-08-12	2013-08-12	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5918	5918	5919.jp2	/scbooks/image/5919.jp2
Page 145																																asc9999001017		I  ,  130  Some of them broke the windows of the bed room, forcing in  the glass, frames and shutters, with such violence, that the  bed in which Mrs. Baylis (the missionary's wife) and her infant were lying, was nearly covered with pieces of glass.  They then fired in at each of the windows, and one of the  ruffians applied a candle to one side of the room for the purpose of setting it on fire ; but the candle was put out. They  proceeded to break the hall window, swearing the house  should be down that night. Seeing the candle was out, one  of them broke open the door of an out-house, supposing it to  be the kitchen, saying he wanted fire, and that he would  burn down the houses but the alarm being given, they made  off. This outrageous act of brutality was perpetrated by the  white people employed as Overseers and Bookkeepers on several properties in the neighbourhood.  We shall now exhibit the principal losses and injuries sustained by some of the missionaries in the destruction or theft  of their -private property. The greatest loser by far is Mr.  Burchell, who is indeed a deeply injured man, and whose  grievances claim particular consideration. Possessed of private property before he engaged in the missionary enterprise,  he has since rendered important pecuniary aid to the Jamaica  mission. Having fixed his heart on his missionary engagements, he had purchased, and furnished at his own ex-pence,  & residence in the mountains, to afford occasionally a refreshing retreat for himself and family from the sultry temperature  of Montego Bay. This house, called llillingtoh, and situated in Hanover, was burnt down by ihe militia, (hiring the  existence of Martial Law. Near this spot is a bouse which  Mr. B. rented as a chapel, and preached in, called Shepherd's  Hall (or Gurney's Mount.) At this place a Christian church  was formed, and a congregation of several hundred persons  usually assembled. It was entered by the militia, during Martial Law, and the benches, pews, pulpit, and household -furm-  lure, the latter Mr. Burcheli's property, were taken out and  burnt! Various other damages were sustained by Mr. Burchell, of which we have no particulars. The total amount of  his losses we have no means of ascertaining.  On the day the chapel at Montego Bay was demolished, the  rioters found in the chapel-yard a chaise belonging to Mr.  Cantlow, which they maliciously chopped to pieces, supposing it to have been Mr Burcheli's.  Mr. Abbott also deeply participated in the dainages oc'ca^ 	asc99990010170145001											61563130 Bytes	3784	5421	3797402380	RGB	asc99990010170145001.tif		2013-08-12	2013-08-12	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5919	5919	5920.jp2	/scbooks/image/5920.jp2
Page 146																																asc9999001017		121  sioned by insolent aggressors at Lucea.; and but for the" do*  hie exertions of his friends, he had suffered considerably  more. The following information, given by one of his free  members, relative to these outrages, will convey some idea of  the state of society, and the unprotected situation of a missionary, in that town ;-—•  Lucea, Feb. 13th, 1332. Had Mr. Abbott been present at this time, it is highly probable his life would have been sacrificed. This fearful probability is strongly marked in the following brief extract from  a letter of Mrs. Abbott (who had gone down for the purpose  of saving what she could of the property), written from  Lucea, to her husband at Montego Bay, dated February 14th.  ** Do not, on any account, come down here; every one says  you would be in very great danger. Many have sworn to  mob. and, if possible, murdeii youV  Mr. Knibb paid a visit to Falmouth early in March. For  three successive nights his lodgings were stoned, and he wascautioned by two respectable genii em en against venturing out in  the evening, as a party had clubbed together to tar and feather him. She replied, that she denied that ; for if he was killed, she was sure he would go to  Heaven, and wished she was as sure of going to Heaven as  he was. She also told Mr. Dyer, the Scriptures said, he  that would live godly in Christ Jesus, should suffer persecution. After searching the house, out offices, &c.  they carried away the papers and a box, and left two sentinels  at the door, who stopped half an hour. Miss D. further  states that she went to Dr. Neil-son, a magistrate, (also Major of the Trelawny Regiment) and told him that Parson  Fraser (Rector of Falmouth) had come into Mr. Knibb's  yard to insult them. He replied, he did not care what  Parson Fraser chose to do to her, or Knibb. She then asked  him if they were not to get redress? He said no, not from  him, she might go to any one else ; if he had his will he would  trample Knibb and herself together ; and that she and Knibb  might be d—d. She told him she was obliged to him, and  walked away."  All the missionaries in the disturbed districts, and some,  where no disturbance existed, suffered by the ill-usage of their  horses, which were eagerly sought after during Martial Law,  and for which they never received or sought any remuneration. To lend horses for the general good, they had not the  smallest reluctance ; but Mr. Knibb had nearly lost three al-»  together, two of his own, and one of Mr. Cantlow's, under his  care ; for after Martial Law was discontinued, they were taken  away from Falmouth .to St, Ann's by Major-General Hilton,  who retained possession of them, till repeated applications had  been made to him to deliver them up 1  A horse of Mr. Gardner's, which had been in the King's  service nearly from the commencement to the expiration of  Martial Law, was not returned to him, but detained by an  Overseer in the country for several weeks after, until sending  his Bookkeeper to Montego Bay with the horse, it was recognized as Mr. Gardner's by a gentleman, who was  empowered to seize it. Mr. John Coates, a magistrate, called  on the person who had taken the horse, and asked what business he had with it; remarking, that Mr. Gardner was a  guilty rascal, and would not want it again.  The following statement will give some idea of the amount  of property destroyed, and the situation of the chapels, &c. A letter from Mr. Nichols, dated 3&lt;*&  7th, directed to Mrs. Knibb, Montego Bay ; and another of the  same date to Mr. Tinson, Kingston, never reached them.  —Also a letter from Mr. Knibb, Montego Bay, and a no-*  ther from Mr. Tinson, Kingston, both addressed to Mr.  Nichols, at St. Ann's Bay, were never received.— Early in  Martial Law, a letter addressed by Mr. Tinson to Mr. Burton,  at Mancbioneal, was detained at that place by order of the  Court-lViartial, and opened ; they decided that so far from cri*  ruinating him, it had a contrary tendency ; yet when he sent  for it, the answer returned by the messenger was, that "Mr,  Burton could not have the letter, unless he went to fetch it."  —The following circumstance deserves particular notice.  On Friday, March 2d, a letter from the Rev. John Dyer, our  Secretary in London, addressed to Mr. Nichols, St. Ann's  Bay, was printed in the "Jamaica Courant," which letter had  not reached Mr. Nichols's hands, and, to the present moment,  has never been sent to him. Application being made to the  Editor of that paper, be stated that he had published the letter entire, that the original bore ex facie evidence of transmission through the post-office, and that it was then in the  possession of Mr. Lynch, Member of Assembly, and Chairman of the Rebellion Committee. This statement was made  known at the General Post-Office, when Mr. Anstey informed  Mr. Nichols he could not find that the letter had ever passed  through that office, but enquiry should be made at St. Ann's  Bay. This was done, and Mr. Lemon, Deputy Postmaster  there, returned answer that it never passed through that  office, nor could he give any information respecting it.—  But, notwithstanding this declaration of Mr. Lemon, we have;  the following evidence to support our conviction that this  letter did reach his office. We have ascertained that it was  brought to this country by the Hon. William Miller, Custos  of Trelawny, who arrived in the " Australia" at Falmouth,,  in February, and who assures us that it was put, with other  letters, into the Falmouth post-office. Among these letters  there was one for Mr. Knibb, and one for Mr. Whitehorne*  both of which reached them from that office. What reason  then have we to suppose that Mr. Nichols's letter was not  forwarded as directed, and therefore sent, to St. Ann's Bay?  Our conviction that the fraud originated in Mr. Lemon's  office is strengthened by the fact, that a letter, since addressed  by Mr. Nichols to Mr. William Watkis, St. Ann's Bay, was-  never delivered to that gentleman It was dated April, and  posted in Spanish Town, and we ba*1 no doubt, safely reached 	asc99990010170150001											60816572 Bytes	3736	5424	2782816439	RGB	asc99990010170150001.tif		2013-08-12	2013-08-12	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5924	5924	5925.jp2	/scbooks/image/5925.jp2
Page 151																																asc9999001017		126  St. Ann's Bay post-office. As one of the chapel-breakers; sf  young man named Valentine Grey, is a clerk in that office, it  is natural to conclude that an accomplice in such fraudulent  transactions would not be wanting.  Mr. Millers letter to Mr. Nichols is as follows:—  Trelawny, 24th April, 1832.  Sir,  I was not in the parish when  your letter of the 7th instant arrived,  and am only now enabled to reply to it.  I brought several letters'out with me in the ship Australia,  amongst which was one addressed to you, and another to Mr. Knibb.
