Page 152																																asc9999001017		CHAPTER X.  Persecutions against Professors of Religion, instanced in the treatment of Mr,  Thompson, Miss M'Lennan, and Mrs. Case.—Growth and influence of the  Colonial Church Union.—Mr. Abbott proceeds to Montego Bay, butis prevented from preaching.—His appearance before the Magistrates.—Attempts  made to drive him from the town.—Mrs. Renwick is tried and fined for tenting  her hoarse to him.—Mr. Burton is prohibited from preaching at Morant Bay.—  Imprisoned, and released on Bail.—His trial stands over for the Surry Assizes.—  Mr. Taylor is interrupted at Old Harbour.—The Quartet Sessions tefused to administer the oaths to him. — At Montego Bay the Quarter Sessions determine to  sanction no Sectarians.—Mr. Kingdon arrives at Savanna-la-Mai —is threatened  and is prosecuted for a breach of a disallowed law.—Mrs. Robe is fined for allowing a prayer-meeting in her house.—The Quarter Sessions refuse to qualify  Mr. Kingdon.—A deputation of the Colonial Church Union wait on him.—A  meeting of that body held.—They attack Mr. Kingdon's lodgings, and a riot ensues.—Various barbarous outiagesof the Unionists. —Mr. Kingdon's friends are  overpowered, and fly for their lives.—A Union Magistrate commits them togaol.—  Death of a female occasioned by the Unionists.—Mr. Kingdon and his friends  are bound over to appear at the Cornwall Assizes.—Mr. and Mrs.Kingdon leave  Savanna-la-Mar and arrive in Kingston.—•Continued outrages of the Unionists,  —Cornwall Assizes held at Montego Bay.—The partial proceedings thereat.  *Yuk spirit of persecution which has so seriously affected  the missionaries, has operated, as the reader may suppose,  with nearly equal violeoce against the adherents to their  cause. Professors of v religion, whether members of their  churches or not, and whether slaves or persons of free condition, have writhed under the infliction of unmerited punishment, arxl suffered from the iron hand of oppression. Of the  cruellies inflicted on slaves, on mere suspicion of insubordination, and that suspicion having no foundation but their connexion with the missionaries, some cases have come to our  knowledge, supported by credible testimony, notwithstanding  our unfavourable circumstances for obtaining such information. But these cases, from prudential motives, and not from  any doubt of their truth, we shall refrain from publishing, and  shall merely exhibit some instances of oppression practised on  free people, from which the reader may safely inter that the  treatment of slaves was still more inhuman.  During Martial  Law, on Salurd:^ January 7th,   as Mr.  , iil' 	asc99990010170152001											60287672 Bytes	3720	5400	3433818230	RGB	asc99990010170152001.tif		2013-08-12	2013-08-12	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5926	5926	5927.jp2	/scbooks/image/5927.jp2
Page 153																																asc9999001017		J2S  William Thompson, a person of colour, a member of the church  at Rio Bueno, was going on his duty as a pilot at that place,  he was informed by a trooper that Mr. Cropper, the officer of  the guard, wished to speak to him. Not suspecting the  design, he accompanied the trooper, arid in a few minutes  his arms ivere lied behind him with a rope', he was railed  at as a preacher, and asked if he was a member of the  Baptist church : He replied, that he was, but no preacher  -—that he wished he was capable of being otje. He was  taken to the Long Wharf, and there tied to a negro man.—  They-took his hand kerchief and a note from his pocket, inquired if he had any money, and searched him all over, lie  was much abused by Mr. Taylor, Quartermaster of the St.  Ann's militia, then stationed at Rio Bueno. That day the  guard conducted him to the Spring estate, where he was  confined in the boiling-house, ivith both legs and arms tied,  and the end of the rope carried up aloft. The next morning he was sent to Falmouth, where his feet were put in  irons among upwards of forty rebellious condemned  negroes. In this situation lie was detained four days altogether—allowed only two slices of bread, with water, per  day, and exposed to the taunts of many who railed on him as  a preacher. While in custody he was closely questioned,  " whether he had not heard his ministers say and preach to Ike  •negroes, that the King had given them their freedom, and  they were to set fire to the estates, and fight for it." He answered, u he had heard the ministers preach contrary to that,  namely, that they must be obedient to their earthly master,  whom they saw, otherwise they could not be obedient to their  Heavenly master, whom they could not see." Colonel Hilton,  afterwards Major General, wanted much to have him hung, and  told his wife that if he escaped the gallows, he should be sent  awav to the mad-house, in Kingston, for life; but! Mr. W. Prater,  member of assembly forTrelawny, pleaded hard in his behalf;  "Mr. Herring, overseer of Braco estate, made affidavit that he  once saw him on that property; but when questioned by Mr,  Frater, whether he heard him preaching, he was reduced to (he  necessity of judging, or thinking, that he ilid. It is remat liable, that the very informer, Murray, the constable, was  never in the chapel in the absence of the minister, and men&gt;  tioned to Mr. Edward Dickenson, that he had never heard  Mr. Thompson preach, nor pray, but he only thought so. As no  charge could be substantiated against him, he was released,  and, by order of Colonel Hilton, his wife was appointed his  security, that he would go to no ne^ro house, nor hold ;any 	asc99990010170153001											62823648 Bytes	3848	5440	1262847704	RGB	asc99990010170153001.tif		2013-08-12	2013-08-12	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5927	5927	5928.jp2	/scbooks/image/5928.jp2
Page 154																																asc9999001017		m  meeting with any congregation, ^gp.eciaB'j negroes* Uttfc mlf  pray as he might think proper with his family and servant*.—  While in confinement he knew several members of both Bap*  tist and Methodist Societies sentenced to three hundred, four  hundred, and even five hundred, lashes, for no other fault  than their being such members ; some of tbera informed hira  that their houses had been pulled down, while others wen?  sentenced to the workhouse for life.*  Early in January M iss Emily M'Lennan, a free coloured person, who resided at Putney, in St. James, was sent for by Mr.  Charles O'Connor, a magistrate of Westmorland, on suspicion  that she had received letters from Mr. Burchell, to go to different properties, particularly Seven Rivers aud Haxlelymph.  She found him with Mr. Robert Watt, a magistrate of S't James,  in the house of the latter; to both of them she denied having received such letters, and informed them that she could not  read. Mr. Watt said, ** we have good proof that you did re~  ceive them. Now you must tell the truth, if you don't, there  is a boat ready to ship you off." On her still denying it, Mr.  Watt took her to the Court-house and put her into a roora  with about one hundred or more negroes in hand-cuffs, say*  ing to the guard '* take care of this prisoner." Immediately  Mr. George Delisser, who kept the list of prisoners, took  down her name in his book, and she remained therefrom two/  o'clock that day till the next morning.—With a view to elicit  the desired confession, terrifying language was employed.  Lieutenant Colonel Morris pointed outthe gallows to bkr ;  others said in her hearing '* her trial will be very hard—it will  go very hard with her, &c. &c." At length Mr. Manderson  went to her, and asked her if she had not been to Hazle-  lymph, to one of the members named Zincke, with a message  from Mr. Burchell, and, on her denying it, she was discharged  by him.f  The last instance we shall here specify is one of dishonesty^  Captain Andrew Drummond, Mr. Scott, and Lieutenant  Fearon, of the Clarendon Regiment, lodged at the house of  Mrs. Case, of Stewart Town, in the parish of Trelawny, during  Martial Law. When they were about to quit, she brought  forward her bill. Adjutant Thompson received it, and said,  " You need not think that I will pay this t&gt;ill.** Mrs. Case  asked the reason; and Mr. Thompson replied, "Because  * We refer mr readers to the Christian Record, No. V. pa«e 123, fer the full  particulars of this raost'atrocious case, afc furnished ia writing by Mr. Thompiot  Mrriself. ^,      &lt; ,   , *' v  f Till care -also *£$taH m tfcf Vt» !ra of tH C%rhtian Hecowj $.a£$ 12S1. 	asc99990010170154001											59657040 Bytes	3694	5381	2444654066	RGB	asc99990010170154001.tif		2013-08-12	2013-08-12	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5928	5928	5929.jp2	/scbooks/image/5929.jp2
Page 155																																asc9999001017		130  yon are a. Baptist. T would rather give £.10 to any one wfyo  is not praying, than lOd. to oiie that is." She was therefore  not paid, nor are we aware that she has been paid since.  Martial Law having been withdrawn, and the trials at the  Cornwall Assize Court brought to an issue favourable to the  cause of religion, the missionaries soon meditated a return to  some of the Stations from which they had been driven by  persecution. After much consultation and prayer, it was resolved, at the meeting of the missionaries, held in Kingston,  in April, that an attempt should first be made to resume the  work at Montego Bay, as the largest Station which had been  abandoned, and that which.embraced the greatest number of  free persons to attend the means of grace. It was farther  agreed that Messrs. Nichql and Abbott should undertake this  service. But the accomplishment of this object was delayed  nearly two months, owing to the continuance of persecution,  kept aliye throughout the island by the public press, by the  proceedings of the House of Assembly, and especially by the  operations of the Colonial Church Union. For this faction,  formed for the purposes of expelling all Sectarian missionaries from the island, and protecting the destroyers of mission  property, rapidly gathered strength and extended its influence.  13eing headed, by custodes and magistrates, and joined by  some of the most influential men in the respective parishes,  however intolerant or absurd in its nature, its progress was  natural enough. It was not difficult for its promoters, (*' taking advantage of the prevailing excitement," and assisted by  t|ve " false and wicked reports" of the enemies of missions,  " industriously circulated by aid of the press throughout  the island,") to "impose on the disturbed imaginations" of  many, a belief that an enormous evil would be productive of  the highest good, and that the best and only way to recover  the country from the effects of the rebellion, was for all the  free inhabitants to become rebels! Though highly presumptuous and lawless in its design, and, in proportion to its success,  destructive of the peace and the rights of society, yet, being  constantly represented by "crafty and evil disposed persons" as a  public good, and asthe only means which could save the country from utter ruin, its bombastic pretensions prevailed on the  less informed and "more peaceable" inhabitants, to become  " the dupes of the more artful and intelligent, " and to  strengthen their hands in crime. Nearly all the parishes of the  island, or rather some of the leading members of those pa-  ri§hes&gt;,-seton foot a Union of this kind, and passed their re^  spective series of intolerant resolutions, differing but little 	asc99990010170155001											63253564 Bytes	3880	5432	2864743130	RGB	asc99990010170155001.tif		2013-08-12	2013-08-12	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5929	5929	5930.jp2	/scbooks/image/5930.jp2
Page 156																																asc9999001017		131  from each other, and all avowing jhe^.grand object of getting  rid of "Sectarian Missionaries."    With the view of effecting  this purpose, the Unionists determined to discountenance and  oppress the free people connectedwith the Missionary Societies,  or in any way attached to their interests. Ata general meetingof\  the parochial branches of the Union, held at Falmouth, July  28th, the Chairman, Mr. J. L. Hilton, of St. Ann's, set forth  the following among the objects and duties of the Union, ♦To  expel the Sectarians,  and other incendiaries from the island;  to give no employment to any of their proselytes ; to hold everyr  man an enemy who fosters or encourages them."    And it was  resolved. " because it is necessary that: a stop should be put  to the further propagation of the pernicious doctrines of those  Sectarians, we consider it necessary to withdraw all support,  and intercourse  whatever from any one who may either adopt  the destructive principles of the Baptists or   other .Sectarian",  preachers in this island, or countenance them or'their follow*,  ers in any degree." This unjust resolution, beirig adopted by  magistrates, would   naturally possess,   in the estimation of  many, the force of law ; and indeed an intimation was added*  that in  compliance with the resolutions of the   Union  the  laws might be set aside.    The reader may judge whether this  intimation is not conveyed by the following declaration, subjoined to the resolution we have quoted.    That "thefullest  reliance is entertained that they (the members)  ivill hold the  observance of this and every other obligation of the Union,  under all circumstances, paramount to every other consider a-*  Hon,"    Thus indemnified, even by the administrators of the  laws, against the penalties merited by acts of injustice,   the  LJnionists   immediately   acted   upon  this   resolution,    and  consequently, many respectable, tradesmen and others, than  whom none were more deserving of support, have been deprived of employment, refused payment of their lawful debts,  and exposed with their families to the hazard of poverty and  distress.    We have taken this  notice of the Union, because  of its connexion with the spirit of civil and religious persecution, to which in fact it has mainly contributed.    The prevalence of the Union and that of persecution are commensurate,  the Unionists having solemnly bound themselves to promote  and tolerate none who   support or protect the missionaries ;-  and if the faction were dissolved, as its intention and acts deserve,  opposition,to  religion and justice Would decline, and  tranquillity soon be restored.  At length such a measure of tranquillity as was considered  adequate'to the personaVsjfetv of "a   resident' missionary,  » a 	asc99990010170156001											59504476 Bytes	3688	5376	1922335649	RGB	asc99990010170156001.tif		2013-08-12	2013-08-12	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5930	5930	5931.jp2	/scbooks/image/5931.jp2
Page 157																																asc9999001017		iss  hating been restored at Montego Bay, Messrs. Nichols and,  Abbott rented a house of Mrs. Margaret Renwick, and had  it registered in the Bishop's office as a place of worship.  Sickness and other circumstances detaining Mr. Nichols id  Kingston longer than was intended, Mr. Abbott went alone. He  arrived at. Montego Bay on Saturday, June 16th ; and the friends  of the cause, having been destitute of the ordinances of religion for six months, were desirous of his commencing public  worship the next day. Having already had the house regis*  tered'in the Bishop's office according to law, he complied with  their desire, and sent word to a few of the free people to that  effect. But Satan was vigilant, and his servants were active ;  this attempt to renew the preaching of that gospel, by which  his kingdom is destined to be overturned, could notbemade  without engaging his prompt opposition. A house full of  people assembled in the forenoon, consisting almost entirely  of free persons, and Mr. Abbott was about to commence a  prayer meeting, when Mr. Popkin, the head constable, made  ids appearance, and enquired for Mrs. Renwick. When she  appeared, he said, M The magistrates have sent me to enquire  if this is your house." She replied, " Yes." Mr. Popkin said,  " because the magistrates wish to know if you are aware o(  the consequences of having an illegal assemblage of persons  in your house." She replied, "This house is mine, Sir, but  it is tenanted by Mr. Abbott, Baptist missionary, who has had  it licensed." Mr. Popkin thensaid to Mr. Abbott, •' [suppose,  Sir, yon know the consequences of collecting an illegal meeting, and disturbing the public peace." Mr. Abbott replied,  ♦VI am far from wishing to disturb the public peace; the persons collected have come to worship God. 1 propose meeting with them for that purpose, which I have authority for  doing, having had the house licensed." Mr. Popkin then  left, observing that he shotdd communicate this information  to the magistrates. In a few minutes he returned, and said  the magistrates requested Mr. Abbott would let them see his  authority for preaching there. The certificate of registry was  then given to Mr. Popkin, with a request that it might be returned as soon as they had seen it. In a short time Mr. Poplin again returned with the certificate, and informed Mr. Abbott that the magistrates said they had nothing to do with the  Bishop's office, that they considered the meeting an illegal  one, and unless it was dispersed, they would issue a warrant  for Mr. Abbott's apprehension. Mr. A. said he considered  the meeting a legal aujj a peaceable one, and should commence service'at: the sppoi sited time. After  hearing this, Mr. Abbott requested the people, who had assem-  hled, to go quietly to their homes ; and then said to Mr. Popkifc  that he had dispersed the assembly as the magistrates had  thus officially ordered it, but that he should consider it his  duty to meet, with the people for public worship again in a  few days, if he had not further communication with the magistrates upon the subject ; and that if they wished to give or  receive any explanation, he would be ready to meet theui  whenever they thought proper. In reply, the magistrates  sent word to say that they would meet him the next morning  between ten and eleven o'clock.  At the appointed time Mr. Abbott went to the  Court-house and found about twenty of the magistrates  assembled, with Thomas Jos. Grey, Jtisq. senior magistrate,  presiding. After the head constable had stated what., had  passed on the preceding day, Mr. Grey asked Mr. Abbott to produce his authority for convening the meeting.  Mr. Abbott gave him the certificate, which shewed that the  house had been registered in the Bishop's office. It was  handed round the table, and after it had been examined,  some said it was sufficient, while the majority denounced  if as a gross imposition—a fradulent attempt to impose upon  them and the public. Mr. Abbott said he was prepared to  shew that it was not an imposition, but the kind of certificate required by law ;and m confirmation of this, requested them to reefer to the 1st William and Mary, chap. I8,and LOth Anne, chap 2,  which acts he maintained were in force in this island. They refused to make the reference, saying that hemightput one construction upon the laws, and they another. Mr. Abbott observed that the acts were sufficiently explicit not to be mistaken^—that they required a house to be registered as a  Place of Worship either at the Court, of Quarter Sessions, or  in the Bishop's registry, and as he was proceeding to state  the opinion of the. late Attorney-General, Hugo James,  Esq. as given in the case of Mr. Whitehouse, Wesleyan missionary, Dr. Lawson senior interrupted him by saying, ''The  gentleman may have one case, and I may have another, but  our object is to decide on the present case, and we shall place  our own constructioa upon the law" Mr. Abbott requested  them to refer to the two acts to which he had alluded, but  the British Statutes not being at hand, he pUced before the magistrates a passage from Gilford's Commentaries 	asc99990010170158001											60856760 Bytes	3744	5416	3174543108	RGB	asc99990010170158001.tif		2013-08-12	2013-08-12	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5932	5932	5933.jp2	/scbooks/image/5933.jp2
Page 159																																asc9999001017		134  on the Toleration Acts, which states that the certificate shall  Be registered in the Bishop's or Archdeacon's court, or at a  Sessions of the Peace. Dr. Longmore then said " But we  claim that prerogative to ourselves." Mr. Alexander Camp-  hell said, " The Baptists have done so much mischief in this  country that we ought to be very cautious how we permit  them to return amongst us." Dr. Lawson, senior, said, he  thought so too—that they ought to use all their influence,  persons, and property, to prevent their re-introduction ; and  afterwards said that Mrs. Renwick ought, io have been present  also, and that she should be tried for allowing an illegal meeting in her house. Mr. Watt added *'yes, and Mr. Abbott  should be indicted as a vagrant."  During the following week, various and violent attempts  were made to compel Mr. Abbott to leave the town ; inflammatory placards were posted up; and even at a public meeting, it was proposed by Mr. John Coates, a magistrate, that  Mr. Abbott should be driven out of the parish. This  proposition was strongly opposed by Mr. Samuel Man*-,  derson, a gentleman of colour, who said " That they  could not, and should not, eject Mr. Abbott." On the  day of that meeting, a muster of .the St. James's militia  took place, when a vigorous effort was made, chiefly by Adjutant  Lawson, to improve so favourable an opportunity for tarring  Mr. Abbot, and drumming him'out of the town ; but perceiving a powerful combination among the coloured inhabitants  for his protection, they desisted from the attempt. The  efforts to expel Mr. Abbott having proved unsuccessful, after a few days Mrs. Renwick was taken before a  bench of magistrates, and told by them that she had no business to hire her house to Mr. Abbott. She was then  hound over for the next Quarter Sessions, to take her trial  for having allowed an unlawful assemblage of slaves in her  house.  At the Quarter Sessions held on the 30th October, Mrs.  Renwick was brought to trial, having traversed the indictment at the July court. At the commencement of the proceedings, it was moved on her behalf that the indictment  should be quashed, on the ground of its not setting forth the  charge as the law directs ; and that as the house was rented  at the time referred to, to Mr. Abbott, the indictment, if sustainable at all, should have been preferred against him.  jri support of this motion, legal authorities were quoted,  hut to no  purpose;  the court negatived the proposal. Page 160																																asc9999001017		135  three witnesses, 4he principal of whom was Mr. Popkin,  the constable sent by the magistrates, and the only witness who  saw or knew what persons were present at the meeting. Neither of these witnesses could prove that a single slave attended it.  Yet, notwithstanding this failure in the most material part of  the evidence, and the explanation given in the slave law of  the words u unlawful assemblage of slaves ;" and notwithstanding the facts, that the house had, prior to the said meeting,  been registered as a Place of Worship, and was rented and  occupied by Mr. Abbott ; the Jury found Mrs. Renwick  guilty, recommending her to the leniency of the court. She  was fined £.20, in order, as Mr. Coates declared, to deter  others from doing as she had done.  On the same day that Mr. Abbott was prevented from  preaching at Montego Bay, Sunday June 17th, Mr. Burton  was interrupted at Morant Bay, where he had lately recommenced his stated labours, after having voluntarily abstained  from them during Martial Law, and for some weeks after  its termination. On this occasion Mr. Thomas Blakely, a  magistrate, sent a constable with an order to prevent the  preaching, and disperse the people, assigning as his reasons,  that Mr. Burton was not a licensed preacher, (though he  had taken the usual oaths some years before, at Port Maria,)  and that the house was not licensed for a place of worship.  The latter reason was founded in fact, for Mr. Burton had not  registered the house, partly because he did not expect that  the magistrates would interfere in the matter, and partly owing  to the uncertainty which then prevailed as to the requirement  of the law. The same week he addressed a memorial to his  honour President Cuthbert, on the subject, and registered  the house in the Bishop's office. After this registration, and  before receiving a reply to the memorial, the Quarter Sessions  of Morant Bay were held, and Mr. Burton attended. Having  obtained permission to address the court, he stated how long  he had been preaching at Morant Bay without interruption,  and observed that as recent circumstances had led him to  suppose that one or more of the magistrates required him to  take the usual oaths, he had come to express his readiness to  do so. Without regarding this, the presiding magistrate, Mr.  M'Cornock, informed the clerk of the peace that application was made for a license to preach, and wished to know  whether it was in the power of the court to grant or refuse  what was asked for, according to its pleasure. The answer  was that the court had a discretionary power. Mr. Burton  was then asked if he had with him his license for preaching ;  I 	asc99990010170160001											59951638 Bytes	3672	5440	4089438482	RGB	asc99990010170160001.tif		2013-08-12	2013-08-12	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5934	5934	5935.jp2	/scbooks/image/5935.jp2
Page 161																																asc9999001017		m  he presented his certificate of having; taken the oaths at Port  Maria, which the magistrates pronounced to be good only for  the parish In which the oaths had been taken. He was asked  for any papers showing his connexion with the Missionary  Society; but, not expecting they would be required, he had  left them at Mancbioneal. Nothing however was said about  registering or licensing the house. After a few minutes conversation among the magistrates, Mr. M'Cornock called Mr,  Burton to receive the decision of the court, which he delivered in a lecture to the following effect—"That Mr. Burton had  opened a place for public worship at Morant Bay without any  necessity—without any thing like an excuse for such conduct.  There were the Established Church and Wesleyan Chapel, neither of which was more than half filled before he came; his  object therefore must have been to make proselytes to a sect, and  not to make Christians. Besides, the sect to which he was attached had recently evinced its mischievous character. One  of its ministers had said that the gospel must be preached,,  thoimh a thousand lives were sacrificed.# Now, though such  an assertion might do very well at a missionary meeting, the  magistrates had no wish to be martyrs in such a cause. It  was therefore their duty to be watchful over men avowing such  sentiments; and over Mr. Burton in particular, it was their  province and obligation to be especially strict, as there  had been so much evidence against him laid before the  Court Martial during the late insurrection, as satisfied them  that he was a dangerous person, and not to be trusted j.—■  For these reasons, therefore, Mr. Burton was ordered not to  preach any more at Morant Bay. This was the decision of  the Court; and if in any error, there was no objection against  being set right by superiors, but it would receive no correction  from inferiors. Mr. Taylor, who has never attempted to resume his labours  in Vere since the destruction of the chapel, nor even ventured  !uto the parish, though he rents a house there, has also been  Compelled to relinquish his duties at Old Harbour, where he  had peaceably pursued them for four years, and, as he supposed, in strict accordance with the laws, On the I3ih of  September, he was ci*ed before Messrs. Hannuford, M'Cook,  and Robertson, magistrates, and threatened that if lie preached any more in the parish of St. Dorothy until he obtained a  license at the Quarter Sessions, he should be sent to prison. On Mr. Taylor's pleading the Toleration Acts of  George III. he was told that they were guided by the Act of  William and Mary, and v\hen he expressed his readiness to  take the oaths of allegiance, they refused to administer them,  saying that they were not a constituted body, and had not the  power. With due respect to the magistrates, as well as in  .strict compliance with the Governor's recommendation of  ''submissive deference in the first instance to the decisions of  those authorities, to whom the administration of the laws is  ;enlilisted," -Mr. Tavlor immediately desisted from preaching  in the parish. At the October Quarter Sessions, held m  Spanish Town, he attended, and offered to take the  usual oaths, when the sitting magistrates, (the hon. John Lillian, Custos, presiding,) refused his application, and also  another of the same nature made by Mr. Wilcox, Wesleyan  ■■'missionary. The sitting magistrates for the Court of Quarter Sessions  were Messrs. John Coates, William.Mitchell Kerr, and Alexander Campbell, but ten or twelve others whose attendance  was not required, except to manifest their opposition to ^Sectarians," voluntarily made their appearance on the bench,.anil  withdrew as soon as the decision in this .matter was given.—  Mr. Murray made his application, and handed some ..document?  to the Bench, shewing his connexion with the Wesleyan Missionary Society, and certifying that he had once taken the  necessary oaths in this Island. No magistrate took the trouble  to read his documents, and the answer peremptorily given  was—that the magistrates had made up their minds not to  sanction any Sectarians whatever, as there was no Island  Law requiring them to do it; and when Mr. Murray was  about to refer to the Toleration Acts, he was interrupted and  told by Mr. Henry VVaite Plummer in particular, that they  did not acknowledge any English Statutes, and that he (Mr,  Plummer) neter Would, Mr. Murray was assured that no'  feeling existed in their minds against him, personally, for  they believed his conduct to have been uniformly correct;  but still they could not grant his request, because they .had  determined to admit no Sectarians at all. This refusal being;  of a general nature, Messrs. Nichols and. Abbott considered  it equally applicable to themselves as to Mr. Murray, and  therefore withdrew.  On the 4th of June Mr. and Mrs. Kingdon landed at Savanna-  la-Mar, with the view of recommencing missionary work in  that town. Threats of murdering him were immediately held  out, and insolence was offered in order to deter him from his  purpose \ but not deeming this opposition of much importance,  and trusting to divine protection, he rented a house in the town  from Mrs. Mary Robe, and had it registered in the Bishop's  office, refraining from assembling any congregation till he had  obtained the certificate of registration. Possessed of this document, Mr. Kingdon considered -himself at liberty to preach ;  but Dr. Distin, a magistrate, having expressed doubts as to the  sufficiency of such a certificate, he still deferred preaching till  he might procure legal advice, and therefore on Sunday,  June 17th, merely held a prayer-meeting, which that gentleman himself had declared lawful. But whilst thus engaged  on the following Sabbath, between ten and twelve in the forenoon, the congregation were alarmed by the information that  Mr. Thomas A. Mitchener (one of the chapel destroyers), was 	asc99990010170164001											60328266 Bytes	3728	5392	387462170	RGB	asc99990010170164001.tif		2013-08-12	2013-08-12	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5938	5938	5939.jp2	/scbooks/image/5939.jp2
Page 165																																asc9999001017		collecting a mob to pull down (he house, and it appeared afterwards that the assault was not made, only because many  failed to fulfil their pledge of assisting him. The next day,  "the 25th, Mr. Kingdon was required to appear before the*  magistrates, to answer to a charge preferred against him by  Messrs. T. A. Mitchener, A. Munroe, and John Thompson, of  having held an illegal meeting of slaves the day before. The  Bishop's certificate was produced, yet was Mr. K. obliged tofind  Security for his appearance at the ensuing Cornwall Assizes,  to answer for the breach of a law passed by the Island Legislature in 43 Geo. III. but which had been several years disallowed by the King ! In travelling thirty two miles tc*  Montego-Bay, to attend the court, Mr. Kingdon had  to encounter the risk of crossing a part of the country  abounding with anti-Sectarians; and, after all, the matter was not brought forward. The fact that the instru*  inents of this persecution, the witnesses, had their expensed  paid by the Vestry at Savanna la Mar^ affords ground to con*  jecture at whose instigation they acted.  Mrs. Robe was tried at the Quarter Sessions held at Savanna la Mar on July 10th, for having on the 24th, June, permitted  art illegal meeting of slaves at her house, and for having attended the same herself, which were alleged to be respectively  violations of the 65th and 84th sections of the Slave Code. Tc*  any person who considers the import of these clauses, and the  nature of the meeting in question, it will'be obvious that Mrs.  Kobe could not be convicted on such grounds, without doing  violence to the law. The law explains the words u unlawful  assemblage of slaves'* to mean, a meeting of slaves, at which  they " beat drums, blow horns, &c." and the 84th clause declares its object to be ,u to prevent nightly and other private  meetings \" whereas Mrs. Robe had only permitted a quiet  and peaceable meeting for religions worship, held publicly, and  inthe forenoon. Yet, notwithstanding the inapplicabifiiy of  the law to the alleged offence, Mrs. R. was found guilty on  both charges, and iined £25! As the magistrates had declared, when first they summoned Mr. K. before them, that the  Bishop's registration of the house was of no value, Mr.  K. presented a request to the bench at the Sessions, after the  said trial, praying that they Would license it. But this tbe  magistrates refused to do, saying, that both Mr. K's. safety  and that of the parish required them so to act ; and, on their  being reminded of the lawfulness of the request, the answer  made to Mr. K. was, " We take the responsibility on ourselves  ~we must scfnetimes mt without law, under peculiar circuia--- 	asc99990010170165001											62735086 Bytes	3856	5421	2321155843	RGB	asc99990010170165001.tif		2013-08-12	2013-08-12	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5939	5939	5940.jp2	/scbooks/image/5940.jp2
Page 166																																asc9999001017		141  stances." As such proceedings naturally encouraged the enemies of missions, only four days after, about thirty persons,  all whites, excepting one, proceeded to Mr. K's. lodgings, and  said they wanted the Baptist parson; they endeavoured to go  up stairs to his apartments, but were prevented. Dr. Harvey  did however go upas their delegate, and endeavoured to persuade Mr. K. to leave, urging " the strong excitement of the  -popular feeling againsthim, on account, hesaid, of theBaptist  missionaries being suspected, and in his opinion truly, of having  excited the lite insurrection.' Mr. K. told him the charges  against the missionaries could not be substantiated ; that he,  as a British subject, had a right to live there, and it was the  magistrate's duty to protect him if in danger. Here Dr.  Harvey left in anger, saying, u 1 have done my duty." Henvas  at length prevailed on by Mr. John Deleon to do his duty as a  magistrate in sending away the mob. When the Custos  was apprized of the disturbance, he ordered the constables to  be oil the alert, and as it was asserted that an attack  was to be made at night, a few of Mr. Kingdon's friend*  -kept watch at his house, with a constable, in consequence of  which the attack was prevented. No complaint whatever was  made about this defensive measure, which might have been  expected, had it been illegal. Between this day (the 14th July,)  and the 1st August, the day first appointed for the Colonial  Church Union meeting, various menaces were held out  ♦against Mr. K., as that, he should be tarred, driven away, or  murdered ; and against Mr.Aaron Deleon, jun. that his house,,  in which Mr. K. resided, should be pulled down. They both  therefore wrote to the Custos on the 31st July, seeking protection. The following is a copy of Mr. K's. note, to which  Mr. Deleon's was similar :  To Joseph Stone Williams, Esq.  Custos of Westmoreland,  Sfr,  I am sorry to he under the nsecr'ssity of again appealing to yon for  protection from unprincipled men, hut as it is reported that a meeting  of the Colonial Church Union will he held here to-morrow, and a^  the avowed purpose of this faction is the expulsion of Dissenting Missionaries—which purpose some of its members have proceeded to as-  complish, it is deemed proper by my friends that 1 should, for the  safety of the parish, as well as of myself, thus seek security from th@  possible effects pi frantic declamation upon prejudiced met*.  I am, ^ir, yowr obedient servant,  JOHN KINGDON.  Savanna-la-Mar, July 31, 1832.  The answer received from the Custos was,   that no   one  would  propose, in   his presence, a resolution to expel the  # 	asc99990010170166001											60118032 Bytes	3704	5408	3106198990	RGB	asc99990010170166001.tif		2013-08-12	2013-08-12	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5940	5940	5941.jp2	/scbooks/image/5941.jp2
Page 167																																asc9999001017		142  missionary, or make any assault ; and that if' Mr. Aaron  Deleon or Mr. Kingdon were alarmed, they had hetter swear  the peace against any persons they feared. This advice it was  impossible to follow, the reports which gave rise to their apprehensions not specifying the individuals who uttered the  threats ; however, the said Union meeting being deferred a  week, the expected evil was consequently postponed.  Jt was next reported that on muster day, August 4th,  the attack would take place, and as no precautionary measures  were adopted by the magistracy, a few of Mr. Kingdon's  friends again quietly resorted to his lodgings for his protection.  The expected attack did not takeplace, but threats continued  to be held out.—On the 8th the said Colonial Union meeting  was held, but the Custos refused to preside at it. Those  who spoke at the meeting manifested contempt for that gentleman ; and a resolution was proposed by Mr. Whitelocke, of  Belle Isle estate, and seconded by Mr. Vickers, of Sweet  River pen, to expel all Sectarian teachers and preachers. In  opposition to a proposal to tar and feather Mr. Pennycook,  for refusing to sign the resolutions, a person publicly said at  the meeting, "No, the Baptist Parson is the man, and have him  we will this day." In the evening of this day, when it was found  that a party were parading the streets, as they had done on former public days, Mr. Kingdon wrote tothe Custos and Dr. Distin,  requesting them to come to the spot. The note to the Custos was inadvertently taken to his brother, Mr. Wm. Williams,  a magistrate, who happened to be from home ; on his return  he hastened to the spot, but unfortunately he did not arrive  till after the attack had commenced. Dr. Distin excused  himself from attending, by saying that Mrs. D. was sick.  /Vfterthe partyhad passed andrepassed fromaboutseventill nine  o'clock, they wheeled round in front of Mr. Kingdon's lodgings, marched up to the house, and commenced battering the  . door. Some females threw out of the window upon the assailants a quantity of hot water, which providentially extinguished some combustible matter that had been placed under*  neath, for the purpose of blowing up the house, or at least  setting it on Tire. On this being done, the Colonial Union men*  who were outside, fired a great many times into the upper  windows, namely, those of the hall and study occupied by  Mr, and Mrs. K, in the latter of which apartments they very  narrowly escaped being shot. After firing many shots, and  being themselves fired upon, the Unionists went off and beat  to arms, and having collected a larger force, renewed the attack. Alter secreting themselves in the negro houses, Mr. and Mrs. K. proceeded to the house of Mr. Deleon, senior, where they remained  until the following day, whilst the rioters swore they would  search through Savanna-la-Mar to find Deleon and Kingdon,  and murder them. A credible witness states that when  he saw the crowd passing up the street, he ran amongst  them, and tried to dissuade them from their purpose—that he  found them armed with sticks, swords, pistols, and guns—and  that as they went on, he accompanied them and saw them  commence a violent attack on the front door and windows of  the house.  On retreating from the first assault, Messrs. Wm.Taylor, T. A.  Mitchener, Medley, and Davidson were seen with fire-arms in  their possession. When the drum was beating, many came together armed, and Mr. V/alter Young, after saying, '• Let us get  the great gun, and blow down the house," went with several  others to the Court-house for this piece, but could not obtain  it. An attempt was made to shoot Mrs. John Deleon, for  Mr. Mitchener was seen by a credible witness to present a gun  at that lady as she stood at the window of her residence, and  snap it ; and when it. failed to go off, he was heard to say  *' d—-n this worthless gun"—she herself saw Jno. MTvoy pick  up a stone and throw it at her, and she avoided it by turning  aside. This Mitchener was also heard to say '•' I'd give any  thing to get John Deleon's head to-niiiht."—In the afternoon  of Thursday the 9ih, Mr. Kingdon was sent for by the Custos  to the Court-house ; he was then requested, in the presence  of the mob, to make a deposition, if he chose, when he related the circumstances, and underwent an examination which  •was taken down in writing by a clerk in the peace office.—  In order to appease the fury of a mob of whites, and prevent  them from tearing him to pieces in the Court-house, Mr. K.  was reluctantly obliged to promise that he would leave the town  and never return to it again, and the Custos kindly sent him  and Mrs. K. to his residence at Anglesea for safety till they  coidd leave the parish.  But the malignity of his foes weirt further than this ; for  the same night Mr. Whitelock, a magistrate, who only the day  before had publicly pleaded for (he expulsion ol the Sectarians, issued warrants against him and Messrs. John and Aaron  Deleon, who,, with other friends,   had ?xcrted themsclveo to 	asc99990010170168001											60726356 Bytes	3736	5416	3044925558	RGB	asc99990010170168001.tif		2013-08-12	2013-08-12	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5942	5942	5943.jp2	/scbooks/image/5943.jp2
Page 169																																asc9999001017		lii  defend life and property. They were committed to gao! the  next day, Friday the 10th, and but for the great exertions of  the Custos, Mr. John Deleon would have been murdered  while going thither.  V*, o  Let the reader mark this most palpable perversion of justice. An inoffensive missionary and his wile, in danger of  being murdered, suffer a few7 persons to collect in their dvseliding for the purpose of resisting an expected attack, in the absence of protection bym the constituted authorities ; they are  overcome by an armed banditti, who (ire into various parts  of the house, and are compelled to flee for their lives; the  house is attempted to be demolished, which is effected the  next day; and then, because two or three of the depredators  are slightly wounded or scalded, the assailants become the  accusers, and charge Mr. Kingdon and his friends with hav-&gt;  rng broken the peace by commencing the affray 1 Falsehood,  deception, and even perjury are invoked against the innocent  sufferers, and they are cast into prison, while the real rioters  are permitted to walk at large and to commit new depredations ! The matter is reported in the Jamaica Conrant, with  all the false colouring which can be given to it by an Editor,  who never hesitates to publish as many falsehoods as he con*  ceives necessary for his purpose. Perhaps it would be difficult to find a transaction in which Satan has more strikingly,  than in the misrepresentation of this outrage, illustrated and  confirmed his character as the father of lies and accuser of  the brethren.  Still the rioters persisted in their work of destruction,  completed the demolition of the house where Mr. Kingdon  had lodged, belonging to Mr. Aaron Deleon, and nearly ruined  the new and costly residence of Mr. John Deleon. Several  of the same party went in open day to the store of Mr. Dol*  phy, one of the persons present at Mr. Kingdon's lodgings  when the attack was made, threw into the yard and street his  dry goods, provisions, and furniture, and turned his family out  of doors I The house of Samuel Swiney, a free member of  the Baptist church, and that of Cornelius Gammon, were destroyed. His honour the Custos was present at some of these  demolitions, and used his utmost personal exertions to restrain  the mob. Many other depredations were committed, one of  which we mention, because it occasioned loss of life! A  party went to the house of Miss Wilson, and began to de*  stroy it; this so alarmed Miss Helen M'Mali on as to throw  her into a state of torpor, from which she never revhed : she  died in two days after! Even in the gaol Mr. Kingdon and his friends were unsafe |  such was the horrid feeling against them, that they were obliged  to keep watch even there, lest they should be betrayed into the  hands of murderers by Mr. James E. Burlton, the deputy-marshal,and Mr. Harry Dawson,* thedeputy gaoler, who were both  among the rioters and house-breakers. Threats were loudly  made, and several times were they awoke in the night, expecting that an attack was about to be made—several times  their friends were denied admittance to them, and various  grievances and insults were offered them, chiefly by the individual who has since been called into the presence of his  God. Mr. Kingdon and his friends continued in confinement  twenty four days, and after having been closely examined by  Mr. Davies, a gentleman from Kingston, deputed to inquire  into the affray&gt; they were admitted to bail, September 3d.—  Messrs. Kingdon and Aaron and John Deleon were required  to find bail fur their appearance at the Cornwall Assizes in November, each in £500, and ihe like sum for their securities.  The former asked and obtained permission to remain that  night iu gaol for safety.  Mr. and Mrs. Kingdon left Savanna-la-Mar on the evening  of September 4th, in a canoe for Black River. In go:n£  from the gaol to the sea&gt; great caution was required to a\oid  falling in with a gang of rioters (hen abroad ; and, on arriving  at the beach, delay and difficulty were experienced before they  procured acanoe, which occasioned distressing anxiety, as manv  enemies were watching their movements, and they knew not  a moment but they might be attacked again,—in this open  canoe they were on the sea till two or three o'clock next  morning, when they reached Black River, and went on board  the schooner West Indian, which safely conveyed them to  Kingston.  On the night of their leaving, their friends were compelled  to hide themselves, or they would have been murdered ; and  soon afterwards they were obliged to escape, some into Han-*  over, others into the morass and woods. Deleon,  arter having lost property to the amount of several thousand  pounds, were compelled, on being released from gaol, to flee  into the interior of the country, neglecting their bus mess, and  leaving their wives, children, and property exposed to insult  and depredation ; and to this day they have not ventured to  return.  The Cornwall Assizes, held at Montego Hay, commenced  on the 5th November, at which Mr. Kingdon, Messrs. J. and  A. Deleon, and other of Mr. Kingdon's friends attended, *xk  gether with several of the rioters who had likewise been bound  over to appear. Bills were first sent before the Grand Jury  against the rioters—all the capital indictments against them  were ignored, and but few of those sent in for misdemeanors  were found. The Attorney General, who must have been  satisfied of Mr. Kingdon's innocence, did not prepare any in*  diet men t against him. The Chief Justice asked if a precedent  could be shewn; the case of Mr. Knibb was mentioned,  but Mr. Justice Gordon, who sat during the March Court  when that case occurred, professed not to remember that Mr.  Knibb was admitted to bail under similar circumstances. It  is well known that Mr. Knibb v;as admitted to bail after he  had been capitally indicted and arraigned ; it is also well  known that the late Chief Justice (G. L. Tuckett, Esq.) at  the Surrey Assizes for April last, liberated Mr. Edward Jordori  on bail, admitting as a precedent the case of Mr Knibb. As  it is difficult to believe that Mr. Justice Gordon could have  forgotten these facts, no very favourable construction can be  placed upon his opposition to the liberation of Messrs. Page 174																																asc9999001017		CHAPTER XI.  Means employed to obtain redress, stay persecution, and allay prejudice.—  Piayer Meetings.—Appeals chrough Newspapers.—Correspondence with Commodore Farquhar and Admiral Colpoys—Letters and Memorials to Lord Bel-  more.—Mr. Knibb proceeds to England as a deputation.—Applications to Urn  Governor and Attorney-General lor Evidence laid befoie them against us, that  we might refute the Report of the Rebellion Committee.—Address to Lord  Mulgrave.—Memorial to him.—Correspondence with Mr. Custos Miller.—  The Christian Record.—Summary of the Evidence therein.  We shall now proceed to lay before the reader some of the  means we have, from time to time, adopted to obtain redress  for our grievances,—to avert the torrent of persecution,—■',  and to remove the misconceptions and prejudices with which  the public mind has been filled,—-with a few occasional re*  marks as to the results.  The principal of these means were humble prayer to Almighty God, and respectful representations to their Excellencies the Earl of Beimore and the Earl of Mulgrave respectively. We have occasionally referred to other authorities,  and in several instances availed ourselves of the columns of  the " Jamaica Watchman," a Newspaper, which has made a  linn and independent stand against the prevailing intolerance  and cruelty. We have never " resisted the power," nor given  cause for the charge of disobedience to the ruling authorities,  though some of their measures and requirements have appeared to us uncalled for and unjust  During the disturbances, those of the missionaries, who  were in Kingston and Spanish-Town, held stated meetings for.  prayer (commonly at noon), to implore the Divine interposition for the deliverance of their suffering hrethren from unmerited punishment—to assuage the storm of persecution,  and to over-rule every trying event to the furtherance of the  Gospel.  Three Memorials to the Earl of Beimore, together with  the circumstances which occasioned them, have already been  laid before the reader.  At the height of the persecution, when some public state*  wient from the missionaries was imperatively called for by  existing circumstances, and we could no longer forbear from 	asc99990010170174001											59904910 Bytes	3680	5424	4210011519	RGB	asc99990010170174001.tif		2013-08-12	2013-08-12	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5948	5948	5949.jp2	/scbooks/image/5949.jp2
Page 175																																asc9999001017		150  making a declaration of our innocence, those of us who wers  in Spanish-Town and Kingston addressed a letter to the pub*  lie through the columns of the u Watchman" and *'Kingston  Chronicle," denying the charges so confidently alleged against  us ; presenting extracts from the |4 Instructions" of the Baptist Missionary Society to their missionaries on leaving Eng-^  land, to show that we were prohibited from all civil and political interference ; and stating some circumstances to induce  a suspension of the public judgment,—See the Letter in Appendix, No. VI.  At the termination of Martial Law, the magistrates and inhabitants of Montego*-Bay, having addressed to Commodore  Farqnhar, of his Majesty's Navy, a letter of thanks for his  zealous exertions to suppress the rebellion, that officer was  pleased, in his reply, to ascribe that calamity " in a great measure to the fanatical preaching and teaching of the sect called  Baptists." Considering that the public expression of such a  sentiment from so high a quarter was likely to be strongly pre*  judicial to our case, and that, as it was altogether uncalled for,  it was scarcely becoming the rank and character of the Commodore, the missionaries felt constrained to notice it, and accordingly addressed a letter to him, inquiring whether the  words ascribed to him in the public prints, actually formed a  part of his reply to the magistrates and inhabitants of Montego Bay. The answer to this letter was so extremely vague  and unsatisfactory, that a statement of the circumstances, con*,  iaining copies of this correspondence, was addressed to Admiral Colpoys,* and a copy of this communication transmitted  to our Secretary in London. The Admiral declined interfering, but it consists with our knowledge that our complaint  has been represented at the Colonial Office, and through that  medium to the Lords of the Admiralty.  In the month of April, a letter was addressed to Mr. Nunes,  the secretary of Lord Beimore, informing his Excellency of  the intention of the military authorities at Falmouth to prosecute two members of the Baptist Church there, for having, a  few days before, interfered to protect Mr. Bleby. Wesleyan  missionary, when in imminent personal danger from a mob of  white persons, who broke into his honse, began to besmear  him with tar, and were proceeding to set him on fire!  The correspondence on this subject (Appendix VIII.) is  worthy of notice. Curious quibbles are resorted to in order  to torture our language into something evil—something not  * See Appendix No, VII. 	asc99990010170175001											63139322 Bytes	3856	5456	1453491815	RGB	asc99990010170175001.tif		2013-08-12	2013-08-12	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5949	5949	5950.jp2	/scbooks/image/5950.jp2
Page 176																																asc9999001017		'  151  far short of a declaration of war ?ga£e»l the Govern-£  inent ! The extraordinary threat, that the attempt to defend ourselves and our property from lawless mobs, would  he * attended with signal defeat," issuing from the  mouth of a potent British Governor, and addressed to about  a dozen feeble missionaries, sounds ludicrously magnanimous.'  And, together with the advice, gravely given, to receive  the attacks of our foes with folded arms, and then to appeal to  them (as Justices o\ the Peace, &c.) for redress, might have  reasonably excited, in the minds of persons unacquainted with  the reality, a suspicion that his Lordship wished to play into  the hands of the Colonial Church Union. The correspondence was calculated (though perhaps not intended) to deter  us from further appealing to his Excellency for protection  from injury.  At this period, all the missionaries assembled in Kingston  and Spanish-Town to offer united thanksgiving and pra\er,  and to transact the business of the mission.  While thus together, a memorial was addressed to his Excellency,* respecting our grievances generally, accompanied by  a-statement of recent outrages, and detailing the names of the  principal parlies concerned. 'To this communication his Excellency's secretary returned a very prompt reply, stating that  no time should be lost hi forwarding our representation to the  Attorney-General, for the purpose of affording us the protection and redress sought. And a lew days afterwards we re~  ceived another letter from his Excellence's secretary, enclose  ing a copy of the Attorney-General's letter on the subject,  sfaling that our witnesses must go before magistrates, to make  depositions on oath, and enter into recognizances to appear  and ^i\e evidence in Court, and that, when this was done, we  might obtain warrants from the magistiates for the apjrehen^  sion of the parties accused, if we were desirous that they  should not remain at large.—This was strictiy legal :u\\ Ice no  doubt ; but how was it to be acted upon ? For a inissionaiy  to go about the country on such an errand would, as both the  Attorney-General and the Governor well knew, have endangered his life; and to v. rite to friends to act for us was at  least a very uncertain method, as the reader has seen in our  statement of the Post-Office irregularities. Mr. Nichols'  letter on this very subject was never -delivered! Other  letters, however, were deli\ered id the proper parties  ~'but no   practical   good resulted,   while  the  persons   thus  * Set 3fe*w*2kl and Replies in Appendix rfo. We shall  relate an instance illustrating this, nearly in the words  o^i our informant, Mr, Thomas Leverrnore:—"On Monday the lljth June, I went to the office of Mr. Miller (the  Custos of Trelawuy), and presented my affidavit (relating to  the destruction of the Baptist chapel), requesting him to administer the oath to me. lie read it, and asked 'at what time  the occurrence took place?' 1 told him, (on the 8th of February'. He then handed the affidavit to me, saying * I was  not in the is/and at the lime\ and referred me to Mr. George  Marrett, another magistrate, who was standing by him. Mr.  Marrett took the affidavit, read it, and returned it, saying, * I  rqas not in Falmouth when the thinij occurred' ! On the 12th,  Charles H;ovyn and I went to Mr. Wm. Wray, and he declined  signing our affidavits, when he perceived that a man named  John Wray, formerly his servant, was implicated. He inquired  whether I had been to any other magistrate, and why they  Had declined signing the affidavits ? 1 told him of Messrs.  Wilier, Marrett, Lamont, and Kelly, the two latter of whom  had said that it was not their quarter* Mr. Wray then desired us to go to the Court house, to which we therefore repaired, accompanied by Lewis Williams. They looked at the affidavits. Mr. Jackson, the  clerk' of the peace, made some objections to them, and Mr.  Miller referred us to lite Attorney-General on the subject." Although there is not much to encourage in the Governor's  reply to the .memorial, and though, on the contrary, there are  some expressions savouring of an unkind spirit towardrusryet we  feel called upon to express our gratitude for his Excellency's  conduct towards us in the main, and our satisfaction with Iris  proceedings generally, since his arrival in the island. Of those;  things which relate to our affairs particularly, we shall briefly  notice, that on our laying before him a hasty and informal  detail of the attack made on Mr. Kingdon at Savanna la Mar,  it was very kindly received, and the promptest attention  paid to the subject of it. On a memorial being submitted to his Excellency lately, relative to the imprisonment of  Messrs. Deleon and Dolphy, as related at page 147, he took  6uch steps as have resulted in their liberation, on bail, by the  Chief-Justice, and his Excellency has more recently remitted  the fine imposed upon Mrs. Renwick, as related at page 135.  The instance we are now about to mention arose out of the  following circumstances: Some of the members of the Falmouth Church commenced holding Sabbath prayer-meetings  in the house of Miss Rebecca Lawrence. For this heinous  crime they were summoned before Mr. Custos Miller and  sorrie other magistrates on the 19th of June, and on the 20th;  the Editor of the Cornwall Courier thus notices the matter :  • It is rather singular that before they appeared in the Watchman, to whi^h  paper atone we luraibhed then}, they had beea published, ia th* Jamaica CouratU: 	asc99990010170182001											60343738 Bytes	3696	5440	3197375717	RGB	asc99990010170182001.tif		2013-08-12	2013-08-12	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5956	5956	5957.jp2	/scbooks/image/5957.jp2
Page 183																																asc9999001017		LO.S  • "Yesierday a free brown woman, of the name of Rebecca  Lawrence, was brought before the sitting magistrates (his  honour the Custos, Frederick Lamont, Roger Davis, and  John Kelly, Ksqrs.) charged, under the 65th clause of the  sla^e law, with holding unlawful meetings of slaves. From  the testimony of five witnesses, it appeared that the defendant  on Sunday last had a Baptist conventicle at her house, which  was crowded by devout brothers and sifters, of whom the  majority were slaves. The leader on this occasion was one  of Parson Knibb's deacons, by name Lewis Williams, and  they were carrying-on In line style, when a scout gave notice  that the Philistines were approaching ; and all the slave part  of the congregation fled precipitately. On this occasion it  appeared that no sermon was delivered, hut we understand  that the thing has been secretly carried an fov several weeks.  -—His Honour the Custos, after admonishing the pious Miss  Rebecca, ordered her to bail, herself in £20 and two sureties  in £10 each, to answer the charge at the sessions.—The  Custos then desired Mr. Deacon Williams to stand forth, ami  addressed him to (he following effect :—Lewis Williams, you  have heard the evidence which has been brought forward this  day, in which your name bears a conspicuous part ; and one  witness said he heard yen give out the line of the hymn that  was then being sung. It is contrary to law to hold such  meetings as the one you was engaged in ; in the first, place, it  is necessary that the house in which the meeting was held  should be licensed, and in the second, it was necessary that  the preacher should he licensed also.—The deacon here interrupted his Honour, and said he did not preach, he only  prayed.—The Custos proceeded—What qualified missionaries  are not allowed to do, you have attempted ; you must be  aware that from the confessions of many of the unfortunate  people who were executed during Martial Law, and from the  evidence taken before the Committee of the House of Assembly, the. Baptist preachers were deeply implicated in causing  the rebellion. You have not allowed the excited state of  the country to be laid at rest, when you re-commenced to  promulgate those doctrines which were the principal cause of  the war.—We think that your conduct has been highly  improper. Whether the persons who composed your congregation were slaves or not, this is not the time to be holding  such meetings, and if even the country was completely settled,  you would not be a fit person to be allowed to preach.™  'Deacon Willjam.s again said that he only prayed, but was cut  short in a speech by being'warned not to offend again." 	asc99990010170183001											62584128 Bytes	3856	5408	1857109810	RGB	asc99990010170183001.tif		2013-08-12	2013-08-12	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5957	5957	5958.jp2	/scbooks/image/5958.jp2

In consequence of the statement in the reported-charge of (he  Custos, that "the baptist preachers were deeply implicated  in causing the rebellion.'' being very much at variance with ihe  previously expressed sentiments and the public conduct of that  gentleman, doubts were reasonably entertained whether the  Editor of (he Courier was not seeking, by misrepresentation,  to enlist the Custos's influential name, on the fide of intolerance and falsehood, trusting that pohey would deter his Honour from coming forward with a public denial. It was therefore deemed advisable to (.Street, his attention to the subject,  and a letter was written, pointing it out to him, and calling to  his recollection his " assurance to Mr. Knibb that he had  visited many estates under his (the Custos's) charge in St.*  James, Hanover, Trelavvny, &c. and had taken pains to inquhe  among the slaves whether the missionaries had ever held out  to them hopes of freedom, or in any way been th.e means  of inducing ihe expectation of it ; but thai they had one and  all fully exonerated them ; and that he (the Custos) believed  they were innocent of such an offence." lie was also re..,  minded of his having sent for Mr Knihh at Falmouth, and had  much conversation with him and of his having employed him at  Montego Bay to visit and examine the rebel chiefs &lt;iardnej\  Sharpe, and others. Page 188																																asc9999001017		A PPEN.D I 1  A_«  lo.  A  ■Memorial to his Excellency the Earl of Beimore, #c. ^ •  i      •    ' (L)  Jamaica? ss, ■  Tohis Excellency the Governor.  The humble- Memorial of several Baptist Missionaries, .  Shewcth,  That your Memorialists, and other the Missionaries of the Baptist  Persuasion in this island, have been charged with being instrumental  in producing and promoting the dreadful insurrection that has recently  taken place :  That each of your Memorialists for himself solemnly avers that, ha  lias never intentionally, by word or deed, directly or Indirectly, been  instrumental or accessary in the promotion of the unhappy disturb-,  ances, nor have they intentionally led the slaves or any others' to think,  that freedom was theirs, or to draw any of those numerous other erroneous conclusions which report informs your Memorialists thev have  assigned as the causes of their violent conduct ; but that your Memo-.  riaiists have, On the contrary, most heartily deplored and condemned  the proceedings of the slaves from the commencement, not only o.u  account of their ruinous consequences to both, masters and slaves,, bit  also of the disgrace they are calculated to bring upon tire-Christian  1 religion, which many who appear to be engaged in it have professed-;  and moreover, your Memorialists are firmly persuaded, from the knowledge they have of each other and of their brother Missionaries, that  they are equally innocent in intention ; , and they have many reasons  for hoping that they are not justly liable to the charge of being even  the unintentional causes or promoters of the revolt:  That your Memorialists have hitherto refrained from approachingyour  Excellency, and from coming- forward in any public manner to defend  themselves, because they have been expecting to be brought to trial,  when they should have an opportunity of vindicating themselves from  the monstrous iniquities with which they stand charged, but in the  event of a trial not. taking place, their intention was, on regaining their  liberty,, to by before the public- such, a defence of themselves* .and  such testimony in their favour, as would be calculated to remove tlje  unfavourable impression that has been produced by the expiirte statements riow abroad ;  4 	asc99990010170188001											60298964 Bytes	3688	5448	4245075885	RGB	asc99990010170188001.tif		2013-08-12	2013-08-12	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5962	5962	5963.jp2	/scbooks/image/5963.jp2
Page 189																																asc9999001017		2  APPENDIX.  That your Memorialists do not fear the result of a fair and impartial  investigation into their conduct and principles as Christians and  Missionaries, their consciousness of inr ocence has enabled them to  bear with composure the abridgment of their liberty—the opprobrium  heaped upon tneir characters, and the insults offered to their persons ;  find has induced them to reject, so long as there existed a probability  of a trial, the recommendation strongly urged on them by several most  respectable gentlemen to quit the island, although they were told, and  had every reason to believe, permission would be readily granted them  by the competent authorities :  That it was only on receiving a discharge in writing from the honourable Richard Barrett, and his declaration " that there was no legal  evidence implicating him,'* that your Memorialist, Thomas Burchell,  determined to quit the island, which he was about to do at the time he  was committed to prison :  That your Memorialists have been condemned by the public without  a hearing, on evidence which your Memorialists have never been made  acquainted with, and on the testimony of witnesses whom your Memorialists, orany person on their behalf, had not an opportunity of hearing  or cross-examining—that their persons have been threatened with  -violence, and they were obliged to flee for protection on board his  Majesty's ship North Star —that gome of their dwellings have been  entered, and their clothes, furniture, and other property have been  destroyed or plundered—that several of their chapels have been totally  demolished, under the countenance and with the aid of magistrates and  officers in the militia, and your Memorialists expect that many, If not  all the rest, will share the same fate, unless prevented by the interposition of your Excellency's authority :  That most of the places so destroyed, as well as those which still  remain, are the property of a targe body of Protestant Dissenters in  Great-Britain, denominated the Baptist Missionary Society, against  whom no charge can reasonably exist of having excited the slaves to  rebellion :  That your Memorialists are British subjects, devotedly attached to  their gracious Sovereign and his government, and thus humbly and  respectfully submit to your Excellency that they are entitled to protection from the outrages with which they are still threatened.  Your Memorialists therefore humbly pray that your Excellency will  take such steps for the preservation of the remaining Places of Worship, .residences, and property in which your Memorialistsare interested*  and for the security of your Memorialists' persons, and afford such  further relief as to your Excellency shall seem meet.  And your Memorialists shall ever prav, &e.  (Signed) WILLIAM KNIBB.  WILLIAM WHITEHORNE.  THOMAS F. ABBOTT.  THOMAS BURCHELL.  FRANCIS GARDNER.  St it.  (2.)  Montego-Bay, Uth February, 1832. Page 190																																asc9999001017		APPEND1 X.  3  Hfs Excellency the Governor had anticipated the wish expressed in  that petition, having, previously to the receipt of if, issued a Proclamation, of which I enclose a copy, and the same has been promulgated  throughout the island.  I am, Sir, your obedient servant,  W. G. NUNES.  Mr. William Knibb,  (3.)  [Proclamation alluded to in the preceding Letter.J  A PROCLAMATION  By His Excellency the Right Honourable Somerset Lowry, Earl  of Belrnore, Captain General and Governor-in-Chref of this  His Majesty's Island of Jamaica, and the Territories thereon  depending in America, Chancellor, and Vice Admiral of the  same.  Whereas I have received information that several Chapels and  Places of Worship, belonging to the Sect called Baptists, situated in  the towns of Falmouth, Montego-Bay, Lucea, and Savanna la-Mar,  have been wantonly and illegally destroyed by riotous assemblages of  People: And whereas such proceedings are disgraceful to the Colony,  subversive of order, and of dangerous example : I do hereby call on  all Custodes of Parishes and all Magistrates to seek oat and discover  the authors of these outrages, that thsy may be punished according to  Law : And I also require and enjoin the said Custodes and Magistrates, to employ the whole force which the Constitution has i-ntrustcd  to them, in protecting property of every description, whether belonging to private persons or Religious Societies, in quelling all disorderly  Meetings, and in bringing to exemplary punishment every disturber of  the Public Peace.  Given under my hand and seal at arms, at Montego-Bay, this  thirteenth day of February, in the second year of His Majesty's  reign, Aunoque Domini, One Thousand Eight Hundred and  Thirty-Two.
