"Horatio Coriualdi, ditto, ditto,  Alexander Baillie, ditto.  William Fowle Holt, of the parish,of Trelawny, ditto*  John Larkin, ditto, ditto.  Peter Heron, ditto, ditto.  Charles S. Hopkins, ditto, ditto,  Joseph Solomon, ditto, ditto,  James Gerrard, ditto, ditto.  John Ferguson, ditto, ditto*  No. IV.  The Opening Charge of Chief Justice Tuckett to the Grand  -Jury, on the opening of the March Cornwall Assize Court*  Gentlemen of the Grand Inquest.  .Although the duty I owe to the public most imperatively forbids  me from entering into a discussion of the calamitous events, which have  lately devastated so large a portion of this country, yet, I assure you,  I do most sincerely, and, from my, heart, condole with you, and with  the sufferers .in. this most dreadful  disturbance, on   tire destruction  , Which has taken place. Gentlemen, it would be highly unbecoming in  ine from this seat to enlarge further on this'frightful subject. To have  said less than 1 have done, might have been construed into'an insensibility to what has occurred—I therefore turn from so melancholy a  topic to the Calendar of prisoners, which now lies before me.  The first case in that Calendar, is for the murder of a slave. Gentlemen, the law on the subject of murder has been long established, that  whenever tire fact of killing is proved against any individual, it is to  he presumed, in the first instance, that the act was maliciously committed. Mr. Justice Foster, the most eminent writer on Criminal Law,  lays it down, '* that in every charge of murder, the fact of killing being  first proved, all the circumstances of accident, necessity, or infirmity  are to;be satisfactorily proved by the prisoner, unless they arise out  of the evidence produced against him ; for the law presume-th the fact  to have been found in  malice, until the contrary appeareth.    And  ' very right it is'that the law should so'presume. The defendant in  this instance standeth upon just the same foot, that every other defendant doth; the matters tending, to justify, excuse, or alleviate,  must appear in evidence, before he can avail himself of them."  Gentlemen, Mr. Justice Foster goes on to define the meaning of  malice ; and as his definition is the- clearest and most satisfactory to  my raitid, that I have anywhere met with, I will read to you his words  •r. 	asc99990010170191001											64258720 Bytes	3936	5440	2011666984	RGB	asc99990010170191001.tif		2013-08-12	2013-08-12	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5965	5965	5966.jp2	/scbooks/image/5966.jp2
Page 192																																asc9999001017		AEPENDJX,, 5-  on Jhis subject. . He says,/' When the law maketli. use of the term  malice aforethought, as descriptive of the crime of murder, it is not to  be understood in that narrow restrained sense to which tHe^modernuse  of the word malice is apt to lead one, a principle of malevolence' to  particulars. For the law by the term malice in this instance meaneth,  that the fact has been attended with such circumstances, as are the  ordinary symptoms of a wicked, depraved, malignant spirit/'  "And again he says, *' The mains animus, which is to be collected from  all circumstances, and of which, as I before said, the Court, and not the  Jury, is to decide, is what bringeth the offence, whether the denomination of wilful malicious murder, whatever might be the immediate motives to it, whether it be done as the old writers express themselves,  4 Ira vel odio, vei causa lucri/ or from any other wicked, or mischievous incentive : And I believe most, if not all the cases, which, in our  books, are ranged under the head of implied malice, will, if carefully  adverted to, be found to turn on this single point. That -the fact has  been attended with such -circumstances, as carry in them the plain  indications of a heart regardless of social duty, and fatally bent upon mischief."  'Gentlemen, I forbear to enter into the facts of this case.—It would  be most improper for me to do so at this stage of'the investigation,—'  I tiave discharged my doty, oy defining id you, what constitutes the  crime of murder. It will be your duty to apply that definition to Ihe  evidence that will be laid before you, that you might be led to a right  conclusion on this important case.  The remaining cases for your inquiry, Gentlemen, are of a very  different complexion, as'far as I have been able to understand the nature of them'(aud I'have only sough1 instruction on this subject to  have it in my power to explain the law to you for your guidance—from  th'ecircumstances of these cases, I most scrupulously abstain.) The Indictments that will be laid before yon, will be framed-on the second  clause of an Act of Jamaica, which was passed to provide a more effectual remedy for the punishment of treason, treasonable conspifa  cy, and seditious meetings. I will read to you the clause, '* He i»  enacted, that if any person or persons whatsoever, after the day. of. the  passing of this Act, shall maliciously and advisedly endeavour to excite  or stir up any free person or slave to commit any act of insurrection,  of rebellious" or traitorous assembly, or to commit any traitorous or  rebellious practice, or to engage in any confederacy, combination, or  conspiracy, for the purpose, by force or constraint, or otherwise than  lawful means, of effecting a change in the state and condition of Ihe  free people or slaves of this island, as by law established, or by force  or constraint, or compelling the Governor, or person exercising the  functions of the Governor, and the Council, and .Assembly of this  island, or either of them, to consent fo grant or agree to such change,  or in order to put any force or constraint upon, or to intimidate or  overawe the Governor* or the Council and Assembly of this island, or  either of them, being lawfully convicted thereof, that every such person-or persons, so as aforesaid offending, shall be deemed, declared,  and adjudged to'be guilty of felony, and shall suffer death without  benefit of Clergy."  "it will be yourduty, Gentlemen, to investigate these charges calmly,  dispassionately, and without prejudice, forgetting every thing you  have'seen or heard of the Origin, or causes of what has lately happened, aud having no other influence on your minds but the sanctions  it:  * 	asc99990010170192001											60822248 Bytes	3720	5448	3977540301	RGB	asc99990010170192001.tif		2013-08-12	2013-08-12	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5966	5966	5967.jp2	/scbooks/image/5967.jp2
Page 193																																asc9999001017		6  A PPE N DI X.  and obligations of the oath you have taken to administer justice. In  such a temper of mind, iet me entreat you to enter oir the discharge of  the important duties confided to you as a Grand Inquest. Should the  evidence adduced against the accused, or any of them, be overt acts,  they will speak for themselves, and cannot be misunderstood ; but  should the evidence brought forward consist in speeches, conversations, or advisings, or in any other manner, not amounting to overt  acts—should they consist in the use of language, I beseech you to satisfy yourselves that the words charged to have been used by the accused, were actually used by them, and that no misconstruction might  be placed on them, by ignorant and illiterate persons, contrary to the  sense iu which they were spoken. You all know the treachery of  human memory. Personsof the best intentionsfrequently misconceive,  and misrepresent what is addressed to them, and we frequently find  persons of educated minds differing as to conversations, which  took place in their presence; one person recollects some statement that has escaped the rcollection of another, and different  persons put the most different construction on the meaning of  the same passages. As a caution to you on this, I will read tc  you an observation of a very great Lawyer, Mr. Justice Black-  stone, to shew how easy it is for the best men to be deceived as to  words. He says, M they may be spoken in heat, without any inten-  iion, or limitation, perverted or misrepresented by the hearers: their  meaning always depends on their connection with other words, and  things : they may signify differently, even according to the tone of  voice with which they are delivered ; and sometimes silence itself is  more expressive than any discourse. There can be nothing more  equivocal and ambiguous than words."  Having satisfied yourself, that the words said to be spoken were  really spoken by the speakers; in the next place let me entreat you,  with the same calmness and temper of mind, forgetting all you have  seen or heard of the late calamities, with the same solemn obligations of an oath on your minds, to inquire whether the words spoken  were of that dangerous description to the peace and tranquillity of  this island, as has been imputed to them. Try them fairly, and do  not ascribe guilt, where guilt might never have been intended. But  above all, let me entreat you, without prejudice, to enquire whether  the words charged to have been uttered, were uttered in the language  of the statute—maliciously and advisedly, with the endeavour to excite,  or stir up the slave population of this island to insurrection or rebellion. That is the question.—The question is not, whether improper,  indiscreet, or even unjustifiable, language might have been addressed to  this people. It is, Was the design and object of the speaker to excite  rebellion? Gentlemen, you must be persuaded, that this was his real  design, or you cannot find a true hill against him under the clause of  the statute on which he is indicted.  Gentlemen, another part of your duty will be to inquire, whether  the offences were committed within the space of six months from this  prosecution. For if they were beyond that period, the statute is a  bar to their being proceeded in.  Since the last Assizes the Slave Act has come into operation, undei  which, slaves in the several cases mentioned in the Act, are permitte*  to give their testimony in Courts of Justice.    It will be our duty t  take care that no slave shall be sent before you, that is not fully coj:  iiizaat of the nature and obligation of an oath.    We shall careful! 	asc99990010170193001											63383956 Bytes	3888	5432	2635402867	RGB	asc99990010170193001.tif		2013-08-12	2013-08-12	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5967	5967	5968.jp2	/scbooks/image/5968.jp2
Page 194																																asc9999001017		APPENDIX. 7  examine them before they are sworn, and if they are sent before you,  you may rest satisfied, that we are of opinion that they are competent  witnesses, under the requisitions of the act. It will be for yon to sift  their credit, remembering that no free person can be convicted by the  single testimony of one slave alone, unless it be corroborated by other  evidence, and that his evidence is restricted to offences committed  since the first of last November, th* period of the commencement of  the Slave Act.  Gentlemen, with respect to these latter cases, I beg leave again to  remind you, that there are three questions for your consideration :  Were the words charged to have been uttered, really uttered, by the  persons to whom they are imputed ; were they realty of a rebellious  nature ; and lastly, was it the design of the person using them—did ha  meditate the wicked intention, at the time he used them, to excite the  slave population to rebellion?—Calmly ask yourselves, were these  mere words of intemperance or indiscretion, or was the heart bent on  insurrection ? Let me entreat you, Gentlemen, to meet these questions with calmness, temper, and sobriety of mind, expelling from  your minds, in these times of excitement, as far as human infirmity  can go, every prejudice that you may feel, solicitous only to discover  the truth ; that so, while yon are doing justice to your islatrd, you  might do justice also to those prisoners, whose fate is, in a great measure, in your hands.  fjf  No. V.  Resolutions, fyc. of the Colonial Church Union of St. Anris*  At a Meeting held in St. Ann's Bay, the2Gth day of January, 1832,  it was Resolved—  To call on every Friend of the Colony to assist, by an annual Subscription of Twenty Shillings, in the permanent establishment of  A COLONIAL CHURCH UNION,  whose object it should be to resist, by all constitutional means, the  encroachment of their enemies under every disguise, and through  the agency of quarterly Reports, published throughout tin? British  Dominions, to offer to the falsehoods of the opposing Anti-Slavery  Society, an antidote, in the form of arguments and facts, illustrative  of the true state of our labouring classes:-at the same time encouraging and promoting every measure for the advancement of their  temporal and spiritual interests:  M That Subscription Lists be immediately opened and forwarded to  all places of public resort throughout the island.  "That, until a full meeting of all the island Subscribers can be  convened for the purpose of electing the President and Officers of the  Society,  ••James Lawrence Hilton, Esq. President ; J. W. Rose, T. Rafiing-  ton, and R. Cocking, Fsqrs. theii Secretaries; and Hamilton Brown,  James Walker, James Johnston,   Charles Smith,  George Stennett, 	asc99990010170194001											61477290 Bytes	3760	5448	4291016530	RGB	asc99990010170194001.tif		2013-08-12	2013-08-12	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5968	5968	5969.jp2	/scbooks/image/5969.jp2
Page 195																																asc9999001017		END I"X.  William  M^Opqk,   John   Iligginbottom,  .John   W.   Davis,   Robert  Robinson, and 'Henry Smaliwood, Esqrs. be appointed'the acting  Committee for the purpose of publishing and promoting the measures  throughout the other parishes of the Colony.  ifc This meeting elects B. S. MoncrieiTe, Esq. Treasurer/'  INHABITANTS OF JAMAICA !  Your danger is great ! If you have discovered the source of yo«r  disease, lose not a moment in expelling the poison from your veins./  Rally around your Church and Kirk before it be too late, and defeml  yourselves from all who attack tkem.—The preservation of your wives,  your children, your properties, your houses, nay, of your lives?  demands it.  A COLONIAL CHURCH UNION  is all Von want to unite the friends of the Colony in a defence which  must then succeed. Names and Subscriptions will be received at the  Cornwall Courier Office,  and forwarded to the Treasurer, B. S.  Moncrieffe, Esq.  At a General Meeting of the Colonial Church Union of St,  Ann's, this 15th day of February, 1832 : — Present, '    '  The Hot). Henry Cox, and James Lawrence Hilton, Esqrs.  Presidents.  It was Resolved,  " 1st. That at an alarming, crisis like the present, when the possession of our lives and properties depends upon our recovering-the confidence of our people, which -has been estranged by the arts of those  whose influence must be first removed, and when it is the prevailing  fashion of the day to carry every measure against us by organised  . Societies, and Political Unions, it becomes'our duty to arm ourselves  with the same weapons against our'assailants, and to unite in our own  defence for our mutual support, and for that of our existing institutions, by the removal of those who seek their overthrow.  " 2d. That in furtherance of the objects of the Meeting', held here  on the 26t\i January last,- our Secretaries be now instructed to com-  munieate immediately with those of all the Parochial Unions yet  established, for the purpose of collecting- within the General Colonial  Church Union, the whole strength of the island, and obtaining therefrom a General Petition to the Legislature, .lor the expulsion of all  Sectarian Missionaries..  ■!$4. That the Members of the Union,collectively and individually,  shall strive to regain the confidence of their slaves, estranged through  the machinations of the Sectarians, by a. more rigid discipline in the  first instance, and, in the next, by granting" every indulgence consistent with their state, and  merited by their conduct.  " 4th. That the Members of the Union do bind themselves to use  every. possiole exertion to prevent the dissemination of any .religious  doctrines at variance with those of the English and Scotch Churches.  u 5th. Thai in furtherance of the ulterior objects of the Union,, and  to exhibit in their true lights the arts which have been used to bring  ruin and devastation in Jamaica, the first report of the Colonial Church  Union shall contain an authentic account of the late rebellion ; and  that the Committee do forthwith cause such Narrative to be compiled  from official sources of information, 	asc99990010170195001											64840480 Bytes	3960	5456	3897387416	RGB	asc99990010170195001.tif		2013-08-12	2013-08-12	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5969	5969	5970.jp2	/scbooks/image/5970.jp2

That it is expected  from  every Member of the Union, that  he will lend bis influence and support on all  occasion* to those Pa  t riots, who, In behalf of the paramount laws of society, have hazarded  thtdr personal responsibility for our preservation from the lajuiderous  machinations of our enemies. That a Meeting of the Acting Committee of St. Ann be held  at St. Ann's Bay, to commence on tire third Saturday in March, or,  during this eventful crisis, as much oftener as they might think pro-  per to call on the Presidents to convene them/'  JAMES HILTON,!  HENRY COX,  Presidents,  The following remarks relative to this Union form part of a stater  ment which accompanied the Memorial, No. IX. to the Earl of Bel-  more :  "The Jamaica Courant (understood to be the newspaper most extensively circulated in 'this island), has endeavoured, and still endeavours,  with impunity, to excite the inhabitants to the commission of every  species of outrage on the Missionaries, recommending destruction of  property, and even threatening life if they remain on the island. This  paper is generally (and from the almost universal support it receives  is properly) considered as the organ of the Colony. Coinciding iu  opinion with the Jamaica Courant and other newspapers, many of the  inhabitants of this island have^connected themselves irr an Association, under the designation of * The Colonial Church Union;* the  predominant object whereof is to procure the expulsion of all tht*  Missionaries from the island—an endeavour, in fact, to deprive * Englishmen of tire right to abide in tjreir own country so long as they  please, and not to be driven from it unless by the s&lt; ntence of the  law;' and they submit that an Association for such a purpose, is illegal, and at variance with the whole spirit of the British Constitution.  ** The first place at which this * Union* was set on foot, was St.  Ann's Bay, where, on the 15th of February, after the demolition of  several chapels, and the promulgation of the Proclamation, the following, among other resolutions, was passed.—  44 * Sixth. That it is expected from every member of the Union, that  be will lend his influence and support on all occasions, to those patriots who, in behalf of the paramount laws of society, have hazarded  their personal responsibility fur cur preservation, from the murderous  machinatiojis of our enemies.*  " The Presidents of this meeting publicly announced, are the Hon. In the -parish of Trelawny, one Magistrate, Mr.  William Dyer, publishes a newspaper, called * the Cornwall Courier,' in v\ hieh he has repeatedly urged that the Missionaries should  'he tarred and feathered. An attempt was made on the 7th April, to  "^practise this on the Wesleyan Missionary at Falmouth—and in the  •next number of that paper, this art was spoken of with approbation.  Our eyes cannot be shot to the faet^ that William Dyer, Editor, and  William Iher, Magistrate, are one and the same person ; and it seems  *t little too much to expect fro in human nature1, that what the Editor  recommends and applauds, the Magistrate will very rigidly judge, or  '.severely punish.  M Another Magistrate, Joseph Hodgson, who resided within a few  doors of the place where this disturbance occurred, was applied to for  .assistance* His reply to the applicant was, llutt 'she had better go  home, they would not hurt the Minister.' Sir,  Considering the present state of public opinion, as induced by heavy  charges hllodged against the 4l Sectarians," relative to the late rebellion, it is probable that those, by -whom onr characters are appreciated, and doctrines understood, might inquire why we have not  earlier appeared in defence of the &lt;me, and explanation of the oilier.  Onr delay has not arisen from fear of investigation, or reluctance th  -defend ihedoetrines we inculcate : But, long accustomed to revilement  and false accusation—considering the improbable and contradictory  nature of the charges alledged, together with the total ignorance ma-  infested by those who made them, both of our c«-ntiments and discipline  —and feeling- happy in a conscious rectitude Of our motives and  -conduct, we were disposed to pass over in silence such unfounded  ^allegations. But having exercised our patience until the lawless urge  of those, who are alike inimical to the laws of God and mart, has  demolished ten  or eleven of our Chapels,  and  thus destroys d  full 	asc99990010170197001											64055428 Bytes	3912	5456	195594443	RGB	asc99990010170197001.tif		2013-08-12	2013-08-12	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5971	5971	5972.jp2	/scbooks/image/5972.jp2
Page 198																																asc9999001017		A pp e is d rxt.  IB  £.16.000 worth of property belonging to the Baptist Mission in fhiss  island, we deem it high lime, on the part of ourselves, and our bre~-  thren, with whom we are not able at present to confer, to offer the  following remarks, with a view to vindicate our characters, and repress  such disgraceful depredations.  Our Missionaries here, aud the Society at home, have been reviled  and calumniated by every species sf abuse that ingenuity could invent,,  or malice promulgate. Every epithet Iras been employed that could  blacken the character; ox misrepresent tire motives both of the Society  and their Agents. We have been charged with preaching doctrines of  a seditious and dangerous character, and of propagating, among the  slave population, principles and sentiments tending to disobedience-  and insubordination. This charge ice flatly deny ;. and call on our  accusers for pkoof. The doctrines we maintain, we me prepared, afc  any proper time, modestly but fearlessly to defend t But, not; thinking it necessary to trouble the public at present with an extended;  statement of our belief, nor considering a Newspaper the most proper  medium for a confession of faith — it may suffice to remark, that our  religious doctrines, however misrepresented by onr enemies, differ  not from those contained in the authorized compositions of the Established Church ; nor, as they regard the present questionr from, thosov  of any other body of true Christians.  Our doctrines are not only charged with destroying the relative,  obligations between master and servant, but of leading to robbery.  sedition, incendiarism, and murder ! How they can fend to such evils*  more than the doctrines of the Established Church, we sre at a loss to  ascertain, since the fundamental doctrines of our belief are to he found*  iu her Articles.  We are said to be sent hither as spies, and incendiaries—encouraged*  by our Society to propagate sedition—and, finally,, accomplish the-  destruction of the Colony. Charges so ridiculous must carry witljy  them, to every unprejudiced mind, their Own refutation. With reference to our Society, the following quotations from the Instructions;  given to every Missionary, on leaving England, will clearly evince—  that their object is not to spread anarchy and confusion, but, without  any interference wlmtever with the political constitution of the Colony,,  to seek the happiness of the slaves, by presenting to them tire hkssingsv  of Christianity in the life that now is, as well as that which is to come ;  and inculcating attention to all the social and relative duties of life,  "' We enjoin it upon you ever to remember that the office you have  voluntarily undertaken, is wholly of a spiritual nature. Leaving to  others the acquisition of property, and the management of temporal  affairs, you go forth in the service of Jesus Christ, and to seek the  salvation of immortal souls.  *• It is matter of the first importance, that you carefully abstain-  from all interference whatever in political affairs, or with the civil  business of the town and neighbourhood in which you reside. To the  island of Jamaica this direction applies with peculiar force. Be careful, therefore, that your conduct, without any mixture of a wordly or  temporizing spirit, be such as shall give no just occasion of offence,  and that none mav be able to bring airy accusation against you, save  in the mailer of the Lord, your God. As you are going amongst a  people, many of whom are'in a state of slavery, it will be incumbent  upon you to use great caution, both as to your language and conduct,  that there may not be the least ground for the charge of interfering with  u 2 	asc99990010170198001											60520256 Bytes	3696	5456	210980617	RGB	asc99990010170198001.tif		2013-08-12	2013-08-12	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5972	5972	5973.jp2	/scbooks/image/5973.jp2
Page 199																																asc9999001017		12  A PP £ IS DI X.  their civil relations. On all persons in the condition of slaves, you will  diligently and plainly enforce the following Apostolic precepts : Eph.  "*'i.5—8 vs. * Servants, be obedient to them that are your masters accord'  ing to the flesh, with fear and trembling, in singleness of your heart, as  nnto Christ; not with eye service, as men-pleasers ; but as the servants  of Christ, doing the will of God from the heart: With good will doing  service as to the Lord, and not unto men : knowing that whatsoever  #ood thing any man doeth, the same shall receive of the Lord, whether he be bond or free.' Col. iii. 22--25 vs. V Servants, obey in all  things your masters according to the flesh, not with eye service, as  men-pleasers ; but in singleness of heart, fearing God : And whatsoever ye do, do it heartily, as to the Lord, and not unto men ; knowing that of the Lord ye shall receive the reward of the inheritance ;  for ye serve the Lord, Christ. But he that doeth wrong shall receive  for the wrong which he hath done, and there is no respect of persons.' M  We might leave these instructions to speak for themselves, simply  requesting the public to observe that no Missionary eould deviate  from them without incurring the discountenance of his associates here,  and separation from the Society in England. But lest it should be  alledged, that although we have received such instructions, yet, the  many cases in which Baptists are said to have been implicated in the  late rebellion prove that we have not acted '.accordingly, we beg to  suggest some considerations, which we think should induce the public to pause, before they draw this inference.   ■„  The number of slaves connected with our Chapels in the districts  chiefly disturbed, is very large ; much larger, we believe, than the  number connected with any other places of worship in that neighbourhood ; so that if only an equal proportion of Baptists were implicated, their number would necessarily exceed that of other deuomi-  tions.  But as to the real number of persons calling themselves Baptists,  actually engaged in the rebellion, we have as yet no authentic information. Their number, in fact, has not been ascertained ; nor are our  brethren at present in a situation to discover it. The statements  made in the Cornwall Chronicle, Courier, &c. on this point, have been  so mixed up with others already proved false, that they are plainly  unworthy of credence. And even of those actually implicated, and  who call themselves Baptists, many will, we are satisfied, be found,  on impartial inquiry, to have no connexion whatever with our  Churches, nor even to attend at our Chapels ; for it is a fact well  known to most religious persons, that besides a great number of  casual hearers, such as are found iu all denominations of Christians,  there exist a multitude of people in different parts of the island, who  designate themselves Baptists, but yet have no connection whatever  with the Baptist Mission.  But, suppose that some of our members have really been involved,  which we fear is the case, it deserves inquiry what proportion of this  irumber voluntarily engaged in it, because it is notorious that many  negroes were driven to join the rebels by their threats, or induced by  their relative connections with them.  Besides, let it be remarked, that the more intelligent and crafty of  the rebel chiefs, would be strongly induced to use the name of any  Missionary, as an argument to prevail on others to join him. This  remark applies especially to Mr. Bute hell's name^ because, being off 	asc99990010170199001											63347000 Bytes	3880	5440	2256069252	RGB	asc99990010170199001.tif		2013-08-12	2013-08-12	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5973	5973	5974.jp2	/scbooks/image/5974.jp2
Page 200																																asc9999001017		APPENDIX.  13  the island at the time, be could not frustrate such an attempt ; so that  the guilt of any Missionary cannot be inferred Irotn that circumstance,  since his name might have been thus used, without his consent or  knowledge.  Moreover, the fact ought certainly to be borne in mind, that the  evidence hitherto lai I before the public, has, for the most part, been  indirect, and second hand. In nearly every case of crimination, the  negroes are said to have stated, not that they themselves had heard  either of the Missionaries say they were to be made free at Christmas,  6wMhaMhey had been u told" that Mr. Burchell or Mr. Knibb, &c.  had said so.  We cannot be expected in this article to answer to specific charges  alleged against our brethren, whom distance and other circumstances,  prevent us from consulting ; but on the above grounds, we beg the  public, for the present, to suspend their judgment ; at the same time  expressing our conviction, that their suspense will be of short duration, as legal proceedings will probably be soon commenced on one  side or the other, which may afford them an opportunity of forming a  more correct opinion.  We only add, that there are thousands of respectable and intelligent persons, capable of perceiving the real tendency of our preaching and conduct, who are among our regular Leaders ; and many of  whom are slave holders ! ! Let such persons be inquired of by those  whb wish to obtain a just idea of our proceedings, and the objects we  have in view. To them we fearlessly appeal, being fully assured, that  our innocence will be established, in proportion as the truth is told.  We are, Sir, your obedient Servants,  JOSHUA TINSON,  JOSEPH BURTON,  HENRY C.TAYLOR,  SAMUEL NICHOLS;  JOHN CLARKE.  JOHN R.ANDREWS.  *i  No. VII.  Lelter to Admiral Colpogs, dated March 13, 1832. '* And I beg to be permitted, in their name, and that of my own, to  express to you, Gentlemen, our best and most sincere wishes for your  health and happiness, collectively and individually ; and that this Colony may long enjoy uninterrupted peace arm prosperity — that confidence may speedily be restored between master and slave, aud that ages  may pass away in perfect security.  k4 1 havp the honour to be, Gentlemen,  "Your faithful and obedient servant,  "A. Page 204																																asc9999001017		'APPEND! X.  17  "'Tire ieXtrenvely vague and unsatisfactory character of this reply  from the Commodore, compels us, Sir, to follow up the steps of  which our second letter gave him an intimation, especially as he has  thought proper to decline any further correspondence on the subject.  In addressing our first letter to the Commodore, we took the most  proper and honourable method of ascertaining whether the assertion  complained of originated'with him or not; but instead of that candid  and manly reply* which our views of the character of a British Commander had led us to anticipate, he has evaded our inquiry by giving-  us a vague and scarcely intelligible something, leaving us totally destitute of the information solicited, and which information we may infer it is not his intention to impart.  This conduct, as we have said, appears to us scarcely consistent  with the idea we had formed .of tire character of a British Officer.-—  The Commodore directs his Secretary to tell us, 4i that he does not  bold himself responsible for any letter or letters in the public prints,  which he did not order to be so inserted," but, Sir, it is not of a private letter, which may, by improper means have found its way into  the columns of a public print without the writer's sanction that we  complain—it is of a document published as the Commodore's public  answer to a public address. If falsified by any one on its way to the  press, we conceive the Commodore owed it to the calumniated parties, to the country, and to himself, to correct the error. As he has  not done this we must conclude that the document is fairly given, and,  with alt due deference, maintain that the Commodore is justly to he  held responsible for the calumny it contains—for the injury accruing  front it to the innocent individuals, and to the large body of his fellow-subjects, whom he has so gratuitously pronounced guilty before  trill. We say, Sir, gratuitously—for however agreeable it may have  been supposed to be to his Addressers, to have the crime of exciting  the rebellion fastened upon 44 the sect called Baptists," yon will perceive that there is not one sentence in the Address to him of the Magistrates and Inhabitants of Montego-Bay which required him, in his  answer, to fix the crime of the rebellion upon any one.  Were this a frivolous affair, Sir, it should never have been intruded  on your notice, but we consider it fraught with very injurious consequences. The assertion before quoted, going forth to the world, as  the opinion of a British Officer so high in command, who had been  present in the most disturbed districts during a great part of the rebellion, and whose supposed wisdom and honour might he considered  a sufficient guarantee against his publishing such a statement without  evidence, is calculated to injure our reputation in the opinion of those  whoseesteem we value, both in this and the Mother Country. That the  publication of such a sentiment was adapted to dons extensive injury,  few will deny ; and of this we think the Commodore ought to have been  aware, particularly as he must have known that our enemies would  gladly employ it to our disadvantage. For, at the time this public  answer to a public address was given, the community was in a state of  excitement approaching to frenzy; a strong and general prejudice  against us had been created and fostered by the falsehoods of a calumnious press; popular clamour had condemned, unheard, a number of  loyal and peaceable British subjects, as much entitled to a fair hearing and examination as the Commodore himself; popukr fury had  already destroyed part of their property, and driven some of them  from their homes, to^eek n place of safety, from those who were  c 	asc99990010170204001											60212616 Bytes	3688	5440	1876539574	RGB	asc99990010170204001.tif		2013-08-12	2013-08-12	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5978	5978	5979.jp2	/scbooks/image/5979.jp2
Page 205																																asc9999001017		18  A P P £ K DI X.  thirsting for their wrood. Under such circumstances we should hrrre  rxpected that a sense of justice would have induced Commodore Farquhar to have withheld his opinion, till it had been requested by he  proper authorities ; and not have allowed his name to be cinplov&lt; d,  i&gt;v the unstilicitfd publication of that opinion. tv&gt; give an appearance  &lt;&lt;f truth to popular detraction, and of justice to lawless ontrag*.  This might have been expected, had the Commodore's opirricn he. n  founded in truth ; hut we are salisued it is not ; and of this, on an  impartial investigation of tire matter, every unprejudiced mil d  must be convinced. For though every attempt has been made  to convict ohr Missionaries of sedition, though ttiUP.i-.UY has  been rt sorted to, and one witness induced to perjure himself, for  which crime he is threatened with a prosecution, hitherto no evidence  1-as been add'uccd ; ami it has been distinctly affirmed in the Mouse of  vsssemblv, by a meml&gt;er who had been actively ergaged in suppressing the rebellion, and who avows himself no friend to the *4 Sectarians," tlntt not one of the Missiona: i«s was implicated. Notwithstanding 'this, two or three of our Missionaries have .'been imprisoned,  property has been destroyed to tin* amount of full £]fj.OOO, life endangered, families driven from their bourns, Missionaries harrassed  find plundered, ami various other injuries sustained, both by individuals jmuI onr Society ; all proceeding from popular prejudice, which  we have every reason to believe, has been deepened and confirmed by  the publication of the Commodore's assertion.  After having published an assertion so injurious to our reputation,  we conceive that Commodore Fnnjuhar is now bourul in honour ami  justice, either to prove the correctness of that assertion, or publicly  to acknowledge his m'is'nke. Less than this we cannot consider due  to men, who have not merely to sustain a reputation in this country,  on which their success as Christian Ministers so greatly depends—but  whose unsullied character stands intimately connected with the credit  and honour of the large body of British Christians to which they belong.  hi conclusion, Sir, we beg to inquire,, whether, iu your opinion, the  course of conduct we have now laid before you was becoming, in so  hiuh air ofbeer as the Commodore, towards any class ef his Majesty's  subjects; ami respectfully r* quest your inter ferenee, in wloitver  manner your wisdom m;.y suggest, as best adapted to neutralize the  prejudicial influence of this unfounded aspersion.  As * matter of course we shall send a copy of this Correspondence  to oirr Secretary, in London, but shall 'request him to defer any cone  inunieation with the Admiralty on the subject, till we have been ho*  noured with your reply. Tmson ami Burton,  JJaptist Missiouarics, Spanish-Tow n*  No. VIII.  heller to ihe Governor's Secretary, relative to the Riot ai  Fa/mouth.  Kingston, April 14, 1832.  W. G. Nunes, Esq.  Sir,  Having jnst heard that two individuals at Falmouth, of the ttaptist  persuasion, arc about to be tried hv a Court Martial, for the part they  took in quelling a serious riot on Saturday last, we humbly crave the  interposition of Ids Excellency on their behalf.  The circumstances were these :—Mr. illeby, a Wesleyan Missionary,  was attacked by a mob, who broke open the door of his house, assaulted his person, besmeared his face with tar, and then attempted to  set fire to him. This proceeding of tarring and feathering Missioaa&gt;-  lies has been repeatedly recommended by Mr. Dyer, (one of the? Magistrates of Trelawny, and Deputy Judge Advocate of the Trelawny  Ilegiment,) in his paper, entitled the Cornwall Courier, and, from circumstances which will be laid before his Excellency in due time, lifer*  is every reason to believe that Mr. Dyer knew of the intention to  break the peace on this occasion. While.the assault was being made,  and the town of Falmouth was in an uproar, application was made to  a Mr. Hodgson, one of the Magistrates, residing within a few doors of  the spot; his reply to the person was, that'.44 she had better go home;  they would not hurt the Minister." Wre mention these facts to show,  that little, if any, protection, and no alertness, was to he expected  from some of the Magistracy for the protection of the Missionaries ;  and when his Excellency knows that the measures of violence taken  for the destruction of their Chapels, and for their expulsion from tin*  island, are recommended and approved of by one of that body iu his  public paper, and that he and his paper are warmly supported by that  body generally, his Excellency will perceive, that either the Missionaries ami their friends must arm for the defence of themselves and  their property, or submit to every outrage which a lawless mob chooses  to inflict.  On the occasion in question several persons did proceed to the spot  with arms in their hands, one having put on his military coat aud belts,  ami another   his belts only ; their only   object heing to preserve   the  public peace, and protect an tin offending man and his family. Vt\tracts referred to in tiro foregoing Letter :—  ( Watchman, Saturday, 14*/e April.)  44 Between seven and nine o'clock on Saturday evening, the 7th jnst.  ns the Rev, Mr. Bleby, a Wesleyan Minister, and his lady, were sitting to tea at their hired residence in Falmouth, a band of white, and  one or two coloured, ruffians rushed  into the  house and seized him,  using extremely violent  and abusive language, calling him ad- d  preaching villain, &c. &c, they then forced Mr. B. to the opposite  «ide of the room, four or five holding him, whilst one struck him violently on.the head—they were all armed with bludgeons. One of the  ruffians brought a keg of tar into the room, and whilst some held him,  others spread the tar with their hands over his head, face, breast, and  clothes. Whilst this brutal assault was going on, the fellow, named  'Dobsoti, who struck Mr. Bleby, attempted to set Mr. B's pantaloons  on fire, but was prevented by one of the gang. He immediately after  applied the candle to the tar on Mr. B's. breast, but Mrs. Bleby seeing  it, dashed the candle from his hand, and it went out. in attempting  to interpose between the ruffians and Mr. B. Mrs. Bleby was seized  "by one of them and dashed violently on the floor, the effects of  which, our informant affirms, she still severely feels. Two of the gang  attempted to lock her in the pantry, but. she managed to elude their  intention. By this time, the alarm having been given, some people  came to Mr. and Mrs. Bleby's assistance, and commenced an attack  on the villains who were below stairs ; this so alarmed those that were  employed above, ,that they left Mr. Bleby and hastened to the assistance of their fellows, and eventually made their escape, but not until  two or three had received the drubbing which they richly deserved—  one so much so as to endanger his life. About this time Mrs. Bleby  with her child, escaped through the crowd without her bonnett and  with one shoo, the villains having first bedaubed her and her child 	asc99990010170207001											63197182 Bytes	3888	5416	879213962	RGB	asc99990010170207001.tif		2013-08-12	2013-08-12	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5981	5981	5982.jp2	/scbooks/image/5982.jp2

Mr. B. who was guarded by n  party of coloured and black young men, took shelter in a neighbouring house. Mr. B. was taken to the barracks  for the nigbt, and Mrs. Bleby was kindly sheltered by Mrs. Jackson,  the Lady of the Clerk of the Peace, who offered her all requisite  assistance. On Sunday the attack was to have been renewed, but it  did not take place. As a specimen of Falmouth justice, the young  men who went to Mr. Bleby's assistance, were disarmed, by authority,  and are to-day to be tried by a Court-Martial for the crime of protecting a Missionary, his wife, and harmless infant!!!"  "Tarring and burning—or an attempt to murder a missionary.  44 To the Editor of the Watchman.  Sir—I do not know to what extent matters may be carried after the  attempt which was made to assassinate Mr. Bleby, the Wesleyan Missionary at Falmouth, on Saturday night last. There is a laxity somewhere, and unless a peremptory mode of procedure be adopted, to  check the violence of a depraved party, British subjects, unimpeached  by any but a set of unprincipled men, may become a sacrifice to popular rancour,  44 It appears that a party of men, composed of Overseers, in the  neighbourhood of Falmouth, and some persons who live in the town  (about twenty in number), forcibly entered the premises of Mr. Bleby,  at about eight o'clock, whilst he was sitting at tea with Mis. Bleby and  two female friends. He demanded their business, and was told they  came to take tea with him. He politely said, 44 if that be what you  require, you are welcome." At this moment three or four of them  seized him very violently, and placed him against the wall of the house,  and applied tar to his head, face, and breast, whilst others attempted  twice to set him on fire by means of a lighted candle, during the cries  of finish him—finish him, and otherwise treated him most brutally.  44 But, will it be believed, that even Mrs. Bleby, and a babe not five  months old, did not escape the *rengeance of these miscreants ? The  ruffians threw Mrs. Bleby upon the floor with a violence that has done  tier serious injury, and she is still suffering from the effects of it, and  ultimately compelled her to quit the premises with the loss of one of  Jher shoes, without bonnet, and with the infant in her arms, to seek  safety at the house of & kind and  respectable inhabitant of Falmouth.  *4* Mr. Miller was very promptly on the spot, with a party of the 22d  "Regiment, garrisoned in Falmouth, and it is firmly believed, that if  decisive measures had not been used by the friends of Mr. Bleby, the  &lt;dastardly assassins woAild have effected i\%s& design* af destroying that  t*e nil email.  4* The parties who were engaged in the diabolicail proceedings are  well known, and will be identified by several witnesses whenever it  an ay he requicM. (Cornwall Courier, l\th April.)  44 Although thosedens of sedition, the Sectarian preaching shops, in  this parish, have been destroyed to appease the indignant men who  were toiling in the woods for so long a period, to suppress the rebellion i\\e parsons had concocted, still the excitement of the public mind  will be kept up as long as one of these detestable spies remain among  us. Their presence, now that their occupation is, like Othello's, gone,  is purposely to fan anew the embers of rebellion, and we therefore  call upon the Magistracy to keep a watchful eye on these wolves in  sheep's clothing. The ex-fifer, Ward, whose presence still pollutes  this town, by dint of the most gross chicanery and deceit, after ten  days perseverance, managed to hire a house for another of the gang,  who bears the elegant appellation of Beeby, or Booby, and Was formerly a Spitalfield's weaver, but, finding trade rather had in that line,  has now declined the labours of the shuttle for the softer occupations  of cushion thumping, and mac gathering. This fellow's arrival was  but the commencement of a regularly concocted scheme of setting the  Magistrates at defiance, and therefore he was presented with a handsome suit of Tar and Feathers. When the operators had accomplished their object, they retired to their homes—not so the disciples  of the ranters, who arranged themselves under tire banner of the aforesaid ex-fifer, Ward. This modest personage had fire audacity to assume a military jacket of the 22d Regiment, from which he was discharged some twelve months ago. He was assisted by that very  respectable   ex-limb  of the   law,   Whitehorne,   who   has   rendered  'himself notorious by endeavouring to persuade the expatriated Burchell to qnit the man-of-war, and try their strength iir the streets of  Montego-Bay. These pious preachers mustered their troens, consisting of a  few black Militia men, who armed  themselves with  their  "firelocks, wore their uniform, and stopped, and challenged inoffensive  people in the s'reets on Saturday evening. Sir,  [Reply to the foregoing Letter.^  King's House, 14th April. 1832.  I have received, and laid before his Fxcellency the Governor, the  letter signed by yourself, Mr. Knibb, and others, representing that  two individuals of the Baptist persuasion are to be tried by a Court-  Martial at Falmouth for the part they took in quelling a serious riot  on Saturday last.  His Fxeeileney has directed me to transmit copies of your letter to  the Custos of Trelawny, and the Major General of Militia, commanding that District, desiring them to report on the statement contained  therein.  No accounts have reached the Governor of information being laid,  before a Magistrate deposing to the truth of so atrocious an act of  outrage and cruelty as that described in your letter, but when the necessary depositions are trade, the Attorney General will not fail to  perform his duty, and the result of the proceedings will guide his  Excellency in the course be may then find it eNpedieht to pursue.  His Excellency cannot permit an observation, contained in your  letter, to pass unnoticed. vt that the Missionaries and their friends must  arm for the defence of themselves and their property, or submit to  every Outrage which a lawless mob choose to inflict."  If the law cannot secure every man from harm or violenc*, it affords  the means of redress, and it is by means of the law that redress can  alone be obtained, but his Excellency cannot too strongly deprecate  an expression which may seem to imply air intention of resorting to  force, instead of appealing to the law for protection—an attempt  which, if ever resorted to, cannot fail to be attended with signal  defeat.*  The late hour at which your statement- came to hand, occasioned  litmh inconvenience. The* Post Office had closed, and it was not  without difficulty I was able to make the communications I have  before alluded to.  I am. Sir,  Your most obedient servant,  W.G. NUNES. Gentlemen,  Referring to your Memorial of the 14th inst. and to my letters of  14th and 20th inst.* I am now to acquaint you, that the Magistrates  »f Trelawny are investigating the case of Mr. Bleby, and I expect to  receive the examinations, in conformity with the directions of his Excellency the Governor on this subject, by next post.  As respects your statement, that 44 two individuals of the Baptist  Persuasion were about to be tried by a Court Martial, for the part they  took in quelling a serious riot," the Colonel of the Trelawny Regiment  states, 4* that he has not tried, nor is he about to try, by a Court Martial, any two individuals of the Regiment under his command, and the  information received by his Excellency the Governor is without foundation." Sir,  Instructed as we are by the highest authority, not only to obey the  powers that be, but to render honour to whom honour is due, we  should feel extremely sorry had we the consciousness of contributing  a particle of unnecessary trouble to the weight of anxiety which his  Excellency must unavoidably experience in the discharge of his high  and important duties.  But, in reference to your Letter of the 26th inst. alluding to our  Memorial of the 14th, on behalf of two individuals of the Baptist persuasion at Falmouth, we cannot but think that the circumstances  under which we acted, fully justified our petitioning his Excellency ;  ami that, with all due deference to the Colonel of the Trelawny Regiment, the information we sent the Governor was not 44 without foundation ;" for although the Colonel 44 has not tried, nor is about to try,  by a Court-Martial, any two individuals of the Regiment under his  command," it does not follow that he did not intend to try, by a  ** Court Martial," the individuals referred to. [Memorial referred to in the preceding Letter.]  To his Excellency thk Governor.  The humble Memorial of the undersigned Baptist Missionaries.  Sheweth,  - That oil the 13.It of February last, a Memorial, signed by certain of  your present Memorialists, was presented to your Excellency, stating,  atnoLo- other things, that their property had been plundered, "several  of their Chapels totally demolished, aud tlnir persons -threatened with  violence, under the countenance, and with the aid, of Magistrates and  Officers of the MHitia;" and praying, in the apprehension of the continuant e of similar acts of wanton outrage against their  property arret  lives, for the interposition ot your  Excellency's authority and power  to protect them.  That, in answer to that Memorial, your then Memorialists received  a Letter from your Excellency's Secretary, apprising them that its  prayer had been anticipated in the issuing aud promulgation throughout the island, of a Proclamation on the subject, of which a Copy was  enclosed.  That y°ur Memorialists felt grateful to your Excellency for tho  strong terms of condemnation in which that Proclamation spoke, of the  •* wanton and illegal" destructiosi of their Chapels aud Places of Worship—proceedings, as your Excellency not more strongly than justlv  characterised them, "disgraceful to the Colony, subversive of order,  and of dangerous example." And your Memorialists did fain hope,  that the protection which they were seeking at yo'»r Excellency's  hands, would be actually afforded them, in the obedience which would  he paid by the '* Custodes of Parishes and all Magistrates" ti»  tire injunctions laid upon them in that Proclamation, ** to seek out  aud discover the authors of these outrages, that they might be punish  ed according to law ;" and 4t to employ the whole force, which the  Constitution has entrusted to them, in protecting property of every  description, whether belonging to private persons or Religious Societies, in quelling ail disorderly meeting!*, and iti bringing to exemplary  punishment every disturber of the public peace." But w hatevercou-  filence your Memorialists may bave had in a ready attention, on tho  part of these persons, to your Excellency's orders, and to the due execution of their duties, as the legally constituted and sworn preservers  of the public peace, the result has proved it to have been in most  cases totally unfounded.  That from many of the circumstances detailed in the accompanying  statement, of various outrages and indignities, to which they have been  subjected,—of reiterated attacks upon their lives and property (which  your Memorialists conceive must be known to your Excellency, since,  tliey are of public notoriety), it is evident that the Civil aud Local  Miliary Authorities in many parishes of the island, with but few exception^ have treated, and An 'A\\\ treat, your Excellency's Proeiama,- 	asc99990010170214001											59952454 Bytes	3656	5464	402864251	RGB	asc99990010170214001.tif		2013-08-12	2013-08-12	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5988	5988	5989.jp2	/scbooks/image/5989.jp2
Page 215																																asc9999001017		23  ATP E.N BIX.  tion and authority with, contempt. It is equally evident, that, so far  from the first of these affording your Memorialists the protection tliey  required, and as British Subjects, are entitled to, the impunity with  which it has been disregarded—indeed trampled on, by the very persons to whom it was addressed, is a strong encouragement to them  nnd others, to proceed to further acts of wanton aggression and threatened violence. Your Memorialits, therefore, are again obliged to approach your Excellency with the expression of their fears, (which  surely cannot,now be deemed ill-founded,) that, unless a more effectual exertion of your authority is interposed, as heretofore, so in future, their property and persons will lie entirely, as far at least as the  Jaws which should protect them are concerned, at the mercy of a deeply prejudiced, an unprincipled, and lawless party, which is intent upon  their destruction. And your Memorialists submit to your Excellency,  That it is a case cniling for your serious attention, and for the exercise  of your high powers, when, iu a British Colony, and under a British  (governor, and British Laws, British subjects, against whom noi a single charge can be substantiated, dare not return to their homes and  their functions, hut with the certain expectation of suffering personal  •violence under the wilful connivance, if not immediate sanction, of the  "very persons to whom, as Magistrates, the preservation of the public  peace is committed. Though they trust there are some honourable  exceptions, your Memorialists speak advisedly in bringing this charge  ogainat the Magistracy generally, of the parishes in which the outrages detailed in the accompanying Statement have occurred : and,  for their full justification in bringing it, they humbly beg to refer  /your Excellency to the particulars of those outrages, and to the fact,  that not a single attempt, of any one Custos or Magistrate, to seek  out and discover their authors, that they might he punished according to law, in.compliance with the Proclamation, has yet come to their  knowledge.  That your Memorialists now approach your Excellency, humbly, but  earnestly, to seek that effectual protection, to Which, in common with  their fellow-subjects, they feel themselves entitled ; and which, under  the circumstances, none but your Excellency can afford. They detail  specific grounds of complaint; they look to your Excellency for the  redress of their grievances, by the exercise of the power with which  their gracious Sovereign has invested you for the protection of all his  faithful subjects in this Colony, and for the punishment of every contemner of the laws: they desire to do so respectfully, but they must at  the same time solemnly tell your Excellency, that having now adopted  every means in their power to place themselves under the protection  of the laws by which they arc governed, they are about to resume  their duties at some of the Stations, which injustice and cruelty compelled them to leave, in the exercise of an indefeasible right, belonging to every Briton ; and in the consciousness that whatever consequences may ensue to,themselves or others, in th^ execution of.any  of the threats of violence so publicly held out, the blame and the guilt  cannot lie upon them. Gentlemen,      „  1 have received and transmitted your Letter of yesterday, enclosing  a Memorial and Statement to his Excellency the Governor, and no  time will be lost in forwarding your representation to his Excellency's  Legal Adviser, the Attorney General, for the purpose of affording you  the protection of the Laws, aud procuring the redress for past injuries  which you seek. BATTY,  41 To G. Nunes, Esq."  No. X.  Protest of the Baptist Missionaries,  The Baptist Missionaries, have viewed with indignation ami abhorrence, tue unjust attempt made by the Committee of the Hon. House  of Assembly, appointed to examine into the causes of the late rebellion, to injure their characters iu the estimation ot the British Public,  by preferring charges against them which cannot be substantiated ;  charges as repugnant to the feelings of the Missionaries, as dishonourable to the men who framed fhe-m.  It is not for the Baptist Missionaries to say, what was the primary  or secondary cause of tbe late disastrous events ; it is sufficient for  them at present to state, that neither their h* preaching, teaching," nor  conduct, was that cause, and they dare the *• Rebellion Committee"  to prone that it whs s«.  The Baptist Missionaries, conscious of their innocence of the  eharges.publiely pieferred against them, in the report of the '* Kebel-  lion Committee," teel it to be a duty they owe to themselves, to their  friends in this country, to the Baptist Missionary Society in England  to which they are attached, and to the religions world at large, thus publicly to state, that the charges brought against them by that Commit-  tee, are unfounded an 1 unjust; that they have wantonly and grossly  libelled men, whose characters have never \et been sullied ; who have  ever submitted in all civil matters unto the powers that be ; who have  inculcated on servants and slaves, the duty of obedience to their  masters, and the tenor of whose Ministrations has been agreeable  with, and in conformity to, the doctrines aud precepts of that Gospel  which is both pure and peaceable.  One of the Baptist Missionaries has already been tried on these  charges, by the highest legal authorities in the island, and' ACQlUTTKn ;  aud all oi them have shewn their willingness to submit to any .legal  ■investigation into their conduct.  Deeprtufcj d and unbending prejudice has been manifested towards  thein bv men, from whom they ought to have received protection-*—  Bribery, perjury, aud every species of iniquity have been resorted to,  for the purpose of criminating the M Bapfbt Missionaries' in particular," but in vain ; and yet the " Bebeliion Committee" have condemned them unheard, have found them guilty on evidence which the  Mnssionaiies have never been made acquainted with, consequent!),  neither themselves nor their friends, have had an opportunity of disproving i! ; and have condemned, in lota, preaching which they have  never heard.  These fek&lt;Is, to the enlightened and   unprejudiced   public  of Great 	asc99990010170218001											59689606 Bytes	3640	5464	3625680550	RGB	asc99990010170218001.tif		2013-08-12	2013-08-12	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5992	5992	5993.jp2	/scbooks/image/5993.jp2
Page 219																																asc9999001017		32  A P P E N D I X.  Britain, will afford sufficient proof, that the " Rebellion Committee"  have merely chosen this apparently favourable opportunity, for the  purpose of expressing their determined and long-cherished hatred to  religion ami its propagators, and they will, at the same lime, tend to  establish more firmly than ever, the unimpeachable characters of  THE BAPTIST MISSIONARIES.  Kingston, May 8th, 1832.  I  is  No. XI.  Address to his Exccihneij the Earl of Mai grave.  To Mis Excellency tbe Right Honourable Constantine Henry,  Earl of Mulgrave, Knight Grand Cross of the Royal Hanoverian Order, and one of his Majesty's most Honourable Privy  Council, Captain-General and Governor-in-Chief of this tho  Island of Jamaica, and other the Territories thereon depending  in America, Chancellor, and Vice Admiral of the game.  May it please your Excellency,  AYc, the Baptist Missionaries, connected with the Baptist Missionary  Society in England, while desiring to secure ourselves from tho  charge of intrusion, deem it an act of duty and respect to our Sovereign, ns well as to your Excellency, as his chosen Representative in  this Colony, to approach your Excellency on the present occasion.  We beg permission to present our humble, yet cordial congratulations to your Excellency, on your safe arrival in Jamaica. We  believe that none have greater cause for offering congratulations; and  that for the opportunity of offering them, few are more thankful to God  than ourselves. We have had peculiar reason to look forward to  this event with much anxiety and hope ; and now it is our ardent desire and prayer, that as much as possible of prosperity, and as little  ns possible of disquietude, may attend your Excellency's Administration.  We cannot but regret that the present state of society affords little  prospect of freedom from solicitude, and evinces the difficulties, as  clearly as the importance, of -yowr Excellency's hijh and responsible  situation, as tbe Representative of our King. While, therefore, it will  he our constant care to guard against increasing the difficulties of your  Excellency's Government, we fully anticipate the absolute necessity  of an early representation to your Excellency, of our many and great  grievances yet unredressed ; and of an application for protection jn  the discharge of our sacred duties ; and for flie security of Ihose privileges w hich have been graei.usly confirmed nut;) Protestant Dissenters, by the successive Kituvs and Parliaments of Great Britain,—  For, whatever menial annoy ances we may be constrained to endure,  we feel ourselves bound to the Society which sent us out, to abide at  our posts, unless, as already threatened, expelled from the island by  violence—-an event which must involve an acknowledgment, that  Britain's authority is inadequate to the protection of her loyal sub- 	asc99990010170219001											63700112 Bytes	3896	5448	2958856021	RGB	asc99990010170219001.tif		2013-08-12	2013-08-12	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5993	5993	5994.jp2	/scbooks/image/5994.jp2
Page 220																																asc9999001017		APPE ND IX.  33  ject*,  while peaceably   aud   honourably   pursuing the  duties of their  calling.  Circumstanced as the island now is,* we rejoice in the selection of &lt;%  Nobleman of your Excellency's acknowledged reputation for fit to  Government of this valuable portion of his Majesty's Btominions ami  we trust that tbe health of your Excellency, and that of vour amiabib  Countess, may be loug continued in the enjoyment of much happines*  ~ that jour Administration may restore peace to tbis distracted Colony—and that while the welfare of all classes of his Majesty's sub-  jects is promoted under the influence of your Excellency's Gov erei  ment, the invaluable blessings of the Gospel may be widely and uninterruptedly diffused.  Signed, oi» behalf of the Baptist Missionaries in the Island of Ja*  maica, the 3d August,  lo32, by  JOSHUA TINSON,  SAM DEL NIC HOBS,  wvi. whitlhokne;  [His Excellency's Reply.]  Gentlemen.  I return you my best thanks for the expression of your cordial congratulations upon my arrival in this island.  1 have always advocated the perfect freedom of religious opinion,  and therefore I shall not be misunderstood, when, in reference, to-  your assurance that it will be your constant care to guard against increasing the dilliculties of my Government, I remind you that, as  religious toleration has ever been most secure iu seasons of political  tranquillity, none can be expected to feel more strongly than yourselves, that, as preachers of the Gospel of peace, all topics had best  be avoided which might have the effect of aggravating civil discord, or  of propagating ideas tending to disorganize the established frame of  society.  With respect to the apprehensions you express of personal violence,  it will be my duty, in the exercise of that power entrusted to me, ami  which I have no doubt will be adequate to ils object, to protect aliko  from outrage all classes of his Majesty's Subjects, who will best merit  that protection by an implicit obedience to the laws ; and with regard  to any regulation limiting the exercise of your sacred calling, which  the constitution may have reserved, I cannot too strongly recommend,  on your parts, submissive deference in the first instance to the decisions of those Authorities to whom the administration of the laws i*  entrusted ; and who are themselves responsible for the due exercise  of the functions committed to their charge.  At the same time I ueed not assure you, that it will ever be my wish  that the invaluable blessings of the Gospel may be widely and uninterruptedly diifuscd throughout the island, which is under my Govljki-  ment.  ; 	asc99990010170220001											59558374 Bytes	3632	5464	3410335718	RGB	asc99990010170220001.tif		2013-08-12	2013-08-12	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5994	5994	5995.jp2	/scbooks/image/5995.jp2
Page 221																																asc9999001017		34  A I'VE IS UIX.  XII.  Letter to Colonel Yorke, accompany lag a Memorial to his  Excellency the Earl of Mulgrave,  Kingston, 20th September, 1832.  To Colonel C. Yorke,  Sut,  We beg permission to lay before his Excellency the Governor the  accompanying Memorial and Statements.*  Within the last few days we have had an opportunity of seeing tho  opinion of the Attorney General respeciing some of the obstructions  -which have been placed in our way ; and we have thought that our  obligation to apply to his Excellency has not been in any wray lessened. One important part of this opinion is—that the Magistrates are  at liberty to refuse Protestant Dissenting Ministers permission to  preach ; though it is also suggested that from such refusal an appeal  may be made to the Grand Court.  For the information respecting this appeal, as well as for the privilege of making it, we are sincerely thankful. But respecting the advantage to be obtained, we deeply regret the necessity of saying, that  even if we were certain of success, the unavoidable expense and loss  of time attending such a step, in the cage of every appeal, must form  a serious obstacle to the work of religious instructors.  Respecting the Statements, we take the liberty of observing, that  they are given, partly to corroborate the assertions of the Memorial,  and partly to shew that some of the Missionaries are net only prevented from preaching, but that they, and some of their friends, are  awaiting' prosecutions, and expecting to be fined for having had Public Worship, though, to the best of their knowledge, the laws had been  previously obeyed.  Mr. Burton, Baptist Missionary, and the owner of the house which  he used, Miss Durham, are both expecting to he tried at Morant-Bay  Quarter Sessions on the first Tuesday in October. Mrs. Renwick, of  Montego-Bay, is expecting to be tried at tbe Cornwall Assizes in November ; and as Mrs. Robe of Savanna-la-Mar, was fined £25 at the  last Quarter Sessions there, for allowing Mr. Kingdon to convene in  her house a Pontic Religious Meeting, after the place had been registered in the Bishop's Office, we fear a similar decision is likely to be  adopted by the Magistracy in the other cases that have been detailed.  We have the honour to be   Sir,  Your most obedient humble servants,  JOSHUA TINSON,  SAMUEL NICHOLS,  JOSEPH BURTON,  JOHN CLARKE.  • These were the Statements which had been laid before Lord Bdrnore, and a  Karrative of most of the fads detailed in Chap. X. 	asc99990010170221001											63138664 Bytes	3856	5456	423631396	RGB	asc99990010170221001.tif		2013-08-12	2013-08-12	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5995	5995	5996.jp2	/scbooks/image/5996.jp2
Page 222																																asc9999001017		A P P T. N t&gt; I X.  (2.)  35  I Memorial referred to in the preceding Letter,] *  To ins Excellency the Goveh^or.  The Memorial of the Baptist Missionaries.  Humbly Shews,  That they are now driven to the necessity of applying to your Excellency with their complaints and their requests. This necessity wa»  anticipated when the Memorialist* had the honour of presenting mt\  Address to your Excellency, on a recent occasion ; and this anticipation being now fully realised, and an application to your Excellency  being the only constitutional method that■"affords any prospect of redress, with much respect, and at the same time much of that feeling  Which springs from conscious rectitude, and obedience to the laws,  your Memorialists solicit your Excellency's patient attention.  Your Memorialists beg permission to take this opportunity far informing your Excellency, that they never have in any way excited  sedition ; but that, on the contrary, iu public and private, among the  slaves, thev, ami their fellow Missionaries;, have uniformly enforced  the duties of obedience and peace ; and they conceive, that this assertion is both confirmed and made important hy the fact, that though,  from the Eastern to the Western extremity of the island, the utmost  efforts have been made by injthy persons in authority to prove them  guilty, they have not succeeded in establishing the truth of any one  charge.  1'et notwithstanding this inability to convict, among; the most  prejudiced men, there has been commenced, amount the. white inhabitants, a system of outrageous persecution,-'Which, in violence alia  extent, has surpassed all the persecutions of later years throughout  Christendom. More than twenty thousand pounds worth of property,,  belonging to the Baptist Missionary Society, has been destroyed ; and  in many instances the materials of the ruined buildings have, in open  day, by persons of respectability, been carried off, and appropriated  to the improvement of their own houses. Several of the .Missionaries  have been imprisoned upon groundless and preposterous evidence,  collected in the most dishonuu. able manner. Mobs of white men hive  frequently been formed for the avowed purpose of injuring :the Missionaries, or depriving them of lite.- Express orders, attended wifii  threats from the Magistrates, have, in many places, compelled the  preachers to desist from their usual employment of giving religious instruction. A Committee of the Honourable House of Assembly has  pronounced them guilty rtpoir--&r parte evidence, that has hitherto  been kept secret. Aud, to encourage all these measures, there has  been formed a combination, by persons who call themselves the Colonial Church Union, who are rapidly extending their influence through  the island;, and one of whose frequently published determinations is,  that at the risiv of their lives, they will expel all Sectarian preaeheia  fr«*m the land.  Though these outrageous proceedings occurred, or were commenced,  Before the arrival of your Excellency -on the island, your Memorialists take the liberty of thus briefly relating them, foi the purpose of  shewing that the opposition /■which is at present so violent is nofinw.  New pretexts may sometimes be assigned tor it ; but i? is a continuation of the same course, and is excited by the same spoil that began t! e  persecuting ravages in Martial Law. Your Excellency's Memorialists,  however, are" not chargeable with having prolonged their sufferings  k2 	asc99990010170222001											59427948 Bytes	3624	5464	825933299	RGB	asc99990010170222001.tif		2013-08-12	2013-08-12	http://merrick.library.miami.edu:80/cdm/ref/collection/scbooks/id/5996	5996	5997.jp2	/scbooks/image/5997.jp2

They made them known, either imnn in~  &lt;&vidual. or a general manner, to your Excellency's predecessors.  And that the needed decision was deferred till the present time, and  that now yoYir Excellency's Memorialists are compelled to renew their  application for protection, and tor justice, is to them the cause of regret.  But the  grievances to  which   they  now  more  particularly solicit  attention, are those which are existing at the present time.    They also  feioVed  began before  \ouf Excellency \s arrival,, but they  have continued to increase  ever since.    At the present time, some of the  Mis*.  Nonaries are wholly prevented, by some of the Magistrates, from giving religious instruction in those districts where they are appointed to  preach.    At   Montego Bay,   Mr.   Abbott   has   la-en  ordered   not   to  j&gt; each  by a very full Bench of Magistrates;  and he has obeyed  this  *&gt;rder, though   multitudes  would  be thankful   tor the opportunity  of  ineeting  with  him  for the public  worship  of God.    At  Savanna la-  liar, Mr. Kingdon has icecived a similar order front the Magistrates,  mid has been prevented from preaching.    At Morant Bay, by Thomas  M'Comock and Thomas Blakely, Esqrs. ; and at Mancbioneal, by G.  Codrington, Esq, Mr. Burton has been ordered to desist from preaching, and the .orders are now being obeyed,    The Memorialists forbear  troubling your .Excellency, in this Memorial, with the particulars of  opposition which distinguished each place, as they are detailed  in the  accompanying  Statements.    They are anxious  here to state -what is  general ;   and  only so  far   to enter   into   particulars  as  may  be necessary to strengthen the general complaint of not being able to preach  the Gospel, because of the determination to oppose, anions those very  imcii who have received their authority for th?1 security of the innocent,  and   the   protection  of peace.     And  your  Excellency's  Memorialists  submit-,  that   the only general feature iu tbe conduct of many of the  Magistrates towards them, is a determination to oppose and to silence.  Where it has been possible to persecute, under the colour of maintain-  i.ig some Statute, tfie most scrupulous adherence to law has been  assigned  as the  reason.     Where there has -been  no possibility of .thus  frmsploving any Statute, the laws have been openly contemned ; or constructions have   been  put upon  them, only calculated to excite asto-  lasi.nlrni.  At Savanna-la-Mar, when Mr. Kingdon informed the Magistiatrs'  what he understood to be the law respecting Dissenting Preachers,  one of them replied that the Magistrates must sometimes act without  law. And, in accordance with this principle, they bound him over to  appear at Montego-Bay, to answer f jr the breach of a law which was  not in existence. At Montego Bay, when Mr. Abbott referred to the  law which authorizes Dissenting Preachers to register their Ileuses of  Worship, either in the Bishop's Court or at the Quarter Sessions,  Dr, Longmore, Assistant Judge of the Assize Court, remarked, ki But  we claim that prerogative to ourselves ;" and Dr. Lawson, sen.  Assistant Judge of the Assize Court, said, *' We Shall place our own  construction on tbe law." At Mancbioneal, G. It is only since Martial Law that the Authori-  ties, in different parts of the island, have called into question the correctness of the decision, and have taken upon themselves to say what  are the required qualifications of Protestant Dissenters. And, as the  ronsequence  of this   independent  deters  mutation,   your  Ei  xcellencv s  Memorialists have had to learn from very conflicting assertions the  two or three principles which their Rulers have united to teach. Respecting the Toleration Laws, they have been practically taught that  where they could lie used for restricting and punishing, they would  he considered a part of the Colon'al Law, aud employed without hesitation; but that when the privileges of the Toleration Acts were  claimed, the claim would be met with the information that the Acts  were not in force in Jamaica. It has been clearly shewn that still the  finesand the punishm* nts of the Acts are adapted to the Colony, but  that the immunities are not. It is only to the prevalence of a determination to silence and expel, that  your Excellency's Memorialists can possibly attribute the persecutions  they have now to endure. They are satisfied, thai v»ith your ExceU  Jency they have nothing to fear, from charges which cannot be substantiated, or from apparent proofs of charges where there has been  no opportunity afforded of rephing; but, from slanderous accusations circulated among the most inveterate enemies, they have so much  cause for apprehension, as compels them to look to your Excellency  for a deliverance from present evils, and for protection from those that  are threatened ;  and in doing   this, they   have no cause   to   fear  that  they will look   to  your   Excel]  cannot convict them of any crime  encv  m  vain  I'hei  id tl  r  worst  opponents  therefore no cause  to cast themselves upon compassionate feeling.
